array.string: Referendum in Moldova results in the electorate voting against possible reunification with Romania.
David Platt appointed captain of English football team.
Campbell v. Acuff-Rose Music, Inc.: The Supreme Court of the United States rules that parodies of an original work are generally covered by the doctrine of fair use.
US Navy issues first permanent order assigning women on combat ship.
Charles Taylor resigns as President of Liberia.
African National Congress chief Nelson Mandela rejects demand by white right-wingers for separate homeland in South Africa.
8th American Comedy Awards: Carrot Top wins.
The Supreme Court of the United States rules in Campbell v. Acuff-Rose Music, Inc.that parodies of an original work are generally covered by the doctrine of fair use.
Radio host Jack Spector suffers a fatal heart attack while broadcasting popular music on WHLI in Garden City, Long Island, New York, USA.
Train accident at Pinetown, Natal kills 47.
US Defense Department announces smoking ban in workplaces.
B737 plane collides with Ilyushin-86 in New Dehli, India; at least 8 killed.
Knut Haukelid, Norway/US resistance fighter (Rjukan 1943), dies at age 82.
Joop C Swart, publisher/founder (World Press Photo), dies at age 69.
Charles Bukowski, American author/poet, dies of leukemia at age 73 (born 1920).
Irish Republican Army launch first of three mortar attacks on London's Heathrow Airport.
John Harrison, South African correspondent (BBC), dies at age 48.
Louis Freeman, band leader, dies at age 100.
Maurice "Moe" Purtill, jazz drummer, dies at age 77.
Robert Shea, author, dies of cancer.
Cecil Rolph Hewitt, journalist/policeman, dies at age 92.
One million Greeks attend Melina Mercouri's funeral.
Eduardo Frei succeeds Patricio Aylwin as President of Chile.
A photo by Marmaduke Wetherell, previously touted as 'proof' of the Loch Ness monster, is confirmed to be a hoax.
Church of England ordains its first 33 women priests.
A photo by Marmaduke Wetherell, previously touted as 'proof' of the Loch Ness monster, is confirmed to be a hoax.
The Church of England ordains its first female priests.
Sandra Paretti, romantic novelist, dies at age 59.
Donna Andrews wins LPGA Ping Welch's Golf Championship.
Danny Barker, US banjo player/guitarist (Bourbon St Black), dies at age 85.
33.3 percent of Austria votes for ultra-right FP+.
Soyuz TM-21 launches with V Dezyurov, G Strekalov and N Thagard.

Apple Computer introduces its first Power Macintosh computers, featuring 60 to 80 MHz PowerPC processors. Apple successfully managed a major processor transformation, without losing significant market share.
Mexican banker/billionaire Alfredo Harp Helu is kidnapped.
Timeline of Linux development: Linux kernel version 1.0.0 is released.
8th Soul Train Music Awards: Toni Braxton, Whitney Houston win.
U.S. troops are withdrawn from Somalia.
Experts from American League certify Cleveland Indian's Jacobs Field is properly lit.

In Portland, Oregon, Tonya Harding pleads guilty to conspiracy to hinder prosecution for trying to cover-up an attack on figure skating rival Nancy Kerrigan. She is fined $100,000 and banned from the sport.
Tonya Harding pleads guilty to conspiracy to hinder prosecution for trying to cover-up an attack on figure skating rival Nancy Kerrigan.
It is announced there is no smoking in Cleveland Indians' new ballpark.
Iran transport aircraft crashes in Azerbaijan (32 killed).
Harold Myers, film journalist, dies at age 81.
Arthur C Jacobs, poet, dies at age 57.
Zsa Zsa Gabor files for bankruptcy.
South Africa Goldstone committee reveals existence of secret police.
2500 kilograms of cocaine intercepted in Zeewolde, Netherlands.
Giuseppe Diana, Italian anti-mafia priest, murdered.
Jose Coronel Urtecho, poet, dies at age 87.
Lara scores 167 for West Indies versus England at Georgetown.
Largest omelet (1,383 square feet) made with 160,000 eggs in Yokohama, Japan.
New Jersey Devils club record 41st win of the season.
Wrestlemania X at Madison Square Garden New York, Bret Hart pins Yokozuna to win WWF championship.
Zulu-king Goodwill Zwelithini founds realm in South Africa.
El Salvador's first Presidential election following 12-year civil war.
Mashonaland U-24 beats Matabeleland on first inning to win Logan Cup.
Laura Davies wins LPGA Standard Register Ping Golf Tournament.
Anne P Sidamon-Eristoff named chairwoman of Museum of National History.
Watne Gretzky ties Gordie Howe's NHL record of 801 goals.
Dan Hartman, US singer/songwriter (Love Sensations), dies at age 42.
Igor Aleinikov, Russian director (tractors, air crash), dies at age 32.
South African Government/African National Congress take power in Ciskei homeland.
Luther Diamond, radio personality, dies at age 89.
Dutch Ambassador to US christens a new tulip (the Hillary Clinton).
Mark Foster swims world record 50 metre butterfly (23.68 seconds).
Walter Lantz, American cartoonist (Woody Woodpecker), dies at age 93 (born 1899).
Wayne Gretzky sets NHL record with 802 goals scored.
Russian Airbus A-310 crashes in Siberia (74-75 killed).
Luis Donaldo Colosio, Mexican Presidential candidate, assassinated at age 44 (born 1950).
Last day of Test cricket for Kapil Dev.
Graeme Obree bicycles world record 10 km (11:08).
Giulietta Masina, wife of Federico Felini/(La Strada), dies at age 74.
Alvara del Portillo, Spanish Opus Dei bishop, dies at age 80.
Richard Jacobs buys naming rights to Cleveland Indians' new ball park at Gateway for US$13.8 million (renamed Jacobs Field).
At an election rally in Tijuana, Mexican presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio is assassinated by Mario Aburto Martfnez.
F-16 collides with C-130 Hercules above air force base in North Carolina, 120 die.
Tommy Benford, jazz drummer, dies at age 88.
Edith Porada, art historian/archaeologist, dies at age 81.
Yasunori Miyabe skates world record 1000 metre (1:12.37).
Gunda Niemann skates ladies world record 3 km (4:09.32).
David Miles Bensuan-Butt, economist, dies at age 79.
Gunda Niemann skates world record 5 km ladies (7:03.26).
Jan Bor Dutch, violinist/painter, dies at age 83.
Bonnie Blair skates world record 500 metre ladies (38.99 seconds).
Constantine Koukouchkine, Russian diplomat, murdered in Algeria at age 41.
Gunda Niemann skates un-official world record 10 km ladies (14:02.60).
World Ice Pairs Figure Skating Championship in Chiba won by Shishkova/Vadim Naumov (Russia).
23rd Nabisco Dinah Shore Golf Championship won by Donna Andrews.
The biggest tornado outbreak in 1994 occurs in the southeastern United States. One tornado hits a United Methodist Church in Piedmont, Alabama, killing 22.
World Ice Dance Championship in Chiba Japan won by Gritschuk and Platov (Russia).
World Ladies Figure Skating Championship in Chiba won by Yuka Sato (Japan).
World Men's Figure Skating Championship in Chiba won by Elvis Stojko (Canada).
Dennis Hartas, flier, dies at age 69.
In Manching, Germany, the twin-engine Eurofighter first flies.
One of the biggest tornado outbreaks in recent memory hits the Southeastern United States. One tornado slams into a church in Piedmont, Alabama during Palm Sunday services killing 20 and injuring 90.
Inkatha Freedom Party and African National Congress supporters battle in central Johannesburg, South Africa; over 53 killed.
Italy's right-wing alliance under Silvio Berlusconi wins election.
In South Africa, Zulus and African National Congress supporters battle in central Johannesburg, resulting in 18 deaths.
William Natcher, American politician (Representative-Democrat-Kentucky), dies at age 84.
Coach Jimmy Johnson quits Dallas Cowboys.
Paul Grimault, animator, dies at age 89.
Serbs and Croats sign a cease-fire to end the war in Croatia.
Last day of Test cricket for Allan Border.
Bombay beats Bengal by 8 wickets to win Cricket's Ranji Trophy.
Albert Goldman, American rock biographer (Elvis Presley, John Lennon), dies at age 66.
England Cricket all out for 46 at Port-of-Spain.
ABC Masters Tournament won by Hobo Boothe.
Sid Weiss, bassist, dies at age 79.
Walkway from Cleveland's Tower City to Jacobs Field officially opens.
LTon J Ramirez Reine [Degrelle], Belgian/Spanish Nazi (Rex), dies at age 87.
The journal Nature reports the finding in Ethiopia of the first complete Australopithecus afarensis skull (see Human evolution).
Stuart Sloan, war hero/test pilot, dies at age 72.
Bob Feller Statue on Indians Plaza, dedicated.
Rosalind Laura Burke, aviatrix, dies at age 86.
First exhibition game played at Jacobs Field, Pittsburgh Pirates beat Cleveland Indians, 6-4.
13th NCAA Women Basketball Championship: North Carolina beats Louisiana Tech 60-59.
Pat Harper, New York City news anchor (WPIX, WNBC), dies.
Disney President and Chief Operating Officer Frank Wells dies in a helicopter accident, at age 62.
First roster of Silver Bullets (all-female pro baseball team) announced.
Jerome Lejeune, French geneticist (Syndrome of Down), dies at age 67.
Largest opening day crowd at Yankee Stadium, 56,706.
Virginia "Ginny" Simms, actress/singer (Kay Kyser Band), dies at age 77.
Olga Lowina, Dutch yodeler (Edelweisskapel), dies at age 69.
Marc Andreessen and Jim Clark found Mosaic Communications (later renamed Netscape).
KLM Saab 340B crashes at Schiphol, three killed.
56th NCAA Men's Basketball Champion: Arkansas Razorbacks beats Duke 76-72.
First game played at Jacobs Field; Cleveland Indians beat Seattle Mariners 4-3 in 11 innings.
Netscape Communications Corporation is founded (under the name "Mosaic Communications Corporation") by Marc Andreessen and Jim Clark.
Marlon Riggs, US writer/director/producer (Ethnic notions), dies at age 37.
Aubrey J Watson Sr, bishop, dies at age 65.
Andre Victor Tchelistcheff, winemaker, dies at age 92.
Roy Smeck, guitarist/banjoist, dies at age 94.
Miami Heat beat New York Knicks ending 15 game NBA winning streak.
Liberal Supreme Court Justice Blackmun (Roe versus Wade) resigns.
Palestinian suicide bomber kills 7 Israelis and himself.
Rockwell B-1B Lancers break 11 world speed records.
Dick Cary, jazz musician, dies at age 77.
Patricia Louise Dalton, chair (Sherlock Holmes Society), dies at age 75.
Agatha Uwilingiyimana Rwanda/first female Prime Minister in Africa, assassinated.
First scheduled Cleveland Indians night game at Jacobs Field is rained out.
Theo Bosch, humanist/architect (Amsterdam), dies at age 54.
Rwandan President JuvTnal Habyarimana and Burundi President Cyprien Ntaryamira die when a missile shoots down their jet near Kigali, Rwanda.
The Rwandan Genocide begins when the aircraft carrying Rwandan president JuvTnal Habyarimana and Burundian president Cyprien Ntaryamira is shot down by extremists.
First night game at Cleveland's Jacobs Field, Cleveland Indians 6, Seattle Mariners 2.
New York Yankees beat Texas Rangers 18-6.
Rwandan armed forces kill ten Belgian peacekeeping officers leading to the withdrawal of United Nations troops from the country.
Angelus Gottfried "Golo" Mann, German/US historian, dies at age 85 in Leverkusen, Germany (born 1909).
Fran?ois de Grossouvre, President Mitterrand's advisor, dies of suicide at age 76.
Lee Brilleaux, British R&B-singer/guitarist (Stupidity), dies at age 41.
Vatican acknowledges Holocaust (Germans killing Jews) for first time.
Massacres of Tutsis begin in Kigali, Rwanda.
Smoking is banned in Pentagon and all US military bases.
Walter Arnold, German theologist (World council of Churches), dies at age 64.
Kurt Cobain, lead singer of Nirvana, is found dead in Seattle, Washington. His death is believed to have been a suicide.
Atlanta Braves' pitcher Kent Mercker no-hits Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-0.
BPAA US Open won by Justin Hromek.
Cornelis N "Cor" van Dis Jr, Dutch Member of Parliament (1971-94), dies at age 71.
Keith Watson, British comic strip artist (Dan Dare), dies at age 59.

58th Golf Masters Championship: Jose M Olazabal wins, shooting a 279.

Canter & Siegel post the first commercial mass Usenet spam.
P J Engels, Dutch Member of Parliament (KVP), dies at age 70.
Donald Benjamin Harden, archaeologist, dies at age 92.
Presidential guard at Kigali, Rwanda, chops 1,200 church members to death.
United Arab Emirates' first official ODI, losing to India.
Taleb Ali al-Suheil, Iran sheik, murdered in Lebanon at age 64.
Selometsi Baholo, vice-premier of Lesotho, is murdered.
US F-15 accidentally shoots two US helicopters down over Iraq, 26 die.
New Jersey Devils end best regular season, 47-25-12 record for 106 points.
John Curry, British figure skater (Olympics-gold-1976), dies of AIDS at age 44 (born 1949).
Cleveland Indians lose first game at Jacobs Field, Kansas City Royals wins 2-1.

Representatives of 124 countries and the European Communities sign the Marrakesh Agreements revising the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and setting up the World Trade Organization (effective January 1, 1995).
Voters in Finland decide to join the European Union in a referendum.
Samuel Selvon author, dies at age 70.
55th PGA Seniors Golf Championship: Lee Trevino wins.
Val Skinner wins LPGA Atlanta Women's Golf Championship.
98th Boston Marathon won by Cosmas Ndeti of Kenya in 2:07:15.
23rd Boston Women's Marathon won by Uta Pippig of Germany in 2:21:45.
Brian Lara scores 375 for West Indies versus England to beat Sobers' world record.
Former US President Richard Nixon suffers a stroke.
Ken Oosterbroek, South African press photographer, shot dead at age 32.
US Supreme Court outlaws excluding people from juries because of gender.
Rodney King awarded US$3,800,000 in compensation for police beating.
Larry Davis, blues singer/guitarist, dies at age 57.
Louis Simmonds, bookseller, dies at age 87.
Inkatha ends boycott of South African multi-racial election.
American Telephone & Telegraph changes its company name to AT&T Corporation.
Danny Harold Rolling sentenced to death in Florida for killing five.
Serbian army bombs hospital in Goradze, Bosnia, 47 killed.
Sohail and Inzamam make world record ODI partnership of 263.
Paul Touvier is found guilty of ordering the execution of seven Jews when he served in the Vichy France Milice.
The Red Cross estimates that hundreds of thousands of Tutsi have been killed in Rwanda.
Serbian army bombs distress clinic in Goradze, Bosnia, 28 killed.
Eddie Murray sets record for switch hit homeruns in a game (11 times).
Clement Merk, animal trainer, dies at age 93.
The first discoveries of extrasolar planets are announced by astronomer Alexander Wolszczan.
D Nauta, theologist/church historian/lawyer, dies at age 96.
7,000 Tutsis slaughtered in stadium of Kibuye, Rwanda.
Schmidt Hans Burkhardt, artist, dies at age 89.
Richard Milhous Nixon, 37th US President (1969-74), dies of stroke at age 81 (born 1913).
In Denmark, the largest lollipop is made, weighing 3,011 pounds.
Michael Moorer beats Evander Holyfield in 12 for heavyweight boxing title.
Jack Alexander Bently, trombonist, dies at age 80.
Schelto Patijn appointed mayor of Amsterdam.
Army shoots to death 23-40 fishermen in Gonaives, Haiti.
General Tire World Bowling Tournament of Champions won by Norm Duke.
Libertarian party nominates Howard Stern for Governor of New York.
Physicists discover the top quark subatomic particle.
David Robinson scores ties 7th highest total in the NBA - 71.
New York Rangers sweep New York Islanders in NHL playoffs.
Armando Calder=n Sol wins El Salvador presidential election.
14 inches of snow in Southern California.
End of term for Sultan Azlan Muhibbudin Shah ibni Almarhum Sultan Yusuff Izzudin Shah Ghafarullahu-lahu as 9th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia.
Bomb attack on taxi stand in Johannesburg, South Africa; ten killed.
Tsutomu Hata elected premier of Japan.
Talaat Yassin Hamman, militant Muslim leader, shot dead at age 32.
Mexican businessman and billionaire Angel Losada is kidnapped.
George Gennimatas, Greek minister of National Economy, dies at age 55.
Fishing boat with school children capsizes at Lanaka, Syria, 46 killed.
The largest high school arson ever in the United States is started at Burnsville High School, in Burnsville, Minnesota, resulting in over US$15 million in damages.
Tuanku Jaafar ibni Almarhum Tuanku Abdul Rahman, Yang di-Pertuan Besar of Negeri Sembilan, becomes the 10th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia.
First multi-racial election in South Africa begins; Dr Nomaza Paintin in New Zealand is first black South African to vote.
26.9 degrees C in Prestebakke, Norway (Norwegian April high temperature record).
Taiwan Airbus A-300 crashes at Nagoya, Japan, 262 killed.
A China Airlines Airbus A-300-600R crashes at Nagoya Airport, Japan killing 264.
Jerome Lejeune, physiologist, dies at age 69.
29.0 degrees C in Genevad, Sweden (Swedish April high temperature record).
President Richard Nixon buried in Nixon Library in California.
Minnesota Twins righty Scott Erickson no-hits Milwaukee Brewers 6-0.
7th longest NHL game: New Jersey Devils beat Buffalo Sabres (125 minutes 43 seconds).
Graeme Obree bicycles world record time (52,713 km).
South African general election, 1994: The first democratic general election in South Africa, in which black citizens vote.
Freddy Thielemans sworn in as mayor of Brussels, Belgium.
Aldrich Ames, former US Central Intelligence Agency officer and wife Rosario plead guilty to spying.
First multi-racial election in South Africa ends.
Former Central Intelligence Agency official Aldrich Ames pleads guilty to giving U.S. secrets to the Soviet Union and later Russia.
Oscar Sheldon A Williams, artist/critic, dies at age 74.
Israel and Palestinian Liberation Organization sign economic accord.
Ferry boat smashes into Mombasa Harbor, Kenya, kills over 300.
Erik Erikson, anthropologist, dies at age 53.
Geoffery Michael Roberts, vintner, dies at age 46.
Austrian Formula One race car driver Roland Ratzenberger is killed in an accident during the qualifying session for the 1994 San Marino Grand Prix.
Sherri Steinhauer wins LPGA Sprint Golf Championship.
Sandra Palmer wins LPGA Sprint Senior Challenge Golf Tournament.
Tornado and hail storms hit Jiangxi, China, 95 killed.
Brazilian Formula One driver Ayrton Senna dies in an accident during the San Marino Grand Prix.
Imre Gyngyssy, Hungarian director, dies at age 64.
Wilson Charles Geoffery Baldwin, hero, dies at age 75.
Bus crashes into a tree at Gdansk, Poland, 30 killed.
Dr Kevokian found innocent on assisting suicides.
D66/Dutch Liberal Party wins Dutch second Parliamentary election.
Gustaaf baron van Hemert Dingshof, mayor of Maarn, dies at age 78.
Haty Tegelaar-Boonacker, Dutch Member of Parliament (CDA), dies at age 63.
Milford Dolliole, pioneer jazz drummer, dies at age 90.
29th Academy of Country Music Awards: Garth Brooks wins.
The Walt Disney Company announces plans to start a cruise ship venture.
Richard McClure Scarry, American author/illustrator of children's books, dies at age 74.

In Cairo, Egypt, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Palestinian Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat sign an accord on the first stage of Palestinian self-rule. This Gaza-Jericho agreement called for certain Israeli military withdrawals, and Palestinian agreements to combat violence.
Karl Francis Hettinger, onion field survivor, dies at age 59.
Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and PLO leader Yasser Arafat sign a peace accord regarding Palestinian autonomy granting self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho.
North-Yemen air force bombs Aden, South Yemen.
Labour beats Conservatives in British local elections.
American Michael P. Fay is caned in Singapore as punishment for spray-painting two cars.
Nelson Mandela and his African National Congress finally confirmed winners in South Africa elections.
US House of Representatives passes the assault weapons ban.
Helen Lessore, artist, dies at age 86.
Haskell "Cool Papa" Sadler, blues singer/guitarist, dies at age 59.

A rail tunnel under the English Channel is officially opened, connecting Britain and the European mainland for the first time since the Ice Age. England's Queen Elizabeth II and French President Francois Mitterand preside over the opening ceremony. The channel tunnel, the world's longest undersea tunnel (23 miles), connects Folkstone, England, with Sangatte, France, cutting travel time between England and France to 35 minutes. Tunnel construction began in June 1988, and cost US$16 billion to complete.
Montague Modlyn, broadcaster, dies at age 72.
Moses Rosen, Romania's chief rabbi, dies at age 81.
Lennox Lewis TKOs Phil Jackson in 8 rounds for heavyweight boxing title.

Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom and French President François Mitterrand inaugurate the opening of the Channel Tunnel ? a tunnel under the English Channel linking England and France for the first time since the end of the Great Ice Age.
Denver Nuggets become NBA's first #8 seed to beat a #1 seed (Seattle SuperSonics).
120th Kentucky Derby: Chris McCarron on Go For Gin wins in 2:03.6.
Margaret Skeete, oldest American, dies at age 115.

US President Bill Clinton announces US will no longer repatriate boat people.
Rupert Haselden, journalist/screenwriter, dies at age 36.
Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president.
An annular eclipse of the sun is visible across much of North America.
Phyllis Flowerdew, school Reading text author, dies at age 81.
Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's president.
Lucebert [J Swaanswijk], poet/cartoonist (PC Hooft 1967), dies at age 69.
Illinois executes serial killer John Wayne Gacy (age 52) by lethal injection for the murder of 33 young men and boys.
Silvio Berlusconi forms Italian Government with five neo-fascists.

An annular eclipse of the sun is visible across much of North America.

Six white racists sentenced to death in South Africa.
Danny Overbea, blues singer/guitarist, dies at age 68.
Leonard Friedman, violinist, dies at age 63.
Lewis B Puller, US writer (Pulitzer 1992), commits suicide at age 48.
Alfred James Broomhall, methodist missionary, dies at age 82.

Xenophon Balaskas, cricket player (9 Tests for South Africa, 22 wickets), dies.

WIBC Bowling Queens won by Anne Marie Duggan.
U.K. Labour Party leader John Smith, 55, dies of a heart attack. Deputy leader Margaret Beckett stands in until an election can be held.
David Brooks, psychologist, dies at age 91.
The Israeli Defense Forces withdraw from Jericho.
Duncan Hamilton, driver, dies at age 74.

FA cup final at Wembley Stadium London.

40th McDonald's LPGA Championship won by Laura Davies.
Frederik baron van Pallandt, Danish singer (Nina and F), murdered at age 61.

Joaqu?n Balaguer (86), elected President of Dominican Republic.
Tennis star Jennifer Capriati arrested on possession of marijuana.
Malawi holds its first multiparty elections.
Bakili Muluzi's UDF wins Malawi presidents/parliamentary election.
Andrew Brown, film producer, dies at age 55.
AC Milan wins Europe Cup 1: 4-0 against Barcelona.
(to May 19) The Israeli Defense Forces withdraw from most of the Gaza Strip.
Tropical Butterfly Garden at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo opens.
Luis Ocana Span, cyclist (Tour de France 1973), commits suicide at age 48.
Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis, First Lady (1961-63), dies of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma at age 64 (born 1929).
Tennis star Jennifer Capriati (18), checks into a drug rehab center.
Sony Theaters and Cineplex (New York City) hike movie ticket prices to $8.00.
Vivien John, artist, dies at age 79.
Cliff Wilson, snooker player, dies at age 60.
Forsyth Hardy, documentary film pioneer, dies at age 84.
120th Preakness: Pat Day aboard Tabasco Cat wins in 1:56.4.
Giovanni Goria, Prime Minister of Italy (1987-88), dies.
Cincinnati Reds bat out of order against Los Angeles Dodgers in second inning.
Sushmita Sen, 18, of India, crowned 43rd Miss Universe.
Elaine Crosby wins LPGA Lady Keystone Golf Open.
Toronto NBA franchise unveils name "Raptors" and logo.
Mitacq [Michel Tacq], Belgian comic strip artist (Beaver Patrol), dies.

270 pilgrims die in bustle round Mina Saudi-Arabia.
Carl Althoff, German circus director, dies at age 82.

Roman Herzog is elected President of Germany.

Alexander Solzhenitsyn returns to Russia after 20 years in exile.
Norman Cook, British museum curator, dies at age 87.
Red Rodney [Albino Red/The Red Arrow], bebop-trumpeter, dies at age 66.
Theo Swagemakers, portrait painter, dies at age 95.

Julius Boros, pro golfer (US Open 1952), dies of heart attack at age 74.
Minnesota Twins' Dave Winfield passes Rod Carew into 15th hit list (3,054).
Harry Levin, literary Scholar, dies at age 81.
Erich Honecker, President of German Democratic Republic (1971-89), dies in Santiago, Chile at age 81 (born 1912).
Great comet-iceball seen above North Sea.
Hungary's Socialist Party wins parliamentary election.
Oliver "Bops Junior" Jackson, drummer, dies at age 61.
Al Unser Jr wins 78th Indianapolis 500 in 3:06:29.006 (255.89 kph).
Patty Sheehan wins J C Penney/LPGA Skins Golf Game.
Beth Daniel wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Herbert Shughart refuses to shake hands with U.S. President Bill Clinton following a presentation of posthumous Medals of Honor to the widows of two soldiers for valor at the Battle of Mogadishu.
Ezra Taft Benson, US minister of Agriculture/leader of Mormon Church (1985-94), dies at age 94.
Jean Gattegno, translator/scholar, dies at age 58.
Baron Marcel Bich, Italian/French baron/pen manufacturer (Bic), dies at age 79.
Emmanuel "Manny" Klein, trumpeter, dies at age 86.
San Diego Padres score 13 in second versus Pittsburgh Pirates.
Herva Nelli, soprano, dies at age 85.
Doug Freeman, cricket player (two Tests of leg-spin for New Zealand 1933), dies.
Sidney Gilliat, British screenwriter/director, dies at age 86.

In South of Jawa, Indonesia, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurs. At least 250 people killed, 27 missing, 423 injured and many left homeless. About 1,500 houses damaged or destroyed and 278 boats sunk or damaged. Most of the casualties and damage were caused by a tsunami along the southeast coast of Jawa.
In Taiwan, a magnitude 6.4 earthquake occurs.

In Colombia, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. At least 295 people killed, 500 missing, 13,000 homeless and severe damage caused to houses, highways and bridges by the earthquake and ensuing landslides.
(to June 8) Ceasefire negotiations for the Yugoslav War begin in Geneva, Switzerland; they agree to a one-month cessation of hostilities.

In Northern Bolivia, a magnitude 8.2 earthquake occurs. Felt at many locations in North America, including Los Angeles, California; Boston, Massachusetts and Toronto, Canada. This is believed to be the first earthquake from this part of South America to be felt in North America and is also believed to be the largest ever recorded in this general area.
Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman are murdered outside the Simpson home in Los Angeles, California. O.J. Simpson is later acquitted of the killings, but is held liable in a civil suit.
Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman are murdered outside her home in Los Angeles, California. O. J. Simpson is later acquitted of the killings, but is held liable in a civil suit.
German districts Röbel and Waren are merged to form Müritz
Hacker Kevin Poulsen pleads guilty to seven counts of mail fraud, wire and computer fraud, money laundering, and obstruction of justice.
The New York Rangers defeat the Vancouver Canucks at Madison Square Garden in New York in Game 7 of the 1994 Stanley Cup Finals to win their first Stanley Cup Championship in 54 years.
Israel and the Vatican establish full diplomatic relations.
Israel and Vatican City establish full diplomatic relations.
A Chinese operated Tupolev TU-154 crashes 10 minutes after takeoff killing 160.
The 1994 FIFA World Cup soccer competition begins in the United States.

NFL star O.J. Simpson and his friend Al Cowlings flee from police in Simpson's white Ford Bronco. The low speed chase, which unfolds live on television, ends up at Simpson's mansion in Brentwood, Los Angeles, California, where he then surrenders to police.
Following a televised highway chase and a failed attempt at suicide, O. J. Simpson is arrested for the murders of his wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman.
In South Island, New Zealand, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs.
43 baseball fans are injured in an escalator accident at the two-year-old Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore, Maryland.
Members of the Aum Shinrikyo cult release a sarin gas attack at Matsumoto, Japan. Seven persons killed, 660 injured.
In Charlotte Pass, New South Wales, an Australian record cold temperature of -9.4 degrees F is recorded.
Palestinian Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat arrives in Gaza.
Colombian football player AndrTs Escobar, 27, is shot dead in Bogot.
The United States announced it would refuse further unrestricted immigration from Haiti.
Fourteen firefighters die in the South Canyon wildfire on Storm King Mountain in Colorado.
Aden is occupied by troops from North Yemen.
Aden is occupied by troops from North Yemen, completing the reunification of Yemen.
Gary Kildall dies in a bar brawl, at age 52. He was an American microcomputer industry visionary and pioneer, most well-known for creating the CP/M operating system.
American president Bill Clinton visits Berlin and states to the Berliners, "America stands at your side - now and forever."
(to July 21) The planet Jupiter is hit by 21 large fragments of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9.

Microsoft reaches a settlement with the US Department of Justice regarding alleged monopolistic operating system licensing practices. Microsoft agrees to change some of its practices of how it sells its operating systems to vendors in the United States and Europe.
Albert Belle of the Cleveland Indians caught with a corked bat.
The planet Jupiter is hit by fragments of the Shoemaker-Levy 9 comet.
The civil war in Rwanda ends.
Brazil wins the 1994 FIFA World Cup, defeating Italy 3-2 in penalties (Full time score 0-0).
Brazil Capture their Fourth Would Cup beating Italy in a penalty kick shootout
Trailing 11-0 after three innings, the Houston Astros pull off a major comeback defeating the Saint Louis Cardinals, 15-12.
In Buenos Aires, a terrorist attack destroys a building housing several Jewish organizations, killing 85 and injuring many more.
A court upholds NBA salary cap and draft rights.
In Buenos Aires, an explosion destroys a building housing several Jewish organizations killing 85 and injuring many more.
Four 26-pound ceiling tiles fall from the roof of the Kingdome in Seattle, Washington, just hours before a scheduled Seattle Mariners game.
Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9's Fragment Q1 hits Jupiter.
Israel's Shimon Peres visits Jordan, the highest ranking Israeli official to do so
Tony Blair is declared the winner of the leadership election of the British Labour Party, paving the way to him becoming Prime Minister in 1997.
Israel and Jordan sign the Israel-Jordan Treaty of Peace, which formally ends the state of war that has existed between the nations since 1948.
Israel and Jordan sign the Washington Declaration which formally ends the state of war that has existed between the nations since 1948.
The German Bundestag votes to privatize the postal system. The postal service, the telephone service and the postal bank are to be privatized by January 1, 1995.
The University of London founds the School of Advanced Study, a group of postgraduate research institutes.
Fire destroys Norwich Central Library in the United Kingdom, including most of its historical records.
Michael Jackson and Lisa Marie Presley confirm rumors that they had married eleven weeks earlier.
Tokyo Disneyland welcomes its 150 millionth guest.
Groups of protesters spread from Havana, Cuba's Castillo de la Punta ("Point Castle"), creating the first protests against Fidel Castro's government since 1959.

The 1994 Bambino World Series takes place in Henderson, Kentucky for the first time. Two years work of volunteers and funds led up to this event. It is played at Henderson's Park field with over 5,000 people in attendance.
Woodstock 1994 begins in Saugerties, New York. It is the 25-year anniversary of Woodstock in 1969.
Major League Baseball players go on strike, eventually causing the cancellation of the World Series and delaying opening of the 1995 season.
Major League Baseball players go on strike. The work stoppage will force the cancellation of the 1994 World Series.
The Woodstock '94 rock concert takes place in New York.
Ilich Ramfrez Snchez, the terrorist known as "Carlos the Jackal", is captured.
In Northern Algeria, a magnitude 5.9 earthquake occurs. At least 159 people are killed, 289 injured, 8,000 to 10,000 left homeless and thousands of houses destroyed in Mascara Province.

In Honolulu, Hawaii, during a circus international performance at the Neal Blaisdell Arena, a female elephant named Tyke crushes her trainer Allen Campbell to death before hundreds of horrified spectators.
Circus elephant trainer Allen Campbell is crushed to death in Honolulu, Hawaii, by the performing elephant "Tyke".
Jeffrey Katzenberg resigns from the Walt Disney Company.
Initial accord between Israel and the PLO about partial self-rule of the Palestinians on the West Bank.
The Provisional Irish Republican Army announces a "complete cessation of military operations."
The Provisional Irish Republican Army declares a ceasefire.
The National Corvette Museum opens in Bowling Green, Kentucky, USA. 4000 Corvettes attend. Over the three-day weekend, 118,000 people visit the museum. The gift shop does US$1 million in business.
Russia and the People's Republic of China agree to de-target their nuclear weapons against each other.
Sino-Soviet Split: Russia and the People's Republic of China agree to de-target their nuclear weapons against each other.
Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Japan opens. All international services are transferred from Itami to Kansai.
New South Wales State Member of Parliament for Cabramatta John Newman is shot outside his home, in Australia's first political assassination since 1977.

Apple Computer announces its intention to license the Macintosh operating system in 1995. A Mac OS logo is announced, which will be used to identify Mac application programs and Mac-compatible systems.
USAir Flight 427, a Boeing 737 with 132 people on board, crashes on approach to Pittsburgh International Airport; there are no survivors.
A Boeing 737 operating USAir Flight 427 carrying 132 people on board, crashes on approach to Pittsburgh International Airport. There are no survivors.
Frank Eugene Corder crashes a Cessna 150 into the White House's south lawn, striking the West wing and killing himself.
US President Bill Clinton signs the Assault Weapons Ban, which bans the manufacture of new weapons with certain features for a period of ten years.
Ulysses probe passes the Sun's south pole.
Due to the Major League Baseball players' strike, owners vote to cancel remainder of the season including the World Series.
The Major League Baseball season is canceled due to strike.

Disney Chairman Michael Eisner meets with Peter Rummell to discuss the Disney's America project. Projections of revenues and expenses show that the park would operate at a loss. Eisner decides to abandon the idea to build the historical theme park in Virginia, for financial reasons and due to negative press.
Muslim fundamentalists kidnap & behead 16 people in Algeria.
National Party of Canada collapses due to party infighting.
Haiti's military leaders agreed to depart on October 15th.
American troops stage a bloodless invasion of Haiti in order to restore the legitimate elected leader, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power.
The pilot episode of the hit medical drama ER airs in the United States, on NBC, which will become one of the most watched shows of all time.
National League for Democracy is formed by Aung San Suu Kyi and various people to help fight against dictatorship of Myanmar.
Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, Mexican politician, is assassinated.
The car ferry MS Estonia sinks in Baltic Sea, killing 852 people.
The name of Euro Disneyland is officially changed to Disneyland Paris.

In the Kuril Islands, a magnitude 8.3 earthquake occurs. At least ten people killed or missing and extensive damage on Iturup; at least 340 people injured and extensive damage occurred along the east coast of Hokkaido, Japan. Felt in the Tokyo area, Japan. Tsunami wave heights up to 3.46m.
In Switzerland, 23 members of the Order of the Solar Temple cult are found dead, a day after 25 of their fellow cultists are similarly discovered dead in Morin Heights, Quebec.
UNESCO inaugurates World Teachers' Day to celebrate and commemorate the signing of the Recommendation Concerning the Status of Teachers on October 5, 1966.
The President of the United Nations Security Council says that Iraq must withdraw its troops from the Kuwait border and immediately cooperate with weapons inspectors.
NASA loses radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft as the probe descends into the thick atmosphere of Venus (the spacecraft presumably burns up in the atmosphere either October 13 or October 14).
NASA loses radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft as the probe descends into the thick atmosphere of Venus (the spacecraft presumably burned up in the atmosphere either October 13 or October 14)
Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, and Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres receive the Nobel Peace Prize.
Following threats by the U.N. Security Council and the U.S., Iraq withdraws troops from its border with Kuwait.
After three years of U.S. exile, Haiti's president Aristide returns to his country.

The Federal Republic of Germany holds parliamentary elections. The CDU/CSU gets 41.4 percent of the vote, the SPD 36.4 percent, the FDP 6.9 percent, the Green Party 7.3 percent. The CDU/CSU-FDP coalition continues. Helmut Kohl (CDU) continues as chancellor.
Peace treaty between the government of Angola and UNITA rebels.
Draft peace treaty between Israel and Jordan
New Zealand's Goodnight Kiwi says good night for the last time.
In Coleman, Michigan, USA a meteorite penetrates the roof of a house.
North Korea nuclear weapons program: North Korea and the United States sign an agreement that requires North Korea to stop its nuclear weapons program and agree to inspections.
Jordan and Israel sign a peace treaty
Announcement of Andrew Wiles correct proof of Fermat's last theorem.
Francisco Martin Duran fires over two dozen shots at the White House; he is later convicted of trying to kill President Bill Clinton.
Francisco Martin Duran fires over two dozen shots at the White House (Duran was later convicted of trying to kill US President Bill Clinton).
An American Eagle ATR-72 plane crashes in Roselawn, Indiana, after circling in icy weather, killing 64 passengers.

The Duke of Edinburgh attends a ceremony in Israel, where his late mother, Princess Alice of Battenberg, is honoured as "Righteous among the Nations" for sheltering Jewish families from the Germans in Athens, Greece, during World War II.
An American Eagle ATR-72 crashes in Roselawn, Indiana, after circling in icy weather, killing all 68 on board.
The Chijon Family is sentenced to death in South Korea for murdering and eating five people.
George Lucas leaves the day-to-day operations of his filmmaking business and starts a sabbatical. While on sabbatical, he writes the prequel section of the Star Wars movies.

In San Francisco, California, the first conference devoted entirely to the subject of the commercial potential of the World Wide Web opens. Featured speakers include Marc Andreessen of Netscape, Mark Graham of Pandora Systems, and Ken McCarthy of E-Media.
San Francisco: First conference that focused exlusively on the subject of the commercial potential of the World Wide Web.
A letter by former U.S. President Ronald Reagan is released that announces he has Alzheimer's disease.
Johan Heyns, influential Afrikaner theologian and critic of Apartheid, is assassinated.

In Las Vegas, Nevada, George Foreman wins the WBA and IBF World Heavyweight Championships by knocking out Michael Moorer in the 10th round, becoming the oldest heavyweight champion in history (age 45).
Forty-five year old George Foreman becomes boxing's oldest heavyweight champion when he knocks out Michael Moorer.
A letter by former U.S. President Ronald Reagan is released that announces he has Alzheimer's disease.
WXYC, the student radio station of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provides the world's first Internet radio broadcast.

Apple Computer, Motorola, and IBM announce that they will create a computer platform to run all major operating systems, except the Intel x86-based Microsoft Windows 3.1 and successors. To be included are the Mac OS, OS/2, AIX, Solaris, Windows NT, and Netware.

Georgia Representative Newt Gingrich leads the United States Republican Party in taking control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate in midterm congressional elections. This is the first time in 40 years that the Republicans secure control of both houses of Congress. George W. Bush is elected Governor of Texas.
For the first time in 40 years the United States Republican Party takes control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate in midterm congressional elections.
The chemical element Darmstadtium is discovered.
Discovery of the chemical element Darmstadtium.
Bill Gates pays US$30.8 million at auction in New York for Leonardo da Vinci's notebook, the Leicester Codex. The price paid is a record for a manuscript.
A country-wide referendum is held to decide if Sweden should join the European Union. 52.2 percent vote yes, 46.9 percent vote no.
The first passengers travel through the Channel Tunnel between England and France.
Voters in Sweden decide to join the European Union in a referendum.

In Mindoro, Philippine Islands, a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurs. At least 78 people killed and 225 injured on Luzon and Mindoro. A local tsunami contributed to extensive damage in the Calapan and Puerto Galera areas. More than 797 houses destroyed and 3,288 damaged on Mindoro.
Helmut Kohl is re-elected German Chancellor by the Bundestag with a vote of 338-333.
A Federal judge issues a temporary restraining order, prohibiting the State of California from implementing Proposition 187, that would have denied most public services to illegal aliens.
First National Lottery draw in England.
The Angolan government and UNITA rebels sign the Lusaka Protocol.
The Angolan government and UNITA rebels sign the Lusaka Protocol in Zambia, ending 19 years of civil war (in 1995 localized fighting resumed).

Sega introduces the Saturn video game system in Japan. It features two 28.6 MHz 32-bit Hitachi SH7064 RISC processors, two video display processors, Hitachi SH7034 processor controlling the double-speed CD-ROM drive, Tamaha FH1 digital signal processor, Motorola 68EC000 sound processor, QSound surround sound, 2 MB main memory, 1.5 MB video memory, 24-bit color in 640x224 resolution, memory cartridge slot, expansion slot. Price is 44800 yen (about US$450).
Sony founder Akio Morita announces he will be stepping down as CEO of the company.
In Portage, Wisconsin, convicted serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer is clubbed to death by an inmate in the Columbia Correctional Institute gymnasium.
Voters in Norway reject European Union membership (see Norwegian EU referendum, 1994).
Russian aircraft bomb Chechen capital of Grozny.
Hip-hop artist Tupac Shakur is robbed of $40,000 in jewelry and survives being shot five times in a New York music studio.
Ernesto Zedillo innaugrated as President of MTxico.
Hugh Chilvers, cricket player (151 wickets leg-spin for New South Wales 1928-37), dies.
Three Seattle Seahawks players injured in a car accident.
Donald John Urquhart, librarian, dies at age 85.
James Norman Dalrymple Anderson, lawyer, dies at age 86.
The Australian government agrees to pay reparations to indigenous Australians who were displaced during the nuclear tests at Maralinga in the 1950s and 1960s.

Sony introduces the PlayStation video game system in Japan. It features a 33 MHz 32-bit MIPS R3000A processor, with special audio and graphics functions integrated, geometry coprocessor, 2 MB RAM, 1 MB video RAM. Graphics resolution is 640x480 in 24-bit color. Price is 39800 yen, about US$399.
Giorgi Chanturia, President of Georgia, is assassinated.
Elizabeth Meyer, wife of actor Paul Michael Glaser, dies of AIDS at age 47.
Dolf Verspoor, literary/translator (M Nijhoff prize 1958), dies at age 77.
83rd Davis Cup: Sweden beats Russia in Moscow (4-1).
Thomas Roy Garrett, museum curator, dies at age 63.
Robert Jesse Charleston, museum curator, dies at age 78.
Marta Figueras-Dottie and Brad Bryant win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
Julio Ramon Ribeyro, Peruvian playwright, dies at age 66.
Geoffery Rudolph Elton, historiographer, dies at age 73.
Jakob Kaplan, French head rabbi (1955-81), dies at age 99.
Pakistan wins World Hockey Championship after 12 years, beating the Netherlands by four goals to three, in Sydney.
Ronald Ridout, school textbook author, dies at age 78.
AJ Bronkhorst, vicar/theologist (Reform The Netherlands), dies at age 80.
Orange County, California, files for bankruptcy, due to risky investments.
Warner Brothers announces a 5th TV network in the USA to begin on January 11, 1995.
Antonio Carlos Jobim, Brazil composer (Girl From Ipanema), dies at age 67 (born 1927).
Fire in cinema in Karamay, China, 310 killed.
Jes?s "Enrique" L?ster, Spanish/Russian general (Civil War), dies at age 87.
Israel Aaron Maisels, lawyer, dies at age 89.
US President Bill Clinton signs a bill enacting United States participation in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Maureen Cox Starkey, ex-wife of Ringo Starr, dies of Leukemia at age 48.
13m diameter asteroid 1994XM1 passes within 100,000km of Earth.
Max Bill, Swiss painter/sculptor/politician, dies at age 85.
Garnet Silk, Jamaican raggae-singer, dies at age 28.
Kim II Sung, President of North Korea (1945-94), dies at age 82.
Nobel Prize awarded to Yitzhak Rabin, Shimon Peres, and Yasser Arafat.
Keith Joseph, British Member of Parliament (Conservative), dies.
Ruth Evelyn Mansfield, doctor, dies at age 92.
George G F van Renesse, concert pianist/music director, dies at age 85.
Garnett Silk, vocalist, dies at age 28.
European Campaign against racism "All different, All equal" begins.
60th Heisman Trophy Award: Rashaan Salaam, Colorado (RB).
Kelly Robbins and Tammie Green win LPGA Diner's Club Golf Matches.

A small bomb explodes on Philippine Airlines Flight 434, killing a Japanese businessman. The bombing was a field test done by Ramzi Yousef to test explosives that would have been used in Project Bojinka.
Stanislaw Maczek, Polish/British general-major (WWII), dies at age 102.
Boris Yeltsin orders troops into Chechnya.
Yao Yilin, Vice Prime Minister of China (1979), dies.
A bomb assembled by Ramzi Yousef explodes on Philippine Airlines Flight 434, killing a Japanese businessman.
First Chechen War: Russian President Boris Yeltsin orders Russian troops into Chechnya
Antoine Pinay, French Prime Minister (1952)/foreign minister, dies at age 102.
Donna J. Stone, poet, dies of heart failure at age 61.
Herman H Felderhof, radio-announcer/head (NRU/NOS Radio), dies at age 83.
American Eagle commuter plane crashes in North Carolina, killing 15.

Fred West, 53, a builder living in Gloucester, is remanded in custody, charged with murdering 12 people (including two of his own daughters) whose bodies were mostly found buried at his house in Cromwell Street. His wife Rose West, 41, is charged with ten murders. Police believe that the murders took place between 1967 and 1987, and suspect that the couple may have killed up to 30 people.
Herman W "Fritz" Liebert, US librarian/Yale-curator, dies at age 83.
Antoine Pinay, Prime Minister of France (1952-53), dies.

A Learjet piloted by Richard Anderson and Brad Sexton misses an elementary school and crashes into an apartment complex in Fresno, California, killing both pilots and injuring several apartment residents.
Petrus van Doorne, bus manufacturer/owner (BOVA), dies at age 58.
Liberia militia kills 48 inhabitants of Monrovia.
Henry Phelps Brown, historian/economist, dies at age 88.
Diane Modahl banned from athletics for drug use, in the United Kingdom.
Mollie Doreen Phillips, British figure skater (Europe-bronze-1933), dies at age 87.
Hans de Jong, musician/conductor (Amsterdams Vrouwenkoor), dies at age 86.
Samuel Lipman, music critic, dies at age 60.
Mary Durack, poet, dies at age 81.
Heinz Bernard Lowenstein, actor/director, dies at age 71.
Socialist Party (ex-communist) wins Bulgaria parliamentary election.
Norman, Couples and Azinger win LPGA Wendy's 3-Tour Golf Challenge.
Civil unions between homosexuals are made legal in Sweden.
The Whitewater scandal investigation begins in Washington, DC.

A planned exchange rate correction of the Mexican Peso to the US Dollar becomes a massive financial meltdown in Mexico, unleashing the 'Tequila' effect on global financial markets. This will prompt a US$50 billion 'bailout' by the Clinton administration.
Noel Pointer, jazz violinist, dies at age 39.
J C "Jody" Bateman, fiddler, dies at age 75.
Dean Rusk, US Secretary of State (1961-69), dies at age 85.
Shauna McDonald Brown, British TV producer, dies at age 37.
A homemade bomb goes off on the #4 train on Fulton Street in New York City.
Baseball owners impose salary cap, fiercely opposed by players.
Charles Shirley, jazz arranger, dies at age 74.
Didier Rocher, son of French cosmetic maker Yves Rocher, dies at age 41.
Four Muslim fundamentalists capture Air France pilot in Algiers.
John Keith Wright, English Assistant Secretary of State (1971-84), dies at age 66.
John James Osborne (Entertainer Luther), playwright, dies of cardiac arrest at age 65.
John Eastburn Boswell, medievalist, dies at age 47.
Nathan I. Daniel, inventor (Guitars), dies at age 82.
Zail Singh, President of India (1982-87), dies at age 78.
Pierre Dreyfus, French director of Renault (1955-75), dies at age 87.
Asta ER Elstak, Suriname/Netherlands welfare worker, dies at age 74.
French anti-terrorist police storm a hijacked Air France jet at Marseille and kill four Islamist terrorists.
Johannes J "Joop" Klant, Netherlands/South African economist/author, dies.
Karl AF Schiller, West German economist/SPD-minister (1966-72), dies at age 83.
Peter Barker Howard May, cricket player (4537 runs-England 1951-61), dies at age 64.
Sadi de Gorter, Dutch author/diplomat (Abscess), dies at age 82.
Boon completes his 20th Test Cricket century (131 versus England, Melbourne Cricket Ground).
Julian Belfrage, theatre agent, dies at age 60.
Off the east coast of Honshu, Japan, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurs. Two people killed, more than 200 injured and damage in the Hachinohe area. Felt as far away as Tokyo.
Billy Ray Cyrus (Achy Breaky Heart) weds Leticia Finley.
B737-400 flies into a mountain at Edremit East Turkey, 54 killed.
Billionaire J Paul Getty Jr marries Victoria Holdsworth on Barbados.
Last Dutch electro-magnetic telephone exchange shuts down.
Shane Warne takes a hat-trick versus England at cricket Melbourne Cricket Ground.
Lloyd James Austin, french scholar, dies at age 79.

This day is skipped by the Phoenix Islands to switch from the UTC-11 time zone to UTC+13, and by the Line Islands to switch from UTC-10 to UTC+14. The latter becomes the earliest time zone in the world, one full day ahead of Hawaii.
The Walt Disney Company signs a preliminary agreement to commit up to US$34 million to renovate and lease the New Amsterdam Theater in New York.

The work of the Treuhand Organization is finished and the organization is terminated. The Treuhand oversaw the privatization of property in East Germany. The organization had privatized 14,500 businesses.
Harri Webb, poet, dies at age 74.
Thomas J Watson Jr, CEO (IBM), dies of a stroke at age 79.
Leigh Bowery, designer, dies at age 33.
BAM "Bob" Schreiner, airline owner (S Aviation Group), dies at age 79.
This date is skipped altogether in Kiribati, as the Phoenix Islands and Line Islands changed time zones from UTC-11 to UTC+13 and UTC-10 to UTC+14, respectively.
The World Trade Organization comes into effect.
The Kingdom of Sweden and the republics of Austria and Finland are admitted into the European Union.
The Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe becomes the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe.
In Germany, the "SolidaritStszuschlag" (a special tax for rebuilding the East) is introduced and applies to income taxes and corporate taxes.
The World Trade Organization is established to replace GATT.
The Draupner wave in the North Sea in Norway is detected, confirming the existence of freak waves.
Eugene Wigner, Hungarian physicist (Nobel Prize for physics-1963), dies at age 92 (born 1902).
Austria, Finland, and Sweden enter the European Union.
Fernando Henrique Cardoso installed as President of Brazil.
Frederick West, English contractor/serial killer, commits suicide at age 53.
Jess Stacy, US jazz pianist (Great Gatsby), dies at age 90.
Rod Stewart sets a new record for the largest attendance for an open-air concert, as 3.5 million people turn out for his New Year's concert in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
Ted Hawkins, US blues singer ("Watch Your Step", "The Next Hundred Years"), dies at age 58 after a stroke, in Los Angeles, California.
Bravo!, Canada's NewStyleArts Channel launches, along with WTN, The New Country Network, and RDI, the world's first 24-hour French news channel.
Raman Lamba and Ravi Sehgal score 464 for first wicket for Delhi.
Mohammed Siyad Barre, General/President of Somalia (1969-91), dies at age 84 (born 1919).
Manuel Rivera, Spanish painter/co-founder (El Paso), dies at age 67.
Graham Sharp, ice skater, dies at age 77.
Carquest Bowl 5: South Carolina beats West Virginia, 24-21.
Most distant galaxy yet discovered found by scientists using Keck telescope in Hawaii (estimated 15 billion light years away).
Bus crashes in Luzon, Philippines, 29 killed.
Robert Nesbitt, impresario, dies at age 88.
Vladislav Listiev, Russian talk show host/producer, assasinated.
Gerard W Taylor, South African/British surgeon, dies at age 74.
Byron MacGregor, newscaster, dies at age 56.
Al Duncan, drummer, dies at age 68.
Robert Clifford Latham Pepys, scholar, dies at age 82.
Jonathan Zeitlyn, artist, dies at age 43.
The 104th US Congress convenes, the first controlled by Republicans in both houses since 1953. Newt Gingrich is speaker of the House.
Eduardo Mata, Mexican conductor, dies in air crash at age 52.
D Elmina Davies, filmmaker, dies at age 36.
Leonard Hirsch, British violinist/conductor (BBC Empire Orchestra), dies at age 92.
Yahya Ayyash, Palestinian Liberation Organization bomb maker, is killed by booby-trapped cellular phone at age 28.
Mansour Satari, Brigadier General/commandant (Iran Air Force), dies at age 46.
Lockheed C-140 Jetstar crashes at Isfahan Persia, 18 killed.
Atlanta Hawks' Lenny Wilkens becomes NBA's winningest coach (939).
Near the east coast of Honshu, Japan, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurs.

(to January 7) A chemical fire occurs in an apartment complex in Manila, Philippines. Policemen and investigators find a bomb factory and a laptop computer and disks that contain plans for Project Bojinka, a mass-terrorist attack. The mastermind, Ramzi Yousef, is arrested a month later.
Edward Sutcliffe, judge (British Central Criminal Court), dies at age 77.
Joe Slovo, Latvian/South African attorney/Secretary-General (SACR), dies at age 68.
James Clay, saxophonist, dies at age 59.
A chemical fire in an apartment complex in Manila, Philippines, leads to the discovery of plans for Project Bojinka, a mass-terrorist attack.
Murray Newton Rothbard, American economist, dies of cardiac arrest at age 69 (born 1926).
Larry Grayson, British entertainer (Generation Game), dies at age 71 (born 1923).
Viktor Vorobyov, Russian General Major, dies in battle.
Harry Golombek, chess Grandmaster, dies at age 83.
Arthur Leavins, violinist, dies at age 77.
Carlos Monzon [El Macho], Argentine middleweight boxing champion (1970-77), dies at age 52.
Louis "Loulou" GastT, guitarist/composer (Doggy in the Window), dies at age 88.
Mike Schmidt is elected to Baseball's Hall of Fame.
Joyce McCartan, peace campaigner, dies at age 68.
Ecuador and Peru are involved in a boundary fight.
Peter Cook, English comic/actor (Peter n' Dud, Bedazzled), dies at age 57 (born 1937).
Souphanouvong [Red Prince], President of Laos (1975-87), dies at age 85.
Valeri Poliakov completes 366 days in space while aboard the Mir space station, breaking a duration record.
Elaine Greene, literary agent, dies at age 74.
5th US TV network Warner Brothers begins (WPIX-TV in New York City, New York).
Willem N "Pim" Koot, pianist (Concert Building), dies at age 76.
Adrian J "Ad" Kaland, Dutch Member of Parliament (CDA 1977-93), dies at age 72.
Onat Kutlar, Turkish screenplay/producer (Hazal), murdered at age 59.
John AG Gere, English art historian (Raphael and his Circle), dies at age 73.
DC-9 crashes near Maria La Baya, Colombia: 51 die, 9-year-old girl lives.
Birmingham Barracudas granted Canadian Football League franchise.
NHL Players Association and team owners agree to end NHL strike.
The WB Television Network begins operations.
Major earthquake kills 5,092 in Kobe, Japan.
Marion Herbst, German/Dutch jewelry designer, dies at age 50.
Murder trial against OJ Simpson begins in Los Angeles, California.
Pope John Paul II begins visit to Southeast Asia.
Malcolm X's daughter, Qubilah Shabazz, is arrested for conspiring to kill Louis Farrakhan.
26 NHL teams unanimously ratify agreement to end NHL strike.
Arnold Smith, painter (Vigelius Prize 1935), dies at age 89.
Arthur Mervyn Stockwood, bishop, dies at age 81.
Ruby Starr, vocalist (Grey Ghost), dies of brain tumor at age 44.
Over 10,000 South Africans attend state funeral of Joe Slovo.
Stafford William Somerfield, newspaper editor, dies at age 84.
16th ACE Cable Awards: HBO wins 23 awards.
Mark Finch, film festival organizer, dies at age 33.
Alexander Gibson, British conductor/founder (Scottish Opera), dies at age 68.
San Francisco 49ers beat Dallas Cowboys for NFC championship.
San Diego Chargers beat Pittsburgh Steelers 17-13 for AFC championship.
Southern Alabama begins using new area code 334.
Western Washington begins using new area code 360.
Dawn Coe-Jones wins LPGA Chrysler-Plymouth Tournament of Golf Champion.
The first episode of Star Trek: Voyager airs.
An avalanche hits the village S??av?k in Iceland, killing 14 people.
William Dillard, trumpeter/singer, dies at age 83.
Isador Caplan, lawyer/Aldeburgh Festival pioneer, dies at age 82.

A magnitude 6.9 earthquake called the "Great Hanshin earthquake" occurs near Kobe, Japan. 5502 people killed, 36,896 injured, over 200,000 buildings damaged or destroyed. Over 90 percent of the casualties occurred along the southern coast of Honshu between Kobe and Nishinomiya.
Australia beats Australia A 2-0 to win the World Series Cup.
Los Angeles Rams announce that they are moving to Saint Louis, Missouri.
A magnitude 7.3 earthquake (known as "the Great Hanshin earthquake" hits near Kobe, Japan, causing extensive property damage and killing 6,433 people.
Pope John Paul II begins visit to Australia.
Adolf F J Butenandt, German bio-chemist (Nobel Prize for Chemistry 1939), dies at age 91 (born 1903) in Munich, Germany.
Charles Baskerville, vocalist, dies at age 54.
Kumble takes 16-99 in match for Karnataka versus Kerala.
Jean-Claude Juncker (28) sworn in as premier of Luxembourg.

In Colombia, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake occurs. Five people killed, several injured and at least 20 major buildings damaged in the Bogota area. Felt in much of Colombia and western Venezuela and as far as Caracas, Venezuela.
Eugene Fuller, polymath/linguist, dies at age 80.
Russian ruble drops to 3,947 per dollar (record).
Robert Shaw, town planner, dies at age 81.
Mehdi Bazargan, director Iranian oil corp/premier (1979), dies at age 86.
