Igor Hajek, translator/writer, dies at age 64.
Oklahoma City bombing: 168 people, including 8 Federal Marshals and 19 children, are killed at the Murrah Federal Building.
J[oseph] Peter Grace, CEO (W R Grace), dies at age 82.
Kenneth Burslam Gardner, librarian/Orientalist, dies at age 70.
King Herbert Whitaker, tenor sax, dies at age 66.
Oklahoma City bombing: The Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, USA, is bombed, killing 168.
R E S Wyatt, cricket player (England captain 16 times), dies.
Sunil Jayasinghe, Sri Lankan wicketkeeper (1979 World Cup), death by suicide.
Robert Elliott Storey Wyatt, cricket player, dies at age 93.
Boston Celtics final game at Boston Gardens, New York Knicks win 98-92.
In Samar, Philippine Islands, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs.
Stafford Heginbotham, toymaker/Football Club Chairman, dies at age 61.
FBI arrests Timothy McVeigh and charges him with Oklahoma City bombing.
General Tire World Bowling Tournament of Champions won by Mike Aulby.
George Foreman beats Axel Schulz in 12 rounds for heavyweight boxing title.
Don Pullen, pianist/composer, dies at age 53.
Maggie Kuhn, activist (Gray Panthers), dies at age 89.
Lonesome Sundown, blues singer/guitarist, dies at age 66.
Laura Davis wins LPGA Chick-fil-A Charity Golf Championship.
John Stennis, American politician (Senator-Democrat-Mississippi), dies at age 93.
Robert Selby Taylor, bishop, dies at age 86.
President Bill Clinton declares a national day of mourning for Oklahoma City bombing victims.
Package bomb, linked to Unabomber, blows up killing lobbyist Gilbert B Murray in Sacramento, California.
Dow Jones Industrial Average hits record 4303.98.
Douglas Gunsekera, banker, dies at age 77.
Francis Henry Smith, librarian, dies at age 85.
The 257-day Major League Baseball strike ends.
American baseball season begins after lengthy strike.
Coors Field opens in Denver; Colorado Rockies beat New York Mets 11-9 in 14 innings.
Sri Lankaan BAE748 plane crashes at Palaly, 52 die.
Peaches Roy Davis, baseball pitcher, dies at age 89.
Gas explosion in South Korean metro, 103 die.
Henry C Rogers, press agent, dies at age 81.
Andrew Salkey, author editor/broadcaster, dies at age 67.
Longest sausage ever, at 2877 miles, made in Kitchener, Ontario, Canada.
Kansas City Royals' player John Nonely is 70th to homerun on his first time at bat.
Robert Gibb, zoo/theme park creator, dies at age 57.
Val Skinner wins LPGA Sprint Golf Championship.
After 120 years the last 15 A&S department stores close.
Reinaldo de Carvalho, carnival king, dies at age 34.
Donald Edwin White, ad copywriter/opera administrator, dies at age 59.
U.S. President Bill Clinton became the first U.S. President to visit Northern Ireland.
Steve Waugh scores 200 for Australia versus West Indies at Sabina Park.
A fireball is seen in the sky over Australia.
Montreal Expos bat out of order against New York Mets in 6th inning.
Serb missiles explode in the heart of Zagreb, killing six.
David Bell debuts for the Cleveland Indians (third generation player, Gus and Buddy).
Australia beats West Indies to regain the Frank Worrell Cricket Trophy.
Lewis T Preston, banker, dies at age 68.
Louis Krasner, violinist, dies at age 91.
Esther Waterhouse, doctor/methodist, dies at age 86.
Bernard Benjamin Gillis, judge, dies at age 89.
James Pack, naval officer museum curator, dies at age 81.
Lionel Alexander Bethune [Alastair] Pilkington, engineer, dies at age 75.
Thomas Eden Binkley, musician, dies at age 63.
Mikhail Moseyevich Botvinnik, Russian world chess champion, dies (born 1911).
Last basketball game at Boston Gardens (Orlando Magic beats Boston Celtics).
Anthony Wagner, genealogist, dies at age 86.
Leanoard "Red" Truss, R&B singer, dies at age 47.
Classic Sports Network begins on cable TV.
ABC Bud Light Masters Bowling Tournament won by Mike Aulby.
121st Kentucky Derby: Gary Stevens on Thunder Gulch wins in 2:01.2.
Nicholas Palmer, TV writer/producer, dies at age 57.
Dona Maria Pia de Braganca, pretender to Portugal throne, dies at age 88.
Ernest H Martin, impressario, dies at age 75.
Maria Luisa Bemberg, film maker, dies at age 73.
Lawrence Josset, engraver, dies at age 84.
Jacques Chirac wins French presidential election.
Michelle McGann wins LPGA Sara Lee Golf Classic.
Ray McKinley, drummer, dies at age 84.
Minnesota Twins beat Cleveland Indians 10-9 in 17 innings, 6 hours and 36 minutes.
Teresa Teng, Taiwanese singer, dies at age 41 (born 1953).
Carroll Best, bluegrass banjo, dies at age 63.
Jerry Zipkin, socialite, dies at age 80.
Marshall Royal, jazz sax/clarinet, dies at age 82.
Kinshasa, Zaire under quarantine after an outbreak of Ebola virus.
Cleveland Indians tie record of scoring eight runs before making an out, they beat Minnesota Twins 10-0.
Percy Mansell, cricket player (355 runs in 13 Tests for South Africa), dies.
Charles Montgomery Monteith, publisher, dies at age 74.
Abha Gandhi, servant to Gandhi, dies at age 68.
Britain lifts a 23-year ban on ministerial talks with Sinn Fein.
Jimmy Raney, jazz guitarist, dies at age 67.
In South Africa, 104 miners are killed in an elevator accident.
Hilde Jarecki, educationist, dies at age 83.
30th Academy of Country Music Awards: Reba McEntire wins.
In New York City, more than 170 countries decide to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty indefinitely and without conditions.
David Avidan, poet/writer, dies at age 62.
In New York City, more than 170 countries decide to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty indefinitely and without conditions.
Giorgio Belladonna, bridge champion, dies at age 71.
Jose Mesa gets first of his Major League record 37 consecutive saves.
Martin Brodeur ties NHL record getting his third playoff shutout in four periods.
Reza Abdoh, theatre director, dies at age 32.
Dow Jones Industrial Average for fifth straight day of the week sets a new record (4430.59).
Chelsi Smith, 21, of USA, crowned 44th Miss Universe; Shanna Lynn Moakler, (age 19, Miss New York), replaces Chelsi Smith as Miss USA.
New Zealand beats US for the America's Cup.
An earthquake hits the regions of Kozani and Grevena in Greece, with an intensity of 6.6 on the Richter scale. 25 people injured, 12,000 homes damaged or destroyed. Damage estimate at US$450 million.
Cecil Marley, cricket player (WICBC president 1971-74, Jamaican captain 1946), dies.
Maezumi Hakuyu Taizan Koun, teacher (Zen Buddhism), dies at age 64.
Dalai Lama proclaims 6-year-old Gedhun Choekyi Nyima 11th reincarnation of Panchen Lama, Tibet's second most senior spiritual leader.
41st McDonald's LPGA Championship won by Kelly Robbins.
Eddie Murray of Cleveland Indians hits his 463rd career homerun (ties for 18th).
Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama, proclaims six-year-old Gedhun Choekyi Nyima as the eleventh reincarnation of the Panchen Lama.
Perry Lederman, folk singer, dies at age 52.
Johnny Van Derrick, jazz violinist, dies at age 68.
People's Republic of China performs nuclear test at Lop Nor.
Japanese police arrest cult leader Shoko Asahara and charged him with nerve-gas attack on Tokyo's subways two months earlier.
Jacques Chirac assumes the presidency of France.
Lola Flores, singer/actress (Kuma Ching, Faraona), dies at age 70.
In Loyalty Islands region of the south Pacific, a magnitude 7.7 earthquake occurs.
Shawn Nelson, 35, goes on a tank rampage in San Diego, California.
After 18 years as the mayor of Paris, Jacques Chirac takes office as President of France.
Disney announces it is buying 25 percent of the California Angels baseball team.
Gordon Reynolds, musician, dies at age 74.
WIBC Bowling Queens won by Sandra Postma.
Alain JuppT becomes Prime Minister of France.
World's youngest doctor, Balamurali Ambati, 17, graduates Mount Sinai.
CBS News fires co-anchor Connie Chung.
Minnesota Twins Marty Cordova ties rookie record of homeruns in five consecutive games.
Everton FC beats Manchester United 1-0 to win the FA Cup.
121st Preakness: Pat Day aboard Timber Coutry wins in 1:54.4.
Disney Cruise Line announces Cantieri Navali Italiani S.p.A. of Italy is awarded the contract to build the first Disney cruise ship.
In a second Referendum in Quebec, the population rejects by a slight majority the proposal from its government to move towards independence from Canada.
Les Aspin, US Secretary of Defense (1993-95), dies of stroke at age 56.
Patrick Bowles, writer/translator, dies at age 68.
Chris Johnson wins Star Bank LPGA Golf Classic.
Kieron Walsh, academic, dies at age 46.
Pope John Paul II canonizes John Sarkander during his visit to Olomouc, the Czech Republic.
In Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, the remains of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building are imploded.
At the Sun World conference in San Francisco, California, Sun Microsystems introduces the Java interactive programming language. Code-name during development was Oak.
Oklahoma City bombing: In Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, what remains of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building is imploded.
AFC Ajax beats AC Milan 1-0 to win the Champions League.
Mike Pyne, jazz pianist, dies at age 54.
Harold Wilson, British Prime Minister (1964-70, 1974-76), dies of cancer at age 79 (born 1916).
The Quebec Nordiques (NHL) are sold and move to Denver, Colorado.
Dick Curless, singer/songwriter, dies at age 63.
The Supreme Court of Canada rules that sexual orientation is a prohibited grounds of discrimination under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
The Bosnian Serb Army kills 72 youngsters in the Bosnian city of Tuzla.

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates issues an internal memo "The Internet Tidal Wave", saying he believes the Internet to be the single most important development in the computer industry since the IBM Personal Computer. He gives the highest level of importance to the Internet, calling it "critical to every part of our business".
Ron Weatherburn, jazz pianist, dies at age 61.
Isadore "Friz" Freling, cartoon director (Sylvester), dies at age 88 (born 1905).
Severn Darden, comedian (Second City), dies at age 65.
Teresa Heinz marries U.S. Senator John Kerry in Nantucket, Massachusetts.
C W Stubblefield, music promoter, dies at age 64.
On Sakhalin Island, a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurs. About 1,989 people killed, about 750 injured.
In Culpeper, Virginia, actor Christopher Reeve is paralyzed from the neck down after falling from his horse in a riding competition.
In Charlottesville, Virginia, actor Christopher Reeve is paralyzed from the neck down after falling from his horse in a riding competition.
Dottie Mochrie wins J C Penney/LPGA Skins Golf Game.
Alison Nichols wins LPGA Corning Golf Classic.
Jean Elizabeth Leuckert Muir, British designer dressmaker/model, dies at age 66.
Neftegorsk, Russia is hit by a 7.6 magnitude earthquake, killing at least 2000 people (two-thirds of the town's population).
Chicago White Sox (5) and Detroit Tigers (7) combine for record 12 homeruns at Tiger Stadium.
In Indianapolis, Indiana, the 79th Indianapolis 500 race is held. A 1995 Corvette performs the role of Official Pace Car, driven by Jim Perkins.
The Russian town of Neftegorsk is hit by a 7.6 magnitude earthquake that kills at least 2,000 people, 2/3 of total population.
Margaret Chase Smith, US Representative and Senator (Republican-Maine), dies at age 97.
Ted Drake, English soccer star, dies at age 82 (born 1912).
Bobby Stokes, soccer star, dies at age 44.
Thomas Dorrington Tomlinson, British national park warden, dies at age 87.
Philip Owen A Sherrard, scholar theologian poet/translator, dies at age 72.
Tim Mara, owner (New York Giants), dies at age 59.
SS Captain Erich Priebke is extradited from Argentina to Italy.
United States Air Force Captain Scott O'Grady's F-16 is shot down over Bosnia while patrolling the NATO no-fly zone.
The Bose-Einstein condensate is first created, an extremely low-temperature fluid which contains properties and exhibits behaviors that are currently not completely understood.
Downed U.S. Air Force pilot Captain Scott O'Grady is rescued by U.S. Marines in Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Downed U.S. Air Force pilot Captain Scott O'Grady is rescued by U.S. Marines in Bosnia.
French President Jacques Chirac announces the resumption of nuclear tests in French Polynesia.
French president Jacques Chirac announces the resumption of nuclear tests in French Polynesia.
A powerful earthquake, registering a magnitude of 6.5, hits the city of Egion, Greece, resulting in 26 deaths and significant damage to many buildings. Estimate of damage at US$660 million.
Salt Lake City, Utah, is selected as host city for the 2002 Winter Olympics.

The Walt Disney Company announces plans for a fourth theme park in Florida: Disney's Animal Kingdom. The new park is expected to cost US$760 million to create, over a 200-hectare area. It is due to open in 1998.
Oil multinational Royal Dutch Shell caves in to international pressure and abandons plans to dump the Brent Spar oil rig at sea. The platform will be towed to Norway for dismantling on land.
Japanese police rescue 365 hostages from a hijacked Nippon Airlines 747 at Hakodate airport. The hijacker was armed with a knife and demanded the release of Shoko Asahara.
(to July 7) 5,000,000 view Christo's "wrapped" Reichstag in Berlin.
The New Jersey Devils sweep the heavily favored Detroit Red Wings to win their first Stanley Cup in the lock-out shortened season.
The New Jersey Devils win their first Stanley Cup by sweeping the Detroit Red Wings.
Lisa Clayton completes her 10-month solo circumnavigation from the Northern Hemisphere.
The Sampoong Department Store collapses in the Seocho-gu district of Seoul, South Korea, killing 501 and injuring 937.
Space Shuttle program: STS-71 Mission (Atlantis docks with the Russian space station Mir for the first time.)
The Sampoong Department Store collapses in the Seocho-gu district of Seoul, South Korea, killing 501 and injuring 937.
The German Bundestag votes to send German troops to Bosnia as a part of the international peace keeping mission.
In response to UNSCOM's evidence, Iraq admits for first time the existence of an offensive biological weapons program, but denies weaponization.
United Kingdom Prime Minister John Major wins his battle to remain leader of the Conservative Party.

The U.S. Congress passes the Child Protection and Obscenity Enforcement Act, requiring that producers of pornography keep records of all models who are filmed or photographed. This act also requires that all models be at least 18 years of age.
IBM completes its US$3.5 billion acquisition of Lotus Development, making it a wholly-owned subsidiary.
A volcanic eruption begins on the island of Montserrat.
Musical group The Grateful Dead perform the last concert of their 30-year career at Soldier Field, Chicago, Illinois.
Burmese dissident Aung San Suu Kyi is freed from house arrest.
In the Myanmar-China border region, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. Six people killed, 99 injured, more than 100,000 houses destroyed and 42,000 damaged.
Bosnian Serbs march into Srebrenica while United Nations Dutch peacekeepers leave. Large numbers of Bosniak men and boys are killed in the Srebrenica massacre.
A Cubana de Aviacion Antonov An-24 crashes into the Caribbean off southeast Cuba killing 44 people.

Srebrenica Genocide: Serb army from Yugoslavia and Bosnia, capture the Bosniak town of Srebrenica. More than eight thousands inhabitants are murdered. It is generally regarded to be the most horrific event in recent European history.
Full diplomatic relations are established between the United States and Vietnam.
Dozens of cities in the USA, most notably Chicago and Milwaukee, set all-time record high temperatures. Hundreds of people in these and other cities die as the heat wave reaches its peak.
French President Jacques Chirac make a speech, formally apologizing for French involvement in the deportation of Jews during World War II.
The Nasdaq Composite stock market index closes above the 1,000 mark for the first time.
The Nasdaq stock index closes above the 1,000 mark for the first time.

The Midwestern heat wave in the United States reaches its peak. Chicago, Illinois and Milwaukee, Wisconsin, among other cities, set all-time high temperature records. The heat claims over 400 lives on this day alone.

On the Caribbean island of Montserrat, the Soufriere Hills volcano erupts. Over the course of several years, it devastates the island, destroying the capital and forcing most of the population to flee.
The Regents of the University of California vote to end all affirmative action in the UC system by 1997.
In Gansu, China, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake occurs. Fourteen people killed, at least 60 injured, 5,000 left homeless, 4,500 houses destroyed and 5,000 houses damaged in the Yongdeng area.
(to July 26) The People's Liberation Army of the People's Republic of China fires missiles into the waters north of Taiwan.
Third Taiwan Strait Crisis: The People's Liberation Army begins firing missiles into the waters north of Taiwan.
David Daliberti and William Barloon, two Americans held as spies by Iraq, are released by Saddam Hussein.
a gas bottle exploded in station Saint Michel of line B of the RER (Paris regional train network). 8 were killed and 80 wounded.
In Washington, DC, the Korean War Veterans Memorial is dedicated.
Disney agrees to buy Capital Cities / ABC for one Disney share plus US$65 cash per ABC share. Total value of the deal is about US$20 billion.
In Washington, DC, the Korean War Veterans Memorial is dedicated.
Alberto Fujimori becomes Constitutional President of the Republic of Peru for a second time.

Near the coast of Northern Chile, a magnitude 8.0 earthquake occurs. Three people were killed, 58 injured, 630 left homeless and 115 houses destroyed. Also felt in southern Peru and at La Paz, Bolivia. Mild tsunami generated, measured at Hawaii, Alaska, Japan.
Croatian forces launch Operation Storm against Serbian forces in Krajina, with the cooperation of the ARBiH, and force them to withdraw to central Bosnia.
Croatian forces take Knin and continue to advance.
The city of Knin, a significant Serb stronghold, is liberated by Croatian forces during Operation Storm. The date is celebrated as the day of victory ("Homeland Thanksgiving Day") in Croatia.
Operation Storm ends with a United Nations-brokered ceasefire; remaining Serbian forces start surrendering.
Operation Storm is officially declared over in Croatia, resulting in total Croat victory over rebel Serb forces.
Jerry Garcia, famed guitarist of The Grateful Dead dies from an overdose of heroin while in rehab.

Shares of Netscape Communications are first made available to the public on the NASDAQ stock exchange. Before trading, shares are priced at US$28. The stock opens at US$71, reaching a high of US$74.75. The market value of the company becomes US$2.2 billion. This is the best opening day for a stock in Wall Street history for an issue of its size.
Netscape launches IPO. Jerry Garcia, founding member and lead guitarist for Grateful Dead succumbs due to heart failure induced by sleep apnea at Serenity Knolls in Forest Hills, California.
Oklahoma City bombing: Timothy McVeigh and Terry Nichols are indicted for the bombing. Michael Fortier pleads guilty in a plea-bargain agreement for his testimony.
Russell Hill subway accident kills three people in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

Michael Ovitz is appointed president of the Walt Disney Company. His contract is for five years, with base salary US$1 million per year, and options to purchase 5 million shares of the Disney company.
An avalanche buries Alison Hargreaves, climbing Mount Everest without oxygen tank; she is reported dead.
In South Carolina, Shannon Faulkner becomes the first female cadet matriculated at The Citadel, but drops out in less than a week.

US District Court Judge Thomas Jackson holds the first and only hearing on the consent decree between Microsoft and the US Department of Justice. Within 17 minutes, he signs his approval of it. The decree will govern Microsoft's licensing practices of Windows for the next 6.5 years, barring the company from linking unrelated software licenses. The ruling comes after five years of investigation of monopolistic licensing practices.
Windows 95, a computer operating system by Microsoft, is released with much fanfare.
The International Rugby Board lifts all restrictions on payments relating to the game of Rugby Union, thus bringing the game's amateur age to an end.
A Serbian Mortar bomb near a Sarajevo market square kills 37 civilians.
A mortar shell kills 38 people in Sarajevo, Bosnia.
NATO launches Operation Deliberate Force against Bosnian Serb forces.

The NATO bombing campaign against Serb artillery positions begins in Bosnia, continuing into October. At the same time ARBiH forces begin an offensive against the Serb Army around Sarajevo, central Bosnia and Bosnian Krajina.
The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame opens in Cleveland, Ohio.
Frank Bruno wins the WBC World Heavyweight Title from Oliver McCall at Wembley Stadium.
Online auction company eBay is founded.
The Fourth World Conference on Women opens in Beijing with over 4,750 delegates from 181 countries in attendance.
The Fourth World Conference on Women opens in Beijing with over 4,750 delegates from 181 countries in attendance.
Cal Ripken Jr of the Baltimore Orioles breaks the all time consecutive games played record in Major League Baseball with his 2131st game.
NATO air strikes continue, after repeated attempts at a solution with the Serbs fail.
Cal Ripken Jr. breaks Lou Gehrig 's record of 2,130 consecutive Major League Baseball games played at Camden Yards in Baltimore,Maryland.
With the jury absent, Los Angeles police detective Mark Fuhrman invokes his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination in the murder trial of O. J. Simpson.
Sony Electronics introduces the 32-bit CD-ROM game system, PlayStation, in North America. Price is US$299.
Sony's PlayStation game console was released in the US.
Kids WB! debuted on The WB.
Near the coast of Guerrero, Mexico, a magnitude 7.5 earthquake occurs. Three people killed, 100 injured, 900 homeless. Felt strongly along the Pacific coast of Mexico from Michoacan to Chiapas.
The Washington Post and The New York Times publish the Unabomber's manifesto.
The Hindu milk miracle occurs, in which statues of the Hindu god Ganesh began drinking milk when spoonfuls were placed near their mouths.
American millionaire Steve Forbes announces his candidacy for the 1996 Republican presidential nomination.

Argentine national Guillermo "Bill" Gaede is arrested in Phoenix, Arizona on charges of industrial espionage. His sales to Cuba, China, North Korea and Iran are believed to have involved Intel and Advanced Micro Devices trade secrets worth US$10-20 million.
The trial against former Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, accused of Mafia connections, begins.
(to September 28) Bob Denard's mercenaries capture President Said Mohammed Djohor of the Comoros; the local army does not resist.
The Government of the United States unveils the first of its redesigned bank notes with the $100 bill featuring a larger portrait of Benjamin Franklin slightly off-center.
Bob Denard and a group of mercenaries take the islands of Comoros in a coup.
Ten people are convicted of bombing the World Trade Center in 1993.
The Disney Channel U.K. begins television broadcasting in the British Isles, as a subscription-only channel.

In Turkey, a magnitude 6.3 earthquake occurs. One hundred one people killed, 348 injured, 50,000 homeless and 4,500 houses and buildings damaged or destroyed in the Dinar area. About 600 buildings were destroyed at Evciler.
O.J. Simpson is found not guilty of double murder for the deaths of former wife Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman.
O. J. Simpson found not guilty of murder.
Hurricane Opal makes landfall at Pensacola Beach, Florida as a Category 3 hurricane with 115 mph winds.
France launches a counter-coup in the Comoros with 600 soldiers. They arrest Bob Denard and his mercenaries and take Denard to France. Caabi el-Yachroutu becomes the new interim president.
Crash Morgan, drummer for Big Sugar, dies while performing in Waterloo, Iowa, USA at age 36.
Michael Mayor and Didier Queloz announce the discovery of 51 Pegasi b, the first confirmed Extrasolar planet.
In Southern Sumatera, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. Eighty-four people killed, 2,178 injured, nearly 65,000 homeless and over 18,900 homes and buildings damaged or destroyed in Jambi Province.
51 Pegasi, in the constellation of Pegasus, 47.9 light-years away from Earth, was discovered to be the first major star apart from the Sun to have a planet (and extrasolar planet) orbiting around it.

Near the coast of Jalisco, Mexico, a magnitude 8.0 earthquake occurs. At least 49 people killed, 100 injured, nearly 1,000 homeless and extensive damage in the states of Colima and Jalisco. Felt by people in high-rise buildings as far as Dallas and Houston, Texas and Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.
An Amtrak Sunset Limited train is derailed by saboteurs near Palo Verde, Arizona.
An Amtrak Sunset Limited train is derailed by saboteurs near Palo Verde, Arizona.
Walt Disney World in Florida welcomes its 500-millionth guest.
The Carolina Panthers win their first-ever regular season game by defeating the New York Jets at Clemson Memorial Stadium in South Carolina.
Saddam Hussein gains 99.96% of votes in Iraq's presidential elections.
The Carolina Panthers win their first-ever regular season game by defeating the New York Jets at Clemson Memorial Stadium in South Carolina.
The Million Man March is held in Washington, D.C. The event was conceived by Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan.
The Million Man March occurs in Washington, DC.

In Houston, Texas, Yolanda Saldivar is convicted of first degree murder in the shooting death of Selena Quintanilla Perez and three days later is sentenced to life in prison. Saldivar will be eligible for parole in 2025.
A total solar eclipse is visible from Iran, India, Thailand, and Southeast Asia.
A Metra commuter train slams into a school bus in Fox River Grove, Illinois, killing seven students.
A commuter train slams into a school bus in Fox River Grove, Illinois, killing seven students.
An avalanche hits the village Flateyri in Iceland, killing 20 people.
Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Mossad agents assassinate Islamic Jihad leader Fathi Shikaki in his hotel in Malta.
Latvia applies for membership in the European Union.
The Atlanta Braves defeat the Cleveland Indians to win the World Series.
Fire breaks out on a crowded metro train in Baku, Azerbaijan killing more than 300 passengers. This is the world's worst metro disaster.
Quebec separatists narrowly lose a referendum for a mandate to negotiate independence from Canada.
Quebec sovereignists narrowly lose a referendum for a mandate to negotiate independence from Canada (vote was 50.6% to 49.4%).
Intel formally announces and begins shipping the Pentium Pro processor, at speeds of 150 to 200 MHz. The processor incorporates 5.5 million transistors. Prices range from US$974 to $1989.
The U.S. House of Representatives votes to ban "partial birth" abortions by a vote of 288-139.
Participants in the Yugoslav War begin negotiations in Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio.
The Supreme Court of Argentina orders the extradition of Erich Priebke, ex-German SS captain.
At Arlington National Cemetery, U.S. President Bill Clinton dedicates a memorial to the victims of the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing.
Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin is assassinated at a peace rally in Tel Aviv.
Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin assassinated by an extreme right-wing Israeli.

Daniel McLain (aka Country Dick Montana) of the underground rock band The Beat Farmers, dies on stage of a heart attack during a performance at the Longhorn Saloon in Whistler, British Columbia, Canada.
Bill Watterson announsed his retirement in a brief letter to newspaper editors.
With help from Israel and Jordan, United Nations inspector Ritter intercepts 240 Russian gyroscopes and accelerometers on their way to Iraq from Russia.

In Nigeria, playwright and environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa, along with eight others from the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop), are hanged by government forces. This leads to a global boycott of Shell for its oil exploration on Ogoni land.
In Nigeria, playwright and environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa along with eight others from the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop) are hanged by government forces.
In New Orleans, Louisiana, USA, the casino venture files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

A budget standoff between Democrats and Republicans in the Congress of the United States forces the federal government to temporarily close national parks and museums, and run most government offices with skeleton staff.

A budget standoff between Democrats and Republicans in the U.S. Congress forces the federal government to temporarily close national parks and museums and to run most government offices with skeleton staffs.
A United Nations tribunal charges Radovan Karad?ic and Ratko Mladic with genocide during the Bosnian War.
Sergei Grinkov, Soviet ice skater (Olympic Gold 1988, 1994) dies (heart attack) at age 28.
A peace agreement for Bosnia is reached.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 5,000 (5,023.55) for the first time.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 5,000 (5,023.55) for the first time.

The Dayton Peace Agreement was initialled in the Wright Patterson Air Force Base, near Dayton, Ohio, ending three and a half years of war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The agreement was formally ratified in Paris, on December 14 that same year.
Toy Story is released as the first feature-length film created completely using computer-generated imagery.
In Egypt, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs. At least eight people killed and 30 injured in the epicentral region. Felt from Sudan to Lebanon.

Rosemary West is sentenced to life for killing ten women and girls, including her own daughter and stepdaughter, after the jury returns a guilty verdict at Winchester Crown Court. The trial judge recommends that she should never be released from prison, making her only the second woman in British legal history to be subjected to a whole life tariff.
Colin McRae becomes the first ever Scottish world rally champion.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a highway bill that ends the federal 55 mph speed limit.
The Barcelona Treaty is signed by 27 attending nations.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a highway bill that ends the federal 55 mph speed limit.
Charlie Smith, American baseball player, dies at age 57.
Official end of Operation Desert Storm.
Javier Solana becomes the new NATO General Secretary.

First recorded educational Virtual field trip. The audioconference live from Antarctica involved interaction between two teachers and two schools in Canterbury, New Zealand (LEARNZ 1995). Schools from all over New Zealand listen in on the audioconference.
[William] Robertson Davies, Canadian novelist essayist/dramatist, dies (born 1913).
Francis Joseph Quinn, academic, dies at age 90.
84th Davis Cup: USA beats Russia in Moscow (3-2).
Jack Russell takes 11 catches in Test Cricket versus South Africa, a record.
Naeem Akhtar takes 10-28 for Rawalpindi B against Peshawar.
Robertson Davies, author, dies at age 82.
Beth Daniels/Davis Love III win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
Itzhak Rabin, Prime Minister of Israel (1968-73), is assassinated.
Atherton (185) bats for 643 minutes to save Johannesburg Test.
Robert Charles Evans, mountaineer/doctor, dies at age 77.
Dmitri Antonovitch Volkogonov, soldier/historian, dies at age 67.
Tom Burns, editor, dies at age 89.
NBA settles strike of referees, referees to return on December 12.
US NASA space probe Galileo arrives at Jupiter, a little more than six years after it was launched by Space Shuttle Atlantis.
The Galileo spacecraft arrives at Jupiter, a little more than six years after it was launched by Space Shuttle Atlantis during Mission STS-34.
Ernest LeRoy Boyer, educator, dies at age 67.

Heavy rains kill more than 80 campers near Huesca, Spain.
The British rock band Oasis plays the biggest free-standing concert in United Kingdom history at Knebworth, Hertfordshire.
Marc Dutroux, his wife Michelle Martin, and Michel Lelièvre are arrested on suspicion of kidnapping. All are found guilty on June 22, 2004, with sentences of life, 30, and 25 years, respectively.
Bob Dole is nominated for President of the USA, and Jack Kemp for Vice President, at the Republican National Convention in San Diego, California.
Osama bin Laden allegedly writes "The Declaration of Jihad on the Americans Occupying the Country of the Two Sacred Places," his first open call for war.
Osama bin Laden issues message entitled 'A declaration of war against the Americans occupying the land of the two holy places'
Their Royal Highnesses, the Prince and Princess of Wales, are formally divorced at the High Court of Justice in London. Her Royal Highness The Princess of Wales is restyled Diana, Princess of Wales.
Britain's Charles, Prince of Wales, and Diana, Princess of Wales, are divorced.
U.S. President Bill Clinton and Vice President Al Gore are re-nominated at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, Illinois.
Vnukovo Airlines Flight 2801, a Vnukovo Airlines Tupolev Tu-154 crashes into a mountain on the Arctic island of Spitsbergen, killing all 141 aboard.
Iraqi forces launch an offensive into the northern No-Fly Zone and capture Arbil.
The Big 12 Conference is inaugurated with a football game between Kansas State University and Texas Tech University in Manhattan, Kansas.

The Fitzroy Football Club (established 1883) plays its last game ever in the Australian Football League, against Fremantle at Subiaco Oval. The following season the club merges with the Brisbane Bears, ending a long history of the club in the VFL/AFL.
A permanent peace agreement is signed at the Malacaang Palace between the Government of the Philippines and the Moro National Liberation Front.
A peace agreement is signed between the Government of the Republic of the Philippines and the Moro National Liberation Front in Malacañang Palace.
Nintendo releases the Game Boy Pocket portable game system in the USA.
The U.S. launches Operation Desert Strike against Iraq in reaction to the attack on Arbil.
The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia attack a military base in Guaviare, Colombia, starting three weeks of guerrilla warfare that will claim the lives of at least 130 Colombians.
War on Drugs: Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces (FARC) attack a military base in Guaviare, starting three weeks of guerrilla warfare that will claim the lives of at least 130 Colombians.
Rap legend Tupac Shakur is shot in Las Vegas, Nevada, following the Mike Tyson bout; he dies on September 13.
In Las Vegas, Nevada, actor and recording artist Tupac Shakur is shot several times after attending a boxing match, he dies six days later.
Austrian inventor and automotive pioneer Hans List, founder of AVL List, dies
Union Pacific Railroad purchases Southern Pacific Railroad.
Union Pacific Railroad purchases Southern Pacific Railroad
Okinawans vote to have the USA remove its 28,000 troops stationed on their island.
The scoreboard at the HSBC Arena in Buffalo, New York, falls to the ice just hours before a National Hockey League game; no one is injured.
The Panhellenic Socialist Movement under the leadership of Costas Simitis succeeds in the 1996 Greek legislative election.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty at the United Nations.

IBM launches OS/2 Warp 4, in San Francisco, California. New features include Java technology, voice recognition software, and Open32 Win32 APIs. Price is US$249; upgrade is US$149. It is the first operating system to include built-in speech navigation and recognition.
The last of the Magdalen Asylums is closed in Ireland.
The last of the Magdalen Asylums was closed in Ireland.

In Pretoria, South Africa, the Truth and Reconciliation panel holds hearings before the Supreme Court. Secret Service Colonel Eugene de Kock, former head of Operation Long Reach, testifies that his office planned the Olof Palme killing, and that Craig Williamson coordinated the assassination.
In Afghanistan, the Taliban capture the capital city of Kabul, after driving out President Burhanuddin Rabbani and executing former leader Mohammad Najibullah.
In Afghanistan, the Taliban capture the capital city Kabul after driving out President Burhanuddin Rabbani and executing former leader Mohammad Najibullah.

Jockey Frankie Dettori finishes first for the seventh time of the day at Ascot racetrack on racehorse Fujiyama Crest, making racing history. Darren Yates, on a bet of 67.58 pounds, wins 550,823.54 pounds. The William Hill betting agency loses 8 million pounds; total payout on this win is 40 million pounds.
Nintendo released the Nintendo 64 in North America.
The former prime minister of Bulgaria, Andrei Lukanov, is assassinated.
The Electronic Freedom of Information Act Amendments are signed by U.S. President Bill Clinton.
The Electronic Freedom of Information Act Amendments are signed by U.S. President Bill Clinton.
An AeroPer Boeing 757 crashes in Pacific Ocean shortly after takeoff from Lima, Peru killing 70.
American singers Faith Hill and Tim McGraw married after touring on their Spontaneous Combustion Tour.
The Fox News Channel, an American cable news network, is launched.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 40.62 to close at 6,010.00, the Dow's first close above 6,000.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 40.62 to 6,010.00, closing above 6,000 for the first time ever.
84 are killed and more than 180 injured as 47,000 soccer fans attempt to squeeze into the 36,000-seat Mateo Flores Stadium in Guatemala City.
The O.J. Simpson civil trial begins in Santa Monica, California.
The civil trial of former American football player O.J. Simpson opens in Santa Monica, California.

The New York Yankees win their 23rd World Series (first since 1978) with a 3-2 victory over the defending World champs Atlanta Braves in Game 6. John Wetteland is named Most Valuable Player of the series.
On his 5,144th day in office Helmut Kohl surpasses Konrad Adenauer's record as the longest serving post-war chancellor of Germany.
Fighting erupts when Banyamulenga Tutsis of Laurent Kabila in Zaire seize Uvira and proceed to kill Hutu refugees.
Jean ChrTtien becomes UN special envoy to the African Great Lakes.
A Brazilian TAM Fokker F100 crashes into several houses in São Paulo, Brazil killing 98 including 2 on the ground.
U.S. presidential election: Democrat incumbent Bill Clinton defeats Republican challenger Bob Dole to win his second term.
U.S. presidential election, 1996: Democrat incumbent Bill Clinton defeats Republican challenger Bob Dole to win his second term.
The family of Eduardo Quihua Maquixtle from Vicente Guerrero, Mexico, including his four children, are stabbed by three men accusing them of witchcraft.
NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.
A devastating Category 4 cyclone strikes Andhra Pradesh, India. The storm surge sweeps fishing villages out to sea, killing over 2,000 people. 95 percent of crops are completely destroyed.
NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.
A Nigerian Boeing 727 crashes into a lagoon 40 miles southeast of Lagos, killing 143.
In Znrich, Switzerland, a Swedish 1885 yellow 3 Skilling Banco postage stamp sells for a world record $2.3 million.
Rapper Yaki Kadafi, born Yafeu Fula, is shot to death in New Jersey at the age of 19.
Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 has a mid-air collision with Kazakhstan Airlines Il-76, resulting in the loss of 349 lives.
Near the coast of Peru, a magnitude 7.7 earthquake occurs. At least 14 people killed, 560 injured and 12,000 homeless.
A Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and a Kazakh Ilyushin Il-76 cargo plane collide in mid-air near New Delhi, India killing 349.
Mother Teresa receives honorary U.S. citizenship.
Mother Teresa receives honorary US citizenship.
The $127.5 million Jumbotron at Buffalo's HSBC Arena falls to the ice hours before a hockey game; no one is injured.
World-renowned bird expert Tony Silva is sentenced to seven years in prison without parole for leading an illegal parrot smuggling ring.
Martyn Bryant is sentenced to life imprisonment, two weeks after confessing to murdering 35 people in Tasmania earlier this year.
A fire occurs in the Channel Tunnel soon after it opens.
Albert Belle signs a record five-year, $55 million deal with the Chicago White Sox.
A propane explosion at the Humberto Vidal shoe store and office building in San Juan, Puerto Rico kills 33.
The Republic of Angola officially joins the World Trade Organization, as Angola.
The Republic of Angola officially joins the World Trade Organization.
Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 is hijacked, then crashes into the Indian Ocean off the coast of Comoros after running out of fuel, killing 123.

The Toronto Argonauts defeat the Edmonton Eskimos 43-37 to win the 84th Grey Cup at Ivor Wynne Stadium in Hamilton, Ontario. The game is notable for the heavy snowfall that took place, resulting in the game being dubbed "The Snow Bowl".
Rusty Wallace wins the Suzuka NASCAR Thunder 100 racing event at Suzuka Circuitland in Suzuka City (this was the first NASCAR competition held in Japan).
Crowded House play a farewell concert in front of the Sydney Opera House for an estimated crowd of 250,000.
An ice storm strikes the U.S., killing 26 directly, hundreds more from accidents. A powerful windstorm blasts Florida; winds gust to 90 mph.
The Main Street Electrical Parade at Disneyland gives its final performance. The parade made over 3500 trips, to an estimated 75 million guests.
An Ice storm strikes the central U.S. killing 26 people. Powerful windstorm affects Florida, winds gust over 90 mph, toppling trees and flipping trailers.
Near San Luis, Santa Barbara, Honduras, a meteorite slams into a sparsely populated area, leaving a 165-foot-wide crater.
Herbert Khaury (aka "Tiny Tim") dies of a heart attack at age 64 while performing "Tiptoe Through The Tulips" at a Minneapolis fund raiser.
Lance Klusener takes 8-64 in debut Test Cricket to trounce India.
Colin Montgomerie of Scotland wins Million Dollar Challenge, the richest first prize in golf - $1 million.
85th Davis Cup: France beats Sweden in Malmo (3-2).
In Kyushu, Japan, a magnitude 6.7 earthquake occurs.
Penelope Jessel, politcal activist, dies at age 76.

Det Glynn, teacher/anti-apartheid activist, dies at age 84.

Basil Nield, judge/politician, dies at age 83.
The Orlando Magic team ties the NBA record of fewest points scored since inception of 24 second clockm losing to Cleveland Cavalier, 84-57.
NASA's first Mars rover launched from Cape Canaveral.
The A-Bomb Dome in Hiroshima, Japan, is named a World Heritage site. The dome and main structure of the Hiroshima Promotion Hall survived the atomic bomb blast of 1945.
Wilf Carter, country singer, dies at age 91.
Portland's Jermaine O'Neal, 18, becomes youngest NBA player.
Peter Hall, folklorist/musician, dies at age 60.
Mashonaland defeats England in first-class tour match.
[Alvin] Pete Rozelle, American commissioner (NFL), dies at age 70 (born 1926).

Eugene Izzi, mystery writer, hangs himself at age 43.
Donna Andrews and Mike Hulbert win LPGA J C Penney Golf Classic.
Marin Sorescu, poet/dramatist, dies at age 60.

Faron Young, country singer, commits suicide at age 64.

John Duffey, bluegrass musician, dies at age 62.

Rwandan Genocide: Military Advisor to the United Nations Secretary-General and head of the Military Division of the Department of Peacekeeping Operations of the United Nations Maurice Baril recommends that the UN multi-national forces in Zaire stand down.
W G G Duncan-Smith, fighter pilot, dies at age 82.
William George Rushton, English actor (TW3)/author/cartoonist, dies at age 59 (born 1937).

Uday Hussein, son of Iraq's Saddam Hussein, is seriously injured in an assassination attempt.

Disney announces the resignation of Michael Ovitz as president of the Walt Disney Company. His total compensation package totals US$140 million.

Florida Marlins sign their 6th free-agent since November 22, Moises Alou.

In Bonn, Germany, the Swiss National Bank publicly acknowledges that it had profited from wartime dealings in gold bullion with the German central bank, but that there is no evidence that the gold was stolen from Holocaust victims, and no gold in Swiss possession bears German stamps. Total value of wartime gold transactions was 1.2 million Swiss francs, with profit of about 20 million francs.
Kofi Annan is elected as Secretary-General of the United Nations.
62nd Heisman Trophy Award: Danny Wuerffel, Florida (quarterback).

At the Sandia National Laboratory in Albuquerque, New Mexico, the "Option Red" supercomputer is started up, performing one trillion floating-point operations per second, making it the fastest computer in the world. The US$55 million computer uses 9072 Intel Pentium Pro processors with 600 GB memory and 2 terabyte disc storage.
Elizabeth Hill, teacher of Slavonic languages, dies at age 96.
The T?pac Amaru Revolutionary Movement takes 72 hostages in the Japanese Embassy in Lima, Peru.
Stanko Todorov, Prime Minister of Bulgaria (1971-81), dies.

The Oakland, California school board passes a resolution officially declaring "Ebonics" a language or dialect.
Yuli Borisovich Khariton, scientist, dies at age 82.
Amata Kabua, President of Marshall Islands (1979-96), dies.

Apple Computer announces it will buy the NeXT Software company for about US$400 million in cash and Apple stock. NeXT Software CEO Steve Jobs will become an advisor to Apple chairman and CEO Gilbert Amelio.

German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and Czech Foreign Minister Josef Zieleniec meet in Prague, and initial a document in which German appologizes for Adolf Hitler's invasion of Czechoslovakia, and the Czech Republic expresses regret for the postwar expulsion of Germans from the Sudetenland.
NeXT merges with Apple Computer, starting the path to Mac OS X.
Pakistan all out 67 to lose to Tasmania by an inning.

Four women ordained priests in Jamaica, first in 330-year Anglican history.

India all out for 66 at Durban after making 100 in cricket first inning.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway is merged with the Burlington Northern Railroad to form the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway, making it one of the largest railroad mergers in U.S. history.
The Republic of Za? officially joins the World Trade Organization, as Za?.
Graham Kersey, cricket wicket keeper, dies in car crash.

In Detroit, Michigan, the North American International Auto Show is held, over ten days. Chevrolet unveils the 1997 Corvette, dubbed "C5". A new small-block V-8 engine is introduced, the LS1, with 345-hp, and 10:1 compression ratio.
Litz Pisk, movement teacher, dies at age 87.
Desmond Flower, publisher, dies at age 89.
Newt Gingrich narrowly re-elected speaker of the House of Representatives.

Intel releases the 166 MHz and 200 MHz Pentium processors with MMX multimedia extension instructions. Bus speed is 66 MHz. They incorporate 4.5 million transistors. Performance of the 200 MHz version is 350 MIPS. Code-name during development was P55C. MMX originally stood for "matrix-multiplication extensions".
Ronald William Eastman, cinematographer, dies at age 60.
Edward Osobka-Morawski, prime minister of Poland (1945-47), dies.
Junaidu ibn Buhari, scholar, dies at age 90.

Michael Eisner signs a new ten-year contract as chairman of Disney. His base salary is US$750,000 per year, plus a bonus tied to the company's financial performance, and he receives stock options for 8 million shares to be exercised between 2003 and 2006. The value of the options is estimated at US$195-771 million.
A Comair Embraer 120 crashes during approach into Detroit Metro Airport, killing 29.
Dow Corning provides US$2.95 billion to settle breast implant suits.

Alvinio Misciano, Italian tenor, killed in a fall from a window.

Italy's new 1,000 lire coin shows divided Germany on map.
Bulgarian Student strike versus government of Jan Videnov.

Ivan Rodriguez signs the richest one-year deal in baseball history, agreeing to a contract worth US$6.65 million to play with the Texas Rangers.
Yasser Arafat returns to Hebron after more than 30 years, and joins celebrations over the handover of the last Israeli-controlled West Bank city.

In Southern Xinjiang, China, a magnitude 5.9 earthquake occurs. At least 12 people killed, 40 injured, and 2,500 families homeless; about 31,000 homes destroyed or damaged.
Dennis Main Wilson, TV/radio producer, dies at age 72.
Newt Gingrich becomes the first Speaker of the United States House of Representatives to be internally disciplined for ethical misconduct.

Irwin Levine, composer ("Tie a Yellow Ribbon"), dies at age 58.

PepsiCo announces it is making a "total disengagement" from Burma.

O.J. Simpson is found liable in civil court for the death of Ron Goldman and for the battery of Nicole Brown Simpson. Simpson is ordered to pay $35 million in damages to the families of the two victims.
On their way to Lebanon, two Israeli troop-transport helicopters collide, killing 73.
After at first contesting the results, Serbian President Slobodan Milo_evic recognizes opposition victories in the November 1996 elections.
In Northeastern Iran, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake occurs. At least 88 people killed, nearly 2,000 injured, 16,500 houses destroyed or damaged.

Ipswich Town football player Adam Tanner, who recently failed a drugs test, is banned from football for three months at an FA hearing. Tanner received a relatively lenient punishment as he had admitted taking drugs at the first attempt and shown remorse for his behaviour.

En route to Lebanon, two Israeli Sikorsky CH-53 troop-transport helicopters collide in mid-air over northern Galilee, Israel killing 73.

Lemrick Nelson found guilty in the fatal stabbing on Hasidic Jew Yankel Rosenbaum in Crown Heights Brooklyn in 1991.

Bill Parcells becomes head coach of New York Jets.
Fred Goldman says he will settle for a signed murder confession from O J Simpson in lieu of his $20.5 million judgement.
Walter Ritchie, sculptor, dies at age 77.
Hwang Jang-yop, a secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea and a prime architect of North Korea's Juche doctrine, defects at the South Korean embassy in Beijing.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 7,000 for the first time, gaining 60.81 to 7,022.44.

The Washington Post reports that U.S. Justice Department investigators found evidence the Chinese Embassy in Washington, DC may have coordinated financial contributions to the Democratic party in violation of U.S. law.
Tune-up and repair work on the Hubble Space Telescope is started by astronauts from the Space Shuttle Discovery.

WFAA-TV becomes the first TV station in the USA to start broadcasting their newscasts in HDTV on a VHF channel.

Smokers must prove they are over 18 to purchase cigarettes in US.

The Stickney-Eliasberg pedigree US 1804 Draped Bust silver dollar sells for US$1.815 million, a record for a single coin at auction. A US 1885 Trade dollar, Proof, finest of 5 known, sells for $907,500 to Jay Parrino.

In Augusta, Georgia, 21-year-old Eldrick "Tiger" Woods wins the 61st Golf Masters Tournament by a record 12 strokes (total 270; 18 under par), his first victory in one of golf's four major championships, the greatest performance by a professional golfer in more than a century, and the youngest golfer to win the Masters.

Intel releases the Pentium II processor. It features a new 66 MHz bus interface called Slot 1, 200 MHz 32 kB Level 1 cache, MMX instructions, 512 kB Level 2 external cache. CPU speeds available are 233, 266, and 300 MHz. The processor incorporates 7.5 million transistors using 0.35 micron process technology. Prices range from US$636 to $1981. Code-name during development was Klamath.

The Detroit Red Wings win their first Stanley Cup championship in 42 years, defeating the Philadelphia Flyers four games to none. Red Wings goaltender Mike Vernon is awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy as playoff Most Valuable Player.

Interleague play begins in baseball, ending a 126-year tradition of separating the major leagues until the World Series (with the exception of the All-Star Game).

In England, the fast-food chain McDonald's wins a partial victory in its libel trial against environmental campaigners Helen Steel and Dave Morris. The court case over seven years is the lonest trial in England's legal history, including 313 days in court, and 180 witnesses called. In the 1000-page verdict, the judge accepts that McDonald's exploits children, cruelly treats animals, management can be autocratic and unfair, and that a diet of McDonald's food contributes to heart disease. Steel and Morris are ordered to pay US$95,490 damages for other unsubstantiated claims (later reduced to US$61,300, but never collected).
At over 500 McDonald's locations in the United Kingdom and 30 in North America, picketers and protesters pass out leaflets about the controversies of McDonald's food and practices.
French musician Jean Michel Jarre's "Oxygene Tour" concert in Spodek (Katowice, Poland) for deaf and poorly hearing children of Europe.
An unmanned Progress spacecraft collided with the Russian Space station, Mir.

Bertie Ahern is appointed as the 10th Taoiseach of the Republic of Ireland and Mary Harney is appointed as the 16th, and first female, Tnaiste (Deputy Prime Minister), after their parties, Fianna Fil and the Progressive Democrats respectively, won the 1997 General Election.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules that the Communications Decency Act violates the First Amendment.
Boxer Mike Tyson is disqualified from WBA title re-match, for biting off part of the ear of his opponent Evander Holyfield.

China resumes sovereignty over the city-state of Hong Kong, ending 156 years of British colonial rule.

The Thai currency, baht, is allowed to float freely according to market forces.
Tom Walters Sr. of Meridian, Mississippi wins powerball of US$11 million.

NASA's Pathfinder space probe lands on the surface of Mars.
In Cambodia, Hun Sen of the Cambodian People's Party overthrows Norodom Ranariddh in a coup.

90 die in Thailand's worst hotel fire at Pattaya.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 63.17 to close at 8,038.88. It is the Dow's first close above 8,000. The Dow has doubled its value in 30 months.

The fully restored USS Constitution (aka "Old Ironsides") celebrates her 200th birthday by setting sail for the first time in 116 years.
The second Blue Water Bridge opens between Port Huron, Michigan and Sarnia, Ontario.
Digital Equipment Corporation files antitrust charges against chipmaker Intel.
Serial killer Andrew Cunanan commits suicide in a Miami, Florida houseboat.
Digital Equipment Company files antitrust charges against chipmaker Intel.
Spree killer Andrew Cunanan commits suicide in the upstairs bedroom aboard a Miami houseboat to avoid capture by the police
K.R. Narayanan is sworn in as India's 10th president and the first member of the Dalit caste to hold this office.
First light at the Swiss Light Source.
K.R. Narayanan is sworn-in as India's 10th president and the first Dalit? formerly called untouchable? to hold this office.
In Canada, the Toronto Transit Commission opens its Spadina light rail transit line.
Si Zerrouk massacre in Algeria; about 50 people killed.
Si Zerrouk massacre in Algeria; about 50 people killed.
Guatemala becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
Eighteen lives are lost in the Thredbo landslide in New South Wales, Australia.
A double suicide bombing kills 14 people in Jerusalem,Israel.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas complete their merger.
Australian ski instructor Stuart Diver is rescued as the sole survivor from the Thredbo landslide in New South Wales, Australia, in which 18 lives were lost.
Oued El-Had and Mezouara massacre in Algeria; 40-76 villagers killed.
Oued El-Had and Mezouara massacre in Algeria; 40-76 villagers killed.
185,000 UPS drivers (Teamsters Union) walk off the job.
185,000 Teamsters union United Parcel Service drivers walk off the job.
228 die as Korean Air Flight 801 crash lands at Guam International Airport.
Korean Air Flight 801, a Boeing 747-300, crashes into the jungle on Guam on approach to airport, killing 228.
Microsoft buys $150 million worth of shares of financially troubled Apple Computer.
Fine Air Flight 101, a cargo flight from Miami to Santo Domingo crashes onto NW 72nd Ave near Miami International Airport, killing five people.
In Belo Horizonte, Brazil, Cruzeiro wins Sporting Cristal of Peru by 1-0 and are Copa Libertadores de AmTrica champions by second time.
South Park debuts on Comedy Central.
Souhane massacre in Algeria; over 60 people killed, 15 kidnapped.
Souhane massacre in Algeria; over 60 people killed, 15 kidnapped.
Egon Krenz, the former East German leader, is convicted of a shoot-to-kill Berlin Wall policy.
Beni-Ali massacre in Algeria; 60-100 people killed.
The Independent International Commission on Decommissioning is set up in Northern Ireland, as part of the peace process.
Beni-Ali massacre in Algeria; 60-100 people killed.
Rais massacre in Algeria; over 98 (and possibly up to 400) people killed.
At least 98 villagers are killed by the GIA in the Rais massacre, Algeria.

Diana, Princess of Wales, is taken to hospital after a car crash shortly after midnight in the Pont de l'Alma road tunnel in Paris. She is pronounced dead at 4:00 a.m. that morning. Also, death of Dodi Al-Fayed, Egyptian businessman (the same automobile accident), and driver Henri Paul.
Diana, Princess of Wales, dies in a car crash in Paris.
Arizona Governor Fife Symington is convicted for various crimes tied to his real estate business, effectively forcing him out of office.
Arizona Governor Fife Symington is convicted for various crimes tied to his real estate business, effectively forcing him out of office.
A Vietnam Airlines Tupolev TU-134 crashes on approach into Phnom Penh airport, killing 64.
In Lorain, Ohio, the last Ford Thunderbird for three years rolls off the assembly line.
In Lorain, Ohio, United States, the last Ford Thunderbird rolls off the assembly line.
The International Olympic Committee picks Athens, Greece to be the host city for the 2004 Summer Olympics.
Beni-Messous massacre in Algeria; over 87 killed.
At least 87 people killed in the Beni-Messous massacre
The funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales takes place at Westminster Abbey, watched by over one billion people worldwide.
The funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, at Westminster Abbey draws large crowds.
First test flight of the F-22 Raptor.
The first test flight of the F-22A Raptor takes place.
NASA's Mars Global Surveyor reaches Mars.
Scotland votes to create its own Parliament after 290 years of union with England.
Scotland votes to re-establish its own Parliament on the 700th anniversary of the Battle of Stirling Bridge, after 290 years of union with England.

An Iraqi military officer attacks an UNSCOM weapons inspector on board an UNSCOM helicopter while the inspector was attempting to take photographs of unauthorized movement of Iraqi vehicles inside a site designated for inspection.

Hastings Wise murders four at the R.E. Phelon Company lawn mower parts manufacturing factory in Aiken, South Carolina. The only possible motive for the murders was Hastings' dismissal from his job eleven weeks earlier.
National Stepfamily Day chosen in recognition of founder Christy Borgeld which is held every year on September 16-the day of the birth of her first child. more details
While waiting for access to a site, UNSCOM inspectors witness and videotape Iraqi guards moving files, burning documents, and dumping waste cans into a nearby river.
Wales votes in favour of devolution and the formation of a National Assembly.
U.S. media magnate Ted Turner donates USD $1 billion to the United Nations.
Voters in Wales vote yes (50.3%) on a referendum on Welsh autonomy.
Guelb El-Kebir massacre in Algeria; 53 killed.
Guelb El-Kebir massacre in Algeria; 53 killed.
The AIS, the FIS' armed wing, declares a unilateral ceasefire in Algeria.
Bentalha massacre in Algeria; over 200 villagers killed.
Bentalha massacre in Algeria; over 200 villagers killed.
UNSCOM inspector Dr. Diane Seaman catches several Iraqi men sneaking out the back door of an inspection site, with log books for the creation of prohibited bacteria and chemicals.

In Central Italy, magnitude 5.7 and 6.4 earthquakes occurs. As a result of these two earthquakes, a total of eleven people killed, more than 100 injured and about 80,000 homes destroyed. Part of the Basilica of St. Francis at Assisi collapses.
An air crash in Indonesia kills 234 people (likely caused by smoke rising from numerous forest fires in the area).
A Garuda Indonesia Airbus A-300 crashes near Medan, Indonesia, airport, killing 234
An earthquake strikes the Italian regions of Umbria and the Marche, causing part of the Basilica of St. Francis at Assisi to collapse.
The Adelaide Crows win the AFL Premiership for the first time in their 7th season, beating Saint Kilda who have only ever won one premiership in their 100 year history.
Communications are lost with the Mars Pathfinder for unknown reasons.
Luke Woodham walks into Pearl High School in Pearl, Mississippi and opens fire, killing two girls, after killing his mother earlier that morning.

United Kingdom scientists Moira Bruce and John Collinge, with their colleagues, independently show that the new variant form of the Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is the same disease as Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) or "mad-cow disease".
One million men gather for Promise Keepers' "Stand in the Gap" event in Washington, DC.
Gunpei Yokoi, inventor and toy maker, dies of an auto accident. He designed Nintendo's Game & Watch handheld games, Game Boy, and Game Boy Pocket.

The second largest cash robbery in U.S. history ($17.3 million, mostly in small bills) occurs at the Charlotte, North Carolina office of Loomis, Fargo and Company. An FBI investigation eventually results in 24 convictions and the recovery of approximately 95 percent of the stolen cash.
An Austral Airlines DC-9-32 crashes and explodes near Nuevo Berlin, Uruguay, killing 74.
The NHL's Carolina Hurricanes win their first-ever regular season game by defeating the New Jersey Devils 2-1 in Greensboro, North Carolina.
The mixed martial arts organisation PRIDE Fighting Championships holds its inaugural event at the Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan. In the main event Rickson Gracie defeats Nobuhiko Takada by armbar.
Sidi Daoud massacre in Algeria: 43 are killed at a fake roadblock.
Sidi Daoud massacre in Algeria; 43 killed at a fake roadblock
NASA launches the Cassini-Huygens probe to Saturn.

Near the coast of central Chile, a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurs. 8 people killed, more than 300 people injured, 20,000 houses destroyed or damaged, numerous power and telephone outages, landslides and rockslides.

Andy Green sets the first supersonic land speed record for the ThrustSSC team, led by Richard Noble of the United Kingdom. ThrustSSC goes through the flying mile course at Black Rock Desert, Nevada at an average speed of 1,227.985 km/h (763.035 mph).
A tanker collides with an empty Very Large Crude Carrier ship off Singapore, leaking 29 million litres of oil, covering beaches of several islands.
The Cleveland Indians win their second pennant in three years defeating the Baltimore Orioles 1-0 to win the American League Championship Series in six games.
The Cassini probe launches from Cape Canaveral on its way to Saturn.
The first supersonic land speed record is set by Andy Green in ThrustSSC (United Kingdom).

The remains of Che Guevara are laid to rest with full military honours in a specially built mausoleum in the city of Santa Clara, Cuba, where he had won the decisive battle of the Cuban Revolution 39 years before.
After a brief civil war which has driven President Pascal Lissouba out of Brazzaville, Denis Sassou-Nguesso proclaims himself the President of the Republic of the Congo.
Michael Schumacher commits the infamous Dry Sac corner incident at the Jerez track, an act for which the German is disqualified from 1997 season by the FIA and crucified in the press.
The Florida Marlins win Game 7 of the 1997 World Series against the Cleveland Indians 3-2 in 11 innings.
The left arms of Chen Ming-Kuo and Yang Chung-ming are amputated by the rope in a 1,500-person tug-of-war contest in Taipei; both arms are successfully reattached later on.
Basketball player Charles Barkley is charged with aggravated battery and resisting arrest after throwing Jorge Lugo through a plate glass window in a dance club in Orlando, Florida.

Stock markets around the world crash because of a global economic crisis scare. The Dow Jones Industrial Average follows suit and plummets 554.26, or 7.18 percent, to 7,161.15. The points loss exceeds the loss from Black Monday. Officials at the New York Stock Exchange for the first time invoke the "circuit breaker" rule to stop trading.

Stock markets around the world crash because of fears of a global economic meltdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummets 554.26 points to 7,161.15. For the first time, the New York Stock Exchange activated their "circuit breakers" twice during the day eventually making the controversial move of closing the Exchange early (see October 27, 1997 mini-crash).
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains a record 337.17 to 7,498.32. One billion shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange for the first time ever.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains a record 337.17 points to close at 7,498.32.
Iraq says it will begin shooting down U-2 surveillance planes being used by UNSCOM inspectors.
In Newton, Massachusetts, British au pair Louise Woodward is found guilty of the baby-shaking death of 8-month-old Matthew Eappen.
British au pair Louise Woodward is found guilty of the baby-shaking death of 8-month-old Matthew Eappen.
19-year-old British au pair Louise Woodward, convicted by a Cambridge, Massachusetts, jury of second-degree murder the day before, is sentenced to life in prison.
In France, striking truck drivers blockade ports during a pay dispute.

In Southern Quebec, Canada, a magnitude 4.8 earthquake occurs. Felt as far south as Ottawa, Ontario and as far east as Edmundston, New Brunswick. Felt in western Maine, northern New Hampshire, northern Vermont and parts of northeastern New York in the United States.
US president Bill Clinton speaks at a dinner sponsored by the Human Rights Campaign, the USA's largest gay rights organisation.
The infamous Montreal Screwjob happened in Montreal, Quebec.
A Fairfax, Virginia jury finds Mir Aimal Kasi guilty of murdering two US Central Intelligence Agency employees in 1993.
Telecom companies WorldCom and MCI Communications announce a US$37 billion merger to form MCI WorldCom (the largest merger in US history).
WorldCom and MCI Communications announce a $37 billion merger (the largest merger in US history at the time).

The conviction of 19-year-old British au pair Louise Woodward reduced from second-degree murder to involuntary manslaughter and her sentence reduced from life in prison to time served. She had been found guilty less than two weeks earlier in a baby-shaking death.
A jury in Fairfax, Virginia finds Mir Aimal Kasi guilty of the murder of two CIA employees in 1993.
Mary McAleese is elected the 8th President of Ireland.
Mary McAleese inaugurated as the eighth President of Ireland.
Ramzi Yousef is found guilty of masterminding the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.

Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America and Mitsubishi Electric America sign an agreement with the Rainforest Action Network, committing the companies to ecological sustainability and social responsibility.
Ramzi Yousef is found guilty of masterminding the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.

The Toronto Argonauts win their second consecutive Canadian Football League title by defeating the Saskatchewan Roughriders 47-23 to win the 85th Grey Cup at Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton, Alberta.
After nearly 18 years of incarceration, the People's Republic of China releases Wei Jingsheng, a pro-democracy dissident, from jail for medical reasons.
In Luxor, Egypt, 62 people are killed by six Islamic militants outside the Temple of Hatshepsut (police kill the assailants).
In Luxor, Egypt, 62 people are killed by 6 Islamic militants outside the Temple of Hatshepsut (police killed the assailants).
Gary Glitter is arrested in the United Kingdom on child pornography charges.

Bell Laboratories in New Jersey announces that it has developed a 60-nanometre MOS transistor that is five times faster and one quarter the size of current transistors. It also uses 60 to 160 times less power.
In Des Moines, Iowa, Bobbi McCaughey, a resident of the nearby town of Carlisle, gives birth to septuplets in the second known case where all seven babies were born alive.
In the India-Bangladesh border region, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake occurs. Twenty-three people killed, 200 injured, and a five-story building collapsed at Chittagong, Bangladesh.
Australian singer and INXS frontman, Michael Hutchence, 37, is found hanged in a Sydney hotel room.
NASA and Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency jointly launch Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission, a satellite program to study tropical and subtropical rainfall and its effects on global climate.
Second Souhane massacre in Algeria: 25 killed.
Twenty-five are killed in the second Souhane massacre in Algeria.
Kosovo Liberation Army, Albanian guerrilla group fighting for freedom of Kosovo, presents in front of the people of Kosovo.
Denis Gerald Barrington, artist, dies at age 67.
Stephane Grappelli, French jazz violinist, dies at age 89.
Westinghouse formally changes its name to CBS.
Golden State Warriors' guard Latrell Sprewell attacks his coach P J Carlesimo.
Pope John Paul II creates the archbishopric of Vaduz in Liechtenstein. The first archbishop is Wolfgang Haas.
MCI Center opens in Washington DC, as Washington Wizards play the Seattle SuperSonics.
Marian Kratochwil, artist, dies at age 91.
Steve Hamilton, pitcher (New York Yankees), dies of cancer at age 63.

In Ottawa, Canada, representatives from 121 countries sign a treaty prohibiting the manufacture and deployment of anti-personnel land mines. The United States, the People's Republic of China, and Russia do not sign the treaty.
Golden State Warriors' guard Latrell Sprewell's four-year, $32 million, contract terminated for attacking his coach P J Carlesimo.

In Ottawa, Canada, representatives from 121 countries sign a treaty prohibiting manufacture and deployment of anti-personnel landmines. The United States, People's Republic of China, and Russia do not sign the treaty, however.
NBA suspends Latrell Sprewell for one year for attacking his coach.
David Abell Wood, priest, dies at age 72.
Near the East Coast of Kamchatka, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurs.
Colin Franklin, doctor, dies at age 67.

Texas Instruments announces that it has created a manufacturing technique to create integrated circuits using copper wiring. This approach could lead to processors that are ten times faster than today's chips, while using less power.
Daphne Fielding, socialite/writer, dies at age 93.
First game at Washington Capitals' MCI Center versus Florida Panthers.
Edmund Charles Wolf Myers, soldier/engineer, dies at age 91.
Alan Mouncer, film director/producer, dies at age 68.
A Russian Antonov AN-124 transport cargo plane crashes into an apartment complex near Irkutsk, Siberia, killing 67.
Amy Fruhwirth and Clarence Rose win LPGA J C Penney Classic.
Bob Bell, clown (WGN's first Bozo), dies at age 75.
8th Billboard Music Awards: LeAnn Rimes and Spice Girls win.
Violet Carlson, stage dancer/singer, dies at age 97.
Kenneth William Gatland, aerospace scientist, dies at age 73.
The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change opens for signature.
Demonstrations in state capitals of Australia against World Trade Organization and International Monetary Fund.
Federal judge sentences Autumn Jackson, who claims to be Bill Cosby's daughter, to 26 months for trying to extort US$40 million from him.
SWAT team shoots John E Armstrong in Florida, freeing two young hostages.
Boston Red Sox sign Pedro Martinez to record six year $69 million contract.
Carlos the Jackal, "professional revolutionary" goes on trial in Paris, France.
Japanese train builders (Maglev) claim world speed record at 332 MPH.
Florida Marlins release Alex Arias, the last original Marlins player.
Martin Carter, poet/critic, dies at age 70.

The PokTmon episode Electric Soldier Porygon triggers attacks of photosensitive epilepsy in hundreds of Japanese children.
Typhoon Paka makes landfall on the island of Guam with 150 mph winds.
Reginald Victor Jones, scientist, dies at age 86.
The term "weblog" is coined by Jorn Barger.
HTML 4.0 is published by the World Wide Web Consortium.
HTML 4.0 is published by the World Wide Web Consortium.
Masaru Ibuka, co-founder of Sony Corporation, dies at age 89.
Silkair Flight 185 crashes into the Musi River, near Palembang in Indonesia, killing 104.
Vincent Ciccone, inventor (Blow-Pops candy), dies at age 81.

Detroit Lions' Barry Sanders is third to run for 2,000 yards in a season.
Michael Lyne, air-marshal, dies at age 78.

Detroit Lions linebacker Reggie Brown knocked unconscious in game.
Dawn Steel producer/president (Columbia TriStar), dies of brain tumor at age 51.

Merck baldness pill for men approved by US Food and Drug Administration.

Douglas Ranger, surgeon, dies at age 81.

Acteal massacre: Attendees at a prayer meeting of Roman Catholic activists for indigenous causes in the small village of Acteal in the Mexican state of Chiapas are massacred by paramilitary forces.
US Agriculture Department estimates it costs $149,820 to raise a child to 18.
Austin Whitaker, schoolmaster classical scholar/archivist, dies at age 90.

Chicago Bulls' coach Phil Jackson is quickest to reach 500 wins (682 games).
Colorado Avalanche player Jari Kurri is 8th NHL player to score 600 career goals.
Donald Gunn MacRae, sociologist, dies at age 76.
Hrvoje Horvatic, video artist, dies at age 39.
Keith Bentley, international racing cyclist, dies at age 72.
Terry Nichols found guilty of manslaughter in Oklahoma City bombing.
Sid El-Antri massacre in Algeria: 50-100 villagers are killed.
Alan Fluck, musical educationalist, dies at age 69.
Anthea Joseph, music producer, dies at age 57.
First time a Channukah candle is officially lit in Vatican City.

The Sid El-Antri massacre (or Sidi Lamri) in Algeria kills 50-100 people.
Laurence Gower, academic, dies at age 84.

For first time US movie box office receipts pass US$6 billion.

Loyalist paramilitary leader Billy Wright is assassinated in Northern Ireland, inside Long Kesh prison.
Ewart G Abner Jr, president of Motown Records, dies at age 74.

54-car pileup on the Sunshine Skyway Bridge in Tampa Bay, Florida, USA, due to dense fog. One death, 30 injuries.
Tom Hudson, artist/teacher, dies at age 75.
Protestant paramilitary leader Billy Wright is assassinated in Northern Ireland.
Sting beats Hollywood Hogan for WCW Championship.
Ronald Clive Williams, actor/comedian, dies at age 68.

Carquest Bowl 8: Georgia Tech beats West Virginia, 35-30.
(Hanlon) Pat Clarke, cyclist, dies at age 82.

Russia signs agreement to build a US$3 billion nuclear power plant in China.
Hong Kong begins to kill all the chickens within its territory (1.25 million) to stop the spread of a potentially deadly influenza strain.
Hong Kong begins to kill all the nation's chickens (1.25 million) to stop the spread of a potentially deadly influenza strain.

In the worst incident in Algeria's insurgency, 400 people are killed from four villages in the wilaya of Relizane: Khrouba (176 deaths), Sahnoun (113 deaths), El-Abadel (73 deaths), and Ouled-Tayeb (50 deaths).
In the worst incident in Algeria's insurgency, the Wilaya of Relizane massacres, 400 people are killed from four villages.
Marv Levy retires as coach of Buffalo Bills.
Dominique de Menil, arts patron/human rights advocate, dies at age 89.
South African and American surgeons separate Zambian Siamese twins joined at the head.
Michael Kennedy, son of Robert Kennedy, dies in ski accident at age 39.
After 26 years in operation, the Opryland USA theme park in Nashville, Tennessee closes permanently.
Orlando Hernandez, half-brother of pitcher Livan, defects from Cuba.
Floyd Cramer, pianist (Nashville Sound), dies of cancer at age 64.
Quaker Oats settles a lawsuit involving the immoral use of child subjects.
The ESRB rating K-A(Kids to Adults) is replaced by the rating E(Everyone).
US Census Bureau estimates population at 268,921,733.
Mongolia switches from a 46 hour to 40 hour work week.
Smoking is banned in all California bars and restaurants.
Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.
Brazilian radio presenter and local politician Antario Teodoro Filho is shot dead during a live show by a gunman who burst into the studio.
Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.
Wilaya of Relizane massacres in Algeria; over 170 are killed in three remote villages.

Vandals decapitate Copenhagen's Little Mermaid statute.
Ice storm knocks out electricity in QuTbec and Ontario, Canada.
Don Sutton selected to Baseball Hall of Fame.
Barry Switzer resigns as Dallas Cowboys' coach.
The Lunar Prospector spacecraft is launched into orbit around the Moon.
New York Giants' general manager George Young resigns to accept NFL position.
Cosmologists announce that the universe's expansion rate is increasing.
Ramzi Yousef is sentenced to life in prison for planning the World Trade Center bombing.
Walter Diemer, inventor (bubble gum 1928), dies of heart failure at age 93.
Decapitated head of Danish Little Mermaid is returned.
Anatoly Karpov defeats Viswanathan Anand to retain chess title.
Boston Red Sox player Mo Vaughn pleads not guilty to drunken driving.
Anatoly Solovyov and Pavel Vinogradov spacewalk record 3 hours 8 minutes.

In Northeastern China, a magnitude 5.7 earthquake occurs. Seventy people killed, about 11,500 injured, 44,000 families left homeless. Over 70,000 houses were damaged or destroyed. Damage to portions of the Great Wall of China in northwestern Hebei Province.
In Guatemala, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. At least 27 people injured. Felt throughout southern and western Guatemala, in El Salvador and parts of southern Mexico.
AFC Championship: Denver Broncos beat Pittsburgh Steelers 24-21.
US female Figure Skating championship won by Michelle Kwan.
US male Figure Skating championship won by Todd Eldredge.
Sidi-Hamed massacre in Algeria: over 100 people are killed.
NFC Championship: Green Bay Packers beat San Francisco 49ers 23-10.
Sidi-Hamed massacre in Algeria; over 100 people killed.
Nineteen European nations agree to forbid human cloning.
Lrgest ever oil spill in Nigeria, 6.4 million litres spill from a ruptured oil pipeline to one of Mobil's terminals.
