CBS pays US$4 billion to televise AFC games for eight years.
Researchers in Dallas, Texas present findings about an enzyme that slows aging and cell death (apoptosis).
Researchers in Dallas, Texas present findings about an enzyme that slows aging and cell death (apoptosis).
An Afghan cargo plane crashes into a mountain in southwest Pakistan killing more than 50 people.
Gulzarilal Nanda, temporary Prime Minister of India (1964, 66), dies.
David "Junior" Kimbrough, blues musician, dies at age 67.
Peter Diamand, artistic administrator, dies at age 84.
NASA announces that John Glenn, age 76, will return to space when the Space Shuttle Discovery blasts off in October.
Paula Jones accuses President Bill Clinton of sexual harassment.
Boston Celtics retire Robert Parrish's number 00.
ABL All-Star Game at Walt Disney World complex in Orlando, Florida (West beats East 102-73).
Kelly Robbins wins Healthsouth Golf Inaugural.
48th NHL All-Star Game: North America beats World 8-7 at Vancouver, BC, Canada.
Lewinsky scandal: Matt Drudge breaks the Bill Clinton - Monica Lewinsky affair story on his website The Drudge Report.
Zevulun Hammer, Vice Prime Minister of Israel, dies.
Nepalese police intercept a shipment of 272 human skulls in Kathmandu.
Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducts The Mama and The Papas, The Eagles.
Pope John Paul II visits Cuba.
NHL's Minnesota franchise selects the nickname Wild.
Suspected "Unabomber" Theodore Kaczynski pleads guilty, and accepts a sentence of life without the possibility of parole.
Rickey Henderson rejoins Oakland Athletics for fourth time.
World League of American Football becomes NFL East.
Hilla Limann, President of Ghana in (1979-81), dies.
Pope John Paul II condemns US embargo against Cuba.
Helen Alfredsson wins Office Depot LPGA tournament.
Mohammad Yusuf Khan, prime minister of Afghanistan in (1963-65), dies.
Super Bowl XXXII: The Denver Broncos become the first AFC team in 14 years to win the Super Bowl, as they defeat the Green Bay Packers, 31-24.
The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) suicide attack Sri Lanka's Temple of the Tooth kills eight people, injuring 25 others.
During a historic visit to Cuba Pope John Paul II demands the release of political prisoners and political reforms while condemning US attempts to isolate the country.
Intel launches 333 MHz Pentium II chip.
On American television, President Bill Clinton denies he had "sexual relations" with former White House intern Monica Lewinsky.
S P Leary, Texan Blues drummer (Muddy Waters), dies at age 67.
25th American Music Awards: Spice Girls and Babyface win.
Shinichi Suzuki, music teacher (Suzuki Method), dies at age 99.
Lewinsky scandal: On American television, Bill Clinton denies he had "sexual relations" with former White House intern Monica Lewinsky.
WNBA begins filling rosters of Washington Mystics and Detroit Shock.
Crane crashes into Roosevelt Island tram (New York City, New York), injuring 10.
American First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton appears on the Today Show calling the attacks against her husband part of a vast right-wing conspiracy.
Ford Motor Company announces the buyout of Volvo Cars for $6.45 billion.
Gunmen hold at least 400 children and teachers hostage for several hours, at an elementary school in Manila, Philippines.
Gunmen hold at least 400 children and teachers hostage for several hours at an elementary school in Manila, Philippines.
Soyuz TM-27 launches to MIR space station.
Thick fog causes highway carnage in Belgium and Netherlands, six die.
In Birmingham, Alabama, a bomb explodes at an abortion clinic, killing one and severely wounding another. Serial bomber Eric Rudolph is the prime suspect.

Ricky Sanderson, who stabbed a 16-year old girl in North Carolina, executed at age 38.
All-Star Florida Marlins' catcher Darren Daulton retires.
72nd Australian Women's Tennis: Martina Hingis beats C Martinez (6-3 6-3).

The United States Senate passes Resolution 71, urging U.S. President Bill Clinton to "take all necessary and appropriate actions to respond to the threat posed by Iraq's refusal to end its weapons of mass destruction programs."
NFL Pro Bowl Game, AFC beats NFC 29-24.
Australian Mixed Doubles Tennis: J Gimelstob and V Williams beat Suk and Sukova (6-2, 6-1).
86th Australian Mens Tennis: Petr Korda beats Marcelo Rios (6-2, 6-2, 6-2).
Philippine DC-9 crashes apparently killing all 104 on board.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index closes above 1,000 for the first time, at 1,001.27.
A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9-32 crashes into a mountain near Cagayan de Oro, Philippines, killing 104.
Florida Panthers' player Dino Ciccarelli is 9th NHL player to score 600 career goals.
Karla Faye Tucker, age 38, is executed in Texas, becoming the first to be executed in Texas since the American Civil War.
New York Yankees replace general manager Bob Watson with Brian Cashman.
A United States Military pilot causes the deaths of 20 people near Trento, Italy, when his low-flying plane severs the cable of a cable-car.

In Hindu Kush region, Afghanistan, a magnitude 5.9 earthquake occurs. At least 2,323 people killed, 818 injured, 8,094 houses destroyed.
Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates gets a pie thrown in his face in Brussels, Belgium.

Author Tom Clancy confirms he signed agreement to purchase Minnesota Vikings for slightly more than $200 million, an NFL franchise record.
Figure skaters Nancy Kerrigan and Tonya Harding talk on FOX (Taped December 22nd).
Tim Kelly, guitarist, dies at age 34.
Washington National Airport is renamed Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport.
Nazim al-Kudsi, Syrian Prime Minister (1949, 1950-51)/President (1961-63), dies.
International Telecommunications Union of modem vendors agree on v.90 as a common 56 kbps transmission standard.
The French prefect Claude Erignac is assassinated in the streets of Ajaccio (Corse).
Minnesota Twins trade Chuck Knoblauch to New York Yankees for $3 million and four minor league players.
Washington National Airport is renamed Ronald Reagan National Airport.
NHL's Dallas Stars retire Neal Broten's #7.
(to February 22) The XVIII Olympic Winter Games are held in Nagano, Japan.
NHL stops season until February 24th to accommodate the Olympics.
48th NBA All-Star Game East beats West 135-114 at New York City.
William Lambert, Pulitzer prize-winning reporter, dies at age 78.
First female ice hockey game in Olympics history: Finland beats Sweden 6-0.
First female ice hockey game in Olympic history: Finland beats Sweden 6-0.
Failed assassination attempt on Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze.
Maurice Schumann, French foreign minister (1969-73), dies.
AOL raises monthly flat rate Internet access from $19.95 to $21.95.
Voters in Maine repeal a gay rights law passed in 1997, becoming the first U.S. state to abandon such a law.
A college dropout becomes the first person to be convicted of a hate crime committed in cyberspace.
Voters in Maine repeal a gay rights law passed in 1997 becoming the first U.S. state to abandon such a law.
Lyrics to "Candle in the Wind 1997" auctioned for $442,500.
KVBC-FM (Las Vegas) offers Monica Lewinsky $5 million for interview.
250-car Italy pile-up due to fog, four die and 50 hurt.
US district judge T Hogan declares the presidential line-item veto law is unconstitutional.
Intel unveils its first graphics chip, the i740.
Dallas Cowboys sign Chan Gailey as their fourth head coach.
The presidential line-item veto is declared unconstitutional by United States federal judge.
Authorities in the United States announce that Eric Robert Rudolph is a suspect in an Alabama abortion clinic bombing.
In Dayton Beach, Florida, Dale Earnhardt wins the Daytona 500 in his 20th try, after many unsuccessful attempts.
Dale Eggeling wins Los Angeles Women's Golf Championship.
China Airlines Flight 676 crashes into a residential area near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 202 people (all 196 on board and six on the ground).
Tellabs Inc acquires Coherent Communications Systems for $670 million.
Martha Gellhorn, female war reporter for Reuthers, dies at age 89.
China Airlines Flight 676 crashed into a residential area near by Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 202 people, included all 196 on board and six on the ground.
Ernst Juenger, German writer, dies at age 102 in Riedlingen, Germany.
Two white separatists are arrested in Nevada, accused of plotting biological warfare on New York City subways.
Mya Than Tint, Myanmarese author, dies of brain hemorrhage at age 69.
Robert Merrill, songwriter ("Funny Girl"), commits suicide at age 76.
New York Rangers fire head coach Colin Campbell.
Two white separatists are arrested in Nevada and accused of plotting a biological attack on New York City subways.
Larry Wayne Harris of the Aryan Nations and William Leavitt are arrested in Henderson, New York, for possession of military grade anthrax.
US hockey team destroys their rooms at Olympics village in Japan.
A 66-day blackout begins in Auckland, New Zealand.
US movie box office hits quickest $1 billion for year (51 days).

In Hindu Kush region, Afghanistan, a magnitude 6.4 earthquake occurs. One person killed and 11 injured. An earthquake-induced avalanche destroyed 35 houses and a mosque, and left 300 people homeless. Felt in much of northern Pakistan and in northeastern Afghanistan and in parts of Tajikistan.
Iraqi President Saddam Hussein negotiates a deal with U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan, allowing weapons inspectors to return to Baghdad, preventing military action by the United States and Britain.
Tara Lipinski wins Olympics figure skating gold medal.
American figure skater Tara Lipinski becomes the youngest gold-medalist at the Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan.
One third of the Tower block "Palace II" collapses in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
Jose Maria de Areilza, Spanish minister of foreign affairs (1975-76), dies.
XVIII Olympic Winter Games close at Nagano, Japan.
US Supreme Court lets Megan's Law stand.
Tornadoes in central Florida destroy or damage 2,600 structures and kill 42.
Osama bin Laden publishes a fatwa, declaring jihad against all Jews and Crusaders.
Osama bin Laden publishes a fatwa declaring jihad against all Jews and Crusaders.
Tornadoes in central Florida destroy or damage 2,600 structures and kill 42.
NHL resumes season since February 8th to accommodate the Olympics.
A man tries to hijack a Turkish Airlines passenger plane, claiming that he has a bomb in his teddy bear; passengers disapprove and apprehend him.
Musician Elton John knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
Umberto Mastroianni, Italian sculptor, dies at age 87.
Total solar eclipse in Venezuela-Pacific Ocean (4 minutes 9 seconds).
Steven M Gluckstern completes sale of New York Islanders.
Oprah Winfrey beats Texas cattlemen in beef trial.
FBI arrests Ten Most Wanted suspected serial killer Tony Ray Amati.
Serbian police begin to wipe out so-called "terrorist gangs" in Kosovo.
Vancouver Canucks Mark Messier is fourth NHL player to get 1,600 points.
Kosovo War: Serbian police begin the offensive againt the KLA in Kosovo.
Data sent from the Galileo probe indicates that Jupiter's moon Europa has a liquid ocean under a thick crust of ice.
Data sent from the Galileo spaceprobe indicates that Jupiter's moon Europa has a liquid ocean under a thick crust of ice.
The Supreme Court of the United States rules that federal laws banning on-the-job sexual harassment also apply when both parties are the same sex.
Gay rights: The Supreme Court of the United States rules that federal laws banning on-the-job sexual harassment also apply when both parties are the same sex.

Government, naval and university computers running Windows NT across the United States crash as a result of a hacker. The crash affects computers running at MIT, Northwestern University, the University of Minnesota, and the University of California campuses at Berkeley, Irvine, Los Angeles, and San Diego.
NASA announces that the Clementine probe orbiting the Moon has found enough water in polar craters to support a human colony and rocket fueling station.
NASA announces that the Clementine probe orbiting the Moon has found enough water to support a human colony.
First time the British flag is flown over Buckingham Palace.
Adem Jasari, Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) leader, is killed.
Matt Beck, an angry lottery accountant kills four at Connecticut state lottery.
The Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan is fined for burning a cross in his garden and infringing air regulations in California.
United States troops stationed in the Persian Gulf begin to receive the first anthrax vaccine.
American troops stationed in the Persian Gulf begin to receive the first vaccinations against anthrax.
In the Danish parliamentary election, Prime Minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen is re-elected.
In Northern Iran, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. Five people killed and 50 injured. Two thousand houses destroyed, 10,000 people left homeless.
An earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale hits southeastern Iran.
Titanic defeats Star Wars for the #1 place in the North American domestic box office, grossing $471 million.
Pope John Paul II apologises for inactivity and silence of some Roman Catholics during the Holocaust.
USA Women's Hockey Team beats Canada for first Olympic Gold medal.
Liselotte Neumann wins Standard Register PING Golf Tournament.

The Jonesboro massacre: two young boys (aged 11 and 13 years) fire upon students at Westside Middle School while hidden in woodlands near the school. Four students and one teacher are killed, and ten are injured.
Jonesboro massacre: In Jonesboro, Arkansas, two boys (aged 11 and 13 years) fire upon students at Westside Middle School; four students and one teacher are killed and 10 injured.
In Balleny Islands Region, a magnitude 8.1 earthquake occurs. Believed to be the largest instrumentally recorded earthquake in this area to date.
Oued Bouaicha massacre in Algeria: 52 people are killed with axes and knives, 32 of them babies under the age of 2.
Oued Bouaicha massacre in Algeria; 52 people killed with axes and knives, 32 of them babies under the age of 2.
The US Food and Drug Administration approves Viagra for use as a treatment for male sexual impotence, the first pill to be approved for this condition in the United States.
17th NCAA Women's Basketball Championship, at Kemper Arena in Kansas City. Tennessee beats Louisiana Tech 93-75.
A series of tornadoes in southern Minnesota kills three people.
60th NCAA Men's Basketball Championship, at Alamodome, San Antonio. Kentucky beats Utah 78-69.
Tampa Bay Devil Rays' first game; they host Detroit Tigers.

Netscape releases the code base of its browser under an open-source license agreement; the project is given the code name Mozilla and would eventually be spun off into the non-profit Mozilla Foundation.
World Ice Pairs Figure Skating Championship in Minneapolis, Minnesota; Russians Yelena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze win.
Ukrainian serial killer Anatoly Onoprienko is sentenced to death for 52 murders.
World Mens Figure Skating Championship in Minneapolis, Minnesota; Russian Alexei Yagudin wins.
World Ice Dance Figure Skating Championship in Minneapolis, Minnesota; Russians Anjelika Krylova and Oleg Ovsyannikov win.
NFL Europe (formerly WLAF), kicks off season.
In Japan, the Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge linking Shikoku with Honshu and costing about US$3.8 billion, opens to traffic, becoming the largest suspension bridge in the world.
In Japan, the Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge linking Shikoku with Honshu and costing about US$3.8 billion, opens to traffic, becoming the largest suspension bridge in the world.
Pakistan tests medium-range missiles capable of hitting India.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 49.82 to close at 9,033.23 -- its first-ever close above 9,000.
Pakistan tests medium-range missiles capable of hitting India.
Citicorp and Travelers Group announce plans to merge, creating the largest financial-services conglomerate in the world, Citigroup.
A Force 5 tornado strikes the western portion of the Birmingham, Alabama area, killing 32.
UNSCOM reports to the United Nations Security Council that Iraq's declaration on its biological weapons program is incomplete and inadequate.
The National Prisoner of War Museum is located in Andersonville, Georgia, on the site of an old American Civil War POW camp.

Eighteen hours after the end of the talks deadline, the Belfast Agreement is signed between the Irish and British governments and most Northern Ireland political parties, with the notable exception of the Democratic Unionist Party.
62nd Golf Masters Championship: Mark O'Meara wins.
In Slovenia, a magnitude 5.7 earthquake occurs. Felt strongly throughout Slovenia, northeastern Italy, throughout Austria, and in parts of Croatia, Germany, and Hungary.
Catastrophic earthquake in Slovenia, measuring 5.6 on the Richter scale near the town of Poso?je.

Intel announces the 266 MHz Celeron processor with 32 kB Level 1 cache. The Celeron is a Pentium II processor with no secondary cache, making it cheaper and slightly less powerful, targeting home computer users.
A Force 3 tornado passes through downtown Nashville, Tennessee - the first tornado in 11 years to directly hit a major city. An F5 tornado travels through rural portions south of Nashville.
The Nashville Tornado of 1998, one of the most serious urban tornadoes in history, kills one and significantly damages downtown Nashville, Tennessee.
The Walt Disney Company launches the Toon Disney cable television network in the USA.
German terrorist group Red Army Faction announces their dissolution after 28 years.
An Air France Boeing 727-200 crashes into mountain after takeoff from Bogot, Colombia, killing 53.
Disney's Animal Kingdom opens to the public at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Florida.

A waste reservoir at the Los Frailes mine in Andalusia, Spain ruptures, discharging heavy metal waste into the Guadiamar River. The pollution threatens the sensitive ecosystem and endangered species of Doana National Park, Spain's largest nature reserve, but is diverted into the Guadalquivir River. Up to 100 square km of farmland are ruined by the spill.
Dutch economist Wim Duisenberg is elected as the first president of the European Central Bank.
The European Central Bank is founded in Brussels in order to define and execute the EU's monetary policy.
124th Kentucky Derby: Kent Desormeaux aboard Real Quiet wins in 2:02.4.
The European Central Bank is founded in Brussels in order to define and execute the EU's monetary policy.
Astronaut Buzz Aldrin and Buzz Lightyear attend the re-opening of the Moonliner attraction in Disneyland, California. The original Moonliner was removed in 1966.
A federal judge in Sacramento, California, gives "Unabomber" Theodore Kaczynski four life sentences plus 30 years after Kaczynski accepted a plea agreement sparing him from the death penalty.
Apple Computer introduces the iMac computer, with 233 MHz PowerPC G3 processor, 32 MB RAM, 4 GB hard drive, 15-inch monitor, for US$1300.
Swiss Guard Alois Estermann, his wife Gladys Meza Romero, and a Swiss Guard corporal, CTdric Tornay, were found dead in Estermann's quarters in the Vatican.
Mercedes-Benz buys Chrysler for US$40 billion and forms DaimlerChrysler in the largest industrial merger in history.
Dana International, a singer from Israel, wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1998 in Birmingham, United Kingdom.
India conducts three underground nuclear tests in Pokhran, including one thermonuclear device.
Nuclear testing: In the Rajasthan Desert, India conducts its first underground nuclear tests and prompting its rival neighbor Pakistan to test its own nuclear weapons).
An election is held in the Philippines where actor Joseph Estrada emerged as winner for President.
India carries out two more nuclear tests at Pokhran. The United States and Japan impose economic sanctions on India.

(to May 14) Riots directed against Chinese Indonesians break out in Indonesia. Indonesian natives destroy and burn Chinese Indonesian-owned properties and kill and rape more than 1,000 Chinese Indonesians.
India carries out two more nuclear tests at Pokharan in Rajasthan.
Following India's second round of nuclear tests the United States and Japan impose economic sanctions.

The finale of Seinfeld airs on NBC, with 76 million viewers tuning in to watch Jerry Seinfeld, George Costanza, Elaine Benes, and Cosmo Kramer stand trial in the fictional Lathem, Massachusetts for breaking the Good Samaritan Law.
UNSCOM learns that an Iraqi delegation has travelled to Bucharest, to meet with scientists who can provide the country with missile guidance systems.

First Global Street Party, with events in Czech Republic, Netherlands, Finland, Germany, USA, Australia, Canada, Switzerland, England. Total of 30 Reclaim The Streets events are held in 20 countries, on sections of public roads, by hundreds or thousands of people.
124th Preakness: Kent Desormeaux on Real Quiet wins in 1:54.8.

The US Department of Justice and twenty state attorneys general file a lawsuit against Microsoft, charging the company with violations of the Sherman Act: exclusive dealing and unlawful tying, monopoly maintenance in the operating system market, and attempted monopoly of the browser market.
United States v. Microsoft: The United States Department of Justice and 20 U.S. states file an antitrust case against Microsoft.
(to September 30) Expo 1998 is held in Lisbon, Portugal, with the title "Oceans, an Heritage for the Future".

At Thurston High School in Springfield, Oregon, Kipland Kinkel (who was suspended for bringing a gun to school) shoots a semi-automatic rifle into a room filled with students, killing two and wounding 25 others, after killing his parents at home.

Suharto resigns after 32 years as President of Indonesia and his 7th consecutive re-election by the Indonesian Parliament (MPR). Suharto's hand-picked Vice President, B. J. Habibie, becomes Indonesia's third president.

At Thurston High School in Springfield, Oregon, Kipland Kinkel, suspended for bringing a gun to school, shoots a semi-automatic rifle into a room filled with students, killing 2 wounding 25 others after killing his parents at home.
Reproductive rights: In Miami, Florida, five abortion clinics are hit by a butyric acid attacker.
In Central Bolivia, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. At least 105 people killed and 150 injured. Eighty percent of the buildings at Aiquile and seventy percent at Totora destroyed.
A federal judge rules that United States Secret Service agents can be compelled to testify before a grand jury concerning the Lewinsky-Clinton scandal.
DisneyQuest opens at Downtown Disney West Side in Walt Disney World in Florida. It provides five stories of high-tech attractions, including Explore Zone, Create Zone, and Replay Zone.
The Rocket Rods attraction opens in Tomorrowland at Disneyland, California. It occupies the old PeopleMover track.
Tomorrowland at Disneyland in California re-opens after extensive remodelling.
Murray Gleeson is appointed Chief Justice of Australia, succeeding Sir Gerard Brennan.
Lewinsky scandal: A federal judge rules that United States Secret Service agents can be compelled to testify before a grand jury concerning the scandal, involving President Bill Clinton.
The Good Friday Agreement is accepted in a referendum, with a high margin of three-fourth 'yes' votes to Northern Ireland.
In Indianapolis, Indiana, the Indianapolis 500 race is held. Eddie Cheever Jr. wins with an average speed of 145.155 mph. A 1998 Corvette is official pace car, driven by Parnelli Jones.
At 23 years of age, Bear Grylls became the youngest British climber to scale the top of Mount Everest and back down.
Oklahoma City bombing: Michael Fortier is sentenced to 12 years in prison and fined $200,000 for failing to warn authorities about the terrorist plot.
Oklahoma City bombing: Michael Fortier is sentenced to 12 years in prison and fined $200,000 for failing to warn authorities about the terrorist plot.

In response to a series of Indian nuclear tests, Pakistan explodes five nuclear devices of its own in the Chaghai hills of Baluchistan, prompting the United States, Japan and other nations to impose economic sanctions.
In Southern Xinjiang, China, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake occurs. Twenty-eight people injured, more than 2,000 buildings destroyed, an additional 3,000 damaged.
Nuclear testing: Pakistan responds to a series of Indian nuclear tests with five of its own, prompting the United States, Japan, and other nations to impose economic sanctions.
Pakistan conducts a second nuclear explosion following its first test.
In the Afghanistan - Tajikistan border region, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. At least 4,000 people killed, many thousands injured and homeless.
A 6.6 magnitude earthquake hits northern Afghanistan, killing up to 5,000.
California voters approve Proposition 227, abolishing the state's bilingual education program.
The CIH virus is discovered in Taiwan.
The CIH computer virus is discovered in Taiwan.

An InterCityExpress high speed train derails between Hannover and Hamburg, Germany, causing 101 deaths. The train, ICE 884 "Wilhelm Conrad Rntgen", was traveling at 200 kilometres per hour when it derailed and crashed into a bridge.
Eschede train disaster: an ICE high speed train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, causing 101 deaths.
Terry Nichols is sentenced to life in prison for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing.
Terry Nichols is sentenced to life in prison for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing.
A strike begins at the General Motors Corporation parts factory in Flint, Michigan.
A strike begins at the General Motors parts factory in Flint, Michigan, that quickly spreads to five other assembly plants (the strike lasted seven weeks).
Three white supremacists murder James Byrd Jr. in Jasper, Texas.
James Byrd, Jr is dragged to death by Shawn Allen Berry, Lawrence Russel Brewer, and John William King in Jasper, Texas in a racially-motivated hate crime.
Actor Charlton Heston becomes president of the National Rifle Association.
President Sani Abacha of Nigeria dies of apparent heart failure.
Charlton Heston assumes the presidency of the U.S. National Rifle Association.
The 1998 FIFA World Cup begins in France.
Compaq Computer pays $9 billion for Digital Equipment Corporation in largest high-tech acquisition.
A jury in Hattiesburg, Mississippi, convicts 17-year-old Luke Woodham of killing two students and wounding 7 others at Pearl High School.
The Philippines celebrates its centennial year of Independence from Spain.
In Portales, New Mexico, USA a meteorite penetrates a barn roof.
The Chicago Bulls win their 6th NBA title in 8 years when they beat the Utah Jazz, 87-86 in Game Six. This is also Michael Jordan's last game as a Chicago Bulls player.
The Detroit Red Wings sweep the Washington Capitals in four games in the 1998 NHL Stanley Cup Finals.
The United States Supreme Court rules that the Line Item Veto Act of 1996 is unconstitutional.
In Clinton v. City of New York, the United States Supreme Court decides that the Line Item Veto Act of 1996 is unconstitutional.

In Turkey, a magnitude 6.3 earthquake occurs. At least 145 people killed and more than 1,500 injured. At least six major buildings collapsed and about 17,000 houses destroyed. Felt in Cyprus, Israel and Syria.
German author Sibylle Lewitscharoff receives the Ingeborg Bachmann Prize for literature.
Opening of the Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia.
Japan launches a probe to Mars, joining the United States and Russia as an outer space-exploring nation.
Japan launches a probe to Mars, and thus joins the United States and Russia as a space exploring nation.
The new Hong Kong International Airport at Chek Lap Kok opens.
In the Azores Islands, a magnitude 6.2 earthquake occurs. Ten people killed, about 100 injured and 1,000 left homeless.
The DNA-identified remains of United States Air Force 1st Lieutenant Michael Joseph Blassie arrive home to his family in St. Louis, Missouri, after being in the Tomb of the Unknowns since 1984.

The remains of United States Air Force 1st Lt. Michael Joseph Blassie are returned to his family in St. Louis, Missouri from the Tomb of the Unknowns upon identification through DNA analysis. The remains had been in the first tomb since 1984.
Roman Catholic sex abuse cases: The Diocese of Dallas agrees to pay $23.4 million to nine former altar boys who claimed they were sexually abused by former priest Rudolph Kos.
In Kitchener, Ontario, Canada a meteorite falls harmlessly to the ground.
France defeats Brazil 3-0 to win the 1998 FIFA World Cup.

In Papua New Guinea, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurs, generating a tsunami up to 10 metres in height. At least 2,183 people killed, thousands injured, about 9,500 homeless. Several villages were completely destroyed and others extensively damaged.
In Saint Petersburg, Nicholas II of Russia and his family are buried in St. Catherine Chapel, 80 years after he and his family were killed by Bolsheviks.
At a conference in Rome, 120 countries vote to create a permanent International Criminal Court to prosecute individuals for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression.
In St. Petersburg, Nicholas II of Russia and his family are buried in St. Catherine Chapel 80 years after he and his family were killed by Bolsheviks.
A tsunami triggered by an undersea earthquake destroys 10 villages in Papua New Guinea killing an estimated 1,500, leaving 2,000 more unaccounted for and thousands more homeless.
Biologists report in the journal Science how they sequenced the genome of the bacterium that causes syphilis, Treponema pallidum.
A 23-foot tidal wave kills nearly 3,000 people in Papua New Guinea.\
Two hundred aid workers from CARE International, Doctors Without Borders and other aid groups leave Afghanistan on orders of the Taliban.
Russell Eugene Weston Jr. bursts into the United States Capitol and opens fire, killing two police officers. He is later ruled incompetent to stand trial.
Russel Eugene Weston Jr. bursts into the United States Capitol and opens fire killing two police officers. He is later ruled to be incompetent to stand trial.
63 are sickened and four killed by arsenic in a festival in the town in Wakayama Prefecture in Japan; Masumi Hayashi is arrested for murder.
The United States Navy commissions the aircraft carrier USS Harry S. Truman and puts her into service.
Monica Lewinsky scandal: Ex-White House intern, Monica Lewinsky receives transactional immunity in exchange for her grand jury testimony concerning her relationship with US President Bill Clinton.
The United Kingdom bans the importation of land mines.
Near the coast of Ecuador, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs. Few deaths and injuries, but widespread damage.
Iraq officially suspends all cooperation with UNSCOM teams.

The bombings of the United States embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya kill 224 people and injure over 4,500; they are linked to terrorist Osama Bin Laden, an exile of Saudi Arabia.

In China the Yangtze River breaks through the main bank, following breaches of periphery levees in Jiayu County Baizhou Bay in recent days. The death toll exceeds 12,000, with many thousands more injured.
1998 U.S. embassy bombings: Bombing of the United States embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya, kill 224 people and injure over 4,500.
In Myanmar, a popular uprising against military rule is staged.
Gary C. Evans, infamous in New York's Capital Region for killing five people, escapes police custody and kills himself by jumping off a bridge.
Apple Computer begins shipping the iMac to retail outlets in the US. Price is US$1299. 278,000 units are shipped in the first six weeks.
The Real Irish Republican Army detonates a car bomb in Omagh, County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, killing 29 and injuring over 200.
Omagh bomb in Northern Ireland, becoming the worst terrorist incident of The Troubles
Silk-Miller police murders: Australian police officers are murdered in Moorabbin, Victoria.
US President Bill Clinton testifies before a grand jury, acknowledging that he had had an extramarital affair with Monica Lewinsky.

Monica Lewinsky scandal: US President Bill Clinton admits in taped testimony that he had an "improper physical relationship" with White House intern Monica Lewinsky. On the same day he admits before the nation that he "misled people" about his relationship.

On the day of his 52nd birthday, U.S. President Bill Clinton admits in taped testimony that he had an "improper physical relationship" with White House intern Monica Lewinsky. He also admits before the nation that night in a nationally televised address that he "misled people" about his sexual affair with Lewinsky.
Russia defaults on the state short-term bonds, and devalues the ruble.

The United States military launches cruise missile attacks against alleged Al-Qaeda camps in Afghanistan and a suspected chemical plant in Sudan in retaliation for the August 7 bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The al-Shifa pharmaceutical factory in Khartoum is destroyed in the attack.
The Supreme Court of Canada states Quebec cannot legally secede from Canada without the federal government's approval.
The Supreme Court of Canada states Quebec cannot legally secede from Canada without the federal government's approval.

U.S. embassy bombings: The United States military launches cruise missile attacks against alleged al-Qaida camps in Afghanistan and a suspected chemical plant in Sudan in retaliation for the August 7 bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The al-Shifa pharmaceutical factory in Khartoum is destroyed in the attack.
The United States destroys a pharmaceutical plant (erroneously believed to be a chemical weapons plant) in Sudan.
The Netherlands is selected as the site for the trial of the two Libyan suspects of the 1988 PanAm bombing.

Scott Ritter resigns from UNSCOM, sharply criticizing the President Bill Clinton administration and the U.N. Security Council for not being vigorous enough about insisting that Iraq's weapons of mass destruction be destroyed. Ritter tells reporters that "Iraq is not disarming," "Iraq retains the capability to launch a chemical strike."
Pakistan's National Assembly passes a constitutional amendment to make the "Qur'an and Sunnah" the "supreme law" but the bill is defeated in the Senate.
North Korea reportedly launches Kwangmyongsong, its first satellite. Although North Korea reports that it reached stable orbit, NORAD is not able to confirm this assertion.
North Korea reportedly launchs Kwangmyongsong, its first satellite.
In Canada, pilots for Air Canada launch the first strike in the company's history.
A McDonnell Douglas MD-11 airliner carrying Swissair Flight 111 crashes near Peggys Cove, Nova Scotia, after taking off from New York City en-route to Geneva. All 229 people on board are killed.
A United Nations court finds Jean-Paul Akayesu, the former mayor of a small town in Rwanda, guilty of nine counts of genocide, marking the first time that the 1948 law banning genocide is enforced.
In Canada, pilots for Air Canada launch the first strike in company's history.
The UN's International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda finds Jean-Paul Akayesu, the former mayor of a small town in Rwanda, guilty of nine counts of genocide.
Swissair Flight 111 crashes near Peggys Cove, Nova Scotia. All 229 people on board are killed.
In Somalia, the southern port of Kismayo is declared the capital of independent Jubaland under Muhamed Said Hersi.
Larry Page and Sergey Brin, two students at Stanford University in California, found Google.
Google, Inc. is founded, in Menlo Park, California, by Stanford University Ph.D. candidates Larry Page and Sergey Brin.

Saint Louis Cardinals' first baseman Mark McGwire breaks Major League Baseball's single-season home-run record, formerly held by Roger Maris. McGwire hits number 62 at Busch Stadium in the fourth inning off of Chicago Cubs' pitcher Steve Trachsel.
At Busch Stadium in St. Louis, Missouri, Mark McGwire breaks Roger Maris' 1961 record of 61 home runs hit in a single season.
The United Nations General Assembly elects Didier Opertiri of Uruguay as president for its 53rd session.
A coroner records a verdict of suicide on former football player Justin Fashanu, who was found hanged in a London lock-up garage four months ago.
Kenneth Starr submits his report and 18 boxes of supporting documents to the House of Representatives, outlining a case for impeaching Clinton on 11 grounds.
Opening ceremony for the 1998 Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Malaysia was the first Asian country to host the games.
Independent counsel Kenneth Starr sends a report to the U.S. Congress accusing President Bill Clinton of 11 possible impeachable offenses.
Yevgeny Primakov is appointed Prime Minister of Russia.

At the end of the day's stock market trading Microsoft stands as America's most valuable company, at US$261.1 billion. Microsoft and General Electric were both valued at over US$300 billion in July, but Microsoft survived a stock market plunge better, putting it on top.
The GSPC is formed in Algeria, splitting off from the GIA over its policy of massacring civilians.
Telecommunications companies MCI Communications and WorldCom complete their $37 billion merger to form MCI WorldCom.
Telecommunications companies MCI Communications and WorldCom complete their $37 billion merger to form MCI WorldCom.
WorldCom and MCI Communications finish their landmark merger, forming MCI WorldCom which would later be renamed WorldCom and become the largest bankruptcy in United States history.
The Food and Drug Administration approves a once-a-day easier-to-swallow medication for AIDS patients.
Baseball: After playing 2,632 consecutive games for the Baltimore Orioles, Cal Ripken, Jr takes a day off.

(to September 28) Major creditors of Long-Term Capital Management, a Greenwich, Connecticut-based hedge fund, after days of tough bargaining and some informal mediation by Federal Reserve officials, agree on terms of a re-capitalization.
Sammy Sosa hits homerun number 66 to take the lead in the Major League Baseball homerun race. Less than an hour later Mark McGwire also hits his 66th.
The Adelaide Crows defeat the North Melbourne Kangaroos in the AFL Grand Final to become the first club to win back-to-back premierships since the VFL became the AFL in 1990.
Germany holds parliamentary elections. A new coalition government is formed by the SPD (40.9 percent), and Buendnis 90/The Greens (6.7 percent) with leader Gerhard Schrder.
In the season finale, Mark McGwire ends the historic Major League Baseball season hitting his 69th and 70th home runs in the Saint Louis Cardinals' 6-3 win over the Montreal Expos.
The U.S. Congress passes the "Iraq Liberation Act", which states that the United States wants to remove Saddam Hussein from power and replace the government with a democratic institution.
Sky Digital television service launches in the United Kingdom.
In Australia, John Howard's coalition government is re-elected for a second term.
Leafie Mason of Hughes Springs, Texas, is murdered by ngel Maturino ResTndiz. She is the serial killer's second victim.
Gay-bashing: Near Laramie, Wyoming, University of Wyoming student Matthew Shepard is viciously attacked by two assailants for being gay (he died on October 12).

The United States Congress passes the Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act, which gives copyright holders 20 more years of copyright privilege on work they control. This effectively freezes the public domain to works created before 1923 in the United States.
The Buzz Lightyear's Space Ranger Spin attraction opens in the Magic Kingdom Park at Walt Disney World in Florida.
Oslo's Fornebu Airport closes in Norway.
The House of Representatives authorizes an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton.
Edith Stein is canonized a saint by Pope John-Paul II.
A Congo Airlines Boeing 727 is shot down by rebels in Kindu, Democratic Republic of the Congo, killing 40
The Congress of the United States passes the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.
U.S. Congress passes Digital Millennium Copyright Act
Eric Robert Rudolph is charged with six bombings (including the 1996 Olympic bombing) in Atlanta, Georgia.
Eric Robert Rudolph is charged with 6 bombings including the 1996 Centennial Olympic Park bombing in Atlanta, Georgia.
American Airlines becomes the first airline to offer electronic ticketing in all 44 countries it serves.
British police place General Augusto Pinochet under house arrest during his medical treatment in the United Kingdom.
Elfriede Jelinek, a feminist writer in Austria, is presented with the Bnchner-Prize from the German Academy for Language and Literature (Deutsche Akademie fnr Sprache und Dichtung).
(to October 18) Severe flooding takes place in south Central Texas.
Travelers Group changes its company name to Citigroup Incorporated.
The Earth Liberation Front sets fire to the Vail Mountain ski resort in Vail, Colorado, causing $12 million in damage.

The New York Yankees defeat the San Diego Padres to sweep them in the baseball World Series. The Yankees had a magical season with 114 regular-season wins and 11 postseason victories (125 total - the most by any team in 123 years of Major League Baseball).

In Japan, Nintendo releases the Game Boy Color portable video game system. It features 2.1 MHz processor, and 32 kB RAM. It can display 56 colors simultaneously from a palette of 32,000. Size is 3 x 5.25 x 1 inches; weight is 6.7 ounces.
Abortion in the United States: In Amherst, New York, abortion doctor Barnett Slepian is killed in his home by a sniper.
Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian Chairman Yasser Arafat reach a "land-for-peace" agreement.
Launch of Deep Space 1 comet/asteroid mission
Catcher Mike Piazza signs the most lucrative contract in Major League Baseball history: over US$91 million for a seven-year deal.
Last day in office of Helmut Kohl as German Chancellor, ending his 16 years in office.
New German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and his liberal SPD-Green Coalition take office.
Gerhard Schröder becomes Chancellor of Germany for the first time.
An Air China jetliner is hijacked by disgruntled pilot Yuan Bin and flown to Taiwan. After landing the plane safely, Yuan Bin is arrested.
An Air China jetliner is hijacked by disgruntled pilot Yuan Bin and flown to Taiwan.
Hurricane Mitch makes landfall in Central America, killing an estimated 18,000 people.
In Gothenburg, Sweden, two arsonists burn down a local Macedonian Society disco, killing 63 and injuring 200, most of them children of refugees.
In South Africa, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission presents its report, which condemns both sides for committing atrocities.

While en route from Adana to Ankara, a Turkish Airlines flight with a crew of 6 and 33 passengers is hijacked by a Kurdish militant, who orders the pilot to fly to Switzerland. The plane instead lands in Ankara after the pilot tricks the hijacker into thinking that he was landing in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia to refuel.
Space Shuttle Discovery blasts-off with 77-year old John Glenn on board, making him the oldest person to go into space. He became the first American to orbit Earth on February 20, 1962.
Apartheid: In South Africa, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission presents its report, which condemns both sides for committing atrocities.
Hurricane Mitch made landfall in Honduras.

In Freehold Borough, New Jersey, Melissa Drexler pleads guilty to aggravated manslaughter for killing her baby moments after delivering him in the bathroom at her senior prom, and is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment.

While en route from Adana to Ankara, a Turkish Airlines flight with a crew of 6 and 33 passengers is hijacked by a Kurdish militant who orders the pilot to fly to Switzerland. The plane instead lands in Ankara after the pilot tricked the hijacker into thinking that he was landing in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia to refuel.
Iraq announces it will no longer cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors.
Iraq disarmament crisis begins: Iraq announces it would no longer cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors.
The European Court of Human Rights is instituted.
The European Court of Human Rights is instituted.
WWF hardcore title awarded to Mankind
Jesse Ventura, former professional wrestler, is elected Governor of Minnesota.
Edmonton, Canada and Wonju, South Korea are declared sister cities.
Former professional wrestler Jesse Ventura is elected Governor of the U.S. state of Minnesota.
Lewinsky scandal: As part of the impeachment inquiry, House Judiciary Committee chairman Henry Hyde sends a list of 81 questions to US President Bill Clinton.
The journal Nature publishes a genetic study showing compelling evidence that Thomas Jefferson fathered a son, Eston Hemings Jefferson, by his slave Sally Hemings.
Hugo Chvez is elected president of Venezuela
John Glenn returns to Earth aboard the Space Shuttle Discovery.
United Kingdom formally abolishes the death penalty.

In the largest civil settlement in United States history, a federal judge approves a US$1.03 billion settlement requiring dozens of brokerage houses (including Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs, and Salomon Smith Barney) to pay investors who claim they were cheated in a wide-spread price-fixing scheme on the NASDAQ.
Brokerage houses are ordered to pay US$1.03 billion to cheated NASDAQ investors to compensate for their price-fixing. This is the largest civil settlement in United States history.
Daimler-Benz completes a merger with Chrysler Corporation to form Daimler-Chrysler.
Daimler-Benz completes a merger with Chrysler to form Daimler-Chrysler.
(to November 14) U.S. President Bill Clinton orders airstrikes on Iraq, then calls them off at the last minute when Iraq promises once again to "unconditionally" cooperate with UNSCOM.
In Southern Iran, a magnitude 5.4 earthquake occurs. Five people killed, 105 injured and at least 850 houses damaged by the earthquake and landslides.
The ball hit by Babe Ruth for his first home run hit in Yankee Stadium is sold at an auction for US126,500 (US$110,000 bid + 15 percent commission).
The United State House of Representatives' Judiciary Committee begins impeachment hearings against U.S. President Bill Clinton.
Galina Starovoitova, Russian legislator and democracy advocate, is assassinated in St. Petersburg, Russia.
The first module of the International Space Station, Zarya, is launched.
A court in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan declares accused terrorist Osama bin Laden "a man without a sin" in regard to the 1998 U.S. embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.
The first module of the International Space Station, Zarya, was launched.
A court in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan declares accused terrorist Osama bin Laden "a man without a sin" in regard to the 1998 U.S. embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.
In HyvinkSS, Finland, satanists Jarno Elg, Terhi Tervashonka and Mika Riska murder, cut up, and partly eat a 23-year-old man.
According to UNSCOM, Iraq once again ends cooperation with the United Nations inspectors, alternately intimidating and withholding information from them.
Nintendo releases the Game Boy Color handheld video game system in the USA. Price is US$79.95.
America Online announces an agreement to acquire Netscape Communications for US$4.2 billion in stock.
America Online announces it will acquire Netscape Communications in a stock-for-stock transaction worth US$4.2 billion.
Japan-China Joint Declaration On Building a Partnership of Friendship and Cooperation for Peace and Development.
Tony Blair becomes the first Prime Minister of the United Kingdom to address the Dil +ireann, the Republic of Ireland's parliament.
Tony Blair becomes the first Prime Minister of the United Kingdom to address the Republic of Ireland's parliament.

In Japan, Sega Enterprises releases the Dreamcast video game system. It features a 200 MHz 128-bit Hitachi SH-4 processor, special NEC graphics processing chip, built-in 56 kbps modem, Web browser, one controller, and CD-ROM drive for 1 GB capacity disks. Price is 29,800 Yen, about US$220. 101,490 units sell in the first week. About 10 million systems and 400 different games are shipped in the product's lifetime.
In the Ceram Sea, a magnitude 7.7 earthquake occurs.
Deutsche Bank announces a US$10 billion deal to buy Bankers Trust, thus creating the largest financial institution in the world.
Deutsche Bank announces a $10 billion deal to buy Bankers Trust, thus creating the largest financial institution in the world.
Rafael Palmeiro signs a five-year US$45 million contract with the Texas Rangers.
Exxon announces a US$73.7 billion deal to buy Mobil, thus creating Exxon-Mobil, the second-largest company on the planet by revenue.
Exxon announces a US$73.7 billion deal to buy Mobil, thus creating Exxon-Mobil, the largest company on the planet.
The second (Unity) module of the International Space Station is launched.
Unity, the second module of the International Space Station, is launched.
D.C. United defeats Vasco da Gama 2 - 1 on aggregate to win the Interamerican Cup (one of the greatest triumphs in the history of U.S. club soccer).
Hugo Chvez Fr?as, former member of the Venezuelan military and politician, is elected President of Venezuela.
Tadjena massacre in Algeria: 81 villagers are killed.
Tadjena massacre: 81 people are killed by armed groups in Algeria.
In Hindu Kush region, Afghanistan, a magnitude 5.7 earthquake occurs.
Iraq announces that United Nations weapons inspections will no longer take place on Friday, the Muslim day of rest. Iraq also refuses to provide test data from the production of missiles and engines.
The House Judiciary Committee approves three articles of impeachment against President Bill Clinton.
A Thai Airways Airbus A310-200 crashes near Surat Thani Airport, killing 101.
Pitcher Kevin Brown becomes baseball's first US$100+ million dollar man as he signs a seven-year deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers for US$105 million.
U.S. President Bill Clinton orders American and British airstrikes on Iraq. UNSCOM withdraws all weapons inspectors from Iraq.
Iraq disarmament crisis: Operation Desert Fox - The United States and United Kingdom bomb targets in Iraq.
Claudia Benton, of West University Place, Texas, is murdered in her house by Angel Maturino Resendiz (his third victim in his third incident).
Iraqi Vice-President Taha Yassin Ramadan announces that Iraq will no longer cooperate and declares that UNSCOM's "mission is over."
Mel Fisher, underwater film maker, dies from bladder cancer at age 76.
The US House of Representatives approves two articles of impeachment against President Bill Clinton, charging him with lying under oath to a federal grand jury and obstructing justice.
Lewinsky scandal: The United States House of Representatives forwards articles I and III of impeachment against President Bill Clinton to the Senate.

United Nations Security Council members France, Germany and Russia call for sanctions to end against Iraq. The three Security Council members also call for UNSCOM to either be disbanded or for its role to be recast. The U.S. says it will veto any such proposal.
Iraq announces its intention to fire upon U.S. and British warplanes that patrol the northern and southern "no-fly zones".
Severe gales over Ireland, northern England, and southern Scotland cause widespread disruption and widespread power outages in Northern Ireland and southern Scotland.
Iraq announced its intention to fire upon U.S. and British warplanes that patrol the northern and southern no-fly zones.
Khmer Rouge leaders apologize for the genocide in Cambodia that claimed over one million in the 1970s.
Leaders of the Khmer Rouge apologize for the 1970s genocide in Cambodia that claimed over 1 million.
In the eurozone, the currency rates of this day are fixed permanently.
The first leap second since June 30, 1997 occurs.

The Euro begins to be introduced as the common currency of Belgium, Germany, France, Ireland, Italy, Luxemburg, Holland, Austria, Portugal, Spain and Finland. All non-cash transactions in the Eurozone are now conducted in the common euro currency.

A brutal snowstorm smashes into the Midwestern USA, causing 14 inches (359 mm) of snow at Milwaukee, Wisconsin and 19 inches (487 mm) at Chicago, Illinois. In Chicago, temperatures plunge to -13F (-25C), and 68 deaths are reported.

A brutal snowstorm smashes into the Midwestern United States, causing 14 inches (359 mm) of snow at Milwaukee, Wisconsin and 19 inches (487 mm) at Chicago, Illinois. In Chicago, temperatures plunge to -13 degrees F (-25 degrees C), and 68 deaths are reported.
In Sichuan, China, a magnitude 4.5 earthquake occurs.
Israel detains, later to expel, 14 members of Concerned Christians.
Former professional wrestler Jesse Ventura was sworn in as governor of Minnesota.
Gunmen open fire on Shiite Muslims worshipping in an Islamabad mosque, killing 16 people and injuring 25.
A proposal emailed out across the world led to the International Firefighters' Day institution.
Aluminum Company of America changes its company name to Alcoa Incorporated.
Gunmen open fire on Shiite Muslims worshipping in a mosque in Islamabad, Pakistan, killing 16 people and injuring 25.
For the first time since the 1868 impeachment trial of President Andrew Johnson, the trial of President Clinton begins in the Senate.
The impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton begins.
The Walt Disney World attraction Horizons closes for good.
Setting an all-time record, Mark McGwire's 70th home run ball in one season is purchased at an auction by an anonymous buyer for $3 million.
After 13 years of playing NBA basketball, superstar Michael Jordan announces his second retirement from basketball.
The Racak incident: 45 Albanians in the Kosovo village of Racak were killed by Yugoslav security forces.
The China News Service announces new government restrictions on Internet use aimed especially at Internet cafes.
The China News Service announces new government restrictions on Internet use aimed especially at Internet bars.
In one of the largest drug busts in American history, the United States Coast Guard intercepts a ship with over 9,500 pounds (4.3 t) of cocaine aboard, headed for Houston, Texas.
War on Drugs: In one of the largest drug busts in American history, the United States Coast Guard intercepts a ship with over 9,500 pounds (4,300 kg) of cocaine on board.
Australian missionary Graham Stewart Stains and his two sons are burned alive by radical Hindus while sleeping in their car in Eastern India.
In Colombia, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake occurs. At least 1,185 people killed, over 4,750 injured and about 250,000 homeless. 50-60 percent of buildings destroyed in Armenia, Calarca, and Pereira.
A 6.0 Richter scale earthquake hits western Colombia killing at least 1,000.
NFL Super Bowl XXXIII: Denver Broncos beat Atlanta Falcons in Miami, Florida; Most Valuable Player: John Elway, Denver, Quarterback.
Super Bowl XXXIII: The Denver Broncos defeat the Atlanta Falcons, 34-19. After the game, the TV show Family Guy airs its pilot episode.
North Dakota Public Radio is launched.
In Jammu & Kashmir the political party Democratic Janata Dal (Jammu and Kashmir) is revived.
Unarmed West African immigrant Amadou Diallo is shot dead by New York City police officers on an unrelated stake-out, inflaming race relations in the city.
Unarmed West African immigrant Amadou Diallo is shot dead by four plainclothes New York City police officers on an unrelated stake-out, inflaming race-relations in the city.
Hugo Chvez Frfas, Venezuelan military and politician, is elected President of Venezuela.
King Hussein of Jordan dies from cancer (born 1935), and his son Abdullah II inherits the throne.
Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the King of Jordan on the death of his father, King Hussein.
Avalanches in the French Alps near Geneva kill at least 10.
Avalanches in the French Alps near Geneva kill at least 10.
Pluto moves along its eccentric orbit further from the Sun than Neptune. It had been nearer than Neptune since 1979.
In Afghanistan, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurs. Seventy people killed, 500 injured, at least 14,000 homeless and 7,000 houses destroyed.
Pluto, a planet with an irregular orbit, changes from the eighth to ninth planet furthest from the sun. It had been the eighth furthest since 1979.
The US Senate votes on whether to remove President Bill Clinton from office. The president is acquitted on both articles of impeachment.
President Bill Clinton is acquitted by the United States Senate in his impeachment trial.
Abdullah ÿcalan, leader of the terrorist organization Kurdistan Workers Party, is arrested in Kenya by Turkish agents.
Across Europe, Kurdish rebels take over embassies and hold hostages after Turkey arrests one of their rebel leaders.
In Uzbekistan, an apparent assassination attempt against President Islom Karimov takes place at government headquarters.
In Uzbekistan a bomb explodes and gunfire is heard at the government headquarters in an apparent assassination attempt against President Islam Karimov.
Across Europe, Kurdish rebels take over embassies and hold hostages after Turkey arrested one of their rebel leaders, Abdullah ÿcalan.
Dennis Franz receives a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
Moderate Iraqi Shiite cleric Mohammad Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr is assassinated.
An avalanche destroys the village of Galtnr, Austria, killing 31.
Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah +calan is charged with treason in Ankara, Turkey.
Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah ÿcalan is charged with treason in Ankara, Turkey.
An avalanche destroys the Austrian village of Galtür, killing 31.
A China Southern Airlines Tupolev TU-154 airliner crashes on approach to Wenzhou airport in eastern China, killing 61.
The State of Arizona executes Karl LaGrand, a German national involved in an armed robbery, in spite of Germany's legal action to attempt to save him.
Intel announces the 500 MHz Pentium III processor. The processor introduces 70 new Streaming SIMD Extensions (SSE).
While trying to circumnavigate the world in a hot air balloon, Colin Prescot and Andy Elson set a new endurance record after being in a hot air balloon for 233 hours and 55 minutes.
While trying to circumnavigate the world in a hot air balloon, Colin Prescot and Andy Elson set a new endurance record after being in a hot air balloon for 233 hours and 55 minutes.
Olusegun Obasanjo becomes Nigeria's first elected president since mid-1983.
Rwandan Hutu rebels kill and hack to pieces eight foreign tourists at the Buhoma homestead, Uganda.
The Convention on the Prohibition of Anti-Personnel Mines comes into force.
One of four bombs detonated in Lusaka, Zambia, destroys the Angolan Embassy.
Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones begin their attempt to circumnavigate the world in a hot air balloon without stopping.
Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones begin their successful attempt to circumnavigate the world in a hot air balloon without stopping.
LaGrand case: The State of Arizona executes Walter LaGrand, a German despite German legal action in the International Court of Justice.

In a military court, United States Marine Corps Captain Richard Ashby is acquitted of the charge of reckless flying which resulted in the deaths of 20 skiers in the Italian Alps, when his low-flying jet hit a gondola cable.

In a military court, Captain Richard Ashby of the United States Marines is acquitted of the charge of reckless flying which resulted in the deaths of 20 skiers in the Italian Alps when his low-flying jet hit a gondola cable.
Paul Okalik is elected first Premier of Nunavut.
Oklahoma City bombing: The Supreme Court of the United States upholds the murder convictions of Timothy McVeigh.
Infosys becomes the first Indian company listed on the NASDAQ stock exchange.
Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic join NATO.
Former Warsaw Pact members the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland join NATO.
In Brussels, Belgium, the Santer Commission resigns over allegations of corruption.
In Germany, the Krupp and Thyssen Companies (steel) complete their merger.
Serbs launch an offensive in Kosovo.
Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones become the first to circumnavigate the Earth in a hot air balloon.
Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones become the first to circumnavigate the Earth in a hot air balloon.
U.S. pro-euthanasia doctor Jack Kevorkian goes on trial for murder in Pontiac, Michigan.
Gunmen assassinate Paraguay's Vice President Luis Mar?a Argaa.
Gunmen assassinate Paraguay's Vice President Luis Marfa Argaña.
Fire in the Mont Blanc Tunnel kills 39 people, closing the tunnel for nearly three years.
NATO launches air strikes against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, which refused to sign a peace treaty. This marks the first time NATO attacked a sovereign country.
Kosovo War: NATO commences air bombardment against Yugoslavia, marking the first time NATO has attacked a sovereign country.
Enron energy traders allegedly route 2,900 megawatts of electricity destined for California to the town of Silver Peak, Nevada, population 200.
Enron energy traders allegedly route 2,900 megawatts of electricity destined to California to Silver Peak, Nevada, population 200.
A Michigan jury finds Dr. Jack Kevorkian guilty of second-degree murder for administering a lethal injection to a terminally ill man.

The computer virus "Melissa" attacks about 250,000 PCs worldwide in about three days, using Microsoft Outlook to mail the virus to email addresses in the address book. This is the first virus capable of jumping from computer to computer on its own.
A jury in Michigan finds Dr. Jack Kevorkian guilty of second-degree murder for administering a lethal injection to a terminally ill man.
The "Melissa worm" infects e-mail systems around the world.
Kosovo War: A U.S. F-117 Nighthawk is shot down by Serbian forces.
18th NCAA Women's Basketball Championship: Purdue beats Duke 62-45 in San Jose California.
In the Xizang-India border region, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs. At least 100 people killed and 394 injured, over 21,100 houses destroyed.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 10,000 (10,006.78) for the first time.
UConn defeats Duke 77-74, for the 61st NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 10006.78 ? above the 10,000 mark for the first time ever.
The Matrix, first episode of the Matrix trilogy movies, is released in theaters.
Nunavut, an Inuit homeland, is created from the eastern portion of the Northwest Territories to become Canada's third territory.
Nunavut is established as a Canadian territory carved from the eastern part of the Northwest Territories.
Two Libyans suspected of bringing down Pan Am flight 103 in 1988 are handed over to Scottish authorities for eventual trial in the Netherlands. The United Nations suspends sanctions against Libya.
Two Libyans suspected of bringing down Pan Am flight 103 in 1988 are handed over for eventual trial in the Netherlands.
Kosovo's main border crossings are closed by Serbian forces to prevent ethnic Albanians from leaving.
A bomb explodes at the Valley of the Fallen Church in Spain; GRAPO claims responsibility.
In China, a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurs. Also felt in southern Hokkaido, northern Honshu and at Tokyo, Japan.
Haryana Gana Parishad, a political party in the Indian state of Haryana, merges with the Indian National Congress.
Ibrahim BarT Ma?nassara, president of Niger, is assassinated.
Ismail Omar Guelleh is elected president of Djibouti.
Ibrahim BarT Maïnassara, President of Niger, is assassinated.

American President Bill Clinton was cited for contempt of court by federal district judge Susan Webber Wright for giving "intentionally false statements" in sworn testimony during his deposition in the Paula Jones sexual harassment civil lawsuit. Clinton was fined $90,000.[1]

The official move of the German federal government begins as the first trucks with documents from the ministries of the interior and economics leave Bonn on the way to the new seat of government in Berlin.
A nail bomb explodes in the middle of a busy market in Brixton, South London.
The Great One Wayne Gretzky plays his final National Hockey League game.

The US Navy kills a civilian guard in the Naval Base at Vieques, an island east of Puerto Rico which the Navy has used since 1943. The death of the civilian officer sparks off a civil disobedience campaign throughout the island of Puerto Rico to protest the presence of the Navy on the island.
The German Bundestag returns to Berlin.
Two Littleton, Colorado teenagers, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, open fire on their Columbine High School teachers and classmates, killing 12 students and one teacher, and then themselves.
Largest bombing of Kosovo by the United States in the Kosovo War.
Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold kill 12 students and a teacher before killing themselves in the Columbine High School massacre.
The term of Tuanku Jaafar ibni Almarhum Tuanku Abdul Rahman as the 10th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia ends.
Sultan Salahuddin Abdul Aziz Shah ibni Almarhum Sultan Hisamuddin Alam Shah Al-Haj, Sultan of Selangor, becomes the 11th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia.
British TV presenter Jill Dando, age 37, is shot dead on the doorstep of her home in Fulham, London.

A third nail bomb explodes in the Admiral Duncan pub in Old Compton Street, Soho, London, killing a pregnant woman and two friends and injuring 70 others, including the woman's husband. This is part of a hate campaign against ethnic minorities and gay people by David Copeland.
Cambodia joins the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), bringing the total members to ten.
Cambodia joins the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) bringing the total members to 10.
125th Kentucky Derby: Chris Antley aboard Charismatic wins in 2:03.2.
Norman J. Sirnic and Karen Sirnic are murdered by the serial killer Angel Maturino Resendiz in a parsonage in Weimar, Texas (his fourth and fifth victims in his fourth slaying incident).
Panamanian election: Mireya Moscoso became the first woman to be elected President of Panama.
A Force 5 tornado slams into Moore, Oklahoma, killing 38 people - the second strongest tornado ever recorded in United States history.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 11,000 (11,014.70) for the first time.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 11,000 for the first time in its history at 11,014.70.
Oklahoma City is slammed by an F5 tornado killing 42 poeople, injuring 665, and causing $1 billion in damage. The tornado was one of 66 from the Oklahoma Tornado Outbreak.
In California, Manuel Babbitt is executed for the 1980 murder of Leah Schendel. While on death row Babbitt was awarded a Purple Heart for injuries he received in the Vietnam War.
In Southern Iran, a magnitude 6.2 earthquake occurs. At least 26 people killed, 100 injured and 800 houses destroyed.
Elections are held in Scotland and Wales for the new Scottish Parliament and National Assembly for Wales.
In Guinea-Bissau, President Jo?o Bernardo Vieira is ousted in a military coup.
The Cleveland Indians score 18 runs in the final three innings to overcome a 9-1 deficit to beat the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, 20-11.
In the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, three Chinese embassy workers are killed and 20 wounded, when a NATO aircraft mistakenly bombs the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
Kosovo War: In Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, three Chinese embassy workers are killed and 20 wounded when a NATO aircraft mistakenly bombs the Chinese embassy in Belgrade.

A jury finds The Jenny Jones Show and Warner Bros. liable in the shooting death of Scott Amedure, after the show purposely deceived Jonathan Schmitz to appear on a secret same-sex crush episode. Schmitz later killed Amedure and the jury awarded Amedure's family US$25 million.
Pope John Paul II travels to Romania becoming the first pope that had visited a predominantly Eastern Orthodox country since the Great Schism in 1054.
In Guinea-Bissau, President João Bernardo Vieira is ousted in a military coup.
Jimmy Glass scores the goal that keeps Carlisle United in the Football League.
Nancy Mace becomes the first female cadet to graduate from The Military College of South Carolina.
Goalkeeper Jimmy Glass saved Carlisle United from certain death when he scored last minuite goal against Plymouth Argyle and relegate Scarborough FC instead
Nancy Mace becomes the first female cadet to graduate from The Citadel military college.
David Steel becomes the first Presiding Officer (Speaker) of the modern Scottish Parliament.
David Steel becomes the first Presiding Officer (speaker) of the modern Scottish Parliament.
Carlo Azeglio Ciampi is elected President of Italy.
125th Preakness: Chris Antley on Charismatic wins in 1:55.2.
Ehud Barak is elected prime minister of Israel.
Ehud Barak is elected prime minister of Israel.
In Germany, Johannes Rau is elected BundesprSsident.
Canadian professional wrestler Owen Hart dies after falling 90 feet as he was being lowered into the ring for the "Over the Edge" sports entertainment event in Kansas City, Missouri.
World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) superstar Owen Hart falls to his death during the Pay Per View Over the Edge at the Kemper Arena in Kansas City, Missouri after a botched entrance stunt.

The two officers scapegoated after the 1941 Attack on Pearl Harbor, Rear Admiral Kimmel and Lieutenant General Short are exonerated (posthumously) by the U.S. Senate of all charges of dereliction of duty.

Manchester United wins the UEFA Champions League at the Nou Camp stadium, Barcelona, beating Bayern Munich to lift their third major trophy of the season, after winning the English Premier League and FA Cup, an unprecedented feat for a single season.
The first Welsh Assembly in over 600 years opens in Cardiff.
The Indian Air Force launches an attack on intruding Pakistan Army troops and mujahadeen militants in Kashmir.
Manchester United win the UEFA Champions League to complete an unprecedented treble.
The International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague, Netherlands indicts Slobodan Milo_evic and four others for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Kosovo.
The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague, Netherlands indicts Slobodan Milo?evi? and four others for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Kosovo.

Swedish police officers Robert Karlstrm and Olov BorTn are wounded by three bank robbers armed with automatic weapons and later executed with their own service pistols by shots in the head from close distance on the scene in Malexander.
In Milan, Italy, after 22 years of restoration work, Leonardo da Vinci's newly-restored masterpiece "The Last Supper" is put back on display.
Cathy O'Dowd, a South African mountaineer, conquers the summit of Mount Everest from both the north and south sides.
Nigeria terminates military rule, and the Nigerian Fourth Republic is established with Olusegun Obasanjo as president.
Olusegun Obasanjo takes office as President of Nigeria, the first elected and civilian head of state in Nigeria after 16 years of military rule.
The Napster peer-to-peer file-sharing network debuts.

After decades of fighting off outside technological influences like television, the King of Bhutan allows television transmissions to commence in the Kingdom for the first time, coinciding with the King's Silver Jubilee.
The Bhutan Broadcasting Service finally brings television transmissions to the Kingdom for the first time.
The Islamic Salvation Army, the armed wing of the Islamic Salvation Front, agrees in principle to disband in Algeria.
In Brazil, 345 prisoners escape from Putim prison through the front gate.

At the Putim maximum security prison in Brazil, 345 prisoners run from the main gate in the largest jailbreak in Brazilian history, marking the 10th escape for the three-year-old facility. In the ensuing manhunt, two fugitives are killed and five innocent bystanders are accidentally jailed.
The government of Colombia announces it will include the estimated value of the country's illegal drug crops, exceeding half a billion US dollars, in its gross national product.
War on Drugs: The government of Colombia announces it will include the estimated value of the country's illegal drug crops, exceeding half a billion US dollars, in its gross national product.
The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and NATO sign a peace treaty.
Kosovo War: Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and NATO sign a peace treaty.
NATO suspends its air strikes after Slobodan Milo_evic agrees to withdraw Serbian forces from Kosovo.
Kosovo War: NATO suspends its air strikes after Slobodan Milo?evi? agrees to withdraw Serbian forces from Kosovo.
Texas Governor George W. Bush announces he will seek the Republican Party nomination for President of the United States.
Operation Joint Guardian begins - NATO-led United Nations peacekeeping forces KFOR enter the province of Kosovo in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
Kosovo War: Operation Joint Guardian begins ? NATO-led United Nations peacekeeping force KFor enters the province of Kosovo in Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
George Morber Senior and Carolyn Frederick are murdered by Angel Maturino Resendiz in Gorham, Illinois (his 8th and 9th victims, in his 7th and final incident).
IBM releases the 37.5 GB Deskstar 37GP hard drive, the world's largest personal computer hard drive. It features 5400-rpm motor, five platters, 2 MB cache buffer, ATA-4 interface. Price is US$350.
In Central Mexico, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurs. 20 people killed, about 275 injured and considerable damage to thousands of buildings and several bridges.

Ira & Larry Goldberg Coins & Collectibles auctions a US 1907 Saint-Gaudens, Ultra-High Relief, Roman Numerals gold double eagle, PR-67 PCGS, for $1.21 million to Tangible Asset Galleries, the first $1 million coin at auction.
Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras wins the Libertadores Cup.
Thabo Mbeki elected President of South Africa.
The Second Global Street Party is held around world including Bangladesh, USA, Uruguay, Spain, Germany, England (10,000 in London), Switzerland, Nigeria (10,000 in Port Harcourt).

The Dallas Stars defeat the Buffalo Sabres in triple overtime of game six of the Stanley Cup Finals to win their first Stanley Cup. Brett Hull scores the controversial cup-winning goal to seal the victory.
Stephen King was hit in a car accident on Route 5 in North Lovell, Maine by Bryan Smith.
First iBook introduced by Apple Computer.
The San Antonio Spurs defeat the New York Knicks 78-77 in Game 5 of the NBA Finals to take home the title in a strike-shortened season.
The American soap opera Another World airs its 8891st and final episode.
After a loss at Wimbledon, Boris Becker announces that he will end his tennis career.
Johannes Rau succeeds Roman Herzog as Germany's President (BundesprSsident).

The Scottish Parliament is officially opened by Queen Elizabeth on the day powers are officially transferred from the old Scottish Office in London to the new devolved Scottish Executive in Edinburgh.
Benjamin Nathaniel Smith begins a three-day killing spree targeting racial and ethnic minorities in Illinois and Indiana, USA.
David Beckham marries Victoria Adams in Ireland
U.S. Army Pfc. Barry Winchell is bludgeoned in his sleep at Fort Campbell, Kentucky by fellow soldiers; he dies the next day from his injuries.
Mark Sandman, lead singer of the Boston-based rock band Morphine, collapses on stage during a concert in Rome and dies of a heart attack at age 47.
In Rome, Hicham El Guerrouj runs the fastest mile ever recorded - 3:43:13.
Allen Lee Davis is executed by electrocution by the state of Florida. That is the last use of the Electric Chair for capital punishment in Florida.
Days of student protests begins after Iranian police and hardliners attack a student dormitory of University of Tehran.

In Honduras, a magnitude 6.7 earthquake occurs. Few injuries, damage to houses, bridges, and highways. Felt throughout most of Honduras and in eastern Guatemala. Felt in Belize, El Salvador and at Villahermosa, Mexico.
India recaptures Kargil, forcing the Pakistan Army to retreat. India announces victory ending the two-month conflict.
Safeco Field opens in Seattle, Washington.
Off the coast of Martha's Vineyard, a plane piloted by John F. Kennedy Jr. crashes, killing him and his wife Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and her sister Lauren Bessette.

John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and sister-in-law Lauren Bessette are killed in a plane crash off the coast of Martha's Vineyard. The Piper Saratoga aircraft was piloted by Kennedy.
David Cone pitches a perfect game, the 16th in history, as the New York Yankees defeat the Montreal Expos, 6-0, to celebrate Yogi Berra Day.
David Cone of the New York Yankees pitches the 16th perfect game in baseball history against the Expos at Yankee Stadium.

Apple Computer introduces the iBook portable computer. It features 12.1-inch TFT display, 300 MHz G3 processor, 4 MB ATI Rage Mobility graphics chip, CD-ROM drive, 32 MB RAM, modem, USB and 10/100Base-T Ethernet ports, 3 GB hard drive, keyboard, Mac OS 8.6, V.90 modem, AppleWorks software, Microsoft Internet Explorer, Netscape Communicator, and comes in a translucent cover in tangerine or blueberry colors. Battery power lasts about six hours. Price is US$1599; weight is 6.6 pounds; size is 2 x 13.5 x 11.6 inches.
Mercury program: Liberty Bell 7 is raised from the Atlantic Ocean.
The European Parliament elects Nichole Fontaine its president.
Falun Gong is officially banned and defined as an "evil cult" (xiejiao) by Chinese government, and a large-scale persecution of its practitioners is launched.
Persecution of Falun Gong begins. Falun Gong is banned in the People's Republic of China under Jiang Zemin.
ANA Flight 61 is hijacked in Tokyo, Japan.
Mohammed VI of Morocco becomes king upon the death of his father Hassan II.
The Woodstock 99 festival is held in New York.
Hijack of ANA Flight 61 in Tokyo.
Crown Prince Mohammed Ben Al-Hassan, is crowned King Mohammed VI of Morroco at the death of his father.
Lance Armstrong wins his first Tour de France (cycling).
Lance Armstrong wins his first Tour de France.
The last Checker taxi cab is retired in New York City and auctioned off for approximately US$135,000.
Twenty-one people die in a canyoning disaster near Interlaken, Switzerland.
Twenty-one die in a canyoning disaster near Interlaken, Switzerland.
The Rock 'N' Roller Coaster attraction opens in the Disney-MGM Studios Theme Park at Walt Disney World in Florida.
Mark O. Barton kills nine in Atlanta, Georgia.
NASA intentionally crashes the Lunar Prospector spacecraft into the Moon, thus ending its mission to detect frozen water on the lunar surface.
NASA intentionally crashes the Lunar Prospector spacecraft into the Moon, thus ending its mission to detect frozen water on the moon's surface.
Mark McGwire becomes the 16th member of the 500 home run club with a home run at Busch Stadium in St. Louis, Missouri.
Hundreds of Chechen guerrillas invade the Russian republic of Dagestan, triggering a short war.
A group of Indian army veterans launch the political party Rashtriya Raksha Dal.
The first Callatis Festival, the largest music and culture festival in Romania, is held.
Russian President Boris Yeltsin fires his Prime Minister, Sergei Stepashin, and for the fourth time fires his entire cabinet.
