The Diet of Japan enacts a law establishing the Hinomaru and Kimi Ga Yo as the official national flag and national anthem.
Russian President Boris Yeltsin fires his Prime Minister, Sergei Stepashin, and for the fourth time fires his entire cabinet.
An intruding Pakistan Navy plane is shot down in India. The incident sparks tensions between the two nations, coming just a month after the end of the Kargil War.
Buford O. Furrow, Jr. wounds five and kills one in the Los Angeles, California, Jewish Community Center.
A total solar eclipse is seen in Europe and Asia.
An F-2 tornado rips through downtown Salt Lake City, Utah, killing one person and injuring over 100.
A total solar eclipse visible from Europe and Asia.
Steffi Graf announces her retirement from tennis after a 17 year career in which she won 107 career titles including 22 Grand Slams.
Beni Ounif massacre in Algeria; some 29 people killed at a false roadblock near the Moroccan border, leading to temporary tensions with Morocco.
A 7.4-magnitude earthquake strikes Izmit and levels much of northwestern Turkey, killing more than 17,000 and injuring 44,000.
Baltimore Orioles' pitcher Jesse Orosco sets a major league mark pitching in his 1,072nd game.
A 7.4-magnitude earthquake strikes Izmit, Turkey, killing more than 17,000 and injuring 44,000.
In Belgrade, tens of thousands of Serbians rally to demand the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milo_evic.
In Belgrade, tens of thousands of Serbians rally to demand the resignation of Federal Republic of Yugoslavia President Slobodan Milo?evi?.
Mandarin Airlines Flight 642 crashes in Hong Kong.
Michael Johnson captures the 400m world record.

Bowers and Merena auctions the Watters-Childs Collection. A US 1804 Draped Bust dollar PR-68, finest known, believed to have been in the Sultan of Muscat presentation set, first public offering since 1945, sells for $4.14 million, a world record price for a rare coin.
East Timorese vote for independence in a referendum.
The first of a series of Russian Apartment Bombings in Moscow, killing one person and wounding 40 others.
A LAPA Boeing 737-200 crashes during takeoff from Jorge Newbury Airport in Buenos Aires, killing 74, including 10 on the ground.
In Greece, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake occurs. 143 people killed, 1,600 injured, 50,000 homeless and at least 53,000 buildings damaged or destroyed in the Athens area.
A major earthquake close to Athens, Greece, results to the collapse of few buildings in the area. About 150 people are killed.
The first of a series of Russian apartment bombings occurs. 22 fails.

US Attorney General Janet Reno names former US Senator John Danforth to head an independent investigation of the 1993 fire at the Branch Davidian church near Waco, Texas in response to revelations in the film Waco: The Rules of Engagement contradicting the official government stories.

Sega releases the Dreamcast video game system in the USA. Price is US$199. In the first 24 hours, Sega sells US$97 million worth of hardware and software, setting an entertainment industry record for highest-grossing day.
Sega's Dreamcast game console was released in the US.
Eric Milton of the Minnesota Twins pitches a 7-0 no-hitter against the Anaheim Angels.

Tennis: Serena Williams, 2 weeks short of her 18th birthday, wins her first Grand Slam tournament when she became US Open champion, becoming the first African American woman to win a Grand Slam tournament since Althea Gibson in 1958.
Bomb explodes in Moscow, Russia. At least 119 people are killed.
Kiribati, Nauru and Tonga join the United Nations.
Kiribati, Nauru and Tonga join the United Nations.

For the first time in its 28-year history, most of Walt Disney World in Florida is closed for the day, due to the threat of Hurricane Floyd. Disney's Animal Kingdom re-opens at 12:00 PM for resort guests.

A large earthquake registering 7.6 on the Richter scale shakes Taiwan. About 2,400 people killed, 8,700 injured, 600,000 people left homeless and about 82,000 housing units damaged. Damage estimated at US$14 billion, leading to a two-week halt to manufacturing of many components of personal computers.
Chi-Chi earthquake occurs in central Taiwan, leaving about 2,400 people dead.
NASA announces that it lost contact with the Mars Climate Orbiter.
The last professional baseball game is played at historic Tiger Stadium in Detroit, Michigan.
In Oaxaca, Mexico, a magnitude 7.5 earthquake occurs. At least 35 people killed, 215 injured, thousands of buildings damaged or destroyed, utilities disrupted and roads blocked by landslides.

Japan's worst nuclear accident at a uranium reprocessing facility in Tokai-mura, northeast of Tokyo. Workers overload a container with uranium, exposing workers and local residents to very high radiation levels.
Pudong International Airport opens in Shanghai, China, taking over all international flights to Hongqiao.
The Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas sign goes dark as its new owner doesn't pay the power bill.
Thirty-one people die in the Ladbroke Grove rail crash, west of London, England.
Angel premieres on the WB network.
The Lord of the Rings movies begin principal photography.
World population reaches six billion people, as the six billionth person (according to the United Nations) is born in Sarajevo, in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif attempts to dismiss Army Chief General Pervez Musharraf and install ISI director Khwaja Ziauddin in his place. Senior Army generals refuse to accept the dismissal. Musharraf, who was out of the country, attempts to return in a commercial airliner. Sharif orders the Karachi airport to not allow the plane to land. The generals lead a coup d'Ttat, ousting Sharif's administration and taking over the airport. The plane lands with only a few minutes of fuel to spare, and Musharraf takes control of the government.
Pervez Musharraf takes power in Pakistan from Nawaz Sharif through a bloodless coup.
The Day of 6 Billion: The 6 billionth human in the world is born.
The United States Senate rejects ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT).
The United States Senate rejects ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT).
A National Geographic Society press conference reveals the fossil of Archaeoraptor (which is later found to be a forgery).
In Southern California, a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurs. Few injuries, light damage.
In Frankfurt am Main, Germany, historian Fritz Stern is given the Peace Prize of the German Book Association.
In Germany, Arnold Stadler is presented with the Georg Bnchner Prize for Literature.
Apple Computer's Mac OS 9 is released and sold
Britain's House of Lords votes to end the right of hereditary peers to vote in Britain's upper chamber of Parliament.
The New York Yankees complete a four-game sweep of the Atlanta Braves to win their second consecutive World Series of baseball.
Gunmen open fire in the Armenian Parliament, killing Prime Minister Vazgen Sarkisian, Parliament Chairman Karen Demirchian, and six other members.
Miss Saigon closes in London after 4264 performances.
Roman Catholic Church and Lutheran Church leaders sign the Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification, ending a centuries-old doctrinal dispute over the nature of faith and salvation.
EgyptAir Flight 990 traveling from New York City to Cairo crashes off the coast of Nantucket, Massachusetts, killing all 217 on-board.
EgyptAir Flight 990 traveling from New York City to Cairo crashes off the coast of Nantucket, Massachusetts, killing all 217 on-board.
Roman Catholic Church and Lutheran Church leaders sign the Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification, ending a centuries-old doctrinal dispute over the nature of faith and salvation.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average removes Chevron Corporation, Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Union Carbide Corporation, and Sears Roebuck from its index, replacing them with Microsoft Corporation, Intel Corporation, SBC Communications, and Home Depot Incorporated.

Hong Kong International Theme Parks announces an agreement has been reached with the Walt Disney Company on building a Disneyland park in Hong Kong. Hong Kong Disneyland will be 126 hectares (299 acres) in size, built on Lantau Island. The park is scheduled to open in 2005.

US District Judge Thomas Jackson issues his 207-page Findings of Fact, ruling that Microsoft has monopoly power over personal computer operating systems, and uses that power to harm American consumers.
United States v. Microsoft: U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issues a preliminary ruling that software maker Microsoft had "monopoly power".
Australians vote to keep the monarch as their head of state.
Australians vote to keep the British monarch as their head of state in the Australian republic referendum..
The German Gerichtshof (supreme court) sentences Egon Krenz, former East German political leader, to prison for his role in the killing of East Germans seeking to flee the country.
TAESA Flight 725 crashes a few minutes after leaving the Uruapan airport en-route to Mexico City; 18 people are killed in the accident.
TAESA Flight 725, went down a few minutes after leaving the Uruapan airport en-route to Mexico City. 18 people were killed in the accident
A six-story apartment building collapses in Italian city of Foggia killing more than 60 residents.
A six-storey apartment block collapses in Foggia, Italy, killing 62.
In northwest Turkey, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs. At least 894 people killed and 4,948 injured.
In College Station, Texas, 12 are killed and 28 injured at Texas A&M University when the annual Aggie Bonfire collapses while under construction.
In Jasper, Texas, 24-year old Shawn Allen Berry is sentenced to life in prison, becoming the third person convicted in the racially-motivated death of James Byrd, Jr..
In College Station, Texas, 12 are killed and 28 injured at Texas A&M University when a huge bonfire under construction collapses.
In Istanbul, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) ends a two-day summit by calling for a political settlement in Chechnya and adopting a Charter for European Security.
The People's Republic of China launches the first Shenzhou spacecraft.
Saundra Santiago of Miami Vice fame marries Roger Squintero
Wayne Gretzky is inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, his number 99 permanently retired by the National Hockey League.
Wayne Gretzky is inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, his number 99 permanently retired by the NHL.
The United Nations General Assembly passes a resolution designating November 25 as the annual International Day to Eliminate Violence Against Women.
In Vanuatu Islands, a magnitude 7.5 earthquake and tsunami occur. At least ten people are killed.
The New Zealand Labour Party, led by Helen Clark, wins office in a General Election, unseating the incumbent administration of Jenny Shipley.
The left-wing Labour Party takes control of the New Zealand government with leader Helen Clark becoming the first elected female Prime Minster in New Zealand's history.
The Hamilton Tiger-Cats defeat the Calgary Stampeders 32-21 to win the 87th Grey Cup at B.C. Place Stadium in Vancouver.
A man wielding a samurai sword enters St. Andrew's Catholic Church in Thornton Heath and injures 11.
Jorge Batlle, of the Colorado Party, is elected president of Uruguay.

In Seattle, Washington, the first major mobilization of the anti-globalization movement catches police unprepared and forces the cancellation of the opening ceremonies of the WTO Meeting of 1999 (protests end on December 3).
Exxonmobil Corporation merger is completed, and forms the largest company in the world.
British Aerospace and Marconi Electronic Systems merge to form BAE Systems, Europe's largest defence contractor and the fourth largest aerospace firm in the world.
In Seattle, Washington, United States, protests against the WTO meeting by anti-globalization protesters catch police unprepared and force the cancellation of opening ceremonies.
British Aerospace and Marconi Electronic Systems merge to form BAE Systems, Europe's largest defence contractor and the fourth largest aerospace firm in the world.
Exxon changes its company name to Exxon Mobil Company.
AlliedSignal Incorporated changes its company name to Honeywell International.
The United Kingdom devolves political power in Northern Ireland to the Northern Ireland Executive.
The United Kingdom devolves political power in Northern Ireland to the Northern Ireland Executive.
After rowing for 81 days and 2,962 nautical miles (5486 km), Tori Murden crosses the Atlantic Ocean by rowboat alone, when she reaches Guadeloupe from the Canary Islands.
NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Polar Lander, moments before the spacecraft enters the Martian atmosphere.
NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Polar Lander moments before the spacecraft enters the Martian atmosphere.
The RIAA files a lawsuit against the Napster file-sharing client.
The European Union, at its meeting in Helsinki, Finland, determines to take up negotiations with Rumania, Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, the Slovak Republic and Malta for admission to the Union.
German author Gunter Grass wins the Nobel Prize for Literature.
President Lieutenant General Umar Hasan Ahmad al-Bashir of Sudan dismisses the National Assembly, during an internal power struggle between him and speaker of the Parliament Hasan al-Turabi.

Algerian Ahmed Ressam is arrested while crossing the United States-Canada border at Port Angeles, Washington, when United States Customs finds explosives in the trunk of his automobile. The arrest causes fears of a terrorist attack in the United States, and is a major factor in the cancellation of a public New Year's celebration in Seattle, Washington. Ressam is later convicted in a plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport on New Year's Eve.
Charles M. Schulz, creator of the comic strip Peanuts, announces his retirement.
Torrential rains cause catastrophic floods and mudslides in the coastal regions of Venezuela, killing an estimated 25,000 people and leaving 100,000 others homeless.

The United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission (UNMOVIC) is created to replace UNSCOM. The U.N. Security Council once again orders Iraq to allow inspections teams immediate and unconditional access to any weapons sites and facilities. Iraq rejects the resolution.
NASA launches into orbit the Terra platform carrying five Earth Observation instruments: ASTER, CERES, MISR, MODIS and MOPITT.
NASA launches into orbit the Terra platform carrying five Earth Observation instruments, including ASTER, CERES, MISR, MODIS and MOPITT.
Portugal transferred sovereignty of Macau to the People's Republic of China.
The Vermont Supreme Court orders the state to legalize same-sex unions.
Portugal returns Macau to the People's Republic of China.
Macau is handed over to the People's Republic of China by Portugal.
Vermont's Supreme Court rules that homosexual couples are entitled to same benefits and protections as married heterosexual couples.
The Spanish Civil Guard intercepts near Calatayud (Zaragoza) a Madrid-bound van driven by ETA and loaded with 950kg of explosives.
The Spanish Civil Guard intercepts a van loaded with 950 kg of explosives which ETA intend to use to blow up Torre Picasso in Madrid.
The Spanish Civil Guard finds near Calatayud (Zaragoza) another van loaded by ETA with 750 kg of explosives (see related event on December 21, 1999).
Tandja Mamadou becomes President of Niger.
Indian Airlines Flight 814, en route from Kathmandu, Nepal to Delhi, India is hijacked and taken to Kandahar, Afghanistan.
Severe weather in France kills over 100 people and causes extensive damage to property and trees and the French national power grid (see Lothar).
A Maltese-registered tanker runs aground at the mouth of the Bosporus strait across Istanbul, Turkey.
Saparmurat Niyazov is proclaimed President for Life in Turkmenistan.

In Henley-on-Thames, England, former Beatle George Harrison is stabbed several times in the chest by Michael Anram, who had broken into his home. Harrison's wife wrestles the knife out of the assailant's hand before the police arrive. The man apparently believes that Harrison is the devil. He is later charged with attempted murder.
Boris Yeltsin resigns as President of Russia, replaced by Vladimir Putin.
Five hijackers, who had been holding 155 hostages on an Indian Airlines plane, leave the plane with two Islamic clerics that they had demanded be freed.
Millennium celebrations begin worldwide (although technically the third millennium starts in 2001 not 2000). Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom opens the Millennium Dome at Greenwich, London.

US turns over complete administration of the Panama Canal to the Panamanian Government as stipulated in the Torrijos-Carter Treaty of 1977 free of liens and debts, in good operation and with a $1 billion investment program in place designed to ensure continued first class service to the maritime world. At the transfer, more than 97 percent of the Canal's 9,000 workers are Panamanian.

At noon, according to the Torrijos-Carter Treaties, the United States Government handed Panama Canal control over to Panama. The Panama Canal Authority, the Panamanian Government Agency created to run the Canal, takes over.
Boris Yeltsin resigns as President of Russia, to be replaced by Vladimir Putin.
Five hijackers, who had been holding 155 hostages on an Indian Airlines plane, leave the plane with two Islamic clerics that they had demanded be freed.
As the world celebrates, no major crisis arises from the dreaded Y2K computer 'millennium bug'.
Millennium celebrations take place throughout the world.
Y2K passes without serious, widespread computer failures, as many experts and businesses had feared.
Scientists Matt and Mike Chapman create the Homestar Runner Flash animated Internet cartoon.
The last "Peanuts" comic strip is created by Charles Schulz.
(to January 10) Israel and Syria hold inconclusive peace talks.
Alan Greenspan is nominated for a fourth term as U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman.
The 1st day of the 2000 Al Qaeda Summit.
Steve Jobs announces that he is accepting the position as full-time CEO of Apple Computer.

America Online announces it is buying Time Warner, in a stock-trade deal valued at $160 billion, the largest in corporate history. The new firm, AOL Time Warner, will have a combined value of $350 billion.
America Online announces an agreement to buy Time Warner for $162 billion, the largest corporate merger in history.
The armed wing of Islamic Salvation Front concludes its negotiations with the government for an amnesty and disbands in Algeria.
Carlton Fisk and Tony Perez are elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.
In Yunnan, China, a magnitude 5.9 earthquake occurs. Seven people are killed, 2,528 injured, and 92,479 are left homeless. More than 41,000 houses are destroyed in central Yunnan Province.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 11,722.98, a level never reached before (the peak of the Dot-com bubble).
United Nations tribunal sentences five Bosnian Croats to up to 25 years, for the 1993 killing of over 100 Bosnian Muslims in a Bosnian village.
Sport Club Corinthians Paulista wins Vasco da Gama, on the final match for the FIFA Club World Championship.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record high of 11,722.98.
David Letterman undergoes quintuple heart bypass surgery.
A United Nations tribunal sentences five Bosnian Croats to up to 25 years for the 1993 killing of over 100 Muslims in a Bosnian village.
In Sacramento, California, a commercial truck carrying evaporated milk is driven into the State Capitol building, killing the driver.
A broken pipeline in Rio de Janeiro state, Brazil, leaks 492,000 litres of crude oil, covering about 5km of coastline.
The Tagish Lake meteorite impacts the Earth.
Fire at Seton Hall University kills three students and injures 54.
God's Army, a Karen militia group led by twins Johnny and Luther Htoo, take 700 hostages at a Thai hospital near the Burmese border.
At the Desert Inn casino in Las Vegas, Nevada, Cynthia Jay-Brennan wins $34,959,458.56 on a Megabucks slot machine, the world's largest payout. She had entered a total of $27.
Robert F. Vasa ordained Bishop of the Diocese of Baker.
The US Mint releases a new circulating dollar coin, depicting Sacagawea.
Kenya Airways Flight 431 crashes off the coast of C?te d'Ivoire into the Atlantic Ocean, killing 169.
The Saint Louis Rams win the NFL Championship for the first time since 1951, defeating the Tennessee Titans 23-16 in Super Bowl XXXIV at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, Georgia.
Off the coast of Côte d'Ivoire, Kenya Airways Flight 431 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing 169.
Alaska Airlines Flight 261 crashes off the California coast into the Pacific Ocean, killing 88.

In England, Dr. Harold Shipman is found guilty of murdering 15 patients between 1995 and 1998 and sentenced to life imprisonment. The trial judge recommends that Shipman, 54, should never be released from prison. Shipman's victims were all patients at his surgery in the North Cheshire township of Hyde, where he had worked for six years leading up to his arrest in September 1998.
An Alaska Airlines MD-83 crashes in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Malibu, California killing all 88 aboard.
A flash flood in Bolivia breaks a crude oil pipeline, spilling over 30,000 litres of oil into the Desaguadero River.
German extortionist Klaus-Peter Sabotta is jailed for life for attempted murder and extortion, in connection with the sabotage of German railway lines.
German extortionist Klaus-Peter Sabotta is jailed for life for attempted murder and extortion in connection with sabotage of German railway lines.
Tarja Halonen is elected the first female president of Finland.
A barge holding 1.8 million litres of oil sinks to the bottom of the Amazon River in Brazil.
Stipe Mesic is elected president of Croatia.
Bahria University is established through the Presidential Ordinance No. V of 2000 of Government of Pakistan.
A blast from an explosive device in front of a Barclay's Bank across from the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street wounds dozens but kills none.
The last original "Peanuts" comic strip appears in newspapers one day after Charles M. Schulz dies.
The spacecraft NEAR Shoemaker enters orbit around asteroid 433 Eros, the first spacecraft to orbit an asteroid.
Indian Point II nuclear power plant in New York State vents a small amount of radioactive steam when a steam generator fails.
David Letterman returns to The Late Show over a month after having an emergency quintuple heart bypass surgery.
The Swedish political party New Democracy is declared financially bankrupt.
In the Mariana Islands, a magnitude 6.2 earthquake occurs. It is felt strongly on Guam and Saipan.
Six year old Dedrick Owens shoots and kills Kayla Rolland, also six years old, at Theo J. Buell Elementary School in Mount Morris Township, Michigan. [1]
The Constitution of Finland is rewritten.
Hans Blix assumes the position of Executive Chairman of UNMOVIC.
The Constitution of Finland is rewritten.
Hans Blix assumes the position of Executive Chairman of UNMOVIC.

Sony releases the PlayStation 2 video game system in Japan. It features 294.912 MHz 128-bit Emotion Engine processor, 32 MB RAM, 147.456 MHz Graphics Synthesizer with 4 MB embedded VRAM cache, 2 MB sound RAM, 48 sound channels, 24X CD-ROM, 4X DVD ROM drive. Price is 39,800 yen. One million units are sold on the first weekend.
The 22nd Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras is held in Sydney, Australia.
Advanced Micro Devices ships the first commercially-available 1 GHz processor.
George W. Bush and Al Gore emerge victorious in the Republican and Democratic caucuses and primaries of the United States presidential election.
In Japan, a sideswipe collision of two Tokyo Metro trains kills five people.
A collision between two Tokyo Metro trains kills 5 people.
The FBI arrests art forgery suspect Ely Sakhai in New York City.
German-born filmmaker Billy Wilder is honored with the German "Verdienstkreuz". The award is presented in Hollywood, California.
The NASDAQ Composite Index reaches an all-time high of 5048.
The NASDAQ stock market index peaks at 5048.62, signaling the beginning of the end of the dot-com boom.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises by 499.19 points (4.93 percent), its second-largest one-day point gain.
Ron Watson (aka "Uncle Ron the Magician") dies of a heart attack while putting on a magic show for a group of hospital patients at Tokoroa Hospital in New Zealand.
Chen Shui-bian is elected President of the Republic of China (Taiwan). Democratic Progressive Party ends Kuomintang rule for the first time.
U.S. President Bill Clinton arrives in New Delhi, India, for a state visit.
Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin (H. Rap Brown), a former Black Panther, is captured after a gun battle in Atlanta, Georgia, that leaves a sheriff's deputy dead.
Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, a former Black Panther once known as H. Rap Brown, is captured after a gun battle that leaves a Georgia sheriff's deputy dead.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules the government lacks authority to regulate tobacco as an addictive drug, throwing out the Clinton administration's main anti-smoking initiative.
Pope John Paul II begins the first official visit by a Roman Catholic pontiff to Israel.
In Seattle, Washington, the Kingdome sports arena is demolished into a mound of rubble over 65 feet high, to make way for a new stadium.
Presidential elections in Russia: Vladimir Putin is elected President.
The Seattle Kingdome is imploded to make room for a new stadium.
Presidential elections are held in Russia, and Vladimir Putin is elected President.
America's Cup 2000 sailing race is retained by Team New Zealand near Auckland. Prada Challenge 2000 lost 0-5 in a "best-of-9".
At its annual meeting, the jury of the German Academy of Language and Literature designates the 2000 Bnchner Prize winner as Volker Braun.

The German ministry of justice determines that drunkenness will no longer be an excuse. It had been a tradition that crimes committed while under the influence of alcohol were sentenced more mildly than in other circumstances.
Japanese prime minister Keizo Obuchi suffers a stroke and falls into a coma.

In the US Justice Department versus Microsoft anti-trust case, Judge Thomas Jackson issues his Conclusions of Law, ruling that Microsoft acted illegally to protect its operating system monopoly, and used its monopoly position to attempt to monopolize the market for Web browser software.
United States v. Microsoft: Microsoft is ruled to have violated United States antitrust laws by keeping "an oppressive thumb" on its competitors.
Yoshiro Mori replaces Keizo Obuchi as prime minister of Japan.

Pepco's Chalk Point Generating Station on the Patuxent River in southern Maryland, USA, spills about 420,000 litres of oil. Some 6 1/2 miles of oil containment booms are positioned in the river capturing an estimated 300,000 litres.
Sultan Hisamuddin Alam Shah, Sultan of Selangor, dies after a reign of 55 years. He was the longest reigning monarch in the world since the death of Prince Franz Joseph II of Liechtenstein.
Protests against the World Bank and IMF in Washington, DC.
Tuanku Syed Sirajuddin becomes Raja of Perlis.
An Air Philippines Boeing 737-200 crashes near Davao International Airport, killing 131.
Actor Renato Di Paolo accidentally hangs himself and dies playing Judas in Camerata Nuova, near Rome, Italy.
Brazil issues its first polymer bank notes.
The Big Number Change takes place in the United Kingdom, to allow more telephone numbers.
In a predawn raid, federal agents seize six-year-old Elin Gonzlez from his relatives' home in Miami, Florida.
The Big Number Change takes place in the United Kingdom.
The State of Vermont passes HB847, legalizing Civil unions for same-sex couples.
Bill Clinton announces that accurate GPS access would no longer be restricted to the U.S. military.

Her Royal Highness Princess Margriet of the Netherlands unveiled the Man With Two Hats monument in Ottawa on May 11, 2002, and the other in Apeldoorn on May 2, 2000. Symbolically linking both Netherlands and Canada for their assistance throughout the Second World War.
Bill Clinton announces that GPS access equivalent to the U.S. military would be available for regular citizens.
A rare conjunction of seven celestial bodies (Sun, Moon, planets Mercury-Jupiter) occurs on the New Moon.

In the Philippines, 24-year-old Onel De Guzman releases a virus that he had proposed creating as part of his undergraduate thesis. The email message was sent with subject "ILOVEYOU", and attachment "LOVE-LETTER-FOR-YOU". When opened, the virus activates, sending the message and attachment to every name on the email program's address list.
In San Antonio, Texas, computer pioneer Datapoint files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
The sport of Geocaching begins, with the first cache placed and the coordinates from a GPS posted on Usenet.

In Sulawesi, Indonesia, a magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurs. At least 46 people killed, 264 injured, and extensive damage and power outages occur in the Luwuk area, Sulawesi and on nearby islands. 80 percent of buildings damaged or destroyed on Banggai. A local tsunami with estimated wave heights up to 6 metres cause much damage east of Luwuk and on Peleng.
Last performance of the musical Cats in London's West End.
The Tate Modern Gallery opens in London, England.
The Tate Modern art gallery opens in London.
Lara Dutta (21), who said beauty pageants give women a platform to voice our choices and opinions is named Miss Universe 2000 in the Cyprus capital Nicosia.
In Enschede, the Netherlands, a fireworks factory explodes, killing 22 people, wounding 950, and resulting in approximately ?450 million in damage.
Beverly Hills 90210 airs its last episode.
Boo.com collapses in London after six months, due to lack of funds.
A chartered British Aerospace Jetstream 31 crashes near Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, killing 19.
Israeli troops withdraw from southern Lebanon after 22 years of occupation.
Israel withdraws IDF forces from southern Lebanon after 22 years.
Liberation Day of Lebanon. Israel withdraws its army from most of the Lebanese territory after 22 years of its first invasion in 1978.
Mount Etna erupts on the island of Sicily.
The multilateral Patent Law Treaty (PLT) is signed.

U. S. President William Jefferson Clinton is awarded the Charlemagne prize of the city of Aachen, Germany. Clinton is the first American president to win the prize which is given for contributions toward the unity of Europe.
In Southern Sumatra, Indonesia, a magnitude 7.9 earthquake occurs. At least 103 people killed, 2,174 injured, extensive damage and landslides.

In the US Justice Department versus Microsoft anti-trust case, Judge Thomas Jackson orders the breakup of Microsoft into two companies, one producing operating systems, the other producing application programs.
The Austrian writer of experimental literature, Ernst Jandl, dies in Vienna at age 74; writer of lyric, dramas and radio plays, won the Georg Bnchner Prize for literature.
The New Jersey Devils defeat the defending champion Dallas Stars 2-1 in double overtime in Game six of the 2000 Stanley Cup Finals to win their second Stanley Cup Championship.

Sandro Rosa do Nascimento takes hostages while robbing Bus #174 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; the highly-publicized standoff becomes a media circus and ends with the death of do Nascimento and a hostage.
South Korean President Kim Dae Jung visit North Korea, first as a president of opposite side, to participate in the first North-South presidential summit.
President Kim Dae-jung of South Korea meets Kim Jong-il, president of North Korea, for the beginning of the first ever inter-Korea summit, in the northern capital of Pyongyang.
Italian President Carolo Ciampi pardons Mehmet Ali Agca for the attempted assassination on Pope John Paul II 19 years ago.
An earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale strikes Iceland.

The Oakland Athletics beat the Kansas City Royals 21-3; the 18-run difference is largest margin of victory for the Athletics and the largest margin of defeat for the Royals in the teams' respective histories.
The Los Angeles Lakers defeat the Indiana Pacers 116-111 in Game 6 of the 2000 NBA Finals, winning the series.
Andrea Yates drowns her five children in a bathtub in their Houston, Texas home.
Section 28, a law preventing the promotion of homosexuality, is repealed by the Scottish Parliament.

England-based footballer Shaun Goater is given the freedom of his home country of Bermuda and the day is declared Shaun Goater day (N.B. Contrary to popular belief this day was just a one-off and has *not* subsequently been officially annually marked by the Bermudian authorities.)
Section 28 (outlawing the 'promotion' of homosexuality in the UK) repealed in Scotland with a 99 to 17 vote.
A preliminary draft of genomes, as part of the Human Genome Project, is finished.
Vandals break into the tombs of Lynyrd Skynyrd's Ronnie Van Zant and Steve Gaines.
At the Roskilde Festival near Copenhagen, Denmark, 9 die and 26 are injured on a set while the rock group Pearl Jam performs.
The Oresund Bridge, connecting Sweden and Denmark, opens for traffic.
Vermont's civil unions law goes into effect.
Vicente Fox is elected President of Mexico, as candidate of the rightist PAN (National Action Party), ending 71 years of PRI (Institutional Revolutionary Party) rule.
France beats Italy 2-1 to win Euro 2000 with a golden goal.

Vicente Fox Quesada is elected the first President of MTxico from an opposition party, the Partido Acci=n Nacional (PAN) after more than 70 years of continuous rule by the Partido Revolucionario Institucional (PRI).
A barge and a tug towing it collide off Middletown, Rhode Island, USA, spilling 53,000 litres of oil in Narragansett Bay.
The American Sportscasters Association vote Vin Scully the Number 1 sportscaster of the 20th century.
In southern Nigeria, a leaking petroleum pipeline explodes, killing about 250 villagers who were scavenging gasoline.
EADS, the world's second largest aerospace group, is formed by the merger of ATrospatiale-Matra, DASA and CASA.
Bashar al-Assad is confirmed as Syria's leader in a national referendum.
EADS, the world's second largest aerospace group is formed by the merger of ATrospatiale-Matra, DASA, and CASA.
A leaking southern Nigerian petroleum pipeline explodes, killing about 250 villagers scavenging gasoline.
(to July 25) Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian Liberation Organization head Yasser Arafat meet at Camp David, but fail to reach a peace agreement.
Tokyo Disneyland welcomes its 250 millionth guest.
George Speight, the principal instigator of the Fiji coup of 2000, was arrested with 369 of his followers and charged with treason.
Alex Jones and cameraman Mike Hanson successfully infiltrate the controversial Bohemian Club and expose the occultist rituals taking place there.
A pipe breaks from a Petrobras oil refinery spewing about 4 million litres of oil over two hours into the Barigui River near Curitiba.
An 1919 Chicago 'Black Sox' autographed baseball is auctioned for US$93,666 on eBay. The ball's autographs include "Shoeless" Joe Jackson.
Alex Salmond resigns as the leader of the Scottish National Party.
The first 15 women pass the test for service with weapons in the German army.
Apple Computer begins shipping the first personal computers with standard dual processors, the Power Mac G4 with dual 450 or 500 MHz processors.
The leaders of Salt Lake City's bid to win the 2002 Winter Olympics are indicted by a federal grand jury for bribery, fraud, and racketeering.
American President Bill Clinton arrives on Okinawa, Japan, for the G8 summit and pledges to the islanders that the United States will reduce the impact American military bases have on their lives.
Terrorist Carlos the Jackal sues France in the European Court of Human Rights for allegedly torturing him.
In Zimbabwe, Parliament opens its new session and seats opposition members for the first time in a decade.
(to July 23) G-8 Nations hold their 26th Annual Summit. Issues include AIDS, the 'digital divide', and halving world poverty by 2015.
Cincinnati Reds' shortstop Barry Larkin agrees to a three-year, US$27 million contract extension.

Air France Flight 4590, a Concorde aircraft, crashes into a hotel in Gonesse just after takeoff from Paris, killing all 109 aboard and four in the hotel. The jet hit runway debris, preventing a proper takeoff.
Air France Flight 4590, a Concorde supersonic passenger jet, G_BTSC, crashes just after takeoff from Paris killing all 109 aboard and 4 on the ground.

In Norstead, Newfoundland, Canada, near L'Anse aux Meadows, thirteen replica Viking longships from Sweden, Norway, and elsewhere arrive as part of a Grand Encampment Ceremony, in celebration of the 1000th anniversary of the arrival of Vikings in North America, and their establishment of a settlement.
Alberto Fujimori becomes Constitutional President of the Republic of Peru for a third time.
Venezuela's president Hugo Chvez is re-elected with 59 percent of the vote.
(to August 3) The Republican National Convention in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania nominates George W. Bush for U.S. President and Dick Cheney for Vice President.
An oil pipeline break in northern British Columbia, Canada spills about 1 million litres of crude oil into the Pine River near Chetwynd.
Academy Award winning actor Sir Alec Guiness dies at Midhurst in West Sussex at the age of 86. He had recently been diagnosed with prostate cancer.

The Roman Catholic Church's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, under Prefect Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, publishes Dominus Iesus, notable for its lack of the filioque clause in the Latin text of the Nicene Creed.
An unknown ship dumps oil off the South Florida coast, creating an oil slick covering 24km of beaches.
Confederate submarine H.L. Hunley is raised to the surface after 136 years on the ocean floor.
A Piper Navajo and a Piper Seminole collide in mid-air over a housing development in Burlington, New Jersey, killing 11
The Russian submarine K-141 Kursk sinks in the Barents Sea, resulting in the deaths of all 118 men on board.
The Oscar class submarine K-141 Kursk of the Russian Navy exploded and sank in the Barents Sea during a military exercise.
(to August 17) The Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles nominates U.S. Vice President Al Gore for President and Senator Joe Lieberman for Vice President.
Czar Nicholas II and his family are canonized by the synod of the Russian Orthodox Church.

Nicaragua becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty. This essentially deprecated the Buenos Aires Convention treaty, because as of this date, all members of the BA Convention were also signatories to Berne.
A Gulf Air Airbus A320 crashes into the Persian Gulf near Manama, Bahrain, killing 143
The Ostankino Tower in Moscow, Russia, catches fire; three people are killed.
Ostankino Tower in Moscow catches fire, three people are killed.
(to September 8) World leaders attend the Millennium Summit at United Nations Headquarters.
The last wholly Swedish-owned arms manufacturer, Bofors, is sold to American arms manufacturer United Defense.
In New York City, the United Nations Millennium Summit begins with more than 180 world leaders present.
(to September 14) The United Kingdom fuel protests take place, with refineries blockaded, and supply to the country's network of petrol stations halted.
Albania officially joins the World Trade Organization.
The Republic of Albania officially joins the World Trade Organization, as Albania.
Activists protest against the World Economic Forum meeting in Melbourne, Australia. See S11.
(to October 1) The Games of the XXVII Olympiad are held in Sydney, Australia.
Peru's president Alberto Fujimori calls for new elections in which he will not run.
Ukrainian journalist Georgiy Gongadze is last seen alive.
Last performance of the musical Cats (musical) on Broadway.
McAfee.com and F-Secure researchers discover the first handheld computer virus "Phage", which targets the Palm OS.
Anti-globalization protests in Prague, Czech Republic, (some 15,000 protesters) turn violent during the IMF and World Bank summits.
The Greek Express Samina ferry sinks off the coast of the island of Paros; 80 out of a total of over 500 passengers perish in one of Greece's worst sea disasters.
Anti-globalization protests in Prague (some 20,000 protesters) turned violent during the IMF and World Bank summits.
The United States Olympic team beats the favored Cuban team to win the country's first gold medal in baseball.

Israeli opposition leader Ariel Sharon visits the Temple Mount, protected by a several-hundred-strong Israeli police force. Palestinian riots erupt, leading into a full-fledged armed uprising (called the Al-Aqsa Intifada by sympathizers and the Oslo War by opponents).
The Al-Aqsa Intifada begins after the visit of Ariel Sharon to the Al-Aqsa Mosque.
The Long Kesh prison in Northern Ireland is closed.
Closing ceremony of Games of the XXVII Olympiad in Sydney, Australia.
President Slobodan Milo_evic leaves office after widespread demonstrations throughout Serbia and the withdrawal of Russian support.
Mass demonstrations in Belgrade lead to resignation of Serbian strongman Slobodan Milo?evi?. These demonstration are often called the Bulldozer Revolution.
The last Mini automobile is produced in Longbridge, England.
At Shea Stadium, the New York Mets defeat the San Francisco Giants to win the National League Division Series in four games.
250 million gallons of coal sludge spill in Martin County, Kentucky, USA.
In Aden, Yemen, the USS Cole is badly damaged by two suicide bombers, killing 17 crew members and wounding at least 39
In Hollywood, Don Rickles receives a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
The New York Yankees defeat the Seattle Mariners to win their 37th American League pennant.
Toronto Blue Jays signs Carlos Delgado to a Major League record four-year $68 million contract.

Fifteen Arab leaders convene in Cairo, Egypt, for their first summit in four years; the Libyan delegation walks out, angry over signs the summit will stop short of calling for breaking ties with Israel.
The Mainichi Shinbun newspaper exposes Japanese archeologist Shinichi Fujimura as a fraud; Japanese archaeologists had based their treatises on his findings.
American Secretary of State Madeleine Albright holds talks with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Il.
Canada's TSX stock market index drops a record 840.26 points, to 9,511.84.
Pakistani authorities announce that their police have found an apparently ancient mummy of a Persian princess in the province of Balochistan.
The New York Yankees defeat the New York Mets in Game 5 of the 2000 World Series, 4-1, to win their 26th World Series title. This was the first matchup between the two crosstown rivals.

Sony Computer Entertainment introduces the Sony PlayStation 2 in the USA. The system can also play PlayStation games, and supports DVD-ROM, DVD-Video, CD-ROM, and Dolby Digital media. Price is about US$300. Sales during the first week: 681,855.
The successor to the highly successful PlayStation, the PlayStation 2 was released.
Laurent Gbagbo takes over as president of Côte d'Ivoire following a popular uprising against President Robert GuTï
Singapore Airlines Flight 006 collides with construction equipment in the Chiang Kai Shek International Airport, killing 83.
A chartered Antonov An-26 explodes after takeoff in Northern Angola killing 50
The last Multics machine was shut down.
A Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 operating as Flight 006 collides with construction equipment upon takeoff in Taipei, Taiwan killing 79 passengers and 4 crew members
The first crew arrives at the International Space Station.
The first crew arrives at the International Space Station.
Widespread flooding occurs throughout England and Wales after days of heavy rain.
A Petrobras oil tanker spills 50,000 litres of crude oil near a beach resort area.
Emperor Haile Selassie I given an Imperial funeral by the Ethiopian Orthodox church

United States presidential election: Republican candidate Texas Governor George W. Bush defeats Democratic Vice President Al Gore in the closest election in US history, but the final outcome is not known for over a month because of disputed votes in Florida.
In London, a criminal gang raids the Millennium Dome to steal The Millennium Star diamond, but police surveillance catches them in the act.
Hillary Rodham Clinton is elected to the United States Senate, becoming the first First Lady of the United States to win public office.
Hillary Rodham Clinton is elected to the United States Senate, becoming the first First Lady of the United States to win public office.

U.S. presidential election, 2000: Republican Texas Governor George W. Bush defeats Democrat Vice President Al Gore, but the final outcome is not known for over a month because of disputed votes in Florida.
Kaprun disaster, Austria: A cable car fire in an alpine tunnel kills 155 skiers and snowboarders.
In Kaprun, Austria, 155 skiers and snowboarders die when a cable car catches fire in an alpine tunnel.
A small Chinese oil freighter collides with a Norwegian vessel and sinks north of Lantau Island, Hong Kong, leaking about 230,000 litres of heavy oil, creating a 10,000-square metre oil slick.
Netscape Navigator version 6.0 is launched following two years of open source development.
A new Indian state called Jharkhand is formed, carving out the South Chhota Nagpur area from Bihar in India.
A chartered Antonov AN-24 crashes after takeoff from Luanda, Angola killing more than 40 people
Bill Clinton becomes the first sitting U.S. President to visit Vietnam.
Bill Clinton becomes the first serving U.S. President to visit Vietnam.
A catastrophic landslide in Log pod Mangartom, Slovenia, kills seven, and causes millions of SIT of damage. It is one of the worst catastrophes in Slovenia in the past 100 years.
Alberto Fujimori is removed from office as president of Peru.
Pittsburgh Pirates' catcher Jason Kendall signs a US$60 million, six-year contract extension.
Catastrophical landslide in Log pod Mangartom,Slovenia, kills 7, and causes millions of SIT of damage. It is one of the worst catastrophies in Slovenia in the past 100 years.
Alberto Fujimori is removed from office as president of Peru.
The Gateshead Millennium Bridge is lifted into place in one piece by the Asian Hercules II floating crane.

Intel introduces the Pentium 4 processor, at speeds of 1.4 and 1.5 GHz, with a 400 MHz system bus. It features NetBurst micro-architecture, and incorporates 42 million transistors. The processor adds 144 new Streaming SIMD Extensions 2 multimedia instructions.
The PlayStation 2 is released in Europe, for around ?449/£299.
The BC Lions win the Canadian Football League Championship for the first time since 1994, defeating the Montreal Alouettes 28-26 in the 88th Grey Cup at McMahon Stadium in Calgary, Alberta.
Jean ChrTtien is re-elected as Prime Minister of Canada, as the Liberal Party increases its majority in the House of Commons.
A tanker spills 2.1 million litres of crude oil into the Missippi River, USA.
Ukrainian politician Oleksander Moroz touches off the Cassette Scandal by publicly accusing President Leonid Kuchma of involvement in the murder of journalist Georgiy Gongadze.
Ukrainian politician Oleksander Moroz begins the Cassette Scandal by publicly accusing President Leonid Kuchma of involvement in the murder of journalist Georgiy Gongadze.
The eighth tar drop falls in the University of Queensland pitch drop experiment.
Mike Mussina signs a US$88.5 million, six-year contract with the New York Yankees.
The Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000 comes into force in the UK.
Vicente Fox takes office as President of Mexico.
Vicente Fox is sworn-in as President of Mexico, ending the 75 year control of the PRI.
The Smashing Pumpkins perform for the last time at The Metro in Chicago.
The Fireball Network of cameras in Europe records a fireball of estimated weight 270kg over Germany.
Infogrames of France acquires Hasbro Interactive of the USA for US$5 million cash and US$95 million in stock.
The Colorado Rockies announce the signing of pitcher Mike Hampton to a eight-year, US$123.8 amillion contract.
Herbert Kroemer wins the Nobel Prize in Physics; Kroemer carried on his work in fast transistors, laser diodes and integrated chips while working for RCA laboratories and Varian Associates.
Alex Rodriguez signs the richest contract in sports history, a ten-year deal with the Texas Rangers worth US$252 million.
The United States Supreme Court releases its decision in Bush v. Gore
US Vice President Al Gore concedes defeat to Texas Governor George W. Bush in the presidential election.
The U.S. Supreme Court stops the Florida presidential recount, effectively giving the state, and the Presidency, to George W. Bush.
The Boston Red Sox sign Manny Ramirez to an eight-year, $160 million contract.
The Texas 7 escape from their prison unit in Kenedy, Texas, and start a crime spree.
American Vice President Al Gore delivers his concession speech ending his hopes of becoming the 43rd President of the United States.
The "Texas 7" escape from the John Connally Unit near Kenedy, Texas and go on a robbery spree, during which police officer Aubrey Hawkins is shot and killed.
The "Texas 7" rob a Radio Shack store in Pearland, Texas, stealing police radio scanners.

A Norwegian freighter runs aground off the city of Haugesund, Norway, spilling some 116,000 litres of fuel oil, some of which immediately washes up on nearby coastlines. Some 81,000 litres are recovered by use of oil skimmers.
The Leninist Guerrilla Units wing of the Communist Labour Party of Turkey/Leninist attack a Nationalist Movement Party office in Istanbul, killing one person and injuring three.
The Russian government officially admits to the unjustifiable arrest and murder of Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg in 1945.
The Texas 7 rob a sports store in Irving, Texas; police officer Aubrey Hawkins is shot dead.
The Texas 7 holds up a sports store in Irving, Texas. Police officer Aubrey Hawkins is shot during the robbery.
U.S. retail giant Montgomery Ward announces it is going out of business, after 128 years.
U.S. retail giant Montgomery Ward announces it is going out of business after 128 years.
A series of bombs explode in various places in Metro Manila, Philippines, within a span of a few hours, killing 22 and injuring about 100.
Rizal Day Bombings: A series of bombs explode in various places in Metro Manila, Philippines within a span of a few hours, killing 22 and injuring about a hundred.
The Millennium Dome closes its doors one year to the day of its opening.
James Tuozzolo, trumpet player with the Greater Trenton Symphony Orchestra, collapses of a heart attack on stage just after performing a solo and dies in hospital.
The European Union launches a program requiring BSE testing on all cattle older than 30 months.
Swedish Prime Minister Gran Persson begins Sweden's six month role as president of the European Union.
Sila Calder=n becomes first female Governor of Puerto Rico.
J.P. Morgan changes its company name to J.P. Morgan Chase.

The 107th United States Congress is sworn in, including incoming freshmen Senators Bill Nelson (Democrat-Florida), Tom Carper (Democrat-Delaware), Debbie Stabenow (Democrat-Michigan), John Ensign (Republican-Nevada), George Allen (Republican-Virginia), Maria Cantwell (Democrat-Washington), Ben Nelson (Democrat-Nebraska), Hillary Clinton (Democrat-New York), Jon Corzine (Democrat-New Jersey), Jean Carnahan (Democrat-Missouri), and Mark Dayton (Democrat-Minnesota).
RuneScape (Now known as RuneScape Classic) was released.
The Wrestling promotion, ECW airs its final pay-per-view, Guilty as Charged before declaring Bankruptcy.
Noah, a gaur, is born, the first individual of an endangered species to be cloned.
The Cleveland Indians sign Juan Gonzalez to a one-year, US$10 million deal.
Wikipedia starts as part of Nupedia. It becomes a separate site five days later.
The U.S. Federal Trade Commission approves the merger of America Online and Time Warner to form AOL Time Warner.
The Federal Trade Commission approved the merger of AOL and Time Warner to form AOL Time Warner.

Downtown Disney opens, in the Disneyland Resort, between Disneyland and the site of Disney's California Adventure. The 300,000 square foot site features restaurants, nightclubs, shops, and movie theaters.

In El Salvador, a magnitude 7.7 earthquake occurs, felt from Mexico City to Colombia. At least 844 people killed, 4,723 injured, 108,226 houses destroyed and more than 150,000 buildings damaged in El Salvador.
An earthquake hits El Salvador, killing more than 800.
A Greece-registered ship carrying 60,000 tonnes of iron ore runs aground off the Kenting National Park, Taiwan, leaking 1.3 million litres of fuel oil.
Wikipedia, a Wiki free content encyclopedia, goes online.
The first case of BSE (Mad Cow Disease) in Italy is discovered.
In Brevik, Norway, Norcem's oil storage facility leaks 870,000 litres of crude oil; much of the spill is recovered from the containment area and from the sea.
Wikipedia, a free Wiki content encyclopedia, goes online.

US President Bill Clinton awards former US President Theodore Roosevelt a posthumous Medal of Honor for his service during the Spanish-American War. Eleven of Roosevelt's descendants accept the honor on his behalf.
Congolese President Laurent-DTsirT Kabila is assassinated by one of his own bodyguards.

Impeachment proceedings against Philippine President Joseph Estrada end prematurely after the second envelope, which allegedly holds proof that the accused has committed plunder, remains unopened by majority vote of the senator-judges. Those senators who voted for the opening of the envelope walk out of the courtroom along with the people watching inside. This event, covered on several Philippine television channels, and the resulting SMS/text messages encouraging everyone to go to EDSA and shout for the removal or resignation of Estrada from office, triggers the second EDSA People Power Revolution or People Power II.
The British digital television channel e4 is launched.
NASCAR legend Dale Earnhardt dies during a crash on the last lap of the Daytona 500 at the Daytona International Speedway.

Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is sworn in by Chief Justice Hilario Davide as the 14th President of the Republic of the Philippines after the Armed Forces of the Philippines and several cabinet members withdraw their support for Joseph Estrada.
George W. Bush is sworn in as the 43rd President of the United States.
Philippine president Joseph Estrada is ousted in the EDSA II Revolution, succeeded by Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.
George W. Bush is inaugurated as the 43rd President of the United States.
Secretary of State for Northern Ireland Peter Mandelson resigns from the British cabinet for the second time.
A 50-year-old Douglas DC-3 crashes near Ciudad Bolivar, Venezuela, killing 24.

In India, a magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurs. At least 20,085 people killed, 166,836 injured, approximately 339,000 buildings destroyed and 783,000 damaged in the Bhuj-Ahmadabad-Rajkot area and other parts of Gujarat. Felt throughout northern India, much of Pakistan, Bangladesh, and western Nepal.
An earthquake hits Gujarat, India, causing more than 20,000 deaths.
A 50-year-old Douglas DC-3 crashes near Ciudad Bolivar, Venezuela killing 24.
A plane crashes 40 miles east of Denver, Colorado, killing two players of the Oklahoma State University basketball team, six team staffers, and the two-person crew.
Ten members of the Oklahoma State University men's basketball team and support staff die in a plane crash in Colorado.
Super Bowl XXXV: The Baltimore Ravens beat the New York Giants 34-7.
Thousands of student protesters in Indonesia storm parliament and demand that President Abdurrahman Wahid resign due to alleged involvement in corruption scandals.
The Scottish Court in the Netherlands convicts one Libyan and acquits another for their part in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 which crashed in Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
In the Netherlands a Scottish court convicts a Libyan and acquits another for their part in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 which crashed into Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
Likud Party leader Ariel Sharon wins election as Prime Minister of Israel.
Don Felder is fired from the Eagles
A comet plunges into the Sun.

In Anaheim, California, Disney's California Adventure theme park opens, next to Disneyland. The 55-acre site includes three areas: Paradise Pier, Hollywood Pictures Backlot, and the Golden State. The theme park cost US$1.4 billion to build. Admission prices are US$43 for adults, and US$33 for children.
Derek Jeter and the New York Yankees finalize a $189 million, 10-year contract, making Jeter the second highest paid player in the history of the sport.
The American submarine USS Greeneville accidentally strikes and sinks the Ehime-Maru, a Japanese training vessel operated by the Uwajima Fishery High School.
The East beats the West 111-110 in the 50th NBA All Star Game in Washington, DC.
Three Rivers Stadium, 30-year-old home of the Pittsburgh Pirates, is imploded.
The NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft touches down in the "saddle" region of 433 Eros, becoming the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid.
NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft touchdown in the "saddle" region of 433 Eros becoming the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid.

In El Salvador, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs, felt also in Guatemala and Honduras. At least 315 people killed, 3,399 injured and extensive damage. Landslides occurred in many areas of El Salvador.
An earthquake measuring 6.6 on the Richter Scale hits El Salvador, killing at least 400.
British and U.S. forces carry out bombing raids, attempting to disable Iraq's air defense network. Three people are killed in a suburban area of Baghdad.
FBI agent Robert Hanssen is arrested and charged with spying for Russia for 15 years.

NASCAR driver Dale Earnhardt is killed instantly in a crash on the last lap of the Daytona 500 while his DEI cars driven by his son, Dale Earnhardt Jr., and Michael Waltrip, finish second and first, respectively.
NASCAR legend Ralph Dale Earnhardt is killed in a crash during the last lap of the Daytona 500
An Oklahoma City bombing museum is dedicated at the Oklahoma City National Memorial.
A Oklahoma City bombing museum is dedicated at the Oklahoma City National Memorial.
The United Kingdom foot and mouth crisis begins.
FBI agent Robert Hanssen is arrested and charged with spying for Russia for 15 years.
The Taliban destroy two giant Buddha statues in Bamiyan, Afghanistan.
The Selby rail crash near Selby, North Yorkshire, England, kills ten people.
In Washington state, a magnitude 6.8 earthquake occurs. About 400 people injured and major damage in the Seattle-Tacoma-Olympia area. Damage estimate between US$1 and 4 billion.
An earthquake measuring 6.8 on the Richter Scale hits the Nisqually Valley and the Seattle, Tacoma, and Olympia area of the U.S. state of Washington.
Rusty Greer signs a $21.8 million, three-year contract extension with the Texas Rangers. Greer could make as much $36 million with incentives and options.
A U.S. Air Force Materiel Command C-23 Sherpa transport crashes during stormy weather in the U.S. state of Georgia, killing 21.
Hintze Ribeiro disaster: A bridge collapses in northern Portugal, killing up to 70 people.
During the early hours a massive bomb located in a taxi explodes in front of BBC Television Centre in London, seriously injuring 11 people. The attack was attributed to dissident Irish republicans.
Swiss referendum overwhelmingly rejects a proposal for immediate membership talks with the European Union.
U.S. Attack on Afghanistan: Seven American Special Operations Forces soldiers are killed as they attempt to infiltrate the Shahi Kot Valley on a low-flying helicopter reconnaissance mission.
Hintze Ribeiro disaster, a bridge collapses in northern Portugal, killing up to 70 people.
In Mecca, 35 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death during the annual Hajj pilgrimage.
In Santee, California, a school massacre occurs at Santana High School, leaving 2 dead and 15 wounded.
At an auction in Salt Lake City, Utah, Superior Galleries sells a US 1913 Liberty Head 5-cent coin to Dwight Manley for US$1.84 million.
The only day between 1993 and 2002 when nobody in the United Kingdom killed themselves, according to a health survey.
The world's largest offshore platform, owned by Brazil's Petrobras, sinks 1 mile down to the ocean floor, spilling up to 1.2 million litres of diesel fuel.

In Japan, Nintendo releases the Game Boy Advance handheld video game system. It features 32-bit ARM processor, and 240 x 160 pixel 32,000-color display. A Link Cable allows four players to play together on certain games. Size is 3.25 x 5.6 inches; weight is 140 grams. Two AA batteries power the system for about 15 hours. Price is 9800 yen. 611,504 units sell in the first week.
The Russian Mir space station is disposed of, breaking up in the atmosphere before falling into the southern Pacific Ocean near Fiji.

During an exhibition baseball game between the San Francisco Giants and the Arizona Diamondbacks, Randy Johnson's fastball hits and instantly kills a dove flying in front of home plate. The bird appears to explode as the pitch sends it over the catcher's head.
An oil tanker collides with a freighter between eastern Denmark and northwest Germany, spilling 2.9 million litres of oil, creating a slick about 15km long, largest ever in Denmark.
The last edition of WCW Monday Nitro airs, ending the Monday Night Wars which had captivated audiences since the mid 1990s.
The very last broadcast of WCW Monday Night Nitro is held on TNT in Panama City Beach, Florida.
Todd Helton signs a nine-year, $141.5 million contract extension with the Colorado Rockies.
Former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia President Slobodan Milo_evic surrenders to police special forces, to be tried on charges of war crimes.
The first Major League Baseball game is played in Puerto Rico, as the Toronto Blue Jays defeat the Texas Rangers 8-1.

A Chinese fighter jet bumps into a U.S. EP-3E surveillance aircraft which is forced to make an emergency landing in Hainan, China. The U.S. crew is detained for ten days and the F-8 Chinese pilot, Wang Wei, goes missing and is presumed dead.
In the Netherlands, the Act on the Opening up of Marriage goes into effect. The Act allows same-sex couples to legally marry for the first time in the world since the reign of Nero.
Former president of Federal Republic of Yugoslavia Slobodan Milo?evi? surrenders to police special forces, to be tried on charges of war crimes.
The first legal same-sex marriage in the Netherlands is celebrated.

An EP-3E United States Navy plane collides with a Chinese People's Liberation Army fighter jet. The Navy crew makes an emergency landing in Hainan, People's Republic of China and is detained. See Hainan Island incident.
Timothy Thomas, a 19-year-old African-American, is shot by a police officer in Cincinnati, Ohio, sparking riots in downtown Cincinnati from April 10 to April 12.
The Cincinnati Reds defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates 8-2 in the first game at PNC Park, the first two-deck stadium built in the U.S. since Milwaukee County Stadium opened in 1953.
Australia beat American Samoa 31-0 in a 2002 FIFA World Cup qualifying game, an international record.
The detained crew of a United States EP-3E aircraft that landed in Hainan, People's Republic of China after a collision with an J-8 fighter is released.
Disney's Animal Kingdom Lodge opens at Walt Disney World.
San Diego Padres' outfielder Rickey Henderson breaks the career walks record established by Babe Ruth when he receives his 2,063rd base on balls.
Junichiro Koizumi becomes Prime Minister of Japan.
Soyuz TM-32 lifts off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome, carrying the first space tourist, American Dennis Tito.
Millionaire Dennis Tito becomes the world's first space tourist.
The United Kingdom Census is conducted.
Blanche Barton, High Priestess of the Church of Satan, steps down and gives her position to Peter H. Gilmore and Peggy Nadramia.
The Japanese cities of Urawa, Omiya, and Yono merge to form the city of Saitama.
Space tourist Dennis Tito returns to Earth aboard Soyuz TM-31. Soyuz TM-32 is left docked at the International Space Station as a new lifeboat.

In Banja Luka, Bosnia-Herzegovina, an attempt is made to reconstruct the Ferhadija mosque. However, the ceremony results in mass riots by Serb nationalists that beat and stone 300 elderly Bosnian Muslims.
A soccer game stampede in Ghana kills over 120.
The XFL ceases operation by Vince McMahon, Chairman of World Wrestling Federation Entertainment and NBC, citing rapidly decresing ratings.
In Ghana, a stampede at a football game kills over 120 spectators.
Silvio Berlusconi and the Italian House of the Liberties coalition win general elections.
In Germany, Cardinal Karl Lehmann is honored on his 65th birthday for his contributions to cooperation between the Church, society and the state.
Arianna, Queen of Persia, announces her engagement.
French Taubira law which officially recognize the Atlantic slave trade and slavery as crimes against humanity.
(to May 23) The Bah'? Terraces officially open on Mount Carmel in Haifa, Israel (site of the Shrine of the Bb and the Bah'? World Centre).
A large trans-Neptunian object (28978 Ixion) is found during the Deep Ecliptic Survey.
Bayern Mnnchen wins the UEFA Champions League.
Brazil's Petrobras shuts down 12 oil rigs after detecting two oil slicks on the ocean surface, the larger one approximately 110,000 litres.
The Versailles wedding hall collapse in Jerusalem, Israel, kills 23 and injures over 200 in Israel's worst-ever civil disaster.
Mountain climbing: 15-year-old Sherpa Temba Tsheri becomes the youngest person to climb to the top of Mount Everest.
Sherman Bull and Erik Weihenmayer reach summit of Mount Everest, respectively becoming the oldest and first blind person to do so.
An oil tanker runs aground in a southern Chilean fjord, spilling about 350,000 litres of crude oil, creating an oil slick 112km long.
64-year-old Sherman Bull, of New Canaan, Connecticut, becomes the oldest person to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
32-year-old Erik Weihenmayer, of Boulder, Colorado, becomes the first blind person to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
A break in Petrobras' Paulinia oil pipeline dumps 220,000 litres of fuel oil in a residential neighborhood 30km from Sao Paulo, in Brazil.
A Hamas suicide bomber kills 21, mostly teenagers, in the Dolphinarium disco in Tel Aviv, Israel.
Crown Prince Dipendra of Nepal kills his father (King Birendra), his mother (Queen Aiswarya), and other members of the royal family with an assault rifle and then shoots himself, dying June 4.
Crown Prince Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal slaughters his family during a royal dinner. Diprenda was also shot, and was proclaimed king in his hospital bed where he died three days later.

(to June 9) Houston, Texas is devastated by flooding when Tropical Storm Allison produces 36 inches (900 mm) of rain. Particularly hard hit are the downtown area and the Texas Medical Center, which loses years of research and data and thousands of lab animals. Twenty-two people die; damage exceeds US$5 billion.
With a home run in his 57th game, Barry Bonds becomes the fastest player ever to hit 30 home runs.
U.S. Senator Jim Jeffords leaves the Republican party, an act which changes control of the United States Senate from the Republican party to the Democratic party.
U.S. Senator Jim Jeffords leaves the Republican Party, an act which shifts control of the United States Senate from the Republicans to the Democratic Party.

Tropical Storm Allison makes landfall on the upper-Texas coastline as a strong tropical storm and dumps large amounts of rain over Houston. The storm caused $5.5 billion in damages, making Allison the costliest tropical storm in U.S. history.
In Germany, Jnrgen Habermas recieves the Peace Prize of the German Book Dealers Association.
Tony Blair's Labour Party wins the United Kingdom general election.
Tony Blair's Labour Party wins another landslide victory in the General Election.
Mamoru Takuma murders eight first and second grade students and wounds 15 others in Osaka, Japan.
In Germany, Roman Herzog is awarded the "Staatsbnrgerpreis".

The Colorado Avalanche win their second Stanley Cup Championship with a 3-1 victory in Game 7 of the 2001 Stanley Cup Finals over the defending champion New Jersey Devils at Pepsi Center in Denver, Colorado.
Pope John Paul II canonized Saint Rafqa
Nintendo launches the Game Boy Advance portable game system in the USA.
In Terre Haute, Indiana, Timothy McVeigh is executed for the Oklahoma City Bombing.
Timothy McVeigh is executed for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing.
The Los Angeles Lakers beat the Philadelphia 76ers 4-1 to win their second straight NBA Title. They also finish with the best overall record in playoff history, 15-1.
The Lord Mayor of Berlin, Ebehard Diepgen (CDU), is removed from office by a vote of no confidence. The new Lord Mayor is Klaus Wowereit (SPD).
George W. Bush and Vladimir Putin meet in Brdo pri Kranju, Slovenia."
Protests occur in Manipur over the extension of the ceasefire between Naga insurgents and the government of India.
An American missile hits a soccer field in northern Iraq (Tel Afr County), killing 23 and wounding 11.
In Germany Heinz Josef Algermissen is named the bishop of Fulda.
Pervez Musharraf becomes President of Pakistan after the resignation of Muhammad Rafiq Tarar.
With his 38th homerun of the season, Barry Bonds breaks the major league record for home runs hit before the All-Star game.
Pervez Musharraf becomes president of Pakistan.

Near the coast of Peru, a magnitude 8.4 earthquake occurs. At least 75 people killed, 2,687 injured, 17,510 homes destroyed and 35,549 homes damaged in the Arequipa-Camana-Tacna area. A resulting tsunami measured as high as 7 metres, reaching inland 1 kilometre.
International Court of Justice finds against the United States in its judgement in the LaGrand Case.
U.S. Appeals Court overturns a lower court's order to breakup Microsoft in an antitrust case.
Aliso Viejo officially becomes the 34th city in Orange County, California.
The world's first self-contained artificial heart is implanted in Robert Tools.
A Vladivostokavia Tupolev Tu-154 jetliner crashes on approach to landing at Irkutsk, Russia, killing 145.
A Vladivostokavia Tupolev TU-154 jetliner crashes on approach to landing at Irkutsk, Russia killing 145 people.

Hannelore Kohl, the wife of the former chancellor, Helmut Kohl commits suicide. She suffered from a rare, incurable and increasingly painful allergy to light. She had not been able to leave a completely darkened room in their home for 15 months prior to her death.
Near the coast of Peru, a magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurs. Few deaths and injuries, but hundreds of buildings that had been weakened by the previous earthquakes were destroyed.
Beijing wins the bid to host the 2008 Summer Olympics.
The People's Republic of China and the Russian Federation sign the Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation.
The FBI arrests Dmitry Sklyarov at a convention in Las Vegas, Nevada for violating a provision of the DMCA.
The People's Republic of China and the Russian Federation sign the Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation
Inauguration of the Altamira caves' replica created by Manuel Franquelo and Sven Nebel.
In Baltimore, Maryland, a 60-car train derailment occurs in a tunnel, sparking a fire that lasts days and virtually shuts down downtown Baltimore.
In Baltimore, Maryland, a 60-car train derails in a tunnel, sparking a fire that lasts days and virtually shuts down downtown Baltimore.
United Kingdom politician and novelist Jeffrey Archer is sentenced to four years in prison for perjury and perverting the course of justice.
UK politician and novelist Jeffrey Archer, Lord Archer of Weston-super-Mare, is sentenced to four years in prison for perjury and perverting the course of justice.

(to July 22) The 27th G8 summit takes place in Genoa, Italy. Massive demonstrations are held against the meeting by anti-globalisation groups. One demonstrator, Carlo Giuliani, is shot dead by a carabiniere and several others are badly injured, during a police attack on a school used by the protesters as their headquarters.
The London Stock Exchange goes public.
Megawati Soekarnoputri becomes the fifth President of Indonesia, replacing Abdurrahman Wahid.
Tamil Tigers attack Bandaranaika International Airport in Sri Lanka, causing an estimated $500 million of damages.
Larry A. Silverstein signs a $3.2 billion, 99-year lease on the entire World Trade Center complex in New York.

Simeon Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, the last Tsar of Bulgaria when he was a child, was sworn in as Prime Minister of Bulgaria, and became the only monarch in history to regain political power through democratic election to a different office.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union is established.
(to September 23) Over Kerala, India, rain sporadically falls with colors red, yellow, green, and black, the result of the atmospheric disintegration of a comet.
Alejandro Toledo is sworn in as the new president of Peru, 8 months after a vote of no-confidence in former President Alberto Fujimori.
Alejandro Toledo becomes Constitutional President of the Republic of Peru.

Alabama Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy Moore has a 2.5-ton monument of the Ten Commandments (dubbed by both detractors and the media as 'Roy's Rock') surreptitiously installed in the Rotunda of the Judiciary Building.
Bulgaria, Cyprus, Latvia, Malta, Slovenia and Slovakia join the European Environment Agency.
An agreement is reached on the position of the minority Albanian language in the Republic of Macedonia.

Alabama Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy Moore has a 2-1/2 ton Ten Commandments monument installed in the rotunda of the judiciary building, leading to a lawsuit to have it removed and his own removal from office.
Robert Mueller is confirmed as the new FBI director.
The Cleveland Indians defeat the Seattle Mariners 15-14 in a record-setting baseball game known as the Impossible Return.
The Cleveland Indians defeat the Seattle Mariners 15-14 in a record-setting game known as the Impossible Return.
White House briefing entitled Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S. delivered to George W. Bush. This document foreshadowed the September 11, 2001 attacks.
Black Betsy, Shoeless Joe Jackson's 40-ounce warped hickory bat, is won in a 10-day eBay auction. The $577,610 price tag is believed to be the largest amount ever paid for a baseball bat.
U.S. President George W. Bush announces his support for federal funding of limited research on embryonic stem cells.
In the Comoros, the "Military Committee" of Major Mohamad Bacar seizes power in the island of Anjouan, that had declared independence. They plan to rejoin the Comoros.
US President George W. Bush announces his support for federal funding of limited research on embryonic stem cells.
In Jerusalem, 15 people die and 130 are wounded in the Sbarro restaurant suicide bombing.
The Hudson River Way is opened to traffic.
The movie [B] is created on Newgrounds, starting an internet revolution.
The Red Cross announces that a famine is striking Tajikistan, and calls for international financial aid for Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.
A sixth-century temple is discovered in central Mexico.
NATO decides to send a peace-keeping force to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
In Finland, four teenagers assassinate businessman Martti Heino and his wife Elise Heino.
Air Transat Flight 236 runs out of fuel over the Atlantic Ocean (en route to Lisbon from New York) and makes an emergency landing in the Azores.
A Cessna 402 aircraft carrying nine people, including R&B singer Aaliyah, crashes in the Bahamas, killing all aboard.
The libertarian Free State Project is founded at Yale University.
Almost every single commercial television station in Vancouver, British Columbia switches network affiliations after a round of ownership changes in 2000 - the largest change in North America.
Google is awarded a patent, number 6,285,999, for the PageRank search algorithm used in the Google search engine.
Hewlett-Packard announces it will acquire Compaq Computer in a stock swap worth about US$25 billion.

The Tokyo DisneySea theme park opens in Japan. It features seven "ports of call": American Waterfront, Port Discovery, Lost River Delta, Mermaid Lagoon, Arabian Coast, Mysterious Island, and Mediterranean Harbor. There are initially 23 attractions. The park is owned by the Oriental Land Company, Ltd., operated under licence from the Walt Disney Company.
Peru's attorney general files homicide charges against ex-President Alberto Fujimori.
Young Left formed in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
Peru's attorney general files homicide charges against ex-President Alberto Fujimori.
Barry Bonds becomes the fifth major leaguer to hit 60 home runs in a season, reaching the milestone in the shortest time, just 141 games.
The United States Justice Department announces that it no longer seeks to break-up software maker Microsoft, and will instead seek a lesser antitrust penalty.
United States v. Microsoft: The United States Justice Department announces that it was no longer seeking to break-up software maker Microsoft and will instead seek a lesser antitrust penalty.
Durban, South Africa hosts the World Conference against Racism.
68 people die in Estonia after drinking bootleg alcohol that contained methanol.
A suicide bomber kills Ahmed Shah Massoud, military commander of the Afghan Northern Alliance.
Ahmed Shah Massoud, leader of the Northern Alliance, is assassinated in Afghanistan.

US Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld calls a meeting of hundreds of Pentagon senior staff, giving a speech calling the Pentagon bureaucracy an adversary to the security of the USA. He says "... today we declare war on bureaucracy".
Norwegian parliamentary election: Kjell Magne Bondevik returns to power as head of a conservative coalition.
2740 Americans and 236 foreigners die in airplane attacks at the World Trade Center in New York City, The Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia, and in rural Shanksville, Pennsylvania.

Following four plane crashes in the USA, Disney Chairman Michael Eisner and Disney President Robert Iger decide to stage an orderly closing of Walt Disney World, and not open Disneyland or Disney's California Adventure for the day.

The September 11 attacks destroy the World Trade Center in New York City, part of The Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia, and crash a passenger airliner in Pennsylvania. In total almost 3,000 are killed.
NATO Article V of the NATO agreement is invoked for the first time in response to the September 11, 2001 attacks against the United States of America.
Due the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Major League Baseball postpones all games through September 17.
Civilian airplane traffic in the U.S., which had been grounded following the September 11, 2001 attacks, is allowed to resume.
US President George W Bush stands with firefighters and rescue workers at Ground Zero in New York.
