In Japan, Nintendo launches the GameCube video game system. It features 405 MHz "Gekko" processor based on a 256-bit IBM Power PC, and 43 MB RAM. Size is 6 x 6 x 4.3 inches; price is 25,000 yen. Code name during development was Dolphin. 133,719 units sell in the first week.

Historic National Prayer Service held at Washington National Cathedral for victims of the September 11 attacks. While the rest of the world sees the service at the National Cathedral, Canada sees the similar service on Parliament Hill, the largest single vigil ever in the nation's capital. The successor to the Nintendo 64; the Nintendo Gamecube was released in Japan.
President George W. Bush says that the United States of America is at war against terror.
The Queen Isabella Causeway in Texas collapses after being hit by a tugboat, killing eight.
Alex Zanardi, driving in a CART race is injured in Germany, resulting in both legs being amputated below the knee.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes for the day down 684.81 points (7.1 percent), the second largest one-day point drop.
The New York Stock Exchange reopens following the terrorist attacks in New York.
The Late Show with David Letterman is the first TV talk show to return to the airwaves six days after terrorists attack the United States in New York City and Washington D.C.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average opens for the first time after the September 11 attacks. The stocks plummet throughout the trading session and posts its biggest point drop in its history closing down 684.81 points to 8920.70.
First mailing of anthrax letters from Trenton, New Jersey in the 2001 anthrax attacks.
In the light of the New York attack by terrorists the German Bundestag votes full support and solidarity with the USA, including military support.
Commencement of combatant activities in Afghanistan (the date designated by U.S. President George W. Bush in Executive Order 13239 of December 12, 2001).
George W. Bush delivers his "Freedom at War with Fear" speech to a joint session of Congress.
Deep Space 1 flies within 2,200 km of Comet Borrelly.

Sports return to New York for the first time since the terrorist attacks with the New York Mets/Atlanta Braves game at Shea Stadium. Mike Piazza hits a two-run home run in the 8th inning off Steve Karsay to win the game 3-2.
Deep Space 1 flies within 2,200 km of Comet Borrelly.
A ship and a barge collide at Barbour's Cut in La Porte, Texas, USA, leaking about 137,000 litres of fuel oil into the channel.
Thieves with Kalashnikov assault rifles and a wrecking ball break into a cash depository in Bari, Italy, stealing US$4.16 million worth of euro coins.
The Syracuse Herald-Journal, a U.S. newspaper dating back to 1839, ceases publication.
Rickey Henderson of the San Diego Padres breaks Ty Cobb's record to become the leading run-scorer in baseball history, with 2,246th runs.
A hunter shoots a hole in the trans-Alaska Oil Pipeline, causing a leak of 1.1 million litres of oil into the wilderness.
Siberia Airlines Flight 1812 crashes over the Black Sea en route from Tel Aviv, Israel to Novosibirsk, Russia; 78 are killed.
The first case of anthrax attack in the U.S. is announced by federal officials.
A Sibir Airlines Tupolev TU-154 crashes into the Black Sea after being struck by an errant Ukrainian S-200 missile. 78 people are killed.
Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants breaks the single season home run record with his 71st and 72nd home runs of the year. Both are off pitcher Chan Ho Park of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The Atlanta Braves defeat the Florida Marlins 20-3 to clinch the National League East title and becomes the first team in professional sports to win 10 consecutive division titles.
Tom Ridge resigns as Governor of Pennsylvania to become the first director of the newly created United States Office of Homeland Security.

The Seattle Mariners break the Major League Baseball record for wins in a season set by the 1998 New York Yankees, winning their 115th game, defeating the Texas Rangers at Safeco Field. The Mariners finish the season 116-46.
Robert Stevens becomes the first victim in the 2001 anthrax attacks.
Tom Ridge resigned as Governor of Pennsylvania to become President Bush's Homeland Security Advisor.
The Seattle Mariners tie the 1906 Chicago Cubs with 116 wins in a single season for winningest team in major league history.
Pope John-Paul II beatifies two Germans, Nikolaus Gro? and Maria Euthymia _ffing.
The United States armed forces invade Afghanistan, with participation from the United Kingdom.
Start of U.S. invasion of Afghanistan with an air assault and covert operations on the ground.
Flight SK686 of SAS collides first with a private plane and then a building in Milano Airport; 100 are killed.
The 2001 anthrax attacks continue as anthrax letters are mailed from Princeton, New Jersey, to U.S. Senators Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Patrick Leahy of Vermont.
Second mailing of anthrax letters from Trenton, New Jersey in the 2001 anthrax attack.
U.S. President George W. Bush presents a list of 22 most wanted terrorists.
US President George W. Bush presents a list of 22 most wanted terrorists.
The Polaroid Corporation files for federal bankruptcy protection.
Prompted by a request from U.S. President George W. Bush, an episode of America's Most Wanted features the 22 most wanted terrorists.
War on Terrorism: Prompted by a request by US President George W. Bush, an episode of America's Most Wanted aired featuring 22 most wanted terrorists
Michael Schumacher wins the 52nd FIA Formula One World Championship, with a record margin of 58 points.

Delta Flight 458 from Atlanta, Georgia to Newark, New Jersey, is diverted to Charlotte-Douglas International Airport, and passengers are taken off the flight while officials investigate a report of two "Middle Eastern men" making threats in a foreign tongue. It turned out to be two Orthodox Jews who were praying peacefully.
NASA's Galileo spacecraft passes within 112 miles of Jupiter's moon Io.
The New York Yankees beat the Oakland Athletics to win the American League Division Series.
The Arizona Diamondbacks win the National League Division Series beating the Saint Louis Cardinals.
NASA's Galileo spacecraft passes within 112 miles of Jupiter's moon Io.
U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: U.S. warplanes mistakenly bomb International Red Cross warehouse in Kabul, Afghanistan.
A Petrobras tanker strikes underwater rocks off Paranagua, Brazil, leaking about 392,000 litres of naphtha.
SIEV-X sinks en route to Christmas Island.
SIEV-X sinks en route to Christmas Island

The Concert for New York City, "a celebration of the strength, resilience, and pride of New York and America" is held, featuring performances by The Who, Paul McCartney, David Bowie, Backstreet Boys, Billy Joel, Destiny's Child, Eric Clapton, Adam Sandler, Bon Jovi, Elton John and many more.

What More Can I Give benefit concert held in Washington D.C., featuring performances by Michael Jackson, Aerosmith, Mariah Carey, James Brown, Al Green, Carole King, the Backstreet Boys, 'N Sync, P!nk, and others.
Apple Computer introduces the iPod portable music player. It features 5 GB hard drive, and FireWire port. Price is US$399.
The Provisional Irish Republican Army of Northern Ireland commences disarmament after peace talks encouraged by American President Bill Clinton.
The USA PATRIOT Act becomes law.
The United States passes the controversial USA Patriot Act into law.
Former German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, is awarded the Westphalien Peace Prize in recognition of his effort for German reunification.
George W. Bush throws out the first pitch at Game 3 of the World Series at Yankee Stadium, in what was intended to be a defiant gesture, coming just weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Michael Jordan returns to the National Basketball Association with the Washington Wizards after 3 1/2 years (the Wizards lose 93-91 to the New York Knicks).
Searchers recover $230 million in gold and silver from vaults of the Bank of Nova Scotia among rubble of the destroyed World Trade Center in New York City.
Derek Jeter hits the Major League Baseball's first November home run at the World Series.
The Glocal Forum, leading international organization in the field of city-to-city cooperation, is established by Ambassador Uri Savir.
The Police Service of Northern Ireland is established, replacing the controversial Royal Ulster Constabulary.
The Arizona Diamondbacks beat the three-time defending World Series Champions New York Yankees in seven games to win their first ever baseball World Series Championship.
Hurricane Michelle hits Cuba, destroying crops and thousands of homes.
Hurricane Michelle hits Cuba, destroying crops and thousands of homes.
The Police Service of Northern Ireland is established.
John Bennett of the United Kingdom dives 307.8m deep at Escarcia point, Puerto Galero in the Philippines, deepest scuba dive to date.
Michael Bloomberg is elected mayor of New York City.
David Trimble is re-elected prime minister of Northern Ireland
Belgian national airline Sabena is declared bankrupt.
The super-sonic commercial aircraft Concorde resumes flying after a 15-month break.
The supersonic commercial aircraft Concorde resumes flying after a 15-month break.
Heavy rains and mudslides in Algeria kill more than 900 people.
The People's Republic of China is admitted to the World Trade Organization after 15 years of negotiations.
Australian Prime Minister John Howard is elected to a third term.
The National Alliance holds a protest outside the Israeli Embassy in Washington, D. C. concerning the attacks of September 11, 2001.
St. Louis Cardinals' first baseman Mark McGwire turns down a two-year, US$30 million extension, retiring from the sport.

In New York City, American Airlines Flight 587 en route to the Dominican Republic crashes in Queens, New York minutes after takeoff from John F. Kennedy International Airport, killing all 260 on board.
Taliban forces abandon Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, ahead of advancing Afghan Northern Alliance troops, which take the city on November 14.
(to November 13) Stack's of New York sells at auction the finest known 1893-S Morgan dollar for US$414,000, second highest price paid for a Morgan dollar at auction.
In New York City, an Airbus A300 carrying American Airlines Flight 587 crashes minutes after takeoff from John F. Kennedy International Airport, killing all 260 on board.
2001 Attack on Afghanistan: Taliban forces abandon Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, ahead of advancing Afghan Northern Alliance troops.
The World Trade Organization ends a four-day ministerial conference in Doha, Qatar.

In the first such act since World War II, U.S. President George W. Bush signs an executive order allowing military tribunals against any foreigners suspected of having connections to terrorist acts or planned acts against the United States.

War on Terrorism: In the first such act since World War II, US President George W. Bush signs an executive order allowing military tribunals against any foreigners suspected of having connections to terrorist acts or planned acts on the United States.
Doha Round: The World Trade Organization ends a four-day ministerial conference in Doha, Qatar.
Attack on Afghanistan: Afghan Northern Alliance fighters takeover the capital Kabul.

Microsoft launches the Xbox video game system in North America. Price is US$299. The system features four controller ports, one controller, 8 GB hard drive, 733 MHz Intel main processor, 250 MHz NVidia XGP graphics processor, 64 MB RAM, 3D audio support, Ethernet port, broadband Internet connection. Games come on dual-layer DVD-ROM discs that can store 9 GB of data. The system can also play DVD movies. 500,000 units are sold in the first seven days; 1.5 million in the first month.

Nintendo releases the GameCube video game system in the USA. It features four controller ports, one controller, 485 MHz IBM Gekko main processor, 162 MHz ATI Technologies "Flipper" graphics processor, 40 MB RAM, DVD-based proprietary disc drive. Games come on 3-inch optical discs holding up to 1.5 GB. Price is US$199.95. Over 500,000 are sold in the first week.

In Washington, D.C., U.S. President George W. Bush dedicates the United States Department of Justice headquarters building as the Robert F. Kennedy Justice Building, honoring the late Robert F. Kennedy on what would have been his 76th birthday.
Pope John Paul II sends the first papal e-mail from a laptop computer in his office.
Former German Minister of Defense, Gerhard Stoltenberg (CDU) dies of cancer at his home in Bonn-Bad Godesberg.

The Calgary Stampeders win the Canadian Football League Championship for the first time since 1998, defeating the Winnipeg Blue Bombers 27-19 in the 89th Grey Cup at Olympic Stadium in Montreal, Quebec.
Richard Burns becomes first ever English World Rally Championship champion.
The Hubble Space Telescope detects the first atmosphere (in this case, hydrogen) on an extrasolar planet (on Osiris).
A hydrogen atmosphere is discovered on the extrasolar planet Osiris by the Hubble Space Telescope, the first atmosphere detected on an extrasolar planet.
Trans World Airlines flies its last flight, after being bought by American Airlines.

Enron Corporation, based in Houston, Texas, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in a New York court, five days after Dynegy cancels a US$8.4 billion buyout bid. At the time this is the largest bankruptcy in U.S. history.
Officials announce that one of the Taliban prisoners captured after the prison uprising at Mazari Sharif, Afghanistan is John Walker Lindh, an American citizen.

Lisa Beamer, wife of Todd Beamer, through the Todd M. Beamer Foundation, registers [1] the trademark "Let's Roll" with the United States Patent and Trademark Office less than three months after his death in the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States.
World Record set for longest recorded kiss in New York.
The United States government indicts Zacarias Moussaoui for involvement in the September 11, 2001 attacks.
The People's Republic of China joins the World Trade Organization.
U.S. President George W. Bush announces the United States' withdrawal from the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.
The Parliament of India is attacked by terrorists, killing 14 people. This brings India and Pakistan to the brink of war.
The New York Yankees sign Jason Giambi to a seven-year deal worth US$120 million.
the Indian Parliament Sansad is attacked by Terrorists, killing 15 people, including all the terrorists. Tensions escalate in South Asia, with nuclear war likelihoods.
Italy's Leaning Tower of Pisa reopens after 11 years and US$27 million to fortify the tower without eliminating its famous lean.
Stefan Heym, German writer, dies while attending a Heinrich Heine conference in Israel.
The Cathedral of Saint John the Divine in Manhattan, New York City, is damaged by fire.

In Argentina, President Fernando de la R?a and finance minister Domingo Cavallo impose stricter austerity measures. The resulting population revolt is put down by federal police. 21 are killed, 1350 injured.
A new world-record high barometric pressure of 1085.6 hPa (32.06 inHg) is recorded in Tosontsengel, Khvsgl Province, Mongolia.

Argentine economic crisis: December 2001 riots - Riots erupt in Buenos Aires after Domingo Cavallo's corralito measures restrict the withdrawal of cash from bank deposits. The film The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring is released.
A record high barometric pressure of 1085.6 hPa (32.06 inHg) is recorded at Tosontsengel, Hövsgöl in Mongolia.
Argentine economic crisis (1999-2002): President of Argentina Fernando de la Ra is forced out of office.
Chan Ho Park signs a five-year, $65 million deal with the Texas Rangers.
A flight from Paris, France to Miami, Florida is diverted to Boston, Massachusetts after passenger Richard Reid attempts to set his shoe, filled with explosives, on fire.
Hamid Karzai is sworn in as head of the interim government in Afghanistan.
Richard Reid attempts to destroy a passenger airliner by igniting explosives hidden in his shoes aboard American Airlines Flight 63.
Burhanuddin Rabbani, political leader of the Afghan Northern Alliance, hands over power in Afghanistan to the interim government headed by President Hamid Karzai.
Cc the cat, the first cloned pet, is born.
Typhoon Vamei forms within 1.5 degrees of the equator. No other tropical cyclone in recorded history has come as close to the equator.
The People's Republic of China is granted permanent normal trade status with the United States.
The People's Republic of China is granted permanent normal trade relations with the United States.
A massive fire in the historic district of downtown Lima, Peru kills at least 274 people.
The Open Skies mutual surveillance treaty, initially signed in 1992, officially enters into force.
Euro banknotes and coins become legal tender in twelve of the European Union's member states.
Taiwan officially joins the World Trade Organization, as Chinese Taipei.
Euro notes and coins are issued in France, Spain, Germany, Italy, Portugal, Greece, Finland, Luxembourg, Belgium, Austria, Ireland and the Netherlands, replacing those countries' currencies.
Levy Mwanawasa takes office as the third President of Zambia.
The University of Miami defeats Nebraska 37-14 in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, California to win college football's national championship.
The Saint Louis Cardinals agrees to a three-year, $27 million deal with Matt Morris.
Charles Bishop, a 15 year-old student pilot, crashes a light aircraft into a Tampa, Florida building, evoking fear of a copycat 9/11 terrorist attack.
IBM announces it will no longer manufacture desktop personal computers in most of the world. It will sell its desktop facilities in US and Europe to Sanmina-SCI.
Juan Gonzalez agrees to a $24 million, two-year deal with the Texas Rangers.
Billy Wagner signs a US$27 million deal with the Houston Astros.
The United States Department of Justice announces it will pursue a criminal investigation of Enron.
The United States Department of Justice announces it is going to pursue a criminal investigation of Enron.
Enrique Bolaos begins his five-year term as President of the Republic of Nicaragua.
The X (roller coaster) opens at Six Flags Magic Mountain in Valencia, Santa Clarita, California.
In the AFC Divisional Playoffs the New England Patriots defeat the Oakland Raiders 16-13 in overtime at their home finale Foxboro Stadium.
Barry Bonds agrees to a five-year, $90 million deal with the San Francisco Giants.
U.S. Attorney General John Ashcroft announces that American Taliban member John Walker Lindh will be tried in the United States.
The United Nations Security Council unanimously establishes an arms embargo and freezes the assets of Osama bin Laden, Al-Qaida, and the Taliban.
A student shoots six people at the Appalachian School of Law in Grundy, Virginia, killing three.
The UN Security Council unanimously establishes an arms embargo and the freezing of assets of Osama bin Laden, Al-Qaida, and the remaining members of the Taliban.
Jermaine Dye agrees to a three-year extension worth $32 million to stay with the Oakland Athletics.
The eruption of Mount Nyiragongo in the Democratic Republic of the Congo displaces an estimated 400,000 people.
Mount Nyiragongo erupts in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, displacing an estimated 400,000 people.
A Canadian Pacific Railway train carrying anhydrous ammonia derails outside of Minot, North Dakota, killing one.
Scott Rolen signs the largest contract in team history, a $8.6 million, one-year deal with the Philadelphia Phillies.

A Canadian Pacific Railway train carrying anhydrous ammonia derails outside of Minot, North Dakota, killing one man and calling into question the maintenance of CP track and the policy of voice-tracking used by Clear Channel Communications.
Michael Jordan, formerly of the Washington Wizards, plays his first game in Chicago since rejoining the NBA.
Canadian Dollar sets all-time low against the US Dollar (US$0.6179).
AOL Time Warner brings a federal suit against Microsoft alleging that the market for AOL's Netscape Navigator Internet browser was harmed when Microsoft started to give away a competing browser.
Kmart Corp becomes the largest retailer in American history to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl is kidnapped in Pakistan, accused of being a US Central Intelligence Agency agent by his captors.
Reporter Daniel Pearl is kidnapped -- and subsequently murdered -- in Karachi, Pakistan.
American Taliban John Walker Lindh returns to the United States under FBI custody.
Thomas Junta kills junior coach Michael Costin during a fight at a junior hockey game in Massachusetts.
Wikipedia switches to the new version of its software ("Phase II") aka Magnus Manske Day.
Several explosions at a military dump in Lagos, Nigeria kill more than 1,000.
Astrid Lindgren dies peacefully in her apartment in Stockholm, Sweden at age 94. About 130 million of her books are in circulation, translated into 86 languages.
An Ecuadoran airline Boeing 727-100 crashes in the Andes mountains in southern Colombia killing 92.
In his State of the Union Address, United States President George W. Bush describes "regimes that sponsor terror" as an Axis of Evil, in which he includes Iraq, Iran and North Korea.
Slobodan Milo?evi? accuses the United Nations war crimes tribunal of an "evil and hostile attack" against him.
A large section of the Antarctic Larsen Ice Shelf begins disintegrating, eventually consuming about 3,250 km (1,254 miles) over a 35-day period.
A large section of the Antarctic Larsen Ice Shelf begins disintegrating, eventually consuming about 3,250 km² (1,254 miles²) over a 35-day period.
Kidnapped Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl is murdered in Karachi, Pakistan.
Crown Prince Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands marries Mxima, Princess of Orange in Amsterdam.
Wedding of Crown Prince Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands to the Argentinean born Mxima Zorreguieta in Amsterdam.
Costa Rica holds presidential and congressional elections.
The New England Patriots beat the Saint Louis Rams 20-17, in NFL Super Bowl XXXVI in New Orleans.
(to February 24) The XIX Olympic Winter Games are held in Salt Lake City, Utah, USA.
A cargo ship carrying over 815,000 litres of fuel oil runs aground near the north island port of Gisborne, New Zealand, sending an oil slick drifting to shore, rivers, and beaches.
In the 52nd NBA All Star Game the West defeats the East in Philadelphia at the Wachovia Center.
For the first time in its history, Major League Baseball owns a team after acquiring the Expos from Jeffrey Loria for $120 million.

The trial of former Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic begins at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Netherlands, on charges of genocide and war crimes in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo.
The U.S. Secretary of Energy makes the decision that Yucca Mountain is suitable to be the United States' nuclear waste repository.
Nuclear waste: US Secretary of Energy makes the decision that Yucca Mountain is suitable to be the United States' nuclear repository.
An Iran Air Tupolev Tu-154 crashes prior to landing in Khorramabad, Iran, killing 119.
The trial of former President of Federal Republic of Yugoslavia Slobodan Milo?evi? begins at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Milo?evi? eventually dies before its conclusion.
Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom gives former New York City mayor Rudolph Giuliani an honorary knighthood.
The Tullaghmurray Lass sinks off the coast of Kilkeel, County Down, Northern Ireland killing three members of the same family on board.

At the Tri-State Crematory in La Fayette, Georgia, investigators find uncremated bodies disposed of in the woods and buildings on the crematorium's property. The discovery reveals one of the worst incidents of abuse in the funeral service industry.
Rachel Thaler, 16, is blown up at a pizzeria in an Israeli shopping mall following a suicide bombing attack on a crowd of teens.
NASA's Mars Odyssey space probe begins to map the surface of Mars using its thermal emission imaging system.
NASA's Mars Odyssey space probe begins to map the surface of Mars using its thermal emission imaging system.
In Reqa Al-Gharbiya, Egypt, a fire on a train injures over 65 and kills at least 370.

In most of the world, at 20:02 (8:02 PM) the local time, date (written as day/month), time, and year are all 2002, making each of them alone, any two together, and the combination of all 3, all palindromes.
In Reqa Al-Gharbiya, Egypt, a fire on a train injures over 65 and kills at least 370.
A Norwegian-facilitated ceasefire begins in Sri Lanka.
Angolan political and rebel leader Jonas Savimbi is killed in a military ambush.
A MH-47E Chinook helicopter crashes into the ocean near the Philippines, killing all 10 aboard.
FARC kidnaps Ingrid Betancourt in Colombia while she campaigns for the presidency.
The Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City, Utah end.
A series of riots leaves hundreds dead, after 59 Hindu pilgrims die aboard a train burned by a Muslim mob in Godhra, India.
Ryanair Flight 296 catches fire in London Stansted Airport. Subsequent investigations criticize Ryanair's handling of the evacuation.

2002 Gujarat violence: a train catches fire a few minutes after it leaves the Godhra railway station, killing an estimated 58 Hindu pilgrims returning from Ayodhya and triggering riots that lead to the death of 1000 people, mostly Muslims.
The ex-currencies of all euro members officially (at EU-level) cease to be legal tender.
At least 55 are killed in Ahmadabad, India when Hindus burn Muslim homes.
The Peseta is discontinued as the official currency of Spain and is replaced with the euro.
Space Shuttle Columbia flies the Hubble Space Telescope service mission, its last before STS-107.
The Envisat environmental satellite successfully reaches an orbit 800 km above the Earth using an Ariane 5 on its 11th launch, carrying the heaviest payload to date at 8500kg.
Continuing violence in Ahmedabad kills 28; police shoot and kill five rioters.
In eastern Afghanistan, Operation Anaconda begins.
U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: Operation Anaconda begins in eastern Afghanistan.
Space Shuttle Columbia lifts off for mission STS-109, its final successful mission.
The Envisat environmental satellite successfully reaches an orbit 800 kilometers (500 miles) above the Earth on its 11th launch, carrying the heaviest payload to date at 8500 kilograms (9.5 tons).
The Peseta is discontinued as official currency of Spain and is replaced with the euro (?).
U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: Operation Anaconda begins, (ending on March 19 after killing 500 Taliban and al Qaeda fighters, with 11 allied troop fatalities).
S?o TomT and Pr?ncipe hold legislative elections.
Citizens of Switzerland narrowly vote in favour of their country becoming a member of the United Nations.
Canada banned human embryo cloning but permitted government-funded scientists to use embryos left over from fertility treatment or abortions.
The moderate leader albanophone Ibrahim Rugova is elected President of Kosovo by the Parliament of the Serb province that had been under international control since 1999.
France agrees to return the remains of Saartjie Baartman to South Africa.
The Network Against Prohibition forms in Darwin, Australia.
Opening of The IX Paralympic Winter Games in Salt Lake City, Utah.
BBC 6 Music, the first new BBC music radio station in decades, is launched.
In Houston, Texas, Andrea Yates is found guilty of drowning her five children on June 20, 2001. She is later sentenced to life in prison.

In Texas, Andrea Yates is found guilty of drowning her five children on June 20, 2001. She is later sentenced to life in prison. Her sentence would be overturned on appeal and she would end up being retried in 2006.
125 vehicles are involved in a massive pile-up on Interstate 75 in Ringgold, Georgia, USA.
The German philosopher Hans-Georg Gadamer dies.
The Walt Disney Studios Park opens next to Disneyland Paris in France.
Closing ceremonies of the Winter Paralympics in Salt Lake City, Utah, USA.
Brittanie Cecil, age 13, is struck by a hockey puck while watching an NHL game in Columbus, Ohio. She dies from her injuries two days later.
In Islamabad, Pakistan, the International Protestant Church attack occurs.
Operation Anaconda in Afghanistan ends (started on March 1) after killing 500 Taliban and al Qaeda fighters, with 11 allied troop fatalities.
U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: Operation Anaconda ends (started on March 2) after killing 500 Taliban and al Qaeda fighters with 11 allied troop fatalities.
In Pakistan, Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh along with three other suspects are charged with murder in the kidnapping and killing of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.
In Pakistan, Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh along with three other suspects are charged with murder for their part in the kidnapping and killing of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.
A suicide bomber kills 28 people in Netanya, Israel.
Passover Massacre: A suicide bomber kills 29 people in Netanya, Israel.
Premiere of Janez Lapajne's first feature film Rustling Landscapes (?elestenje).
A Belize-registered cargo ship collides with a fishing boat and sinks, leaving a 10km long oil slick.
Maryland defeats Indiana 64-52 to win the NCAA Men's Basketball Championship at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, Georgia.
The Netherlands legalizes euthanasia, becoming the only nation in the world to do so.
Israeli forces besiege the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, when militants take shelter there.
Israeli forces surrounded the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem into which armed Palestinians retreated. A siege ensues.
A ship spills 340,000 litres of crude oil off the southeast Louisiana coast, USA.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing changes its company name to 3M Company.
The funeral of Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother takes place in Westminster Abbey, London.
Janez Lapajne's first feature film Rustling Landscapes (?elestenje) is released in theatres.
(to April 14) Failed military coup d'Ttat against Venezuelan President Hugo Chvez.
The Ghriba synagogue bombing by Al Qaeda kills 21 in Tunisia.
An attempted coup d'Ttat in Venezuela against President Hugo Chvez began.
Pedro Carmona becomes interim President of Venezuela during the Venezuelan coup attempt of 2002, a military coup against Hugo Chvez.
In Caracas, Venezuela, poor people protest in the streets against the military coup against Hugo Chvez, resulting in his return to power.
The Venezuelan coup attempt of 2002 ends. President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela returns
An Air China Boeing 767-200 crashes into a hillside during heavy rain and fog near Pusan, South Korea, killing 128.
The Alameda Corridor transportation project in Los Angeles, California opens to rail traffic, ceasing operations of freight trains on the 120-year-old BNSF Harbor Subdivision.
An Air China Boeing 767-200, flight CA129 crashes into hillside during heavy rain and fog near Pusan, South Korea, killing 128.
Dr. Bernd Pischetsrieder becomes the seventh CEO of the Volkswagen automobile company, succeeding Dr. Ferdinand Piech.
Four Canadian infantrymen are killed in Afghanistan by friendly fire from two US F-16s.
Four Canadian Forces soldiers are killed in Afghanistan by friendly fire from two U.S. Air Force F-16s, the first deaths in a combat zone for Canada since the Korean War.
French presidential election: The first round results in a runoff between Jacques Chirac and the leader of the main French far-right party, Jean-Marie Le Pen.
At a special session of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, Director-General Jose Bustani is fired.
Soyuz TM-34: South African Mark Shuttleworth blasts off from the Baikonur cosmodrome; he had paid ?15 million for the trip.
Robert SteinhSuser opens fire on his former teachers and other students in Erfurt, Germany and then kills himself; 16 are dead.
19-year-old Robert Steinhäuser shoots and kills 17 people at his school in Erfurt, Germany.
The Laughlin, Nevada River Run Riot leaves three dead.
The United States is re-elected to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, one year after losing the seat it had held for 50 years.
Pakistani voters approve a referendum granting a five-year term for Pakistani president Pervez Musharraf.
A referendum in Pakistan overwhelmingly approves the Presidency of Pervez Musharraf for another five years.
Tevor Hoffman of the San Diego Padres establishes a new major league record for the most saves for one team: 321.
In Germany, BV Borussia Dortmund wins the Bundesliga title after a 2-1 victory over SV Werder Bremen.
An EAS Airlines BAC 1-11-500 crashes in a suburb of Kano, Nigeria shortly after takeoff killing more than 148 people.
In the second round of the French presidential election, Jacques Chirac is re-elected.
In the Netherlands, politician Pim Fortuyn is killed by Volkert van der Graaf.
Jean-Pierre Raffarin becomes Prime Minister of France.
Pim Fortuyn, Dutch politician, is shot, while he's running for prime minister.
A China Southern Airlines MD-82 plunges into the Yellow Sea, killing 112 people.
The German city of Aachen presents its Charlemagne (Karl) prize to the Euro. The prize is accepted by the president of the European Bank, Wim Duisenberg.
The 38-day stand-off in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem comes to an end when the Palestinians inside agree to have 13 suspected militants among them deported to several different countries.
In Kaspiysk, Russia, a remote-control bomb explodes during a holiday parade, killing 43 and injuring at least 130.
In Kaspiysk, Russia, a remote-controlled bomb explodes during a holiday parade killing 43 and injuring at least 130.
The 38-day stand-off in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem comes to an end when the Palestinians inside agree to have 13 suspected militants among them deported to several different countries.
FBI agent Robert Hanssen is sentenced to life without the possibility of parole for selling American secrets to Moscow for $1.4 million in cash and diamonds.
FBI agent Robert Hanssen is given a life sentence without the possibility of parole for selling United States secrets to Moscow for $1.4 million in cash and diamonds.
Lynda Lyon Block is executed in Yellow Mama, the electric chair of Alabama.

Ray Charles takes part - with other musicians - in a peace concert in Rome, which is the first event to take place inside the city's ancient Colosseum since 404 A.D. The event was organized in partnership with the Glocal Forum and the Quincy Jones Listen Up Foundation.

Her Royal Highness Princess Margriet of the Netherlands unveiled the Man With Two Hats monument in Ottawa on May 11, 2002, and the other in Apeldoorn on May 2, 2000. Symbolically linking both Netherlands and Canada for their assistance throughout the Second World War.
Former President Jimmy Carter arrives in Cuba for a five-day visit with Fidel Castro, becoming the first U.S. President, in or out of office, to visit the island since Castro's 1959 revolution.
The Russian Shuttle Buran is destroyed when the roof of the hangar collapses, killing eight workers.

Former President Jimmy Carter arrives in Cuba for a five-day visit with Fidel Castro becoming first President of the United States, in or out of office, to visit the island since Castro's 1959 revolution.

At the Latino-American Stadium, former US President Jimmy Carter throws the ceremonial first pitch of the Cuban League All-Star game. In warming up, Carter is coached by one-time big league pitching prospect, Fidel Castro.
Ten members of the Darwin-based Network Against Prohibition invade the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory of Australia.
The Netherlands holds elections for the Lower House.
East Timor becomes independent from Indonesian rule.
The US State Department releases a report naming seven state sponsors of terrorism: Iran, Iraq, Cuba, Libya, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.
In Washington, DC, Chandra Levy's remains are found in Rock Creek Park.
A jury in Birmingham, Alabama convicts former Ku Klux Klan member Bobby Frank Cherry of the 1963 murders of four girls.
In Washington, DC, the remains of the missing Chandra Levy are found in Rock Creek Park.

American civil rights movement: A jury in Birmingham, Alabama, convicts former Ku Klux Klan member Bobby Frank Cherry of the 1963 murders of four girls in the bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church.
Estonia hosts the first Eurovision Song Contest in a former Soviet republic.
Irish Football Captain Roy Keane is sent home from the Training Camp in Saipan by Manager Mick McCarthy, after an argument over training arrangements.
The "55 parties" clause of the Kyoto protocol is reached after its ratification by Iceland.
The Boston Celtics come back from 26 points down to defeat the New Jersey Nets in Game three of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference Finals.
China Airlines Flight 611 breaks up near the Penghu Islands at Taiwan Strait, killing all 225 people on board.
China Airlines Flight 611: A Boeing 747-200 breaks apart in mid-air and plunges into the Taiwan Strait killing 225 people.
A train crash in Tenga, Mozambique kills 197 people.
A barge collides with the Interstate 40 bridge across the Arkansas River in eastern Oklahoma, leaving 14 dead.
The Mars Odyssey finds signs of huge water ice deposits on the planet Mars.
The Mars Odyssey finds signs of huge water ice deposits on the planet Mars.
lvaro Uribe becomes President of Colombia.
The Mars Odyssey finds signs of large ice deposits on the planet Mars.
The 2002 FIFA World Cup begins, co-hosted by South Korea and Japan.
A series a major storms blew through Western Pennsylvania killing 1 person when the Whip pavillion at Kennywood collapsed.
The 17th Football World Cup, co-hosted by Japan and South Korea, begins with a 1-0 upset of France by Senegal. The tournament ends on June 30, with Brazil winning a record fifth World Cup title.

The Secretary of the Navy directed all United States Navy ships to fly the First Navy Jack in honor of those killed in the September 11, 2001 attacks. The ensign will be flown for the duration of the War on Terrorism.
The Los Angeles Lakers defeat the Sacramento Kings 112-106, to win Game 7 of the National Basketball Association's 2002 Western Conference Finals.
The "Party in the Palace" takes place at Buckingham Palace, London for Queen Elizabeth II's Golden Jubilee celebrations.
The peak day of Golden Jubilee celebrations occurs in the United Kingdom.
The planetoid Quaoar is discovered orbiting the Sun in the Kuiper belt.

Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh ride in the gold state coach from Buckingham Palace to Saint Paul's Cathedral for a special service marking the Queen's 50 years on the throne. In New York, the Empire State Building is lit in purple for her honor.
Hitting his 587th home run, Barry Bonds passes Frank Robinson becoming fourth on the all-time career home run list.
Mozilla 1.0, the first 'official' version, is released.
An asteroid or comet estimated at 5-10 metres in diameter explodes over the Mediterranean Sea between Greece and Libya with an estimated force slightly more powerful than the Nagasaki atomic bomb.

A near-Earth asteroid estimated at 10 metres diameter explodes over the Mediterranean Sea. The resulting explosion is estimated to have a force of 26 kilotons, slightly more powerful than the Nagasaki atomic bomb.
England beat Argentina in the 2002 FIFA World Cup group stages
Serena Williams defeats her sister Venus Williams in straight sets to win the 2002 French Open.
In the United Kingdom, Kevin Warwick carries out the first direct electronic communication experiment between the nervous systems of two humans.
Antonio Meucci is recognized as the first inventor of the telephone by the United States Congress.
Antonio Meucci was recognised as the first inventor of the telephone by the United States Congress.
The Los Angeles Lakers defeat the New Jersey Nets four games to zero to win the 2002 NBA Finals.
The Detroit Red Wings defeat the Carolina Hurricanes four games to one in the 2002 Stanley Cup Finals.
In Karachi, Pakistan, a car bomb in front of the U.S. Consulate kills 12 Pakistanis and injures 50.
Twelve are killed and 50 injured by a car bomb explosion in front of the U.S. consulate in Karachi, Pakistan.
Near Earth Asteroid 2002 MN misses our planet by 75,000 miles (120,000 km) about one third the distance to the moon.
Arizona experiences its worst forest fire, burning 462,606 acres (1,872 square km) near the Mogollon Rim.
Total Nonstop Action Wrestling makes its debut on Pay-Per-View (the first weekly wrestling show on PPV).
Saint Louis Cardinals pitcher Darryl Kile is found dead of a heart attack in his Chicago hotel room.
An earthquake in western Iran measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale kills more than 261 people.
The Igandu train disaster in Dodoma Region, Tanzania, kills 281 people in the worst rail accident in African history.
U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney serves as Acting President for two and a half hours, while President George W. Bush undergoes a colonoscopy procedure.
Brazil defeats Germany in the 2002 FIFA World Cup.

The International Criminal Court is established to prosecute individuals for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression. Crimes committed on or after this date may be prosecuted by the court.
A Russian passenger jet and a cargo plane collide over the town of Uberlingen in Southern Germany, killing 72.
A Bashkirian Airlines Tupolev TU-154 and a DHL (German cargo) Boeing 757 collide in mid-air over Ueberlingen, southern Germany, killing 71.
Steve Fossett becomes the first person to fly solo around the world in a balloon.
Steve Fossett becomes the first person to fly solo around the world nonstop in a balloon.
The Organization of African Unity is officially disbanded and replaced by the African Union.
The African Union was established in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The first chairman was Thabo Mbeki, President of South Africa.
At a Sotheby's auction, Peter Paul Rubens' painting The Massacre of the Innocents is sold for £49.5million (US$76.2 million) to Lord Kenneth Thomson.
Gay rights: The Superior Court of Ontario orders Ontario to recognize same-sex marriages.
A lightning strike sets off the Sour Biscuit Fire in Oregon and northern California, which is left to burn 499,570 acres (2,022 square km).
A lightning strike sets off the Sour Biscuit Fire in Oregon and northern California, which had burned 499,570 acres (2,020 km2) when finally contained on September 5.
During Bastille Day celebrations, French President Jacques Chirac escapes an assassination attempt unscathed.
During Bastille Day celebrations, French President Jacques Chirac escapes an assassination attempt unscathed.

In Washington, DC, "American Taliban" John Walker Lindh pleads guilty to aiding the enemy and possession of explosives during the commission of a felony. Lindh agrees to serve ten years in prison for each charge.
American Taliban John Walker Lindh pleads guilty to supplying aid to the enemy and for the possession of explosives during the commission of a felony.
Anti-Terrorism Court of Pakistan awarded death sentence to British born Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh and life term to three other suspects in murdering Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.
Apple's program iCal premiers at the Macworld Expo in New York City. This date is displayed on the icon of the program when it is not being used.
In Henan Province, the People's Republic of China, 25 die and hundreds are injured due to hail.
A 250-kilogram American bomb from World War II is found in Berlin during a construction project. Hundreds of residents are evacuated for several hours during the defusing of the bomb.
Italy: The 27th Annual G8 summit opens in Genoa. An Italian protester in Genoa, Carlo Giuliani, is shot by police.
The United States Senate confirms Roger L. Gregory as the first black to sit on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
South America: A fire in a discotheque in Lima, Peru kills over twenty-five.
Telecommunications giant WorldCom files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (the largest such filing in United States history).
Telecom giant WorldCom files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the largest such filing in United States history.
Israel assassinates Salah Shahade, the Commander-in-Chief of Hamas's military arm, the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades, along with 14 civilians.
Vittorio Innocente cycles a record depth underwater, 52.5m down on the ocean floor off Genoa, Italy.
Alfred Moisiu becomes President of Albania.
James Traficant is expelled from the United States House of Representatives on a vote of 420 to 1.
Queen Elizabeth II opens the XVII Commonwealth Games in Manchester, England. The Games run until August 4.
Kardinal Joachim Degenhardt, German Archbishop of Paderborn dies at age 76.
A Sukhoi Su-27 fighter crashes at an air show in Ukraine, killing 78 and injuring more than 100 others (the largest air show disaster in history).
Helen Clark, leader of the New Zealand Labour Party, is re-elected in a historic landslide victory over the Right Wing.
Ukraine airshow disaster: A Sukhoi Su-27 fighter crashes during an air show at Lviv, Ukraine killing 85 and injuring more than 100 others, the largest air show disaster in history.
Nine coal miners trapped in the flooded Quecreek Mine in Somerset County, Pennsylvania, were rescued after 77 hours underground.

Sotheby's in New York in conjunction with Stack's auctions the King Farouk specimen of the US 1933 Saint-Gaudens double eagle for $7,590,020, a world record for a single coin at auction. The $20 represents a $20 Federal Reserve note paid by auctioneer David Redden to Mint Director Henrietta Holsman Fore to officially monetize the coin.
The accounting law referred to as "The Sarbanes Oxley Act" was signed into law by United States President George W. Bush
Los Angeles Sparks center Lisa Leslie became the first woman to dunk in a basketball game.
In the south of Panama, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake occurs. No deaths, about 20 injured, some building damage and collapses, felt strongly in parts of Argentina and Costa Rica.
Torrential rains in southern Romania damage an oil pipeline near the village of Manesti, 50km north of Bucharest, spilling thousands of litres of oil into the Prahova River.
Manindra Agrawal et al prove the long standing number theory conjecture in the article entitled "Primes in P".
Marquis de la Fayette is made Honorary Citizen of the United States
Tama-chan, a bearded seal native to the Arctic, is first spotted in Tama River in Tokyo, Japan. The seal subsequently becomes a national celebrity with TV stations tracking its every move.
Turkmenistan adopts a law to rename all the months and most of the days of the week according to Ruhnama, a book written by Turkmen president Saparmurat Niyazov.
In Arlington, Virginia, US Airways declares bankruptcy.

At the Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, in Monterey, California, the 29th Rolex Monterey Historic Automobile Races are held, over three days. Corvette is the honored marque. Over sixty historic Corvettes are on display and participate in racing, including: Corvette SR-2, Corvette SS, 1959 Sting Ray, CERV-I, Daytona-winning Corvette C5-R, Mako Shark, Aerovette, Grand Sport, 1953 Corvette #2 (EX-122), and plenty of early race Corvettes.
The Major League Players' Association announces a voting result of 57-0 to set an August 30 strike date.
In Baghdad, Iraq, international terrorist Abu Nidal is found dead of several gunshot wounds.
A Russian Mi-26 helicopter carrying troops is hit by a Chechen missile outside of Grozny, killing 118 soldiers.
Jean ChrTtien, Prime Minister of Canada, announces that he will not seek re-election and would resign within eighteen months.
ESPN signature show SportsCenter has their 25,000 episode
The first video streaming coverage of a Major League Baseball game takes place on the internet. Approximately 30,000 fans visit MLB.com to see the New York Yankees defeat the Texas Rangers, 10-3.
Earth Summit 2002 begins in Johannesburg, South Africa.
Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher ÿric GagnT converts his first of a record 84 consecutive successful save opportunities.
A 78-foot long Japanese midget submarine is found in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, believed to have been sunk by the US Navy two hours before the Japanese attack in 1941.
Major League Baseball commissioner Bud Selig announces the players union and owners have reached a settlement on a new four-year agreement, avoiding a strike.

The United Nations World Summit on Sustainable Development, successor of the 1972 Conference on the Human Environment, 1983 World Commission on Environment and Development, and the 1992 Conference on Environment and Development, officially opens.

WWE crowns its first World Heavyweight Champion when Eric Bischoff awarded the belt to Triple H, who was the original Number One Contender for the WWE Championship but his opponent Brock Lesnar refused to defend the belt of the Raw brand.
Consolidated Freightways, the third largest U.S. trucking firm, files for bankruptcy.
An apparent assassination attempt on Afghan President Hamid Karzai fails.
The Sour Biscuit Fire in Oregon and northern California, which burned 499,570 acres (2,022 square km), is finally contained.
A car bomb kills at least 30 people in Afghanistan.
A car bomb kills 30 people in Kabul, Afghanistan, in an apparent assassination attempt on Afghan President Hamid Karzai.
The Sour Biscuit Fire in Oregon and northern California, United States, which burned 499,570 acres (2,020 km²), is finally contained.
Typhoon Sinlaku causes huge waves on the Qiantangjiang River in Sheijang Province, China.
The U.S. Homeland Security Advisory System is set to Orange, or High Condition, for the first time.
Switzerland, known for its neutrality, finally joins the United Nations.

U.S. President George W. Bush addresses the United Nations, and challenges its members to confront the "grave and gathering danger" of Iraq, or stand aside as the United States and likeminded nations act.
A cargo vessel off South Africa burns and spills oil and chemicals.
One Hour Photo by Mark Romanek is released.
The Swedish parliamentary election leaves Prime Minister Gran Persson and the Social Democrats in power.
Civil war starts in C?te d'Ivoire.
The last baseball game is played at Cinergy Field, where the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3.
In German federal elections, the coalition of the SPD led by Gerhard Schrder and the Green party win a narrow election victory (combined 47.1 percent).
Mozilla Firefox (Phoenix) web browser is born: version 0.1.
A large fireball falls to Earth near Bodaibo, Siberia, Russia, resulting in a crater surrounded by burnt forest.
The Vitim event, a possible bolide impact in Siberia, Russia.
Thirty people are killed in a gun attack at a temple in Gandhinagar, India
The overcrowded Senegalese ferry Joola capsizes off the coast of Gambia killing more than 1,000.
Timor-Leste (East Timor) joins the United Nations.

State prosecutors of Dortmund, Germany, charge eleven former German officers with the murder of 5,000 Italian prisoners-of-war on the Greek island of Cephalonia during World War II. The case was re-opened based on new evidence from East German Stasi police files and war diaries.
The Congress of the United States passes a joint resolution, which explicitly authorizes the President to use the United States Armed Forces as he deems necessary and appropriate, against Iraq.
The Beltway sniper attacks begin with five shootings in Montgomery County, Maryland.
The French oil tanker Limburg is bombed off Yemen.
Opus Dei founder Josemarfa Escriv is canonized.
The discovery of Quaoar, a planet-like body orbiting the Sun, is announced.
Maher Arar is deported by the US government to Syria, where he is tortured and held without charge for a year before being returned home to Canada.
Space Shuttle Atlantis flies mission STS-112, its last mission before the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average reaches a low of 7,286.27, its lowest close since October 1997.
After losing a massive amount of ground during the summer of 2002, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 7,286.27, its lowest level in five years. The NASDAQ also hit a six-year low of 1,114.11.
A lone bomber explodes a home-made bomb in the Myyrmanni shopping mall north of Helsinki, Finland.
A bomb attack in a shopping mall in Vantaa, Finland. See Myyrmanni bombing.
Massive bombs are detonated in two nightclubs in Kuta, Bali, killing 202 and injuring over 300.
Bali bombing: In Bali, terrorists detonate bombs in two nightclubs in Kuta, killing 202 and wounding over 300
The Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim beat the Minnesota Twins to win the American League Championship in five games.
US President George W. Bush signs the Iraq War Resolution.
Bibliotheca Alexandrina in the Egyptian city of Alexandria, a commemoration of the Library of Alexandria that was lost in antiquity, is officially inaugurated.
About 50 Chechen rebels storm the Moscow Palace of Culture theater, taking up to 700 people hostage during a performance of a popular musical.
Moscow Theatre Siege begins: Chechen rebels seize the House of Culture theater in Moscow and take approximately 700 theatergoers hostage.
The suspected Beltway snipers, John Allen Muhammad and Lee Boyd Malvo, are arrested.
Police arrest spree killers John Allen Muhammad and Lee Boyd Malvo, ending the Beltway sniper attacks in the area around Washington, DC.
U.S. Senator Paul Wellstone, his family and staff, are killed by a plane accident at Eveleth, Minnesota.
In Moscow, Russia, after a 57-hour-standoff at the Palace of Culture, Russian special forces surround and raid the theater. Most of the guerrillas and 120 hostages are killed during the raid.

Moscow Theater Siege ends: Approximately 50 Chechen rebels and 150 hostages die when Russian Spetsnaz storm the House of Culture theater in Moscow, which had been occupied by the rebels three days before.
The Anaheim Angels defeat the San Francisco Giants in Game 7 of the 2002 World Series of baseball to win the title.

LWT (London Weekend Television) is broadcast for the last time. It is replaced by ITV1 (London Weekends). All other ITV Regions (except UTV, Channel, Scottish TV & Grampian TV) broadcast regionally for the last time before joining a single networked ITV1.
Trades unionist Luiz Incio Lula da Silva is elected as President of Brazil.
Anaheim Angels win the baseball World Series
British digital terrestrial television (DTT) service Freeview starts transmitting throughout parts of the United Kingdom.
British Digital terrestrial television (DTT) Service Freeview starts transmitting throughout parts of the United Kingdom
Jam Master Jay of Run-DMC was shot and killed in a Merrick Boulevard recording studio.

A federal grand jury in Houston formally indicted former Enron Corp. chief financial officer Andrew Fastow on 78 counts of wire fraud, money laundering, conspiracy and obstruction of justice related to the collapse of his ex-employer.
In Central Alaska, a magnitude 7.9 earthquake occurs, the world's largest earthquake in 2002. No deaths, few injuries, but extensive damage to roads. Felt as far away as Seattle, Washington.
In U.S. elections, the Republican Party maintains control of the House of Representatives and regains control of the United States Senate.
The U.S. Federal Reserve System drops its primary discount rate by 50 basis points to 0.75 percent, putting the real interest rate solidly below the inflation rate.
Winona Ryder is found guilty of shoplifting after stealing items worth $5,500 from a New York boutique.
12 people are killed in a fire on board a train headed for Vienna from Paris
Iran bans the advertising of United States products.
Iran bans advertising of United States products.
The United Nations Security Council unanimously approves Resolution 1441, telling Iraq's Saddam Hussein to disarm or face "serious consequences".

Iraq disarmament crisis: UN Security Council Resolution 1441 ? The United Nations Security Council unanimously approves a resolution on Iraq, forcing Saddam Hussein to disarm or face "serious consequences".
In Los Angeles, California, television and film actor Merlin Santana is shot to death.
Iraq agrees to the terms of United Nations Security Council Resolution 1441.
The oil tanker Prestige sinks off the Galician coast and causes a huge oil spill.
Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq agrees to the terms of the UN Security Council Resolution 1441.
Argentina defaults on a US$805 million World Bank loan payment.
Microsoft officially launches the Xbox Live online video gaming service in the USA.
Argentina defaults on an $805 million World Bank payment.
The US House of Representatives votes to not create an independent commission to investigate the September 11 attacks.
Hu Jintao becomes General Secretary of the Communist Party of China.
In England, Myra Hindley, who was involved in the murders of five children between 1963 and 1965, dies in hospital at the age of 60 after suffering a heart attack in prison.
Hu Jintao becomes general secretary of the Communist Party of China.
A Campaign against Climate Change march takes place in London, England, from Lincoln's Inn Fields, past Esso offices to the United States Embassy.
United Nations weapons inspectors led by Hans Blix arrive in Iraq.
Iraq disarmament crisis: United Nations weapons inspectors led by Hans Blix arrive in Iraq.
North Atlantic Treaty Organization Summit in Prague: Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia are invited to join NATO.
NATO invites Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia to become members.
In Nigeria, more than 100 people are killed at an attack aimed at the Miss World contestants.
In Nigeria, more than 100 people are killed at an attack aimed at the contestants of the Miss World contest.

The Montreal Alouettes win the Canadian Football League Championship for the first time since relocating from Baltimore, defeating the host Edmonton Eskimos 25-16 in the 90th Grey Cup at Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton, Alberta.
Space Shuttle Endeavour lifts off on mission STS-113, the final successful shuttle flight before the ill-fated STS-107 Columbia mission.

U.S. President George W. Bush signs the Homeland Security Act into law, establishing the Department of Homeland Security, in the largest U.S. government reorganization since the creation of the Department of Defense in 1947 (the Senate passed the bill 90-9 on November 19).
Reported assassination attempt on Turkmen president Saparmurat Niyazov.

Legislation by the European Court of Human Rights and Law Lords, ruling in favour of convicted murderer Anthony Anderson, officially ends the right of the Home Secretary to set minimum terms for convicted murderers. This gives hope of a quicker release for more than 200 convicted murderers whose minimum terms were increased by politicians, including an estimated 70 who have already served longer than their original recommended minimum term.
13 people are killed in a hotel bombing in Mombasa.
A small general cargo vessel collides with a heavily-laden single-hulled tanker in the middle of the Singapore Straits, spilling 408,000 litres of oil.

As required by the recently passed U.N. resolution, Iraq files a 12,000 page weapons declaration with the U.N. Security Council. Although it is supposed to be a complete declaration, it is seen as incomplete by the Security Council and weapons inspectors.
In Serbia, a general election fails to fill presidency due to insufficient voter turn-out.
United Airlines, the second largest airline in the world, files under the United States Bankruptcy Code Chapter 11.
The High Court of Australia hands down its judgement in the internet defamation case of Gutnick v Dow Jones.
Chile government concludes bilateral trade agreement with the USA.
Hans Enoksen is elected prime minister of Greenland.

Enlargement of the European Union: The European Union announces that Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia will become members from May 1, 2004.
Jeff Kent signs an $18.2 million, two-year contract with the Houston Astros.

2003 California recall: Governor of California Gray Davis announces that the state would face a record budget deficit of $35 billion, roughly double the figure reported during his reelection campaign one month earlier.
General election in South Korea. Roh Moo-hyun of the Millennium Democratic Party narrowly beats rival to become president.
US Senator Trent Lott resigns as majority leader.
A German Sikorsky CD-53 helicopter crashes at Kabul airport, Afghanistan, killing seven German soldiers.
In Montenegro, election of new president is held. Under half of the registered voters turn-out, resulting in no election of a new president.
French Raelian scientist Brigitte Boisselier says Clonaid has delivered the first of a supposed five clone babies through cesarean section.
A suicide truck-bomb attack destroys the headquarters of Chechnya's Moscow-backed government, killing 72 people.
In Kenya, Mwai Kibaki wins election with 60 percent of votes, defeating 24-year ruler Daniel Arap Moi.
Two truck bombs kill 72 and wound 200 at the pro-Moscow headquarters of the Chechen government in Grozny, Chechnya.
In Cincinnati, Ohio, the Cinergy Field stadium is demolished.
The Communist New People's Army blows up a bust of Ferdinand Marcos in Benguet, Philippines.
Cincinnati's Riverfront Stadium/Cinergy Field is demolished.
An eruption on the volcanic island Stromboli off the coast of Sicily causes a flank failure and tsunami. The island is later evacuated.
In Yemen, Abed Abdel Razzak Kamel kills three American missionaries.
United National Security Council passes another resolution restricting more goods for Iraq to import.
In Serbia, speaker of parliament Natasa Micic becomes acting President, due to insufficient voter turn-out earlier in the month to elect a president.
Roger Clemens agrees to a $10.1 million, one-year deal with the New York Yankees.
North Korea kicks out United Nations nuclear inspectors.
The euro currency hits US$1.05, highest in three years.
The European Union takes over the United Nation's police mission in Bosnia.
In S?o Paulo, Brazil, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva takes office as president.
Pascal Couchepin becomes President of the Confederation in Switzerland.
Greece takes over presidency of the European Union for six months.

Ohio State University becomes the first NCAA Division I Football team to complete a season 14-0 by winning the Tostitos Fiesta Bowl over the University of Miami 31-24, and is crowned BCS National Champion.

The 108th United States Congress is sworn in, including incoming freshmen Senators Saxby Chambliss (Republican-Georgia), Lindsey Graham (Republican-South Carolina), John Sununu (Republican-New Hampshire), Lamar Alexander (Republican-Tennessee), Elizabeth Dole (Republican-North Carolina), Norm Coleman (Republican-Minnesota), and Mark Pryor (Democrat-Arkansas).
The Ohio State University defeats the University of Miami in double-overtime in the Fiesta Bowl, 31-24, for the national Bowl Championship Series (BCS) title.
Two suicide bombers in south Tel Aviv, Israel, killing 22, injuring over 100.

Astronomers in Seattle, Washington, announce the discovery of planet OGLE-TR-56b. The planet, about 5000 light-years from Earth, has a surface temperature of 1600 degrees C, and an orbit of 29 hours around its parent star.
US Congress convenes, with Republican Senate majority (51-48-1 independent)
US Airways Express Flight 5481 crashes at Charlotte/Douglas International Airport in Charlotte, North Carolina, killing all 21 people aboard.
Illinois governor George H. Ryan announces decision to grant clemency to all inmates of death row.
At auction in New York City, a Canadian 1911 silver dollar pattern sells for US$1 million. A 1936 dot 1-cent sells for $353,000, a new record for any North American small cent.
The Supreme Court of the United States allows the extension of copyright terms in the U.S.
Lucio GutiTrrez is sworn in as Ecuador's new president.
Sony announces it has shipped over 50 million PlayStation 2 systems worldwide to date.
Space Shuttle Columbia takes off for mission STS-107 which will be its final one. Columbia disintegrates 16 days later on re-entry.
Torii Hunter agrees to four-year, US$32 million deal to stay with the Minnesota Twins.
Bush fires in Australia enter capital of Canberra, killing four, destroying almost 500 houses.
Cuban elections, renewing Fidel Castro as president for next five years, as well as other official candidates for the single-chamber parliament.

The entire German Bundestag visits ElysTe Palace in France to re-affirm the German-France friendship treaty of 40 years ago. This is the largest gathering of German dignitaries in the French palace since 1871.
Catcher Ivan Rodriguez signs a one-year deal worth $10 million to play with the Florida Marlins.
The last successful contact arrives from the spacecraft Pioneer 10, one of the most distant man-made objects.
General elections in the Netherlands: Christian Democrats 44, Labour 42, of 150 seats total.
Last successful contact with the spacecraft Pioneer 10, one of the most distant man-made objects.
World premiere of Chappelle's Show on Comedy Central.
The Netherlands vote for a new parliament after the previous had only been into power for 86 days.
The new United States Department of Homeland Security officially begins operation.
For the first time in the history of bank lending, rates of the Japanese Yen from a European bank to other banks is negative, paying 0.01 percent to borrowers.
In Spain, 200 anti-terrorist policemen raid a dozen apartments in Catalonia, arresting 16 Arabs, with bomb-making devices, false passports, and chemicals.
The United States Department of Homeland Security officially begins operation.

The Slammer worm (also called Sapphire or SQL Hell) begins spreading across the Internet, exploiting a flaw in Microsoft SQL Server 2000, infecting personal computers around the world. Within ten minutes, the worm has reached 90 percent of the Internet, infecting over 75,000 machines. Within another thirty minutes, one-fifth of Internet data packets are infected.
A Central Line train crashes into the tunnel wall at Chancery Lane tube station in London, injuring 34 people.
Government and rebels of C?te d'Ivoire sign a peace accord in Paris, France.
An international group of volunteers leaves London for Baghdad to act as voluntary human shields, hoping to avert a U.S. invasion.
Super Bowl XXXVII: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers defeat the Oakland Raiders 48-21.
The first authorized flight by a Taiwanese aircraft to mainland China since 1949 takes place, though via Hong Kong or Macau.
Philip Morris Companies changes its company name to Altria Group, Incorporated.
In Cambodia, Thai-owned hotels, offices, and factories are burned and looted, following a misleading interpretation of a Thai television actress's comments about Angkor Wat temple.

The leaders of Britain, Czech Republic, Denmark, Hungary, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Romania and the Spain release a statement, The Letter of the Eight, demonstrating support for the United States' plans to invade Iraq.
The Chicago White Sox announces Comiskey Park will now be known as U.S. Cellular Field, in exchange for US$68 million in a 23-year deal with the wireless service provider.
The new Congress of Brazil's parliament is sworn in.
In Northern Ireland, Protestant Ulster Defence Association Belfast leader John Gregg is killed by a loyalist faction.
Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrates over Texas upon reentry killing all seven astronauts onboard.
In Venezuela, a 14-month private-sector strike is lifted.
Vaclac Havel retires as Czech president for ten years, and three more years before that as president of Czechoslovakia.
Platinum hits a 23-year high of US$700 per ounce.
The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is officially renamed to Serbia and Montenegro and adopts a new constitution.
Gold hits US$385 per ounce, highest since September 1996.
U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell addresses the United Nations Security Council on Iraq, giving evidence of Iraq's efforts to conceal weapons of mass destruction from inspectors.
North Korea announces it had re-activated the Yongbyon reactor, producing fuel-rods for reprocessing into bomb-grade plutonium.
U.S. plan to invade Iraq: Colin Powell addresses the UN Security Council on Iraq.
In Bogot, Colombia, a car bomb explodes in the parking garage of the El Nogal social club, killing 35, injuring 160.
The Cricket World Cup begins in South Africa.
BBC Choice closes for the final time at 12:30 am, replaced by BBC Three at 7 pm.
France and Belgium broke the NATO procedure of silent approval concerning the timing of protective measures for Turkey in case of a possible war with Iraq.

In La Paz, Bolivia, striking police clash with the army, first with tear gas, then with bullets. The army was trying to protect the presidential palace from stone-throwing youths. 27 are left dead, over 100 seriously injured. This is followed by 24 hours of mobs looting and burning public and foreign business buildings.

A small airplane crashes in southern Colombia. FARC guerillas kill one American and a Colombian army sergeant, and take three Americans hostage. FARC claims they are CIA agents; the US government claims they are defense contractors.
In Shanghai, China, a ground-breaking ceremony takes place for the Shanghai World Financial Centre, to be the world's tallest building.

Nintendo releases the Game Boy Advance SP in Japan. New features include rechargeable battery and flip-up 2.9-inch color LCD screen with built-in front lighting. Size is 3.33 x 3.23 x 1 inches; weight is 5 ounces.
More than ten million people protest in over 600 cities worldwide, the largest war protest to take place before the war against Iraq occurs.
protests against the Iraq war occur in over 600 cities worldwide. Estimates from 8,000,000-30,000,000 make this the largest day of protest in history.
London, England, introduces a 5 pound (US$8) "congestion charge" to drive within an 8 square-mile patch of central London, to reduce traffic and fund public transport.
The Atlanta Braves and Greg Maddux agree the largest one-year contract in major league baseball history: US$14.75 million.
Arsonist fires on an underground train in the city of Daegu, South Korea, kill more than 190 people.
British Airways begins a three-month trial of offering Internet satellite connections on flights between London and New York.
Nearly 200 people die in the Daegu subway fire in South Korea
The Station nightclub fire in West Warwick, Rhode Island claims the lives of 100 people.
In Rhode Island, in the USA, The Station nightclub fire kills about 100 and injures over 200.
Over 100 concert goers in Rhode Island die in a fire during a performance of the rock band Great White.
In his first fight after losing to Lennox Lewis, Mike Tyson beats Clifford Etienne by first round knock-out in a fight held at The Pyramid in Memphis, Tennessee, USA.

Dutch Royal Ahold, world's third-biggest food retailer, announces the resignation of CEO Cees van der Hoeven and the financial director, after finding it had overstated profits by 463 million euros (US$500 million) in the past two years. The company's market value drops during the day by 63 percent, to 3.3 billion euros, ten percent of its worth in late 2001.
Ira & Larry Goldberg Coins & Collectibles sells a 1943-D copper Lincoln cent graded MS-64 by PCGS for US$212,750, a record for any small cent.
Roh Moo-hyun is sworn in as new president of South Korea.

An American businessman is admitted to the Vietnam France Hospital in Hanoi, Vietnam with the first identified case of SARS. WHO doctor Carlo Urbani reports the unusual highly contagious disease to WHO.
Rowan Williams is enthroned as the 104th Archbishop of Canterbury in the Anglican church.
The Federal Law Enforcement Training Center, the United States Customs Service, and the United States Secret Service move to the United States Department of Homeland Security.
Pakistani authorities capture Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the suspected mastermind of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, along with money-man Mustafa Ahmed al-Hawsawi.

The Turkish parliament votes against U.S. troop access to airbases in Turkey in order to attack Iraq from the north. The Bush administration starts working on Plan B, namely attacking Iraq from the south, through the Persian Gulf.
The United Arab Emirates calls for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to step down to avoid war, a sentiment later echoed by Bahrain and Kuwait.

Representatives of 171 countries agree to the text of the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control treaty, part of the World Health Organization's plan to reduce deaths and health problems due to smoking.
Management of the United States Customs Service and the United States Secret Service move to the United States Department of Homeland Security.
The first International Symposium on Taiwan Sign Language Linguistics is held at Chung Cheng University.
In the southern Philippines, a bomb hidden in a backpack exploded and killed 21 people at an airport in Davao City.
In the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir, at least 9 people were killed and 52 were injured when a bus fell into a deep gorge.
France, Russia, and Germany announce they will not support a United Nations resolution authorizing use of force against Iraq.
The Supreme Court of the United States, by a 5-4 margin, upholds California's "three strikes and you're out" law.
Beginning of annual two-week session of the National People's Congress in China.
Natalie Maines of the Dixie Chicks provokes controversy in the U.S. by stating that the band was "ashamed the president of the United States is from Texas."
SCO Group files a lawsuit against IBM, claiming IBM illegally used licensed Unix technology in its Linux software. SCO seeks US$1 billion in damages.
Malta votes 53.7 percent in favor of joining the European Union.
A by-election in Turkey makes Tayyip Erdogan, leader of the Justice and Development Party, the country's new Prime Minister.
Iraqi fighter jets threaten two U.S. U-2 surveillance planes, on missions for U.N. weapons inspectors, forcing them to abort their mission and return to base.
The International Criminal Court is founded in The Hague.

British prime minister Tony Blair proposes an amendment to the possible 18th U.N. resolution, which would call for Iraq to meet certain benchmarks to prove that it was disarming. The amendment is immediately rejected by France, who promises to veto any new resolution.
The World Health Organization issues a global alert on SARS.
Serbian Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic is assassinated in Belgrade.
Zoran ?in?i?, Prime Minister of Serbia, assassinated in Belgrade.
Kidnapping victim Elizabeth Smart is found alive in Sandy, Utah after missing from her Salt Lake City home for nine months.
Human evolution: The journal Nature reports that 350,000-year-old upright-walking human footprints have been found in Italy.
The Milwaukee Brewers' TV/radio play-by-play announcer, Bob Uecker is chosen for induction into the broadcasters' wing of the Hall of Fame as the recipient of the Ford C. Frick Award.
In Bangui, Central African Republic, ex-chief of army General Fran?ois BozizT and 1000 troops stage a military coup against President AngeFTlix PatassT.
Hu Jintao becomes president of the People's Republic of China, replacing Jiang Zemin.

The leaders of the United States, Britain, Portugal, and Spain meet at a summit in the Azores Islands. U.S. President Bush calls March 17 the "moment of truth", meaning that the "coalition of the willing" will make its final effort to extract a resolution from the U.N. Security Council, giving Iraq an ultimatum to disarm immediately or be disarmed by force.
General elections in Finland: Anneli Jaatteenmaki's Centre Party wins 55 seats in the 200-seat parliament. Paavo Lipponen's Social Democrats win 53 seats.
Voters in Liechtenstein agree to adjust constitution to give more powers to ruling prince Hans-Adams II.
Largest coordinated worldwide vigil, as part of the global protests against Iraq war.
U.S. President George W. Bush gives an ultimatum: Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein and his sons must either leave Iraq, or face military action at a time of the U.S.'s choosing.
British Cabinet Minister, Robin Cook, resigns over government plans for war with Iraq.
The United Kingdom government recognises British Sign Language as an official British language.
About US$1 billion is taken from Iraq's Central Bank by Saddam Hussein and his family, just hours before the United States begins bombing Iraq; biggest bank robbery in history.
Procter & Gamble buys German beauty firm Wella, for 6.5 billion euros (US$6.9 billion).
FBI agents raid the corporate headquarters of HealthSouth Corporation in Birmingham, Alabama on suspicion of massive corporate fraud led by the company's top executives.
A pipeline at the Santos terminal on the Brisbane River in Australia ruptures, spilling up to 1.5 million litres of crude oil.
Serbia's parliament elects Zoran Zivkovic as new prime minister.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom votes in favour of a motion understood as giving the government final authority to join the invasion of Iraq.
US President George Bush's 48-hour mandate for President Saddam Hussein and his sons to exit from Iraq expires. The first American cruise missiles and stealth bombers strike targets in Baghdad.
Land troops from United States, United Kingdom, Australia and Poland invade Iraq.
A ship carrying 699,000 litres of fuel oil sinks in the river in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, spreading an oil slick for several kilometres away.

Germany's biggest insurance company, Allianz, reports its first annual loss since 1945, of 1.2 billion euros (US$1.1 billion). Its subsidiary company, Dresden Bank, Germany's third-biggest, lost 1.4 billion euros.
2003 invasion of Iraq: In the early hours of the morning, the United States and three other countries begin military operations in Iraq.
The United States and the United Kingdom begin their "shock and awe" campaign, with a massive air strike on military targets in Baghdad, Iraq.
The 2003 Cricket World Cup ends as Australia wins over India by 125 runs in Centurion, South Africa.

Nintendo releases the Game Boy Advance SP in North America. Price is US$99.95. Sales in the first two weeks: over 800,000 units. In its first year, over 6.5 million units are sold, a record for any video game system in history.
Slovenia votes 90 percent in favor of joining the European Union.
In Nasiriyah, Iraq, 11 soldiers of the 507th Maintenance Company as well as 18 U.S. Marines are killed during the first major conflict of Operation Iraqi Freedom.
The Arab League votes 21-1 in favor of a resolution demanding the immediate and unconditional removal of U.S. and British soldiers from Iraq.
Japan's Mizuho bank, the world's largest, completes raising a record-breaking 1.1 trillion yen (US$9.2 billion), in under two months.
Japan launches two spy satellites into orbit. North Korea calls it "a hostile act".
World Health Organization doctor Carlo Urbani, who first identified SARS, dies of the disease.
Meigs Field Airport in Chicago, Illinois is demolished overnight.
