In Hong Kong, police cordon off Block E of the Amoy Gardens housing estate, placing those inside under quarantine, to contain SARS.
The European Union launches its first military mission, taking over peace-keeping duties in Macedonia from NATO.
Japan's Mizuho bank, the world's largest, posts a net loss of 2 trillion yen (US$16.7 billion) in the past twelve months, the largest loss in Japanese corporate history.
Air Canada files for bankruptcy protection.
The World Health Organization issues its first ever travel alert, due to the SARS outbreak, advising travellers to avoid Hong Kong and Guangdong province of China.

Todd Zeile becomes the only major league player to hit a home run for ten different teams: New York Yankees, Detroit Cardinals, Chicago Cubs, Philadelphia Phillies, Baltimore Orioles, Los Angeles Dodgers, Florida Marlins, Texas Rangers, New York Mets, and Colorado Rockies.
U.S. forces seize control of Saddam International Airport, changing the airport's name to Baghdad International Airport.
A passenger bus hits a remote-controlled land mine in the Chechen capital, killing at least eight.

The National Association of Broadcasters holds a luncheon honoring the Disney franchise. Company chairman Michael Eisner announces Disney will begin testing a new video-on-demand service called Movie Beam later in the year. A television set-top box will download new film releases over regular television broadcast signal to a local storage device for later playback.
Syracuse wins the NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship, defeating Kansas 81-78.
The Boston Red Sox exercise Pedro Martinez's option for the 2004 season, making Martinez the highest paid pitcher for a season in major league history, at US$17.5 million.
U.S. troops capture Baghdad; Saddam Hussein's regime falls two days later.
A giant statue of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad is pulled down by the US military, and broadcast worldwide.
U.S. forces seize control of Baghdad, ending the regime of Saddam Hussein.
2003 invasion of Iraq: Baghdad, Iraq falls to American forces.
The Human Genome Project is successfully completed, with 99 percent of the human genome sequenced to 99.99 percent accuracy.
Human Genome Project successfully completed with 99% of the human genome sequenced to 99.99% accuracy.
The Treaty of Accession is signed in Athens, Greece, allowing ten new members into the European Union.
The Treaty of Accession is signed in Athens admitting 10 new member states to the European Union.
The Stevens Report concludes that members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary and British Army cooperated with the Ulster Defence Association in the killings of Catholics in Northern Ireland.
Retired U.S. Army General Jay Garner becomes Interim Civil Administrator of Iraq.
Intel releases the 3 GHz Pentium 4 processor with 800 MHz front-side bus.
Advanced Micro Devices releases the Opteron processor, with 32-bit and 64-bit instruction operation, without requiring 32-bit code to be re-compiled.

US President George W. Bush signs legislation authorizing changes to the design of the 5-cent coin through 2005, to commemorate the bicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase and the Lewis and Clark expedition.
Beijing closes all of its schools for two weeks due to the SARS virus.
Beijing closes all schools for two weeks due to the SARS virus.
Apple Computer's iTunes Music Store launches, selling 1 million songs in its first week.
The United States announces the withdrawal of troops stationed in Saudi Arabia, and the redeployment of some at the Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar.

George W. Bush lands on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, in a Lockheed S-3 Viking, where he gives a speech announcing the end of major combat in the 2003 Invasion of Iraq. A banner behind him declares "Mission Accomplished."

2003 invasion of Iraq: In what becomes known as the "Mission Accomplished" speech, President George W. Bush declares "major combat operations in Iraq have ended" on board USS Abraham Lincoln off the coast of California.
The Old Man of the Mountain, a rock formation in New Hampshire, USA, crumbles after heavy rain.
New Hampshire's famous Old Man of the Mountain collapses.
Top Thrill Dragster opens in Cedar Point in Sandusky, Ohio as the world's tallest, fastest roller coaster.
(to May 10) A major severe weather outbreak spawns more tornadoes than any week in U.S. history; 393 tornadoes are reported in 19 states.
The Outbreak of 2003 begins. Ninety-four tornadoes begin the week-long outbreak.
Record shattering tornado activity during the May 2003 Tornado Outbreak Sequence.
In Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, 26 people are killed in the Riyadh Compound Bombings.
A suicide truck-bomb attack kills at least 60 at a government compound in northern Chechnya.
The Riyadh compound bombings, carried out by Al Qaeda, kill 26.
A female suicide bomber blows up explosives strapped to her waist in a crowd of thousands of Muslim pilgrims, killing at least 18 people in Chechnya.
In Casablanca, Morocco, 33 civilians are killed and more than 100 injured in the Casablanca terrorist attacks.
In Casablanca, Morocco, 33 civilians are killed and more than 100 people are injured in the Casablanca terrorist attacks.
Arsenal beats Southampton 1-0 to win the FA Cup.
Pen Hadow becomes the first man to walk alone, without any outside help, from Canada to the North Pole.
F.C. Porto defeats Celtic 3-2 (AET) in the UEFA Cup Final in Seville, Spain.
An earthquake in the BoumerdFs region of northern Algeria kills 2,200.
An earthquake hits northern Algeria, killing more than 2,000 people.
The Sheffield Winter Gardens are officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
Arturo Moreno purchases the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim from the Walt Disney Company for US$184 million.
In Fort Worth, Texas, Annika Sörenstam becomes the first woman to play the PGA Tour in 58 years.
Dewey, the first deer cloned by scientists at Texas A&M University, is born.
US coin dealer Paul Montgomery announces a $1 million bounty for the missing 1913 Liberty Head nickel.
The euro exceeds its initial trading value as it hits $1.18 for the first time since its introduction in 1999.
25-year-old Nepalese Sherpa, Pemba Dorjie Sherpa, makes the fastest-ever ascent of Mount Everest, in 12 hours 45 minutes. This is broken by his rival Sherpa Lakpa Gelu only three days later.
Sertab Erener wins the Eurovision Song Contest 2003 for Turkey with the song "Every Way That I Can", in Riga, Latvia.
NTstor Kirchner becomes President of Argentina after defeating Carlos Menem. He is the first elected President since the economic crisis.
A draft of the proposed European Constitution is unveiled.
Only three days after a previous record, Sherpa Lakpa Gelu climbs Mount Everest in 10 hours 56 minutes. The tourism ministry of Nepal confirms this record in July that year.
AC Milan defeats fellow Italian rival Juventus 3-2 on penalties after a scoreless tie to win the UEFA Champions League, their sixth European title.
Prometea, the first horse cloned by Italian scientists, is born.
Peter Hollingworth becomes the first Governor-General of Australia to resign his office as a result of criticism of his conduct.
The final flight of an Air France Concorde takes place.
Eric Rudolph, suspected in the Centennial Olympic Park bombing in 1996, is captured in Murphy, North Carolina.
1996 Atlanta Olympic bomber Eric Rudolph is captured in Murphy, North Carolina.

In China, a farmer in Sichuan Province discovers a hoard of thousands of ancient coins, stacked 2 metres high, and 1.5 metres diameter, weighing at least 7 tons. The coins mostly date to the Southern Song Dynasty (1127-1279 C.E.).
The People's Republic of China begins filling the lake behind the massive Three Gorges Dam, raising the water level near the dam over 100 metres.
The Group of Eight (G8) summit opens in +vian-les-Bains, France, to tight security and tens of thousands of protesters.
The People's Republic of China begins filling the reservoir behind the massive Three Gorges Dam, raising the water level near the dam over 100 metres.
Europe launches its first voyage to another planet, Mars. The European Space Agency's Mars Express probe launches from the Baikonur space centre in Kazakhstan.

Martha Stewart and her broker are indicted for using privileged investment information and then obstructing a federal investigation. Stewart also resigns as chairperson and chief executive officer of Martha Stewart Living.
A female suicide bomber detonates a bomb near a bus carrying soldiers and civilians to a military airfield in Mozdok, a major staging point for Russian troops in Chechnya, killing at least 16 people.
Severe heat wave across Pakistan and India reaches its peak, as temperatures exceed 50C in the region. (Details)
The New Jersey Devils defeat the Anaheim Mighty Ducks 3-0 in Game Seven of the 2003 NHL Stanley Cup Finals to win their third Stanley Cup championship.
NASA begins its Mars Exploration Rover mission by launching Spirit Rover.
The Spirit Rover is launched, beginning NASA's Mars Exploration Rover mission.
The San Antonio Spurs defeat the New Jersey Nets to win the 2003 NBA Finals, 4-2.
The North East MRT Line, the world's first fully automated and driverless subway opens in Singapore.
Deputy Justice Fazel Ahmed Manawi of the Afghan Supreme Court announces that Aftab editor Sayed Madawi and his deputy Ali Payam Sestani will be tried for "libeling Islam."
The largest hailstone ever recorded falls in Aurora, Nebraska.
Barry Bonds becomes the first major league baseball player to hit 500 homers and steal 500 bases in his career.
The Supreme Court of the United States upholds affirmative action in university admissions.
The U.S. Supreme Court declares sodomy laws unconstitutional.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules that gender-based sodomy laws are unconstitutional in Lawrence v. Texas.

The United States National "Do Not Call Registry" is formed to combat unwanted telemarketing calls and administered by the Federal Trade Commission, enrolling almost three-quarters of a million phone numbers on its first day.

In Nashville, Tennessee, General Motors holds the Official Corvette 50th Anniversary Celebration, over two days. About 10,000 Corvettes and 18,000 people attend. Special cars on hand include the Tiger Shark, XP-880 Astro II, 1963 Monza SS, Astro I, 1969 aluminum Reynolds Corvette EXP 040, 1973 Aerovette, CERV III, CERV IV, C5-R #50 Le Mans race car, LT1 Spyder Concept, ASC Sting Ray III, and Corvette SS. Two raffle draws raise US$700,000 for the National Corvette Museum.

In St. Charles, Illinois, the Bloomington Gold Corvettes USA show is held, over four days. Mecum Collector Car Auctioneers conducts the auction of over 300 Corvettes. Roger Judski pays US$640,000 for a 1967 L88 red coupe with only 12 miles on it. This is a world record for any production Corvette.
Thirteen are killed in a porch collapse in Chicago, Illinois.
500,000 Hong Kong people march to protest Hong Kong Basic Law Article 23, which controversially redefines treason.
In Hong Kong, 500,000 people march to protest a new anti-subversion law.
At the International Olympic Committee session in Prague, Vancouver, British Columbia is declared the Host City for the XXI Olympic Winter Games in 2010.
International Olympic Committee selects Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada to host the 2010 Winter Olympics.
SARS is declared to be contained by the World Health Organization.
A double suicide bombing at a Moscow rock concert kills the female attackers and 15 other people.
The Corsicans rejected a referendum for increased autonomy from France by a very thin majority: 50.98 percent against, and 49.02 percent for.
Corsica voters reject a referendum for increased autonomy for the region from France by a very narrow margin.
The United Communist Party of Armenia was formed.
Sudan Airways Flight 39, with 117 people on board, crashes in Sudan; the only survivor is a two-year-old child.
A Russian security agent dies in Moscow, while trying to defuse a bomb a woman had tried to carry into a cafe on central Moscow's main street.
The last of the original Volkswagen Beetle cars is built at the assembly plant in Mexico. The car had been produced for 69 years. 21 million had been built.

A Neoplan bus, owned by Kowloon Motor Bus, collides with a truck, falls off a bridge on Tuen Mun Road, Hong Kong, and plunges into the underlying valley, killing 21 people. This is the deadliest bus accident to date in Hong Kong.
Lahore-Delhi bus service resumed after suspension of 18 months.
Washington Post columnist Robert Novak publishes the name of Valerie Plame, blowing her cover as a US Central Intelligence Agency operative. The Central Intelligence Agency leak scandal begins.
the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention removed its SARS-related travel advisory for Taiwan, the last area to have such a travel alert.
AOL Time Warner disbands Netscape Communications Corporation. The Mozilla Foundation is established on the same day.
The Corsicans reject a referendum for increased autonomy from France by a very thin majority: 50.98 percent against, and 49.02 percent for.
The body of David Kelly, a scientist at the British Ministry of Defence, is found a few miles from his home, leading to the Hutton inquiry.
The Convention on the Future of Europe finishes its work and proposes the first European Constitution.
Kobe Bryant is charged with sexually assaulting a 19-year old girl.

Fourteen people?an American family of twelve who had chartered the plane and the South African crew of two?die when their light plane crashes into Mount Kenya after taking off from Nairobi for Buffalo Springs National Reserve in northern Kenya.
Golf: Rookie Ben Curtis, ranked 396th in the world, wins the British Open, the first golfer to win a major golf tournament on his first try in more than ninety years.
Richard Sambrook, the Director of BBC News, reveals that David Kelly was the source of claims that Downing Street had "sexed up" the "Dodgy Dossier".
Liberia: Fighting between militias controlled by the country's president, Charles Taylor, and rebels continues in Monrovia.
France: Sixteen people are injured after two bombs explode outside a tax office in Nice.
The last Volkswagen old-style Beetle rolls off the assembly line at Puebla, Mexico.
Uday and Qusay Hussein, sons of Saddam Hussein, are killed by the U.S. military in Iraq, after being tipped off by an informant.

Members of 101st Airborne of the United States, aided by Special Forces, attack a compound in Iraq, killing Saddam Hussein's sons Uday and Qusay, along with Mustapha Hussein, Qusay's 14-year old son, and a bodyguard.
Operation Warrior Sweep is the first major military deployment of the Afghan National Army.
Operation Warrior Sweep is the first major military deployment of the Afghan National Army.
The Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands, Operation Helpem Fren, led by Australia, begins.
In Mexico, the last 'old style' Volkswagen Beetle rolls off the assembly line.
A suicide bomber rams a truck filled with explosives into a military hospital near Chechnya, killing 50 people, including Russian troops wounded in Chechnya.
The United Nations authorizes an international peacekeeping force for Liberia.
A car bomb explodes in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta.
The United Kingdom reaches a record-high temperature, the first time breaking 38.5 degrees C (101.3 degrees Fahrenheit), at Brogdale near Faversham in Kent.
The American television series Futurama ends
Yuri Ivanovich Malenchenko became the first person to marry in space.
The highest temperature ever recorded in the UK, 38.5C (101.3F), occurs in Kent [1]. It is the first time the UK has recorded a temperature over 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
NATO takes over command of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, marking its first major operation outside Europe in its 54-year-history.
Jemaah Islamiah leader Riduan Isamuddin, better known as Hambali, is arrested in Bangkok, Thailand.
A heat wave in Paris causes temperatures up to 44 degrees C (112 degrees F).
NATO takes over command of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, marking its first major operation outside Europe in its 54-year-history.
Jemaah Islamiyah leader Riduan Isamuddin, better known as Hambali, is arrested in Bangkok, Thailand.
A big heat wave in Paris had temperatures up to 112F (44 C), with about 144 people dead.

US intelligence officer Captain William Ponce contacts fellow officers in Iraq, informing them that a colonel has indicated prisoners need to be "broken", to gather information to prevent further attacks on American soldiers.
A widescale power blackout affects the northeast United States and Canada.
A 6.4 Richter scale earthquake occurs near the Greek Ionian island of Lefkada; 24 are injured.
Widescale power blackout in the northeast United States and Canada.
The 2003 Okanagan Mountain Park Fire spreads quickly on the outskirts of Kelowna, British Columbia, threatening to engulf the largest town in B.C.'s interior.

U.S. Representative from South Dakota Bill Janklow hits and kills a motorcyclist with his car at a rural intersection near Trent, South Dakota; he will eventually be convicted of manslaughter and will resign from Congress.
A car-bomb attack on UN headquarters in Iraq kills the agency's top envoy Sergio Vieira de Mello and 21 other employers.
A rocket explosion kills 21 at the Brazilian rocket complex in Alc?ntara, Brazil, due to the premature ignition of a solid rocket booster.
Two bomb blasts in Mumbai, India kill 52.
The Tli Cho land claims agreement is signed between the Dogrib First Nations and the Canadian federal government in Rae-Edzo (now called Behchoko).
Fifty-two are killed in two Islamic terrorist bomb blasts in Mumbai, India.
Columbia Accident Investigation Board releases its final reports on Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.
Mars makes its closest approach to Earth in over 50,000 years.
Mars makes its closest approach to Earth in nearly 60,000 years, passing approximately 34,646,416 miles (55,758,006 kilometers) from Earth.
In the USA, Brian Douglas Wells wears a time bomb explosive fastened to his neck, and dies. The event stands out as the most bizarre event in the history of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Ayatollah Sayed Mohammed Baqir al-Hakim, the Shia Muslim leader in Iraq, is assassinated in a terrorist bombing, along with nearly 100 worshippers as they leave a mosque in Najaf.
US Warden of Guantnamo Bay prison Major General Geoffrey Miller arrives at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, to instruct on techniques of interrogation used at his prison.

A ride accident at Disneyland Park in Anaheim, California claimed the life of one man that was riding the Big Thunder Mountain Railroad. The coupler between the engine and the first car was rumored to have snapped and struck the man in the chest.
Hubble Space Telescope starts Hubble Ultra Deep Field.
Europe's largest shopping centre, the Bullring in Birmingham, is officially opened by Sir Albert Bore.
Brianna LaHara, a 12-year-old U.S. schoolgirl, is sued by the RIAA for sharing music illegally.
Swedish Foreign Minister Anna Lindh is stabbed several times while shopping in Stockholm. She dies the following morning of heart and lung failure.
Estonia approves joining the European Union in a referendum.
Anna Lindh, the foreign minister of Sweden, is stabbed fatally while shopping, and dies of her wounds on September 11.
The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety enters into effect.
Swedish foreign minister Anna Lindh dies after being assaulted and fatally wounded on September 10.
The United Nations lifted sanctions against Libya after that country agreed to accept responsibility and recompense the families of victims in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103
Indiana Governor Frank O'Bannon dies after suffering a stroke on September 8 in Chicago, Illinois. Joe Kernan, the Lieutenant Governor, is sworn in as Indiana's 48th Governor.

In Sweden, a Nationwide referendum is held asking citizens if the country should join the European Monetary Union, and abandon the Krona in favor of the Euro. The vote is 56.1 percent no, 41.8 percent yes.

Top American commander in Iraq Lieutenant General Ricardo Sanchez authorizes a wide range of new interrogation procedures, including deliberate humiliation, exploiting fear of dogs, sensory deprivation, sensory overload, and stress positions.
In a referendum Sweden rejects adopting the euro.
Estonia approves joining the European Union in a referendum.
Barry Bonds walks for the 2,063rd time in his career, passing Babe Ruth on the all-time walks list to become number two on the list.
The ELN kidnaps eight foreign tourists in the Ciudad Perdida in Colombia; they demand a human rights investigation and release the last hostages three months later.
Two suicide bombers drive an explosive-filled truck into a government security services building near Chechnya, killing three and injuring 25.
Hurricane Isabel makes landfall as a Category 2 Hurricane on North Carolina's Outer Banks. It will directly kill 16 people in the Mid-Atlantic area.
The UK's Local Government Act 2003, repealing Section 28, receives Royal Assent.
Hurricane Isabel makes landfall in the U.S.
Musician Elliott Smith plays his final concert at Redfest in Salt Lake City, Utah, only weeks before his suicide.
2003 Maldives civil unrest: the death of prisoner Hassan Evan Naseem sparks a day of rioting in MalT.
A referendum is held in Latvia to decide the country's accession to the European Union
Galileo mission is terminated by sending the probe into Jupiter's atmosphere, where it is crushed by the pressure at the lower altitudes.
Galileo mission terminated by sending the probe into Jupiter's atmosphere, where it is crushed by the pressure at the lower altitudes.
David Hempleman-Adams becomes the first person to cross the Atlantic Ocean in an open-air, wicker-basket hot air balloon.

In Hokkaido, Japan, a magnitude 8.3 earthquake occurs, the world's largest earthquake of 2003. At least 589 people injured, many roads damaged, landslides and power outages in southeastern Hokkaido. A tsunami was generated with an estimated wave height of 4m along the southeastern coast of Hokkaido.
A magnitude-8.0 earthquake strikes just offshore of Hokkaido, Japan.
A power failure affects all of Italy except Sardinia, cutting service to more than 56 million people.
Hurricane Juan lands at Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada as a category two storm, killing two directly and five indirectly.
Hurricane Juan makes landfall at Nova Scotia.
Maxim restaurant suicide bombing in Haifa, Israel: 21 Israelis, Jews and Arabs, were killed, and 51 others were wounded.
Israeli warplanes strike inside Syrian territory.
Akhmad Kadyrov elected President of Chechnya.
Voters recall California Governor Gray Davis from office and elect actor Arnold Schwarzenegger to succeed him.
California recall: California governor Gray Davis is recalled from office and replaced by Arnold Schwarzenegger.
The Mission: Space attraction opens in Epcot at Walt Disney World in Florida. The attraction cost US$150 million to build.

Facing an investigation surrounding allegations of illegal drug use, American right-wing radio host Rush Limbaugh publicly admits that he is addicted to prescription pain killers, and will seek treatment.
Michael Schumacher wins the 2003 FIA Formula One World Championship in Suzuka, Japan, beating Kimi RSikknen to the title.
American author Susan Sontag is presented the Peace Prize of the Frankfurt Book Fair.
Belarus mental hospital fire: Thirty patients die in a mental hospital fire in Randilovshchina, Belarus
The Public Library of Science commences publication of an open-access scientific journal, PLoS Biology.

The Curse of the Billy Goat strikes again, as Steve Bartman becomes famous during The Inning that lead the the Chicago Cubs defeat in Game 6 of the NCLS and eventual loss of the series to the eventual World Series Champions, the Florida Marlins.
China launches Shenzhou 5, their first manned space mission.
The 2003 Staten Island Ferry crash kills 11 after one of its ferries slams into a pier.
Terri Schiavo's feeding tube is removed following numerous failed petitions by her parents to prevent such action.
The Staten Island Ferry boat Andrew J. Barberi collides with a pier at the St. George Ferry Terminal in Staten Island, killing 11 people and injuring 43 others (see 2003 Staten Island Ferry crash)
Ilham Aliyev becomes President of Azerbaijan succeeding his father Heydar Aliyev.
China launches Shenzhou 5, its first manned space mission.
The New York Yankees defeat the Boston Red Sox in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, the 39th American League pennant for the Yankees.
The Red Sox and Yankees face off in a historical ALCS game 7 at Yankee Stadium. The game ends in dramatic fashion with an Aaron Boone walk off home run.

The pinnacle is fitted on the roof of Taipei 101, a 101-floor skyscraper in Taipei, allowing it to surpass the Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur by 50 metres (165 feet) and become the World's tallest highrise.
Carlos Mesa becomes President of Bolivia.

The pinnacle was fitted on the roof of Taipei 101, a 106-floor skyscraper in Taipei, allowing it to surpass the Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur by 50 meters (165 feet) and become the World's tallest highrise.
Eunuchs in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh float the political party Jiti Jitayi Politics.
Bolivian Gas War: President Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada, is forced to resign and leave Bolivia.
David Blaine finally ended his 44-day endurance stunt of being sealed inside a transparent case suspended 30 feet in the air over Potters Fields Park, located in London.
Mother Teresa is beatified by Pope John Paul II.
The Concorde makes its last commercial flight, bringing the era of airliner supersonic travel to a close.
Concorde makes its last commercial flight, bringing the era of airliner supersonic transport to a close, at least for the time being.
The Florida Marlins defeat the New York Yankees to win their second baseball World Series title.
The Cedar Fire begins in San Diego County, burning 280,000 acres (1,100 square km), 2,232 homes and killing 14.
The Cedar Fire is reported at 5:37 pm. It becomes the largest wildfire in California history.
Australia defeat Namibia in the 2003 Rugby World Cup by a record 142 points to zero.
Mahathir Mohamad resigns as Prime Minister of Malaysia after 22 years in power.
A bankruptcy court approves MCI's reorganization plans, essentially clearing the telecommunications company to exit bankruptcy.
Mahathir bin Mohamad resigns as Prime Minister of Malaysia after 22 years in power.
The largest-ever solar flare is recorded.
Former HealthSouth CEO Richard Scrushy becomes the first person indicted under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. He was eventually acquitted.
Gary Ridgway, the "Green River Killer", confesses to murdering 48 women.
The final installment of the Matrix Trilogy (The Matrix Revolutions) is released in theatres simultaneously around the world at 2:00 p.m. (GMT).
A lunar eclipse is seen in the Americas, Europe, Africa, and Central Asia.
During the holy month of Ramadan, a suicide-terrorist attack in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, kills 17 people.
Roy Halladay of the Toronto Blue Jays wins the American League Cy Young Award.
In Nasiriya, Iraq, at least 23 people, among them the first Italian casualties of the 2003 Iraq war, are killed in a suicide bomb attack on an Italian police base.
Occupation of Iraq: In Nasiriya, Iraq, at least 23 people, among them the first Italian casualties of the 2003 Iraq war are killed in a suicide bomb attack on an Italian police base.
Two car bombs explode simultaneously in Istanbul, Turkey, targeting two synagogues, killing at least 25 people and wounding more than 300; Al-Qaida claims responsibility.
The first day of the 2003 Istanbul Bombings takes place, to be followed by additional bombings on November 20.

The Edmonton Eskimos win the Canadian Football League Championship for the first time in a decade, defeating the Montreal Alouettes 34-22 in the 91st Grey Cup at Taylor Field in Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada.
Arnold Schwarzenegger is inaugurated Governor of California.
The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, in Goodridge versus Department of Public Health, rules anti-same-sex marriage laws unconstitutional in the state.
In the UK the Local Government Act 2003, repealing controversial anti-gay amendment Section 28, becomes effective.
The congress of the Communist Party of Indian Union (Marxist-Leninist) decides to merge the party into Kanu Sanyal's CPI(ML).
At the end of a long public inquiry, Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, John Prescott, gives planning approval to London Bridge Tower, set to become the tallest building in Europe.
Entertainer Michael Jackson is arrested by police on charges of child molestation.
Several bombs explode in Istanbul, Turkey, destroying the Turkish head office of HSBC and the British consulate.
Michael Jackson is arrested by police on charges of child molestation.
After the November 15 bombings, a second day of the 2003 Istanbul Bombings occurs in Istanbul, Turkey, destroying the Turkish head office of HSBC Bank AS and the British consulate.
England wins the 2003 Rugby World Cup, defeating Australia 20-17 after extra time.
England defeat Australia to win England's first Rugby World Cup.
The Heritage Classic, the first outdoor hockey game in the history of the NHL, is played in Edmonton, Alberta
In Tbilisi, Georgia, opponents of President Eduard Shevardnadze seize the parliament building and demand the president's resignation.
The Georgian Rose Revolution ends with overwhelming victory - president Eduard Shevardnadze resigns following weeks of mass protests over fraudulent elections.
A total solar eclipse is seen over Antarctica.
Georgian president Eduard Shevardnadze resigns following weeks of mass protests over flawed elections.
The High Court in Glasgow imposes a minimum sentence of 27 years for Al Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, the Libyan convicted of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.
Concorde makes its last ever flight over Bristol, UK.
Kalev Ots succeeds to the presidency of the pre-WW II Republic of Estonia in exile, after the death of Mihkel Mathiesen.
Boeing chairman and CEO Phil Condit resigns unexpectedly. He is replaced by Lewis Platt as non-executive chairman and Harry Stonecipher as president and CEO.
The use of hand-held cell phones while driving is made illegal in the United Kingdom.
Mike Lowell signs a four-year, $32 million deal with the Florida Marlins.
A suicide bombing on a commuter train in southern Russia kills 44 people. President Vladimir Putin condemns the attack as a bid to destabilize the country two days before parliamentary elections.
The new Government in Exile of the pre-World War II Republic of Estonia, headed by Ahti MSnd, assumes office.
Parliamentary elections are held in Russia.
The Conservative Party of Canada is officially recognized after the merger of the Canadian Alliance and Progressive Conservative Party of Canada.
A female suicide bomber blows herself up outside Moscow's National Hotel, across from the Kremlin and Red Square, killing five bystanders.
Andy Pettitte signs a three-year, $31.5 million deal with the Houston Astros.
Saddam Hussein, former President of Iraq, is captured in Tikrit by the U.S. 4th Infantry Division.
Olympic Airlines, Greece's new flag carrier, is launched.
Paul Martin becomes the 21st Prime Minister of Canada.
Paul Martin, Jr. is sworn-in as the 21st Prime Minister of Canada.
Former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is captured near his home town of Tikrit (see Operation Red Dawn).
In the most-attended basketball game in history, 78,129 watch Michigan State University lose 79-74 to the University of Kentucky at Ford Field.
President of Pakistan Pervez Musharaf narrowly escaped an assassination attempt.
The La Fenice opera house in Venice, Italy, rebuilt following arson, is reopened.
Miguel Tejada agrees to a six-year $72 million contract with the Baltimore Orioles making it the largest deal in the history of the franchise.
The United Kingdom announces plans to build a new runway at Stansted Airport in Essex and a short-haul runway at Heathrow Airport, sparking anger from environmental groups.
The New York Yankees and Gary Sheffield finalize a US$39 million, three-year deal.
Libya admits to building a nuclear bomb.
An earthquake shakes up California, killing two people.
Parmalat is first accused of falsifying accounts in the amount of $5 billion, later admitted by founder Calisto Tanzi; observers call it "Europe's Enron".
The Spanish police thwart an attempt by ETA to detonate 50kg of explosives at 3:55 p.m. on Christmas Eve inside Madrid's busy Chamart?n Station.
At the request of the U.S. Embassy in Paris, the French Government orders Air France to cancel several flights between France and the U.S. in response to terrorist concerns.
A BSE (mad cow disease) outbreak in Washington State is announced. Several countries including Brazil, Australia and Taiwan ban the import of beef from the United States of America.
The Spanish police thwarts an attempt by ETA to detonate 50 kg of explosives at 3:55 p.m. inside Madrid's busy Chamartfn Station.
President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan escapes the second assassination attempt in two weeks.
Beagle 2 is scheduled to land on Mars, but nothing is heard from the lander.
The ill-fated Beagle 2 probe which was released from the Mars Express Spacecraft on December 19, disappears shortly before its scheduled landing.

In Southeastern Iran, a magnitude 6.6 earthquake occurs, the deadliest earthquake in 2003, likely the largest earthquake in this area in 2000 years. About 31,000 people killed, 30,000 injured, 75,600 homeless and 85 percent of buildings damaged or destroyed in the Bam area.
A major earthquake devastates southeast Iranian city of Bam, killing tens of thousands and destroying the citadel of Arg-T Bam.
U.S. Attorney General John Ashcroft recuses himself and his office from the Plame affair.
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration announces a ban on the sale of dietary supplement ephedra.

The single largest expansion of the European Union takes place as the number of member states grows from 15 to 25 due to the accession of Cyprus, Malta, Slovenia, and several former Eastern Bloc countries.
Pervez Musharraf wins a vote of confidence from an electoral college consisting of Parliament and the provincial assemblies, confirming him as President of Pakistan and de facto dictator until 2007.
Stardust successfully flies past Comet Wild 2, collecting samples that it will return to Earth two years later.
The Central Bank of Suriname changes banknote denomination from gulden to Suriname dollar. Exchange rate is 1000 gulden to 1 dollar.
Flight 604, a Boeing 737 owned by Flash Airlines, an Egyptian airliner, plunges into the Red Sea, killing all 148 aboard.
Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea off the coast of Egypt, killing all 148 aboard.
Spirit, a NASA Mars Rover, lands successfully on Mars at 04:35 UTC.
Dr. Mikhail Saakashvili is elected the President of Georgia.
Mikhail Saakashvili wins the presidential elections in Georgia.
NASA's MER-A (Spirit) lands on Mars at 04:35 UTC.
The LSU Tigers defeat the Oklahoma Sooners 21-14 for the national Bowl Championship Series (BCS) title.
Wade Boggs and Ryne Sandberg are elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.

Apple Computer introduces the iPod mini music player. Colors available are silver, blue, green, pink, and gold anodized aluminum. Each comes with 4 GB RAM and FireWire port. Price is US$249; weight is 3.6 ounces; size is 3.6 x 2 x 0.5 inches.
RMS Queen Mary 2, the largest passenger ship ever built, was christened by her namesake's granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
At the Detroit Opera House in Michigan, General Motors unveils the next-generation "C6" 2005 Corvette. It features 400-hp engine, fixed headlights, and targa top.

In England, serial killer Harold Shipman is found hanged in his cell at Wakefield Prison, four years after being convicted of murdering 15 patients in Cheshire. Shipman was blamed for the deaths of a further 200 patients at an inquest 18 months ago and some reports claimed that he may have murdered as many as 400 or 500 people.
The national flag of Georgia, the so-called "five cross flag", was restored to official use after a hiatus of some 500 years.
Amartya Sen steps down as Master of Trinity College, Cambridge.
Goatse.cx is suspended by the Christmas Island Technology Corporation following a massive grassroots movement to close the site forever.
In the USA, Carol Moseley Braun drops out of the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, and endorses Howard Dean.
U.S. Senator John Kerry (Democrat-Massachusetts) wins the Iowa Democratic caucus. Vermont Governor Howard Dean's concession speech ends with a lively but controversial scream.
Canada: The residence of reporter Juliet O'Neill is searched by the RCMP investigating leaks concerning the deportation of Maher Arar.
NASA's MER-A (the Mars Rover Spirit) ceases communication with mission control. The problem lies with Flash Memory management and is fixed remotely from Earth on February 6th.
At 05:05 UTC, NASA's MER-B (Opportunity) rover lands on Mars.
Opportunity (MER-B) lands on surface of Mars.
A whale explodes in Tainan City, Taiwan.
President Hamid Karzai signed the new constitution of Afghanistan.
In the USA, John Kerry wins the New Hampshire Democratic primary.

The findings of the Hutton Inquiry are published in London. The British Government is found not to have falsified information in the "sexed up dossier". The report criticizes the BBC's role in the death of David Kelly, a weapons expert on Iraq.
September Dossier: Lord Hutton publishes his report into the death of UN weapons inspector Dr. David Kelly.
A whale explodes in the town of Tainan, Taiwan. A build-up of gas in the decomposing 56-foot long Sperm whale is suspected of causing the explosion.
Mystery Science Theater 3000 ends its run on the Sci-Fi Channel.
The New England Patriots win NFL Super Bowl XXXVIII, as Adam Vinatieri kicks the game-winning field goal with four seconds left.
A hajj stampede in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills 251 pilgrims.
Janet Jackson exposes her breast on American television during the half-time show of the Super Bowl, prompting the Nipplegate controversy which was accociated with riots.
At least 244 people trampled to death in a stampede at the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
An eleven-story apartment building collapses in Konya, Turkey, killing more than 90 residents.
J=annes Eidesgaard becomes Prime Minister of the Faroe Islands.
The US Central Intelligence Agency admits that there was no imminent threat from weapons of mass destruction before the 2003 invasion of Iraq.
The Saint Louis Cardinals and Albert Pujols agree to a US$100 million, seven-year deal.
John Hench dies, at age 95. Hench worked at The Walt Disney Company for 64 years, the longest of any Disney employee. He worked on animation, and took part in the creation of all Disney parks.
Twenty-three Chinese people drown when a group of 35 cockle-pickers are trapped by rising tides in Morecambe Bay, England. Twenty-one bodies are recovered.
Rebels from the Revolutionary Artibonite Resistance Front capture the city of Gonaïves, starting the 2004 Haiti rebellion.
A suicide bomber kills 41 people on a metro car in Moscow.
In Russia, a suicide-attack in a Moscow metro kills 40 commuters, and injures a hundred and twenty-nine. The blast is blamed on Chechen separatist groups.
Several leaders of Abnaa el-Balad are arrested in Israel.
At least 50 people are killed in a car bomb attack on a police recruitment centre south of Baghdad.
The French National Assembly votes to pass a law banning religious items and clothing from schools.
Comcast in the USA launches a US$54 billion hostile takeover bid for the Walt Disney Company. The bid is withdrawn on April 28.
San Francisco, California begins issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples as an act of civil disobedience.

On National Freedom to Marry Day, two days after Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco, California, issued a directive to the county clerk, the City and County of San Franciso begins issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples.
The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics discovers the universe's largest known diamond, white dwarf star BPM 37093.
Athens, Greece, is hit by a major blizzard which blankets the entire city for days, causing widespread havoc.
Scientists in South Korea announce the cloning of 30 human embryos.
Travis Metcalfe from the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics discovers the universe's largest known diamond, white dwarf star BPM 37093.
The roof of the Transvaal water park in Moscow collapses, killing 25 and injuring more than 100.
Riots break out between New South Wales Police and Aboriginal residents of Redfern, New South Wales, a suburb of Sydney, Australia.
In a suburb of Moscow, Russia, the roof of the Transvaal water park collapses, killing more than 25 people, and wounding more than 100 others.
John Daly the PGA golfer, wins his first PGA TOUR event in 9 years by winning the Buick Invitational golf tournament on the first hole of a playoff in San Diego, California.
(to February 20) A nor'easter blizzard devastates Atlantic Canada, dumping more than 95 centimetres on some areas.
A train carrying a convoy of petrol, fertiliser, and sulfur derails and explodes in Iran, killing 320 people.
Up to 295 people, including nearly 200 rescue workers, die near Neyshabur in Iran when a run-away freight train carrying sulfur, petrol and fertiliser catches fire and explodes.
Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal is awarded an honorary knighthood in recognition of a "lifetime of service to humanity."
Conservatives win a majority in the Iranian parliament election.
The first European political party organization, the European Greens, is established in Rome.
A 6.5 Richter scale earthquake in Northern Morocco hits in the Rif mountains near the city of Al Hoceima, killing 400. Ait Kamara is destroyed; 517 are killed.
Mel Gibson releases The Passion of the Christ.
The United States lifts a 23-year travel ban against Libya.
Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski is killed in a plane crash while landing in poor weather near Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The United States lifts a ban on travel to Libya, ending travel restrictions to the nation that had lasted for 23 years.
Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski is killed in a plane crash near Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
A bombing of a Superferry by Abu Sayyaf in the Philippines kills 116, its worst terrorist attack.
Former BPMC general secretary Ordrick Samuel launches a new party in Barbuda, Barbudans for a Better Barbuda.
Over one million Taiwanese participating in the 228 Hand-in-Hand Rally form a 500-kilometre (300-mile) long human chain to commemorate the 228 Incident in 1947.
Over 1 million Taiwanese participating in the 228 Hand-in-Hand Rally form a 500-kilometre (300-mile) long human chain to commemorate the 228 Incident in 1947
Jean-Bertrand Aristide resigns as president of Haiti. The chief justice of the Haitian Supreme Court, Boniface Alexandre, is sworn in as interim president.
The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King wins the Best Picture Oscar, along with 10 other awards, at the 76th Annual Academy Awards.
Jean-Bertrand Aristide resigns as President of Haiti following popular rebel uprising.
Punycode adopted by the national registrars of Germany, Austria and Switzerland.
Mohammed Bahr al-Uloum becomes President of Iraq.
Terry Nichols is convicted of state murder charges and being an accomplice to Oklahoma City bomber Timothy McVeigh.
John Kerry effectively clinches the 2004 U.S. Democratic Party presidential nomination by winning nine out of ten "Super Tuesday" primaries and caucuses.
NASA announces that the Mars rover MER-B (Opportunity) has confirmed that its landing area was once drenched in water.
Voters in the U.S. state of Georgia vote on a referendum concerning its Confederacy-derived flag.
War in Iraq: Al Qaeda carries out the Ashoura Massacre in Iraq, killing 170 and wounding over 500.

War in Iraq: A United Nations report from the weapons inspection teams states that Iraq had no weapons of mass destruction of any significance after 1994, despite President George W. Bush's objection to the contrary before the invasion.
Belgian brewer Interbrew and Brazilian rival AmBev agreed to merge in a $11.2 billion deal that formed InBev, the world's largest brewer.

A mixture of synthetic ammonia and nitrogen from the Sichuan General Chemical Factory leaks into the Tuo river in Sichuan province, Chinam shutting down water for drinking and bathing for nearly one million people.
The guilty verdict for Moroccan al-Qaeda suspect Mounir el Motassadeq's involvement in the September 11, 2001 attacks is overturned by the German appeals court, which orders a retrial.
The files of Supreme Court Justice Harry Blackmun are released to the public five years after his death.
A new constitution is signed by Iraq's Governing Council.
John Allen Muhammad is sentenced to death for his part in the Beltway sniper attacks of October 2002. Lee Boyd Malvo is sentenced to life in prison.
The US federal building and courthouse in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, was renamed the Ronald Reagan Federal Building and Courthouse.
A terrorist attack on a restaurant in Istanbul kills one and injures 5.
Five British men are released from detention at Camp Delta, Guantanamo Bay. After they land at RAF Brize Norton, four of them are immediately arrested for questioning.
Six Flags sells 8 of its theme parks to private investors.
In Madrid, Spain, ten simultaneous explosions on commuter trains and in rail stations kill 190 people.
Simultaneous explosions on rush hour trains in Madrid kill 191 people.
Following the March 11 terrorist attacks in Madrid, millions of protesters take to the streets of Spanish cities against terrorism.
Roh Moo-hyun, President of South Korea is impeached by its national assembly for the first time in the nation's history.
Two suicide bombers kill eleven Israeli civilians in Ashdod, Israel.
Spanish legislative election: The incumbent government led by JosT Mar?a Aznar is defeated by the Socialist JosT Luis Rodr?guez Zapatero.
Russian presidential election: Vladimir Putin easily wins a second term.
Pope John Paul II becomes the second-longest serving pope in history.
Vladimir Putin is re-elected president of Russia, while the PSOE wins elections in Spain just days after terrorist attacks in Madrid.
The new Spanish Government announces that it will withdraw Spain's 1,300 troops in Iraq.
Announcement of the discovery of 90377 Sedna, the farthest natural object in the Solar system so far observed.

Pogrom-like organized violence breaks out over two days in Kosovo. Nineteen people are killed, 139 Serbian homes burned, schools and businesses vandalized, and over 30 Orthodox monasteries and churches burned and destroyed.
Massive Unrest in Kosovo. Over 22 killed, 200 wounded, 35 destroyed Serb Orthodox shrines in Kosovo and two mosques in Belgrade and Nis.
The United Nations launches a political corruption investigation due to the scandal over its Iraqi Oil for Food program.
ÿänekoski bus disaster - A semi-trailer truck and a bus crash head-on in ÿänekoski, Finland. 24 people are killed and 13 injured.
A Swedish DC-3 shot down by a Russian Mig-15 in the 1950s is finally recovered after years of work. The remains of the crew are left in place, pending further investigations.
Taiwanese president Chen Shui-ban is shot just before the country's presidential election on March 20. See 3-19 Shooting Incident.
President Chen Shui-bian wins the Taiwanese presidential election by 0.2 percent of the vote.
Stephen Harper wins the leadership of the newly created Conservative Party of Canada, thus becoming the first leader in the party's history.
The incumbent Barisan Nasional party wins 198 out of 219 seats in the Parliament of Malaysia.
Antonio Saca is elected President of El Salvador.
In Malaysia, the 11th Federal and State elections are held, returning the ruling coalition Barisan Nasional to power with an increased majority.
Palestinians protest in the streets after an Israeli helicopter gunship fires a missile at the entourage of Sheikh Ahmed Yassin in Gaza City, killing him and seven others.
Andhra Pradesh Federation of Trade Unions holds its first conference in Hyderabad, India.

British Prime Minister Tony Blair visits Libyan leader Colonel Muammar al-Qaddafi, in return for the dismantling of Libya's weapons of mass destruction programme in December 2003 - the first time a major western leader has visited the nation in several decades.
Air Holland files for bankruptcy in response to unproven allegations of marijuana abuse by their pilots.
HMS Scylla, a decommissioned Leander frigate, is sunk as an artificial reef off Cornwall, the first of its kind in Europe.
In France, the government of Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin suffers a stunning and unprecedented defeat in regional elections.
The first ever South Atlantic hurricane makes landfall in South Brazil on the state of Santa Catarina - the hurricane is dubbed Hurricane Catarina.
The Republic of Ireland bans smoking in all enclosed work places, including restaurants, pubs and bars.
The largest expansion of North Atlantic Treaty Organization to date takes place, allowing Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia into the organization.
The Republic of Ireland becomes the first country in the world to ban smoking in all work places, including bars and restaurants.
Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia join NATO as full members.
Four American private military contractors working for Blackwater USA are killed, and their bodies mutilated, after being ambushed in Fallujah, Iraq.
In Fallujah, Iraq, 4 American private military contractors working for Blackwater USA, are killed and their bodies mutilated after being ambushed.
Google announces Gmail, the first web-based mail service to offer 1 gigabyte of storage.

The Faroese Prime Minister's Office announces that from then on the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister's Office will use a new version of the Faroese Coat of Arms. The colours were inspired from the Merki? (flag) and yellow/gold was added. The new Coat of Arms depicts a Ram on a blue shield ready to defend. It can be used by the Government Ministries and by Faroese embassies, but some still use older versions of the Coat of Arms.
Gmail, an email service from Google launches.
George W. Bush signs the Unborn Victims of Violence Act, which makes an attack that leads to the death of a mother and her unborn child two criminal charges.
The first legal same-sex marriage in the Canadian province of Quebec: Michael Hendricks and RenT Leboeuf wed in Montreal.

Microsoft and Sun Microsystems settle long-standing hostilities in signing a ten-year technology sharing agreement. Microsoft pays Sun close to $2 billion to settle past issues and for royalty payments.
Islamist terrorists involved in the 11 March 2004 Madrid attacks attempt a thwarted bombing of the Spanish high-speed train AVE near Madrid.
Islamist terrorists involved in the 11 March 2004 Madrid attacks are trapped by the police in their apartment and kill themselves with explosives.
Queen Elizabeth II begins a state visit to France to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Entente Cordiale.
Rolandas Paksas becomes the first president of Lithuania to be peacefully removed from the post by impeachment.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average removes AT&T Corporation, Eastman Kodak Company and International Paper Company from its index, replacing them with American International Group Incorporated, Pfizer Incorporated, and Verizon Communications Incorporated.
The Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement is signed by the Sudanese government and two rebel groups.
Darfur conflict: The Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement is signed by the Sudanese government and two rebel groups.
Phil Mickelson wins The Masters Tournament, his first Men's major golf championship.

Barry Bonds hit his 660th career homerun, tying his godfather, Willie Mays for third on the all-time homerun list. The 72-year old Mays greets Bonds at home plate with an $18,000 torch studded with diamonds forming the numbers 660, 25 (Barry's number), and 1, the number to needed move ahead.
At SBC Park in San Francisco, Barry Bonds hits his 661st career homer to move up to third on the all-time homer run career list.
India defeats Pakistan in their first cricket tour in 14 years.
Israeli helicopters fire missiles at a convoy of vehicles in the Gaza Strip, killing the Gaza leader of Hamas, Abdel Aziz al-Rantissi.
In Iraq, 12 mortars are fired on Abu Ghraib Prison by insurgents; 22 detainees are killed and 92 wounded.
In Iraq, 12 mortars are fired on Abu Ghraib Prison by insurgents, killing 22 detainees and wounding 92.
Mordechai Vanunu, who revealed an Israeli nuclear weapons programme in the 1980s, is released from prison in Israel after serving 18 years for treason.
Two trains carrying explosives and fuel collide in Ryongchon, North Korea, killing 161 people, injuring 1,300 and destroying thousands of homes.
The last coal mine in France closes, ending nearly 300 years of coal mining.
Two fuel trains collide in Ryongchon, North Korea, killing up to 150 people.

Referendums on the Annan Plan for Cyprus, which proposes to re-unite the island of Cyprus, take place in both the Republic of Cyprus controlled and the Turkish controlled parts. Although the Turkish Cypriots vote in favour, the Greek Cypriots reject the proposal.
US lifts economic sanctions imposed on Libya, 18 years previously as a reward for its cooperation in eliminating weapons of mass destruction.
Heinz Fischer is elected the new president of Austria.
The US Bureau of Engraving and Printing introduces new US$50 Federal Reserve notes, incorporating color and more complex security elements.
The last Oldsmobile car rolls off of the assembly line in the USA, ending 107 years of production.
In Washington, D.C., the National World War II Memorial opens on 7.4 acres of land.
Dick Cheney and George W. Bush testify before the 9/11 Commission in a closed, unrecorded hearing in the Oval Office.
Barry Bonds sets a major league record by being walked four times intentionally in a nine-inning game.

The largest expansion to date of the European Union takes place, extending the Union by ten member-states: Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Hungary, Malta and Cyprus.
Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia join the European Union, celebrated at the residence of the Irish President in Dublin.
A WNBC helicopter crashes in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, New York. This event is covered by rival station WABC-TV.
Mike Piazza of the New York Mets hits his 352nd home run, passing Carlton Fisk for most home runs hit by a catcher.
After pitching his 4136th strikeout, Roger Clemens moves ahead of Steve Carlton into second place on the career strikeouts list.
Canada wins the World Ice Hockey Championship in Prague, Czech Republic.
Chechen president Akhmad Kadyrov is killed by a landmine placed under a VIP stage during a World War II memorial parade in Grozny.
The Canadian national team wins the World Ice Hockey Championship in Prague.
Chechen president Akhmad Kadyrov is killed in a landmine bomb blast under a VIP stage during a World War II memorial victory parade in Grozny, Chechnya.
Philippine general election: Incumbent president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is elected for six-year term.
The Stockline Plastics factory explosion in Glasgow kills nine people.
At Dodger Stadium, Alex Cora of Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim hits foul off 14 consecutive pitches, then hits the 18th thrown for a two-run home run.
An American civilian contractor in Iraq, Nick Berg, is shown being decapitated by a group allegedly linked to al-Qaida on a web-distributed video.
In India, the Congress Party wins a surprise victory in the elections to the Lok Sabha.
Two US Marines are sentenced to prison for electrocuting an Iraqi prisoner a month earlier.
Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, marries Australian Mary Donaldson in Copenhagen.
The marriage of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark and Mary Donaldson takes place in Copenhagen.
The Constitutional Court of South Korea overturns the impeachment of President Roh Moo-hyun.
Arsenal complete a whole English Premiership season unbeaten, 38 games.
South Africa is awarded the 2010 FIFA World Cup.
Ruslana wins the Eurovision Song Contest 2004 for Ukraine with the song "Wild Dances", in Istanbul, Turkey.
The largest known prime number at the time of its discovery, 224036583 ? 1, is found by Josh Findley and the GIMPS collaborative effort.
The "We Are the Future" concert takes place in Rome, organized by Quincy Jones in partnership with the Glocal Forum.
A coup d'Ttat in Chad against the President Idriss DTby fails.
Ezzedine Salim, holder of the rotating leadership of the Iraqi Governing Council, is killed in a bomb blast in Baghdad.
Massachusetts legalizes same-sex marriage in compliance with a ruling from the state's Supreme Judicial Court (Goodridge v. Department of Public Health).
For the first time in American history, homosexuals are allowed to marry one another - in the state of Massachusetts
Randy Johnson throws the 17th perfect game in Major League Baseball history and became the oldest pitcher to throw a perfect game.
Brad Thompson breaks a 97-year-old minor league record set by pitching 57 consecutive scoreless innings.
Jeremy Sivits pleads guilty in a court-martial in connection with alleged abuse of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison in Baghdad.
Tony Blair is hit with a purple flour bomb in the chamber of the House of Commons during a session of Prime Minister's Questions.
The Olsen specimen of the US 1913 Liberty Head 5-cent piece (Proof 64 NGC) is sold for $3 million.
Stanislav Petrov is awarded the World Citizen Award for averting a potential World War III in 1983.
Sherpa Pemba Dorje climbs Mount Everest in 8 hours 10 minutes, breaking his rival Sherpa Lakpa Gelu's record from the previous year.
The U.S. town of Hallam, Nebraska, is wiped out by a powerful F4 tornado that broke a width record at an astounding 2.5 miles wide. It also killed one local resident.
Felipe, Prince of Asturias, of the Spanish Royal Family marries Letizia Ortiz Rocasolano.
A section of the ceiling in Terminal 2E at Paris's Charles de Gaulle International Airport collapses, claiming at least six lives.
Japanese prime minister Junichiro Koizumi visits North Korea, to secure the release of the families of the nine abducted Japanese citizens returned earlier.
Part of Paris Charles De Gaulle International Airport Terminal 2E collapses, killing four people and injuring three others.
Terry Nichols is convicted by an Oklahoma state court on murder charges stemming from the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.
F.C. Porto wins the European Champion Clubs Cup defeating A.S. Monaco by 3-0.

The New York Times publishes an admission of journalistic failings, claiming that its flawed reporting and lack of skeptism towards sources during the buildup to the 2003 war in Iraq helped promote the belief that Iraq possessed large stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction.
FC Porto wins the Champions League, defeating AS Monaco by 3-0 in AufSchalke Arena in Gelsenkirchen.
In Washington, D.C., the National World War II Memorial is formally dedicated by U.S. President George W. Bush.
The World War II Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C.
The Al-Khobar massacres in Saudi Arabia kill 22.
Thousands of people in Hong Kong take to the streets to commemorate the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.
A foul-up during routine software update at the Royal Bank of Canada leads to a three-day misplacement of 10 million account balances.
All outgoing flights from the United Kingdom are temporarily grounded following an air traffic control computer failure.

Central Intelligence Agency director George Tenet tenders his resignation, citing "personal reasons". John E. McLaughlin, US Central Intelligence Agency Deputy Director, becomes the acting Director until a permanent Director is chosen and confirmed by Congress.
Marvin Heemeyer destroys many local buildings with a home-made tank in Granby, Colorado.
At the 58th Annual Tony Awards, Avenue Q upsets front-runner Wicked to win the award for Best Musical.
Tampa Bay Lightning defeats Calgary Flames in 2004 NHL Stanley Cup Finals.
The Sikh leader Prem Singh Chandumajra launches the political party Shiromani Akali Dal (Longowal).
The 30th G8 summit takes place over the next two days on Sea Island, in Georgia, USA.
The pickled heart of Louis XVII of France is buried in the royal crypt at Saint-Denis.
The first transit of Venus since 1882 occurs; the next one will occur in 2012.
First Transit of Venus in this millennium.

Terry Nichols is spared the death penalty by an Oklahoma state court on murder charges stemming from the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing. The decision comes on the third anniversary of the execution of his co-defendant, Timothy McVeigh, in Terre Haute, Indiana.
Cassini-Huygens makes its closest flyby of Phoebe.
Ronald Reagan's funeral held at Washington National Cathedral.
A 1.3kg chondrite type meteorite (estimated to be four billion years old) strikes a house in Ellerslie, New Zealand, causing serious damage but no injuries.
A 1.3 kg chondrite type meteorite strikes a house in Ellerslie, New Zealand causing serious damage but no injuries.
The Workers Party of Bangladesh is split, as Khandaker Ali Abbas leaves to form a new party.
The Detroit Pistons upset the heavily favored Los Angeles Lakers to win the 2004 NBA Finals, four games to one.
European delegates agree on the EU constitution. It is anticipated that an additional two years will be required to finish the text and complete the ratification process.
Ken Griffey, Jr. of the Cincinnati Reds hits his 500th career home run, the 20th major league player to reach this mark.
Retief Goosen wins the U.S. Open at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.
SpaceShipOne becomes the first privately funded spaceplane to achieve spaceflight.
Habib Dodo, the general secretary of the Communist Youth of Côte d'Ivoire is assassinated by pro-government forces.
Canadian election: The Liberal Party, led by Paul Martin, is reduced to a minority government, after holding a majority since November 1993.

Union Pacific and Burlington Northern Santa Fe trains collide in a rural area outside of San Antonio, Texas. Forty cars are derailed, including one chlorine car. Three people die, another 50 people are hospitalized because of exposure to the gas.
The U.S.-led coalition occupying Iraq transfers sovereignty to an Iraqi Interim Government.
Estonia, Lithuania and Slovenia join the European Exchange Rate Mechanism
Sovereign power is handed to the interim government of Iraq by the Coalition Provisional Authority, ending the U.S.-led rule of that nation.
Preliminary hearings begin in Iraq in the trial of former president Saddam Hussein, for war crimes and crimes against humanity.
The Cassini-Huygens spacecraft arrives at Saturn.
Horst Khler is inaugurated as Germany's President (BundesprSsident).
Saturn Orbit Insertion of Cassini-Huygens begins at 01:12 UT and ends at 02:48 UT.
Horst Köhler becomes the Federal President of Germany.
In Hong Kong, 530,000 people march to urge a faster pace of democratisation and universal suffrage.
ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) accepted Pakistan as the 24th member.
Official opening of Bangkok's subway system.
Greece beats Portugal 1-0 to win the Euro 2004.
Groundbreaking takes place for the Freedom Tower begins at Ground Zero in New York City.
The cornerstone of the Freedom Tower is laid on the site of the World Trade Center in New York City. (This was largely a symbolic event; actual construction would not start for several weeks)
Pitcher Eric Gagne of the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim sets a new record streak of 84 consecutive saves, as he gives up a win on his 85th game.
First Indonesian presidential election by the nation.
The last patent on the LZW compression algorithm (in Canada) expired.

After JosT Manuel Durão Barroso's appointment to the European Commission, Portuguese President Jorge Sampaio announces that he will invite the second-in-line leader of PSD, Pedro Santana Lopes to form government.
German TV actress Inge Meysel dies at age 94. During the previous 40 years she had starred in over 100 TV productions.
CIA Director George Tenet leaves his position at the CIA.
Pedro Santana Lopes is officially appointed Prime Minister of Portugal.
The BBC airs the documentary The Secret Agent, exposing racism by members of the British National Party.
Monorail service begins in Las Vegas.
A fire at a private school in Kumbakonam, India kills over 90 children.
Barclays Bank freezes the bank accounts of the British National Party.
Millennium Park, considered the first and most ambitious architectural project in the early 21st century for Chicago, Illinois, is opened to the public by Mayor of Chicago Richard M. Daley.
Ninety children die in a fire at a private school in Kumbakonam, Tamil Nadu, India.
Todd Hamilton wins The Open Championship at Royal Troon Golf Club.
The United Kingdom government publishes Delivering Security in a Changing World, a paper detailing wide-ranging reform of the country's armed forces.
Production of the 2004 model Corvette ends, also ending production of the C5 model Corvette. Nearly 250,000 were built since the 1997 model.
The Old Bridge of Mostar in Bosnia-Herzegovina is reconstructed and reopened after being destroyed by Bosnian Croat forces on November 9, 1993.
Eleven years after its destruction, Stari most (the Old Bridge) in Mostar is reopened.
Over 100,000 opponents of Israel's unilateral disengagement plan of 2004 participate in a human chain from Gush Katif, to the Western Wall, Jerusalem (90 kilometres).
Lance Armstrong of Austin, Texas wins an unprecedented 6th consecutive Tour de France cycling title.
Paul Molitor and Dennis Eckersley are inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame. Broadcaster Lon Simmons wins the Ford C. Frick Award and writer Murray Chass wins the J.G. Taylor Spink Award.
Lance Armstrong makes history, winning his 6th consecutive Tour de France.
(to July 29) The Democratic National Convention in Boston, Massachusetts nominates John Kerry for U.S. President and John Edwards for Vice President.
U.S. Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts accepts the Democratic nomination for President of the United States at the 2004 Democratic National Convention in Boston, Massachusetts.
A gas explosion kills 16 people in Belgium.
A bomb attack occurs in front of Prague's Casino Royal.
A supermarket fire in Asunci=n, Paraguay, kills about 400 and leaves over 100 missing.
A supermarket fire kills 215 people and injures 300 in Asunci=n, Paraguay.
A bomb attack in front of Prague's Casino Royal.
Monday demonstrations against social cutbacks began in Germany
In the USA, the Statue of Liberty reopens after security improvements.
The pedestal of the Statue of Liberty reopens after being closed since the September 11, 2001 attacks.
A United Nations report blaming the government of Sudan for crimes against humanity in Darfur is released.

British football player Lee Hughes, 28, is sentenced to six years in prison and banned from driving for ten years after being found guilty of causing death by dangerous driving. Hughes also has his contract terminated by his employer West Bromwich Albion.
Disney's Donald Duck cartoon character receives a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame.
Singapore's prime minister Goh Chok Tong hands over his position to Lee Hsien Loong.
New Jersey Governor James McGreevey announces that he is "a gay American" and will resign effective November 15, 2004.
Sweden's nine millionth inhabitant is born.
Lee Hsien Loong is sworn in as Singapore's 3rd Prime Minister.
(to August 29) The Games of the XXVIII Olympiad are held in Athens, Greece.

Hurricane Charley kills 27 people in Florida after killing four in Cuba and one in Jamaica. Charley made landfall near Cayo Costa, Florida as a Category 4 hurricane. Charley is the most intense hurricane to strike the United States since Hurricane Andrew in 1992.
156 Congolese Tutsi refugees massacred at the Gatumba refugee camp in Burundi.
Black Friday crackdown by NSS on a peaceful protest in the capital city of Maldives, MalT.
The 28th Summer Olympics opens in Athens, Greece.
Adam Curry's first Daily Source Code is created, launching podcasting.
Hurricane Charley, a Category 4 storm, strikes Punta Gorda, Florida and devastates the surrounding area.
Sales tax holiday in Massachusetts. All sales taxes are suspended on purchases of $2500 or less.
Vijay Singh wins the PGA Championship at Whistling Straits.
Severe flooding occurs in the village of Boscastle in Cornwall, England.
The National Assembly of Serbia unanimously adopts new state symbols for Serbia: Boze Pravde becomes the new anthem and the coat of arms is adopted for the whole country.
MD5 collision found by Chinese researchers.
In Dublin, Ireland, the Dublin Port Tunnel excavation works are completed and the final tunnel boring machine breakthrough ceremony takes place.
In Dublin, Ireland the Dublin Port Tunnel excavation works are completed.
Elbegdorj Tsakhia, the peaceful democratic revolutionary leader of Mongolia, becomes Prime Minister of Mongolia for the second time.
A series of blasts rocks an opposition party rally in Dhaka, Bangladesh, killing at least 13 people.
A grenade attack on Bangladesh Awamee League, the biggest political party in Bangladesh kills 22 and injures more than a thousand, including party president Sheikh Hasina.
The Scream, the painting by Edvard Munch, is stolen at gunpoint from a museum in Oslo, Norway.

Two airliners in Russia, carrying a total of 89 passengers, crash within minutes of each other after flying out of Domodedovo International Airport, leaving no survivors. Authorities suspect suicide attacks by rebels from Chechnya to be the cause of the crashes.

Two airliners in Russia, carrying a total of 89 passengers, explode within minutes of each other after flying out of Domodedovo International Airport, near Moscow, leaving no survivors. The explosions were caused by suicide bombers (reportedly female) from the Russian Republic of Chechnya.
Around 200,000 protesters demonstrate in New York City against U.S. President George W. Bush and his government, ahead of the 2004 Republican National Convention.
Michael Schumacher wins a record seventh world championship title by finishing second in the Belgian Grand Prix at Spa-Francorchamps.
(to September 2) U.S. President George W. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney are re-nominated at the Republican National Convention in New York City.
Two suicide attacks on buses in Beer Sheva, Israel, kill at least 16 people and injure at least 60. Hamas claims responsibility for the attacks.
A woman commits a suicide attack near a subway station in northern Moscow, Russia, killing at least ten people and injuring at least 50. Authorities hold Chechen rebels responsible.

Chechen terrorists take between 1,000 and 1,500 people hostage, mostly children, in a school in the Beslan school hostage crisis. The hostage-takers demand the release of Chechen terrorists imprisoned in neighbouring Ingushetia and the independence of Chechnya from Russia.
The Beslan school hostage crisis begins when armed terrorists take hundreds of schoolchildren and adults hostage in the Russian town of Beslan in North Ossetia.
The United Nations Security Council adopts Resolution 1559, calling for the removal of all foreign troops from Lebanon. This measure is largely aimed at Syrian troops.
A small asteroid explodes in the stratosphere above Antarctica depositing micron-sized dust particles.
Hurricane Frances makes landfall in Florida. After killing two people in the Bahamas, Hurricane Frances kills ten people in Florida, two in Georgia and one in South Carolina.
Russian forces end the siege at a school in Beslan, Northern Ossetia. At least 335 people (among which are 32 of the approximately 40 hostage-takers) are killed and at least 700 people injured.
The Beslan school massacre ends in the deaths of approximately 344 teachers and children.
Tropical Storm Ivan becomes Hurricane Ivan in the Atlantic Ocean.
The Scottish Parliament meets in the new Scottish Parliament Building for the first time.

Hurricane Ivan passes directly over Grenada, killing 37 people. It passes over other Caribbean islands over the next two days, killing five people in Venezuela, four in the Dominican Republic, one in Tobago and 20 in Jamaica.
The Serbian government backs a decision by Minister of Education and Sport Ljiljana ?oli? to require the teaching of both creationism and evolution in schools.

In the "Rathergate" affair, the first Internet posts appear pointing out that documents claimed by CBS News to be typewritten memos from the early 1970s appear instead to have been produced using modern word processing systems.
The NASA unmanned spacecraft Genesis crash-lands when its parachute fails to open.
A bomb blast outside the Australian embassy in Jakarta, Indonesia, kills eleven and injures up to 100 people.

Serbian Prime Minister Vojislav Ko?tunica reverses a decision by Minister of Education and Sport Ljiljana ?oli? to require the teaching of both creationism and evolution in schools, and announces that ?oli? will be replaced.
2004 Jakarta embassy bombing: A bomb explodes outside the Australian embassy in Jakarta, killing 10 people.
Barry Bonds becomes the first major league baseball player to walk over 200 times in a single season.
Petros VII, the (Greek Orthodox) Patriarch of Alexandria and his company are killed in an unexplained helicopter crash outside Mount Athos, Greece.
The U.S. Assault Weapons Ban expires.

Dav?? Oddsson, Prime Minister of Iceland, steps down after serving as prime minister since April 30, 1991. Oddsson trades posts with his foreign minister Halld=r ?sgr?msson, who then becomes Prime Minister.
Security at the Palace of Westminster in London England is compromised, when the House of Commons is stormed by a small group of protestors during a debate about fox hunting.
Hurricane Ivan strikes Gulf Shores, Alabama, as a Category 3 storm, killing 25 in Alabama and Florida, becoming the third costliest hurricane in American history.
Hurricane Ivan touches land near Gulf Shores, Alabama, becoming the third costliest hurricane to strike the United States.
The 2004 Summer Paralympics commences in Athens, Greece.
Hurricane Jeanne leaves mudslides in Haiti, killing 3006.
Barry Bonds hits his 700th career home run, third player in major league baseball to reach the milestone.
Tamil is declared the first classical language in India.
Mexico and Japan finish two-year-long negotiations and sign a Free Trade Agreement in Mexico City.
Tamil is declared first classical language in India.
The Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) People's War and the Maoist Communist Centre of India merge to form the Communist Party of India (Maoist).
Mount St. Helens in Washington state, USA, becomes active again.
Tropical Storm Ivan, having come around and reformed in the Gulf of Mexico, makes its final landfall near Cameron, Louisiana, to little effect. In total, the storm will kill 92 people.
At least 1,070 in Haiti reported killed by floods due to Hurricane Jeanne.
Port Adelaide Power win their first premiership against Brisbane Lions in AFL Grand Final.
Hurricane Jeanne makes landfall near Port Saint Lucie, Florida, near location Hurricane Frances hit two weeks earlier. Jeanne kills over 3,030, mostly in Haiti.
Virgin Group announces a joint venture with Mojave Aerospace Ventures to build VSS Enterprise for commercial spaceflight and a new company called Virgin Galactic.
Asteroid 4179 Toutatis crosses path of Earth within 1.5 million km.
Major League Baseball announces the Montreal Expos will move to Washington D.C. in time for the 2005 season.
The asteroid 4179 Toutatis passes within four lunar distances of Earth.
The Burt Rutan Ansari X Prize entry SpaceShipOne performed a successful spaceflight, thereby halfway to winning the prize.
The first images of a live giant squid in its natural habitat is taken 600 miles south of Tokyo.
AIM-54 Phoenix which became the primary missile for the Northrop Grumman F-14 Tomcat retired from U.S. Navy.
Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners breaks the major league record for hits in a single season, with hit number 258.
Baseball: Seattle Mariners outfielder Ichiro Suzuki makes his 258th hit of the season, breaking George Sisler's 84-year-old single-season record.
American Samoa joins the North American Numbering Plan.
American Samoa joins the North American Numbering Plan.
The Montreal Expos play their last baseball game in their 36-year history.
Two car bombs kill at least 16 people and injure dozens more in Baghdad, Iraq.
SpaceShipOne wins Ansari X Prize for private spaceflight.

The Austrian Mint begins producing 1000-ounce gold coins with face value 100,000 euros, 37 cm in diameter, dubbed "Big Phil", to celebrate the 15th anniversary of Austria's Philharmonic gold bullion coin program.
King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia abdicates.
Martha Stewart begins serving a five-month sentence for insider trading, at the Alderson Federal Prison Camp in West Virginia.
Suicide bombers detonate two bombs at the Red Sea resort of Taba, Egypt, killing 34 people, mainly Israeli tourists and Egyptian workers.
Kenneth Bigley, the British hostage held by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, an Iraqi insurgent, is killed after a failed escape attempt.
Queen Elizabeth II opens the new Scottish Parliament Building in a ceremony in Edinburgh.
Direct elections for president are held for the first time in Afghanistan. Interim president Hamid Karzai is eventually declared the winner.
Incumbent Prime Minister of Australia John Howard leads the Liberal-National coalition to victory over the Labor Party led by Mark Latham in federal elections.

The tri-annual federal election is held in Australia and Liberal Party of Australia leader, John Howard, wins a fourth term as Prime Minister in a landslide victory over opponent, Mark Latham of the Australian Labor Party.
Democratic elections held for the first time in Afghanistan.
Abdullahi Yusuf is chosen as the new transitional president of Somalia.
Prince Norodom Sihamoni is chosen as the new king of Cambodia.
Intel announces it has scrapped plans to develop and release a 4 GHz Pentium 4 processor. Instead, it will focus on other ways to boost performance.
Arsenal loses for the first time in 49 league games, a national record, going down 2-0 to Manchester United at Old Trafford.

The New York Yankees defeat the Boston Red Sox 19-8 in Game three of Major League Baseball's American League Championship Series. The game, which pushed the Yankees to a 3 games to 0 series lead, sets a record for longest 9 inning baseball game.
A referendum in Belarus approves the lifting of constitutional term limits for the presidency.
The day TV died, according to Mark Pesce.
A team of explorers reach the bottom of the world's deepest cave, located in Krubera. The depth reached is 2,080 metres (6,824 feet), setting a world record.
General Khin Nyunt is replaced by Lieutenant-General Soe Win as Prime Minister of Myanmar.
