Myanmar prime minister Khin Nyunt is ousted and placed under house arrest by the Thai government on charges of corruption.
Corporate Airlines Flight 5966 crashes in Missouri, killing 13 people and injuring two.
Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono becomes the first directly-elected President of Indonesia.

The Boston Red Sox defeat the New York Yankees 10-3 in Game 7 of the Major League Baseball's American League Championship Series to win the series 4 games to 3. The Boston Red Sox become the first team in baseball history to come back from a 0-3 deficit to win a series. Overcoming a 3-0 series deficit has only happened twice previously in all of professional sports.
Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono is sworn in as the President of Indonesia.

The Boston Red Sox win the American League pennant, defeating the New York Yankees 10-3 in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, becoming the first team in major league baseball history to recover from a 3-0 postseason series deficit.
The Royal Canadian Mint releases a circulating 25-cent coin featuring a black and red colored poppy. This is the world's first colorized business-strike coin in circulation.
The British Ministry of Defence approves the deployment of the Black Watch regiment of the British Army to Baghdad, Iraq after a request for assistance by the U.S. government.
The Saint Louis Cardinals defeat the Houston Astros in game seven to win the National League Championship Series, advancing to the World Series for the first time in 17 years.
Brazil's "Operation Cajuana" launches its first rocket into space, the VSB-30, just 14 months after its space program experienced a deadly launch pad accident.
In Germany, Wilhelm Genazino wins the Georg Bnchner Prize for Literature.
Brazil's "Operation Cajuana" launches its first rocket into space, the VSB-30, just 14 months after its space program was devastated by a deadly launch pad accident.
A powerful earthquake and its aftershocks hit Niigata prefecture, northern Japan, killing 35 people, injuring 2,200, and leaving 85,000 homeless or evacuated.
The bodies of 49 Iraqi soldiers are discovered after being ambushed by insurgents.
Michael Schumacher wins his 7th Formula One World Drivers Championship, his 5th consecutive win, making him the most successful driver in the history of Formula One.
A plane carrying ten members of the NASCAR Hendrick Motorsports team crashes en route to the race held at Martinsville Speedway. There were no survivors.
The US Congressional Gold Medal is awarded to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and Coretta Scott King.
Fidel Castro, Cuba's President, announces that transactions using the American Dollar will be banned by November 8th.
The Cassini probe passes within 1,200km of Titan.
AT&T Wireless is officially acquired by Cingular Wireless.
Barry Bonds' 700th home run ball sells for US$804,129 in an online auction.
Details of the discovery of a new, recent species of fossil hominid, Homo floresiensis, from the island of Flores, Indonesia, are published.

The Boston Red Sox win American baseball's World Series for the first time since 1918, defeating the Saint Louis Cardinals in four games. Curt Schilling becomes the first starting pitcher to win a World Series for three different teams.

End of the Curse of the Bambino: At approximately 11:41 P.M. EST, on a night featuring a lunar eclipse, Major League Baseball's Boston Red Sox defeat the St. Louis Cardinals 3-0 in Game 4 of the World Series to become champions for the first time since 1918.
European heads of state sign in Rome the Treaty and Final Act establishing the first European Constitution.
In Rome, European heads of state sign the Treaty and Final Act establishing the first European Constitution.

The Arabic news network Al Jazeera broadcasts an excerpt from a video of Osama bin Laden in which the terrorist leader first admits direct responsibility for the September 11, 2001 attacks and references the 2004 U.S. presidential election.
A 163-metre-high radio mast in Peterborough, United Kingdom collapses in a fire.
A 163-metre high radio mast in Peterborough, Cambridgeshire, UK collapses in a fire.
In Punjab, India the expelled BSP leader Satnam Singh Kainth launches Bahujan Samaj Party (Kainth).
Leftist candidate TabarT Vzquez is elected President of Uruguay.
Passenger airline service ends at Mirabel International Airport in Montreal, Canada.
A 16-year-old Palestinian Muslim blows himself up in an outdoor market in Tel Aviv, killing three Israelis.
U.S. presidential election: U.S. President George W. Bush defeats Senator John Kerry. Republicans make gains in the House and Senate.
Dutch film maker Theo van Gogh is assassinated in Amsterdam, Netherlands by Mohammed Bouyeri.
The Incredibles is released by Buena Vista Distribution in the United States.
The Ufton Nervet rail crash in Berkshire, England kills seven people.
In C?te d'Ivoire, National Army bombings kill nine people, including French United Nations soldiers. French United Nations forces retaliate by destroying the National Army's air force.
An express train collides with a stationary car near the village of Ufton Nervet, England, killing 6 and injuring 150.
Official Guided by Voices Day in Dallas, Texas.
U.S. forces launch a major assault on the Iraqi town of Fallujah, in an effort to rid the area of insurgents before the Iraqi elections in January.
War in Iraq: The interim government of Iraq calls for a 60-day "state of emergency" as U.S. forces storm the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah.
War in Iraq: More than 10,000 U.S. troops and a small number of Iraqi army units participate in a siege on the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah.
John Ashcroft and Don Evans resign their posts as U.S. Attorney General and U.S. Secretary of Commerce respectively.
Mozilla Firefox 1.0 released. This has become one of Microsoft Internet Explorer's biggest competitors.
Halo 2 is released by the Microsoft Corporation. The sci-fi action shooter smashes entertainment records, grossing $125 Million on its opening day.
Mary McAleese inaugurated for a second term as President of Ireland.
Yasser Arafat is confirmed dead by the Palestine Liberation Organization, of unidentified causes. Mahmoud Abbas is elected chairman of the PLO minutes later.
Under new ownership, G4TechTV terminated many great TechTV hosts, as well as crew, and aired their last episodes on the 10th and 11th.
New Zealand Tomb of the Unknown Warrior dedicated at the National War Memorial, Wellington
In Redwood City, California, a jury finds Scott Peterson guilty of the murder of his wife Laci and unborn son Conner.
Resignation of Colin Powell as Secretary of State.
Scott Peterson is found guilty of firstmurder of his wife Laci Peterson and their unborn son Conner after a five-and-a-half month long trial.
After six days of intense battles, the Iraqi town of Fallujah is fully occupied by U.S. forces.
U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell submits his resignation.
New Jersey Governor Jim McGreevey leaves office, three months after resigning due to a gay extra-marital affair. State Senator Richard Codey takes over as interim governor.
The People's Republic of China agrees to invest $20 billion dollars in Argentina, a deal signed days before the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Santiago, Chile.
NASA's hypersonic Scramjet breaks a record by reaching a velocity of about 7,000 mph in an unmanned experimental flight. It obtains a speed of Mach 9.6, almost ten times the speed of sound.
A train crash near Bundaberg in Queensland, Australia, injures 150 people.
X-43A scramjet becomes the fastest air-breathing jet flying at nearly Mach 10 at approx. 11,200 km/h or 3.11 km/s.
(to November 21) The APEC Summit is held in Santiago, Chile.
Kmart Corp. announces it is buying Sears, Roebuck and Co. for $11 billion and naming the newly merged company Sears Holdings Corporation.
A cargo ship explodes and breaks in half at the port of Paranagua in southern Brazil, spreading a slick of fuel oil, diesel fuel and methanol.
Russia officially ratifies the Kyoto Protocol.
The NBA's Indiana Pacers and Detroit Pistons engage in a brawl that involves fans and players. The incident gets Pacer Ron Artest suspended for the whole season.

The Toronto Argonauts win the Canadian Football League Championship for the first time in seven years, defeating the British Columbia Lions in the 92nd Grey Cup 27-19 at Frank Clair Stadium in Ottawa, Canada.

In the final round of presidential election in Ukraine, Viktor Yanukovych is declared the winner. International election observers express severe criticism, and large crowds gather in a protest rally in Kiev.

Nintendo releases the Nintendo DS handheld video game system in the US and Canada. It features two 3-inch diagonal screens, stereo speakers, microphone, IEEE 802.11 wireless communications with range about 30 feet. Size is 5.85 x 3.33 x 1.13 inches. Price in the US is US$149.99. 500,000 units are sold in the first week; 1.2 million in the first month.
The Terra Nova offshore oil platform malfunctions and spills 166,000 litres of oil off Newfoundland, Canada.
The second round of the Ukrainian presidential election is held, unleashing massive protests and controversy with regards to the election's integrity.

The island of Dominica is hit by its most destructive earthquake in history; the northern half of the island receives the most damage, especially in the town of Portsmouth. It is also felt in neighbouring Guadeloupe, where one person is killed as a result.
The Paris Club agreed to write off 80% (up to $100 billion) of Iraq's external debt.[1]
The Nintendo DS was released in United States and Canada
The recently relocated Washington National League baseball franchise announces its new name, the Washington Nationals.
The Orange Revolution begins in Ukraine, resulting from the presidential elections.
In England, Alex Ferguson takes charge of his 1,000th game as manager of Manchester United.
The Indian political party Congress Jananayaka Peravai merges into the Indian National Congress.
Korean Research team announce that they have used cord blood stem cells to regrow a parapeligic's spinal cord. Patient walks for the first time in 19 years.
A group of Iraqi political leaders, primarily from Sunni and Kurdish parties, advocate a six-month delay in popular elections scheduled for January 2005.
An oil tanker sppills as much as 1.8 million litres of crude oil into the Delaware River between Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, USA.
An explosion occurs in a coal mine in China.
A male Po'o-uli dies of avian malaria at the Maui Bird Conservation Center in Olinda before it can breed, making the species in all probability extinct.
Ricardo Lagos, President of Chile, promises economic compensation to 28,000 torture victims of Augusto Pinochet's military dictatorship.
Male Po'o-uli dies of avian malaria in Maui Bird Conservation Center in Olinda before it could breed, making the species most in all probability extinct.
Brett Favre day in Wisconsin, in honor of his record-setting 200th start as quarterback.
Lion Air Flight 538 crashlands in Surakarta, Central Java, Indonesia, killing 26.
Longtime Jeopardy champion Ken Jennings finally loses, leaving him with $2,520,700, television's all-time biggest game show haul.
Tom Brokaw anchors his last broadcast of NBC Nightly News.
Nintendo releases the Nintendo DS handheld video game system in Japan. 500,000 units are sold in the first four days.

David Bieber, a 38-year-old former American marine, is sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of a Leeds policeman and the attempted murder of two others following an incident on December 26, 2003. The trial judge recommends that he should never be released from prison.
Brian Williams succeeds Tom Brokaw as host of NBC Nightly News.
The Colombian government extradites Gilberto Rodr?guez Orejuela to the United States. Orejuela is one of the most powerful drug dealers in the world, arrested in 1995 and 2003.
Terrorists attack the U.S. Consulate in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, killing several people.
IBM announces it will sell its PC division to Lenovo Group of China, for about US$1.75 billion.
Hamid Karzai is inaugurated as President of Afghanistan.
John Kufuor is re-elected as President of Ghana.
Nathan Gale shoots and kills guitarist Dimebag Darrell onstage in Colombus, Ohio.

The biggest Chinese personal computer producer Lenovo announces its plan to purchase IBM's global personal computer business, which would make it the third largest world PC maker after Dell and Hewlett-Packard.
Guitarist Dimebag Darrell Abbott is murdered onstage by Nathan Gale at a Damageplan concert in Columbus, Ohio.
The Cuzco Declaration is signed in Cuzco, Peru, establishing the South American Community of Nations.
The population of the Australian state of Victoria reaches 5 million for the first time.
Darrell "Dimebag" Abbott, formerly of the metal act Pantera, is shot by a jilted fan while performing with his new group, Damageplan.
New Zealand bans smoking in all public places (bars, restaurants, hotels, school, etc.).
A tombstone commemorating the 35th anniversary of the death of Brazilian guerrilla Carlos Marighella is inaugurated in Salvador, Bahia.
Tests show that Ukrainian opposition presidential candidate Viktor Yushchenko was poisoned with a large dose of dioxin.

Sony Computer Entertainment releases the PlayStation Portable in Japan. It features Memory Stick port, USB port, UMD drive, 4.3-inch 16:9 ratio 480x272 pixel display, Wi-Fi wireless connectivity, headphone jack, speaker. Batteries power the unit for about four hours. Price is 19800 yen (about US$185). 200,000 units sell out quickly.
Software giants Oracle Corporation and PeopleSoft agree to merge in a US$10.3 billion deal, creating the second largest maker of business applications software.

Former Chilean dictator, General Augusto Pinochet is put under house arrest, after being sued under accusations over 9 kidnapping actions and manslaughter. The house arrest is lifted the same day on appeal.
The world's tallest bridge, the Millau bridge over the River Tarn in the Massif Central mountains, France, is opened by President Jacques Chirac.
A Kuwaiti tanker collides with a dredger in the Suez Canal, dumping about 8.3 million litres of crude oil.

The Millau viaduct, the highest bridge in the world, spanning the valley of the River Tarn near Millau, France and designed by British architect Lord Foster in collaboration with French bridge engineer Michel Virlogeux, is officially opened.
Albanian terrorists take a bus and its passengers hostage in Athens, Greece and demand one million euros in ransom money.
The House of Lords rules that the British Government breaches human rights legislation by detaining without trial foreign nationals suspected of being terrorists.
Information technology security company Symantec Corp signs a definitive agreement to merge with Veritas Software Corp, valued at $13.5 billion, in an all-stock transaction.
The Seattle Mariners baseball team sign free-agent third baseman Adrian Beltre to a $64 million, five-year deal.
Iraqi insurgents attack a U.S. military base in the city of Mosul, killing 22 people.

Armed robbers in Northern Ireland steal over 22 million pounds sterling from the headquarters of the Northern Bank. Unionist politicians and the Police Service of Northern Ireland blame the Provisional Irish Republican Army, and stall the peace process.
Free-agent outfielder J.D. Drew signs a five-year, $55 million deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Macquarie Island in the Southern Ocean is hit by an 8.1 magnitude earthquake.
The 2004 Christmas Eve Snowstorm delivers an extremely unusual snowfall to the southern United States.

An historic and unprecedented snowfall occurs over portions of southern Texas during the early morning hours. Daily totals include 1.5 inches at Brownsville, 3.5 inches at McAllen, 4.4 inches at Corpus Christi, and 12.1 inches at Victoria.
Cassini orbiter releases Huygens probe which successfully landed on Saturn's moon, Titan on January 14, 2005.

One of the worst natural disasters in recorded history hits Southeast Asia when the strongest earthquake in 40 years hits the entire Indian Ocean region. The massive 9.3 magnitude earthquake, epicentered just off the west coast of the Indonesian island of Sumatra, generates enormous tsunami waves that crash into the coastal areas of 14 nations including Thailand, India, Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Malaysia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, and Indonesia. 228,000 people are killed or missing in 12 countries, and 1.7 million are left homeless. The tsunami causes more casualties than any other in recorded history and is recorded nearly world-wide on tide gauges in the Indian, Pacific and Atlantic Oceans.
The re-run of the second round of the Ukrainian presidential election takes place. Opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko is declared the victor.

An earthquake measuring 9.0 on the Richter magnitude scale creates a tsunami causing devastation in Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, The Maldives and many other areas around the rim of the Indian Ocean, killing more than 300,000.
The Ukrainian transport minister, Heorhiy Kyrpa, is found shot dead, in a suspected suicide.
A fire in a Buenos Aires night club (Rep?blica Cromagnon) kills 194 people during a rock concert.
A fire in the Repblica Cromagnon nightclub in Buenos Aires, Argentina kills 194.
Ukrainian Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovich resigns.
Taipei 101, the tallest skyscraper in the world, standing at a height of 1,670 feet (509 metres), officially opens.
The official opening of Taipei 101, the current tallest skyscraper in the world, standing at a height of 509 metres (1,670 feet).
Turkey drops six zeroes from its currency denominations.
The Angels of Anaheim baseball team in California announces the franchise will now be known as the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim.
Gunmen assassinate the Governor of Baghdad, Ali Al-Haidri.
Mississippi Civil Rights Workers Murders: Edgar Ray Killen is arrested as a suspect for the 1964 murders of three Civil Rights workers.
First World Congress of Imams and Rabbis for Peace begins in Brussels, Belgium
Baseball commissioner Bud Selig announces Major League Baseball and the Players Association will donate $1 million to help the victims of last month's Indian Ocean tsunami.

Over night, violent storm Gudrun sweeps across the southern half of Sweden, the worst storm in the country since 1969, and one of the worst natural catastrophes in recorded Swedish history. Storm gusts reached 150 km/hour, knocking down 250 million trees, the equivalent of a year's normal harvest of 80 million cubic metres throughout the country. Seven die in the storm, another nine die in clean-up work. 500,000 households are left with no electricity, and the +resund bridge is closed to road traffic.
The same storm which pounded the U.S. earlier in the month hits England, Scandinavia, and the Baltic States, leaving 13 dead with widespread flooding and power cuts.
Carlos Beltran becomes the tenth $100 million player in major league history as he agrees to seven-year deal for $119 million with the New York Mets.
A peace agreement is signed between north and south Sudan ending about 50 years of war, which killed about 2 million Sudanese.
Mahmoud Abbas is elected to succeed Yasser Arafat as Palestinian Authority President.
Elections are held to replace Yasser Arafat.
Apple Computer releases the Mac mini computer, for $500.
Apple Computer releases the iPod shuffle music player. It features 512 MB RAM and USB 2.0 port. Weight is under one ounce. Battery life is about 12 hours. Price is US$99.
Black Tuesday bushfires swept across the southern Eyre Peninsula in South Australia.
Paul Lo Duca signs a three-year, US$18 million deal to remain with the Florida Marlins.
Steven Contursi and Donald Kagin purchase the unique (US) 1787 Brasher gold doubloon for US$2,990,000, third highest price ever paid for a rare coin at public auction.
Deep Impact is launched from Cape Canaveral by a Delta 2 rocket.
At a Dodger Stadium's news conference, general manager Paul DePodesta announces the team has signed Derek Lowe to a $36 million, four-year deal.
Deep Impact (space mission) launches from Cape Canaveral by a Delta 2 rocket.
Armed militants enter Israel from Gaza and open fire near the border, killing six people and wounding five others. Hamas and Al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades claim joint responsibility for the attack.
American major league baseball and the players association agree in principle on a stricter steroid-testing policy. The new program will randomly test players year-round.
Milwaukee Brewers owners unanimously approve the US$223 million sale of the baseball franchise to Los Angeles investor Mark Attanasio.
The Huygens probe lands on Titan, the largest moon of Saturn.
Landing of the Huygens probe on Saturn's moon Titan.
In Detroit, Michigan, the North American International Auto Show is held, over nine days. Chevrolet unveils the 2006 Corvette Z06, with 7-litre LS7 engine, 500 hp, 475 pound-feet torque.
ESA's SMART-1 lunar orbiter discovers elements such as calcium, aluminum, silicon, iron and other surface elements on the moon.
Fishing boat "Big Valley" sinks in the Bering Sea. 5 people die.
Adriana Iliescu gives birth at age 66, the oldest woman in the world to do so.
Armed militants kill one person and wound eight people in the Gush Katif settlement, Gaza Strip.
Adriana Iliescu gives birth at age 66 and becomes the oldest woman in the world to do so.
A U.N. World Conference on Disaster Reduction in Kobe, Japan begins.
Eric Gagne and the Los Angeles Dodgers agree to a $19-million, two-year deal.
George W. Bush is inaugurated in Washington, D.C. for his second term as the 43rd President of the United States.
Ireland completes conversion to the metric system.
George W. Bush is inaugurated for a second term as President of the United States.
In Belmopan, Belize, unrest over the government's new taxes erupts into riots.
Roger Clemens agrees to one-year, US$18 million deal with the Houston Astros, making Clemens the most expensive pitcher in major league history.
In Belize's capital city, the unrest over the government's new taxes erupts into riots.
Viktor Yuschenko is sworn in as president of Ukraine.
Viktor Yushchenko is sworn in as the third President of Ukraine in Kiev, Ukraine.
Carlos Delgado agrees to a four-year, US$52 million contract with the Florida Marlins.
A stampede at the Mandher Devi temple in Mandhradevi during a religious pilgrimage in India kills at least 215, mostly women and small children.
A stampede during a pilgrimage in India kills at least 258.
Two trains derail, killing 11 and injuring 200, in Glendale, California near Los Angeles.

Having been confirmed earlier in the day by a vote of 85-13 in the United States Senate, Condoleezza Rice is sworn in as U.S. Secretary of State, becoming the first African American woman to hold the post.
A helicopter crash in eastern Iraq kills 31 United States soldiers.
Three trains crash , killing 11 and injuring 200 in Glendale, California near Los Angeles.
Lance Berkman agrees to a one-year, $10.5 million deal with the Houston Astros.
A Royal Air Force C-130 Hercules transport plane crashes in Iraq, killing ten British servicemen.
The first free Parliamentary elections in Iraq since 1958 take place.
A Royal Air Force C-130 Hercules is shot down over Iraq
The child molestation trial of superstar Michael Jackson begins in California.
Canada passes Bill C-38, the Civil Marriage Act. The Act passed by a 158-133 majority, and was approved in the Senate in July, making Canada the 4th country to sanction homosexual marriage.
Nepal King Gyanendra exercised Coup d'Ttat to capture the democracy becoming Chairman of the Councils of ministers.
Alberto Gonzales wins Senate confirmation (60-36) as the USA's first Hispanic attorney general.
The Chicago Cubs sign Aramis Ramirez to a US$8.95 million, one-year contract.
Super Bowl XXXIX: The New England Patriots win their second consecutive Super Bowl title, defeating the Philadelphia Eagles 24-21.
Jerrick De Leon, born 13 weeks premature, becomes the world's smallest infant to survive an open-heart procedure called an arterial switch.
The Detroit Tigers sign right-fielder Magglio Ordonez for five-years for US$75 million.
Danish parliamentary election: The center-right coalition led by Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen and his Liberal Party wins another term.
Israel and Palestinians agree to cease-fire.
An ETA car bomb injures 31 people at a conference centre in Madrid, Spain.
Roy Oswalt and the Houston Astros agree to a two-year, US$16.9 million deal.
Saudi Arabia holds its first ever municipal elections, in which only male citizens are allowed to vote.
North Korea announces that it possesses nuclear weapons as a protection against the hostility it feels from the United States.
North Korea and weapons of mass destruction: North Korea suspends participation in multi-nation talks to discuss its arms program and officially admits to developing nuclear weapons.
Fire devastates the Windsor Building, a 32-story office block, in Madrid, Spain.
Around 59 people are killed and 200 injured in a fire at a mosque in Tehran, Iran.
A massive suicide bomb blast in central Beirut kills the former Prime Minister of Lebanon Rafik Hariri and at least 15 other people. At least 135 other people are also hurt.
Lebanon's former Prime Minister, Rafik Hariri, is assassinated, prompting the Cedar Revolution (Intifada of Independence).

Seven people were killed and 151 wounded in a series of bombings by suspected Al-Qaeda-linked militants that hit the Philippines' Makati financial district in Metro Manila, Davao City, and General Santos City.
The National Hockey League cancels its 2004-2005 season, becoming the first North American professional league to cancel a season due to a labour dispute.
The Kyoto Protocol goes into effect, without the support of the United States and Australia.
The National Hockey League cancels the entire 2004-2005 regular season and playoffs, becoming the first major sports league in North America to do so over a labour dispute.
The Kyoto Protocol comes into force, following its ratification by Russia.
The United Kingdom law banning fox hunting, hare coursing and other sports which kill wild mammals is enforced from this date.
Suicide bombers kill more than 30 people in Iraq as Shia Muslims mark Ashura, their holiest day.
Spain holds a referendum on the Constitution for Europe, passing it by a substantial margin, but on a low turnout.
Early legislative elections in Portugal result in a landslide victory for JosT S=crates and the Socialist Party.
Spain becomes the first country to vote in a referendum on ratification of the proposed Constitution of the European Union, passing it by a substantial margin, but on a low turnout.

More than 500 people are killed and over 1,000 injured after entire villages are flattened in an earthquake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale in the Zarand region of Kerman province in southern Iran.
A controversial French law on colonialism, requiring teachers to paint it in a positive light, is passed by the national legislature.
Slovakia Summit 2005 begins, marking the first occasion when a sitting American President visits Slovakia; Bush and Putin are in attendance.
David Hernandez Arroyo goes on a shooting rampage at the Smith County Courthouse in Tyler, Texas. He kills two, including his ex-wife, and wounds four others before being killed in a police chase.
Terrorists kill five and wound 50 in Tel Aviv, Israel; Islamic Jihad claims responsibility for the attack.
Wichita, Kansas police apprehend the so-called BTK serial killer Dennis Rader, 31 years after his first murder.
Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak asks Parliament to amend the constitution to allow multi-candidate presidential elections before September 2005.

Hosni Mubarak the president of Egypt orders the constitution changed to allow multi-candidate presidential elections before September 2005 by asking Egyptian parliament to amend Article 76 of the constitution.
Pre-pay price capping on the Transport for London Oyster card is introduced.
Tim Hudson agrees to a four-year, $47-million contract extension with the Atlanta Braves.
The Supreme Court of the United States rules the death penalty unconstitutional for juveniles who committed their crimes before age 18.
President George W. Bush awards the nation's highest honor, the Congressional Gold Medal, posthumously to Jackie Robinson's widow. Robinson died in 1972.
Millionaire Steve Fossett breaks a world record by completing the first non-stop, non-refueled, solo flight around the world in the Virgin Atlantic GlobalFlyer.

Mayerthorpe Incident: James Roszko murders four Royal Canadian Mounted Police constables during a drug bust at his property in Rochfort Bridge, Alberta, then commits suicide. It is the deadliest peace-time incident for the RCMP since 1885 and the North-West Rebellion.
The freighter M/V Karen Danielsen, crashes into part of the Great Belt Bridge of Denmark, 800 m from Funen. All traffic across the bridge stops, effectively separating Denmark in two.
Steve Fossett becomes the first person to fly an airplane around the world solo without any stops without refuelling - a journey of 40,234 km/25,000 mi completed in 67 hours and 2 minutes.
The car of released Italian hostage Giuliana Sgrena is fired on by U.S. soldiers in Iraq, causing the death of one passenger and injuring two more.
The United Nations warns that about 90 million Africans could be infected with HIV in the future, without further action against the spread of the disease.
Wookiepedia [3]: The Star Wars Wiki is founded.
United Nations warns that about 90 million Africans could be infected by the HIV virus in the future without further action against the spread of the disease.
The car of released Italian hostage Giuliana Sgrena is fired on by US soldiers in Iraq, causing the death of one passenger and injuring two more.
Mass protest outside the National Assembly of Kuwait building for women's voting rights in Kuwait.
The Pakistan Army opens fire on insurgents in Baluchistan, in the first armed uprising since General Rahimuddin Khan's stabilization of the province in 1978.
Large pro-Syrian rally in Riad Al Solh square in Beirut mainly organized by Hezbollah.
Dan Rather presents his final broadcast of the CBS Evening News.
Tung Chee Hwa, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong, resigns.
Three people, including a judge, are murdered in the Fulton County Courthouse in Atlanta, Georgia; the main suspect, Brian Nichols, surrenders to police the next day.
Central African Republic elections: The first round leads to a runoff between top candidates Francois Bozize and Martin Ziguele.
In the United Kingdom, the controversial Prevention of Terrorism Act 2005 is finally given Royal Assent after one of the longest ever sittings by the House of Lords.
Tung Chee Hwa, the first Chief Executive of Hong Kong, steps down from his post after his resignation is approved by the Chinese central government. New SAT is administered.
The People's Republic of China ratifies an anti-secession law, aimed at preventing Taiwan from declaring independence.
Approximately one million people gather for an opposition rally in Beirut, a month after the death of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. It is the largest rally in Lebanon's history.
Mass Protest against Syrian influence in Lebanon takes place in Beirut as part of the Cedar Revolution.
The online statistics service SOTKAnet is opened for the public in Finland.
Ripudaman Singh Malik and Ajaib Singh Bagri, accused of the bombing of Air India Flight 182 in 1985, are found not guilty on all counts.
Ripudaman Singh Malik and Ajaib Singh Bagri, accused of the bombing of the Air India Flight 182 in 1985, are found not guilty on all counts.
Israel officially hands over Jericho to Palestinian control

During over 11 hours of the Committee on Government Reform hearing concerning major league player use of steroids, Mark McGwire refuses to talk about the past and does not deny taking performance enhancing drugs.
The first-ever Muslim Friday prayer led by a woman in a mixed-gender congregation was held in New York City, marking a break with a 1426-year Islamic tradition.
Terri Schiavo's feeding tube is removed at the request of her husband, fueling a worldwide debate on euthanasia.
A suspected suicide bomber in Doha, Qatar kills one person and injures about 12 others.
A time bomb explodes in a Muslim shrine in Quetta, southwestern Pakistan, killing at least 29 people and wounding 40.
A blast occurs at the Xishui coal mine in Shuozhou, China, and rocks nearby Kangjiayao coal mine, killing up to 59.
Lance Berkman agrees to a six-year, US$85 million contract with the Houston Astros.
Wales beats Ireland 32 - 20 to win their first Grand Slam since 1978 in Rugby Union's Six Nations tournament.
At least 250 people in Japan are injured and at least one killed, when a magnitude 7 earthquake strikes west of Kyushu Island, just 9km (5.5 miles) below the ocean floor.
A magnitude 6.6 earthquake hits Fukuoka, Japan, its first major quake in over 100 years. One person is killed, hundreds are injured and evacuated.
Ten are killed in the Red Lake High School massacre in Minnesota, the worst school shooting since the Columbine High School massacre.
In Red Lake, Minnesota, 10 are killed in a school shooting, the worst since the Columbine High School massacre.
The United States 11th Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 2-1 decision, refuses to order the reinsertion of Terri Schiavo's feeding tube.
The Tulip Revolution in Kyrgyzstan reaches its climax with the overthrow of president Askar Akayev.
The Sony PlayStation Portable (PSP) is released in North America.
The Taiwanese government calls on one million Taiwanese to demonstrate in Taipei, in opposition to the Anti-Secession Law of the People's Republic of China. Around 200,000 to 300,000 attend the walk.
Return of Doctor Who after 16-year absence.

In Northern Sumatra, Indonesia, a magnitude 8.6 earthquake occurs. At least 1,300 people killed, 350 injured and hundreds of buildings destroyed. A 3-metre tsunami damaged the port and airport on Simeulue.
The 2005 Sumatran earthquake rocks Indonesia, and at magnitude 8.7 is the second strongest earthquake since 1960.
Pope John Paul II dies at his home in the Vatican, following complications from the flu.
James Stewart Jr. becomes first African American to win a major motorsports event.
Pope John Paul II dies. Hundreds of millions of Catholics and non-Catholics mourn worldwide.

Alex Sanchez becomes the first major league baseball player to be publicly identified under baseball's new steroid policy. The Tampa Bay outfielder will be suspended for ten days for testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs.
North Carolina defeats Illinois 75-70 to win the 2005 NCAA Men's Basketball Championship at the Edward Jones Dome in Saint Louis, Missouri.
ABC News anchor Peter Jennings announces on World News Tonight that he has been diagnosed with lung cancer. It would be his last on-air appearance. Jennings died four months later on August 7.
The first 13th root calculation of a 200-digit number is computed by Frenchman Alexis Lemaire.
Rainier III, Prince of Monaco dies (born 1923), succeeded by his son Albert II.
A suicide bomber blows himself up in Cairo's Khan al Khalili market, killing two foreign tourists and wounding 17 others. A group called "Islamic Pride Brigades" claims responsibility.

MG Rover, the United Kingdom's sole remaining automotive mass-production facility, goes into receivership after a planned alliance with Chinese manufacturer, Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation, collapses.
Two million people pack Vatican City for the funeral of Pope John Paul II, possibly the biggest funeral in history.
A referendum is held in Cura?ao on independence versus integration with the Netherlands.
Funeral of Pope John Paul II.
The marriage of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles takes place, after being briefly postponed after the Pope's death. Camilla assumes the titles Her Royal Highness and The Duchess of Cornwall.

Tens of thousands of demonstrators, many of them supporters of Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr, march through Baghdad denouncing the U.S. occupation of Iraq, two years after the fall of Saddam Hussein, and rally in the square where Hussein's statue was toppled in 2003.
HRH Charles, Prince of Wales weds Camilla Parker Bowles.
Chelsea Cooley becomes Miss USA 2005 after winning the title out of 50 other states. She is the first ever winner from the state of North Carolina.
At least 21 people die and around 50 are injured in a devastating fire at a hotel in central Paris, France.

Shanghai Automotive rules out any possibility of going back on its decision to pull out of a venture with MG Rover. This results in the largest independent British carmaker finishing production with the loss of more than 6,000 jobs at its huge Longbridge plant in Birmingham.
Ben Sheets signs a US$38.5 million, four-year contract with the Milwaukee Brewers American professional baseball team. It is the richest deal in Brewers' history.

The first major league game in Washington D.C. since September 30, 1971 is played between the Washington Nationals and the Arizona Diamondbacks at RFK Stadium. President George W. Bush throws out the first ceremonial pitch. The Nationals win, 5-3.
President Lucio Gutierrez of Ecuador declares a state of emergency in the capital city and dissolves the Supreme Court.
Twelve tourists are killed in southern Switzerland when a bus carrying 27 people plunges 656 feet into a ravine.
In New York City, New York, American Numismatic Rarities auctions a Venetian 50-zecchini coin of Doge Alvise Mocenigo IV (1763-78) for US$379,500.
Five people die in ethnic clashes in Iran's south-west Khuzestan province.
Pope Benedict XVI (Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger) succeeds Pope John Paul II, becoming the 265th pope.
Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger elected Pope Benedict XVI on the second day of the Papal conclave.
A magnitude 5.8 earthquake hits Fukuoka and Kasuga, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan, injuring 56.
A bus crash in Vietnam's Central Highlands kills 30 Vietnamese war veterans.
A gunfight on the edge of the Saudi city of Mecca kills two militants and two members of the security forces.
John Negroponte becomes the first United States Director of National Intelligence.
Silvio Berlusconi, prime minister of Italy, re-forms the government after its dissolution three days earlier.
Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger is inaugurated as the 265th Pope of the Roman Catholic Church taking the name Pope Benedict XVI.
A passenger train derails in Amagasaki Hyogo Prefecture, Japan, killing 107 people and injuring another 456.
107 die in Amagasaki rail crash in Japan.
Bulgaria and Romania sign ascession treaties gaining entrance into the European Union.
The final piece of the Obelisk of Axum is returned to Ethiopia after being stolen by the invading Italian army in 1937.
Facing international pressure, Syria withdraws the last of its 14,000 troop military garrison in Lebanon, ending its 29 year military domination of that country.
Under international pressure, Syria withdraws the last of its 14,000 troop military garrison in Lebanon, ending its 29-year military domination of that country.
The Superjumbo jet aircraft Airbus A380 makes its first flight from Toulouse, France.
The Superjumbo jet aircraft Airbus 380 makes its first flight from Toulouse, France.
The Wynn Las Vegas hotel and casino opens, the world's most expensive casino resort, at a cost of US$2.7 billion.
The Patent Law Treaty goes into effect.
Syria completes withdrawal from Lebanon, ending 29 years of occupation.
Attacks on tourists in the Egyptian capital Cairo leave three militants dead and at least ten people injured.

Major League Baseball commissioner Bud Selig asks players to agree to a 50-game suspension for the first offense for the use of steroids, 100-game suspension for the second offense, and a lifelong ban after the third offense.
A suicide attack targets a Kurdish funeral in the northern Iraqi town of Talafar, near Mosul, killing at least 25 people and injuring more than 30 others.
The Pontiac Grand Am car ceases production at the 100 year-old Lansing Car Assembly plant.
Trailing 9-3 after eight innings, the Saint Louis Cardinals mount their greatest ninth-inning comeback in franchise history defeating the Cincinnati Reds 10-9 at the Great American Ballpark.
A blast at an illegal munitions store in northern Afghanistan kills 28 people and injures at least 13 others.
The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee opens on Broadway.
At least 32 people are killed and nine others injured when three two-story buildings in the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore collapse after gas cylinders stored in one of them explode.
In one of the largest insurgent attacks in Iraq, at least 60 people are killed and dozens wounded in a suicide bombing at a Kurdish police recruitment center in Irbil, northern Iraq.
United Kingdom general election: the Labour Party is re-elected with a substantially-reduced majority.
The United Kingdom general election takes place, in which Tony Blair's Labour Party are re-elected for a third, consecutive term.
At the age of 46 years and 257 days old, Julio Franco of the Atlanta Braves becomes the second-oldest player to hit a home run in major league baseball history.
A plane crash in Lockhart River, Australia kills 15 people.
Former Lebanese Prime Minister, General Michel Aoun returns to Lebanon after 15 years in exile.
The new Canadian War Museum opens, in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of V-E Day.
Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger is selected as the successor of Pope John Paul II.
Joschka Fischer is awarded the Leo Baeck Prize given by the Central Council of Jews in Germany for his efforts toward seeking understanding and reduction of tensions in the Middle East.

A hand grenade ostensibly thrown by Vladimir Arutinian lands about 100 feet (30 m) from United States President George W. Bush while he is giving a speech to a crowd in Tbilisi, Georgia, but malfunctions and does not detonate.

A hand grenade allegedly thrown by Vladimir Arutinian lands about 100 feet from United States President George W. Bush while he is giving a speech to a crowd in Tbilisi, Georgia, but malfunctions and does not detonate.
Serial killer Michael Ross becomes the first person executed in New England in 45 years.

An election is held in the Cayman Islands seven months later than originally scheduled due to Hurricane Ivan. It results in a change of government, with the United Democratic Party giving four seats to the then-opposition People's Progressive Movement in the 15 member Legislative Assembly.
The United States Department of Defense issues a list of bases to be closed as part of the Base Realignment and Closure process (BRAC 2005).
Uzbek troops kill up to 700 during protests in eastern Uzbekistan over the trials of 23 accused Islamic extremists. President Islom Karimov defends the act.
The Andijan Massacre occurs in Uzbekistan.
Pope Benedict XVI observes his first beatification, elevating Blessed Marianne of Molokai on the road to canonization into sainthood.
Will Ferrell returns to host Saturday Night Live.
A passenger ferry capsizes and sinks in strong winds in the Bura Gauranga River in Bangladesh, leaving over 100 people missing.
George Galloway appears before a U.S. Senate committee, to answer allegations of making money from the Iraqi Oil-for-Food Programme.
Kuwait permits women's suffrage in a 35-23 National Assembly vote.
Sony officially unveiled its PlayStation 3 game console during an E3 conference.
Kuwaiti women are granted the right to vote.
The world's tallest and fastest roller coaster, Kingda Ka, opens at Six Flags Great Adventure.
Elena Paparizou wins the Eurovision Song Contest 2005 for Greece in Kiev, Ukraine, with the song "My Number One".
In Kiev, Ukraine, Greece wins the fiftieth Eurovision Song Contest with "My Number One" performed by Elena Paparizou.
Liverpool F.C. wins the UEFA Champions League of soccer by defeating AC Milan 3-2 in a penalty shootout in Istanbul.

The Acting Chief Executive of Hong Kong, Donald Tsang, resigns for participating in the Chief Executive Election last July. As a result, Henry Tang and Michael Suen become the Acting Chief Executive and Acting Chief Secretary for Administration respectively.
A French referendum on the draft European Union constitution votes 55 percent to reject it.

France, one of the founders of a united Europe, resoundingly rejects the European Constitution, throwing the idea of a European Union into question and leaving the continent in a state of anxiety and uncertainty (see French referendum on the European Constitution).
W. Mark Felt admits in the magazine Vanity Fair that he is the anonymous source Deep Throat in the Watergate scandal.
A Dutch referendum on the draft European Union constitution votes 61 percent to 39 to reject it.
The Dutch referendum on the European Constitution results in its rejection.
Construction begins on Northrop Grumman X-47B, the world's first unmanned surveillance attack aircraft that can operate from both land bases and aircraft carriers.
At the Long Beach Coin, Stamp & Collectibles Expo, a US $20 gold coin, 1927-D PCGS MS-66 sells for US$1.65 million.
Switzerland votes to join the Schengen area and to allow same-sex partnerships.
Syrian Vice President Abdul Halim Khaddam resigns.
Apple Computer announces it is abandoning the PowerPC processor in favor of Intel processors for future Macintosh computers.
United States Supreme Court says no to medical marijuana.
At Logan Airport, almost 400 people narrowly avoid death when two jet airliners nearly collide on the runway.
G8 finance ministers agree to cancel the debt owed by 18 of the poorest countries.
Singer Michael Jackson is acquitted of all charges in his child molestation trial.

Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners becomes the third fastest major league player to reach the 1000-hit mark, in his 696th game. Suzuki also holds the record in Japan for being quickest player to attain a 1,000 hits, in his first 757 games.
Asafa Powell from Jamaica sets a new world record on the 100 m sprint in Athens with 9.77 seconds.
Off the coast of Northern California, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake occurs.

Because of "quadruple-witching" options and futures expiration, the New York Stock Exchange sees the heaviest first-hour trading on record. 704 million shares are traded between 9:30-10:30 A.M. (1.92 billion shares for the day).
A 6.7 aftershock, which followed a 5.3 earthquake the previous day, hits California, making it the fourth earthquake since June 12 in California.
Preliminary election results in the Autonomous Community of Galicia, Spain show that Manuel Fraga and the Partido Popular have lost control of the autonomous parliament.
A Volna booster rocket carrying the first light sail spacecraft (a joint Russian-American project) fails 83 seconds after its launch, destroying the spacecraft.
Donald Tsang Yam Kuen is appointed by the People's Republic of China to take over from Tung Chee Hwa as the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.
The San Antonio Spurs defeat the Detroit Pistons in Game 7 of the 2005 NBA Finals. The series is the first NBA Finals in 11 years to go to a seventh game.
AMD files a broad antitrust complaint against Intel Corporation in U.S. Federal District Court, alleging abuse of monopoly powers and antitrust violations.
AMD files broad antitrust complaint against Intel Corporation in U.S. Federal District Court, alleging abuse of monopoly powers and antitrust violations.
A final design for Manhattan's Freedom Tower is formally unveiled.
Canada becomes the third country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage.
The Dominican Republic-Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) is passed by the United States.
Spain joins Belgium and the Netherlands in permitting same-sex marriage.

Microsoft and IBM settle legal claims arising from the US Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft in the mid-1990s. Microsoft agrees to pay IBM US$775 million cash and US$75 million in credit toward Microsoft software.
Live 8, a series of 10 simultaneous concerts take place throughout the world, raising interest in the Make Poverty History campaign.
Ten Live 8 concerts are held around the world in an attempt to force G8 countries to address poverty.
The national law legalizing same-sex marriage takes effect in Spain.
Violent anti-G8 demonstrations occur in Gleneagles, Scotland.
NASA's "Copper bullet" from Deep Impact spacecraft hits Comet Tempel 1, creating a crater for scientific studies.
The Deep Impact collider hits the comet Tempel 1.
Boston Red Sox left fielder Manny Ramirez hits his 20th career grand slam, the second-most in major league history.
The European Parliament rejects the Directive on the patentability of computer-implemented inventions in its second reading in the codecision procedure.
The International Olympic Committee awards the 2012 Summer Olympics to London.
Time Magazine reporter Matt Cooper agrees to testify to a grand jury that Karl Rove revealed to him Valerie Plame's secret CIA identity.
Bob Geldof and Bono meet with the G8 in Gleneagles to discuss increasing aid to Africa. Afterwards, both make appearances at the Edinburgh 50,000 concert, a last concert in the Live 8 series.
The International Olympic Committee announced that London will host the 2012 Summer Olympics
Four explosions rock the transport network in London, three on the London Underground and one on a bus; 56 people die and over 700 are injured.
Al-Qaeda admits to killing Egypt's Ambassador, Ihab al-Sherif.
A series of four terrorist explosions occur on London's transport system killing 52 people, plus four suicide bombers.
Influenced by Live 8, the G8 leaders pledged to double 2004 levels of aid to Africa from US$25 to US$50 billion by the year 2010.

In Singapore, the International Olympic Committee takes a secret vote on the approval of the 28 current summer Olympic events scheduled to be played at the 2012 Summer Games in London. Baseball and softball are eliminated.
Hurricane Dennis strikes near Navarre Beach, Florida as a Category 3 storm, killing ten people after killing over 50 people in the Caribbean.
A Luxembourg referendum on the European Constitution votes to accept it.
Terrorists kill five people and wound 90 in a crowded mall in Netanya, Israel. Islamic Jihad claims responsibility for attack.
Thunder Horse, the largest semi-submersible oil platform in the world, was found listing badly after hurricane Dennis.
Prince Albert II is enthroned as ruler of the Principality of Monaco.
Three trains collide in Ghotki, Pakistan, killing over 150 people.
Three trains collide in the Ghotki rail crash in Ghotki, Pakistan, killing over 150 people.
Disneyland "re-launches" Space Mountain in Anaheim, California.
Jack Nicklaus plays his last hole of competitive golf during The Open Championship at Hole 18 at St Andrews, finishing with a birdie.
President George W. Bush nominates Appeals Court Judge John G. Roberts, Jr. to the United States Supreme Court, following the retirement of Sandra Day O'Connor.
Death Valley, California registers a temperature of 53.9C (129F). A total of 12 days of 50C (122F) or higher was reported. Overnight temperatures of 37.8C (100F) or higher were also observed.
Canada's Civil Marriage Act, legalizing same-sex marriage, receives Royal Assent.
In Yemen, several people die during demonstrations against oil price increases.
In China's Shaanxi province, a coal mine explosion kills two dozen.
Canada becomes the fourth country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage, after the bill C-38 receives its Royal Assent.

A terrorist attack on London, similar to the July 7 attacks, includes four attempted bomb attacks on three underground trains and a London bus. The bombs fail to explode properly, and only one injury is reported, later found to be unconnected.

Four terrorist bombings, occurring exactly two weeks after the similar July 7 bombings, target London's public transportation system. All four bombs fail to detonate and all four suspected suicide bombers escape.
A Brazilian electrician, Jean Charles de Menezes, is shot dead at a London underground station by police who allegedly mistake him for a suicide bomber.
The last Buick LeSabre rolls off the assembly line.
A man is shot dead by police as the hunt begins for the London Bombers. See 7 July 2005 London bombings and 21 July 2005 London bombings
A series of blasts hits a resort town in Egypt.
Lance Armstrong wins a record 7th straight Tours de France before his scheduled retirement.
Lance Armstrong wins his seventh Tour de France.
The 2004-2005 National Hockey League lockout ends.
Greg Maddux of the Chicago Cubs becomes the 13th pitcher in major league baseball history to register 3,000 strikeouts.

Mumbai and the Mumbai Conurbation area are submerged in 5-7 feet of water due to heavy rains, making nearby dams release water causing a massive flood, which virtually stops the financial capital of India for 4-5 days.
Launch of Space Shuttle Discovery, NASA's first scheduled flight mission (STS-114) after the Columbia Disaster in 2003.
Mumbai (f.k.a. Bombay) - the financial capital and most populated city of India - receives 995mm of rain within 24 hours, bringing the city to a halt for over 2 days. (See: 2005 Maharashtra floods.)

STS-114: NASA grounds the Space shuttle, pending an investigation of the external tank's continued foam-shedding problem. During ascent, the external tank of the Space Shuttle Discovery sheds a piece of foam slightly smaller than the piece that caused the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster; this foam does not strike the spacecraft.
The Provisional Irish Republican Army issues a statement formally ordering an end to the armed campaign it has pursued since 1969 and ordering all its units to dump their arms.

In a surprise move, Jnrgen Schrempp, who had been head of DaimlerChrysler for ten years, resigns his position. His successor was designated as Dieter Zetsche, who had been the very successful head of DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler division in the U.S.A.
The Provisional Irish Republican Army (The IRA) call an end to their thirty year long armed campaign in Northern Ireland.
A helicopter carrying John Garang, vice-president of Sudan, crashes in poor weather into a mountain, killing Garang.

Wade Boggs and Ryne Sandberg are enshrined into the Baseball Hall of Fame. Also inducted are San Diego Padres announcer Jerry Coleman, winner of the Ford C. Frick Award, and sportswriter and broadcast analyst Peter Gammon, recipient of the J.G. Taylor Spink Award.
Rafael Palmeiro of the Baltimore Orioles becomes the highest profile player to be suspended for violating the Major League Baseball steroids policy.
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia dies, succeeded by his half-brother Abdullah.
German spelling reform of 1996 is formally implemented
Air France Flight 358 bursts into flames after overshooting the runway at Toronto Pearson International Airport; all aboard survive.
The Dominican Republic-Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) is signed into law in the United States.
Air France Flight 358 skids off the runway at Toronto Pearson International Airport outside Toronto, Canada, destroying the plane but resulting in no loss of life.
President Maaouya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya of Mauritania is overthrown in a military coup while attending the funeral of King Fahd in Saudi Arabia.
Prime Minister Paul Martin announces that Michaëlle Jean will be Canada's 27th ? and first black ? Governor General.
An ATR-72 heading from Italy to Tunisia crashes into the Mediterranean Sea, killing 16 of 39 on board.
Russian Priz class mini-submarine AS-28 and its seven crewmembers are rescued off the Pacific coast
Space Shuttle Discovery returns to Edwards Air Force Base at 8:14 AM EDT, completing STS-114, "Return to Flight."
Space Shuttle Discovery makes successful touchdown at Edwards Air Force Base, California
103-year old Ted Radcliffe, probably the oldest professional baseball player, dies from cancer; Radcliffe was the 1943 Negro American League Most Valuable Player.
Lee Seung Seop dies from exhaustion in South Korea after playing 49 straight hours of StarCraft.
Murderer Mitchell Johnson is released from prison on his 21st birthday.
The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter is launched.
An F2 tornado strikes the coal mining town of Wright, Wyoming, destroying nearly 100 homes and killing two people.
Sri Lanka's foreign minister, Lakshman Kadirgamar, is fatally shot by a sniper in his home.
Civil unrest provoked in the Maldives
An F1 tornado strikes Glen Cove, New York, a rare event on Long Island
Helios Airways Flight 522 crashes into a mountain in Greece, killing 121.
Helios Airways Flight 522 crashes north of Athens, killing the 121 on board.
West Caribbean Airways Flight 708 crashes into a mountain in Venezuela, killing 152 passengers.
The XX World Youth Day begins in Cologne, Germany.
West Caribbean Airways Flight 708 crashes near Machiques, Venezuela, killing the 160 aboard.
Sellapan Ramanathan gains victory in the Singapore Presidential elections.
Bangladesh is hit by bomb explosions.
The first forced evacuation of settlers, as part of the Israel unilateral disengagement plan, begins.
The first forced evacuation of settlers, as part of the Israel unilateral disengagement plan, starts.
Peace Mission 2005, the first joint China-Russia military exercise, begins its eight-day training on the Shandong peninsula.
In the USA, BTK killer Dennis Rader receives ten consecutive life sentences.
Dennis Rader is sentenced to 175 years in prison for the BTK serial killings.
Massive power blackout hits the Indonesian island of Java, affecting almost 100 million people.
The first-ever joint military exercise between Russia and China, called Peace Mission 2005 begins.
Electronic music pioneer Robert Moog dies.
Pope Benedict XVI concludes World Youth Day with a mass. Over 1,100,000+ people attended the closing liturgy.
A 4.1-kg (9-pound) meteorite crashes into the Dotito area of Zambezi Escarpment in Zimbabwe, leaving a 15-cm (6-inch) crater.
Israel's unilateral disengagement from 25 Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip and West Bank ends.
TANS Peru Flight 204 crashes near Pucallpa, Peru, killing 41.
Saint Louis Cardinals' pitcher Tony LaRussa wins his 2,195th career game, moving into third place in all-time major league history.
Hurricane Katrina makes landfall on the Miami-Dade/Broward county line, hours after reaching hurricane strength.
Jean Michel Jarre's "Space of Freedom" concert is held in Gdansk, Poland, commemorating the 25th anniversary of the creation of Solidarnosc ("Solidarity" trade union).
Fiji's High Court rules that the island's sodomy law is unconstitutional.
Jean Michel Jarre's "Space of Freedom" concert in Gda?sk, Poland
Jeff Kent of the Los Angeles Dodgers becomes the first major league player to hit 300 homers as a second baseman.
A mandatory evacuation is ordered by New Orleans, Louisiana mayor Ray Nagin and Louisiana governor Kathleen Blanco as Hurricane Katrina moved nearer to Louisiana.

At least 1,836 are killed, and severe damage is caused along the U.S. Gulf Coast, as Hurricane Katrina strikes coastal areas from Louisiana to Alabama, and travels up the entire state of Mississippi (flooding coast 31 feet/10 m), affecting most of eastern North America.

Hurricane Katrina devastates much of the U.S. Gulf Coast from Louisiana (especially the Mississippi Gulf Coast) to the Florida Panhandle, killing more than 1,836 and costing over 115 billion dollars in damage.
The 17th Street Canal in New Orleans is breached during Hurricane Katrina, leading to massive flooding and destruction.
A crowd crush on the Al-Aaimmah bridge in Baghdad Iraq kills several hundred civilians.
A stampede on Al-Aaimmah bridge in Baghdad kills 1,199 people.
Oil prices rise sharply following the economic effects of Hurricane Katrina.
Protesters and Israeli forces clash in Bil'in.
John G. Roberts is nominated by President George W. Bush for Chief Justice of the United States, to replace William Rehnquist, who had died two days previously.
Mandala Airlines Flight 091 737 crashes in Indonesia, killing at least 117.
The California Legislature becomes the first legislative body in the United States to legalize same-sex marriage without a pre-emptive judicial order to do so.
Incumbent Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak wins the first multi-party presidential election.
Apple Computer introduced the iPod nano, a revolutionary full-featured iPod that holds 1,000 songs yet is thinner than a standard #2 pencil and less than half the size of competitive players.
First presidential election was held in Egypt
Japan general election: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi and the Liberal Democratic Party are returned to power.
The State of Israel officially declares an end to military rule in the Gaza Strip after 38 years of occupation.
The Norwegian parliamentary election results in a victory for the red-green-coalition. The new prime-minister is Jens Stoltenberg from the Labour Party.
The English cricket team draws the final match to win The 2005 Ashes.
In Hong Kong, China, Hong Kong Disneyland park opens.
The red-green coalition, led by Jens Stoltenberg, wins the Norwegian parliamentary election, taking 87 of 169 seats in the parliament.
Israel completes its withdrawal of all troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip.
A blackout in Los Angeles affects millions of Californians.
(to September 16) The largest United Nations World Summit in history is held in New York City.
Helen Clark, leader of the Labour Party, is re-elected for a third term in the New Zealand general election.

The B.C. Lions make CFL history by winning 11 straight games, become the first team ever to do so in the CFL. This day was also the premiere for three new shows on Kids WB: Loonatics Unleashed, Coconut Fred's Fruit Salad Island, and Johnny Test.
Federal elections in Germany. Leading Chancellor candidates are Gerhard Schrder (Social Democratic Party, 34.3 percent) and Angela Merkel (Christian Democratic Union, 27.8 percent).
North Korea agrees to stop building nuclear weapons in exchange for aid and cooperation.
In the USA, the NFL sees the groundbreaking ceremony for two new stadiums, the Indianapolis Colts' Lucas Oil Stadium and the Dallas Cowboys' temporarily named Dallas Cowboys New Stadium.
Simon Wiesenthal, Nazi hunter, dies in Vienna, Austria, at age 96. He was responsible for tracking down over 1100 war criminals.
Convicted bank robber and Boricua Popular Army leader, Filiberto Ojeda R?os, is killed in his home in Hormigueros, Puerto Rico when members of the FBI attempt to serve an arrest warrant.
FBI killing of Filiberto Ojeda on Plan Bonito Hormigueros, Puerto Rico.
Polish parliamentary election: Two center-right parties win the required majority of seats.
Worldwide protests occur against the Iraq War, with over 150,000 protestors in Washington DC.

Hurricane Rita hits the U.S. Gulf Coast, devastating areas near Beaumont, Texas and Lake Charles, Louisiana. The New Orleans's 9th Ward re-floods since Katrina, and Mississippi and Alabama are also affected.

Australian Rules Football team the Sydney Swans win the 2005 Grand Final, to become the AFL Premiers, defeating the West Coast Eagles at the Melbourne Cricket Ground to end a 72 year Premiership drought.
Massive protest drawing 300,000 people to Washington DC in a march past the White house to end the war in Iraq
Hurricane Rita makes landfall in the United States, devastating Beaumont, Texas and portions of southwestern Louisiana.
The Hide (Matsumoto "Hide" Hideto) museum closed due to the lack of funds. (Japan).
U.S. Army Reservist Lynndie England is convicted by a military jury on six of seven counts in connection with the Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse scandal.
Micha?lle Jean, born in Haiti, becomes the 27th Governor General of Canada.
American politician Tom DeLay is indicted on charges of criminal conspiracy by a Texas grand jury.
John G. Roberts, Jr. is confirmed and sworn in as Chief Justice of the United States.
US Senate confirms John Roberts to be the next Chief Justice of the United States.

Michael Eisner resigns from The Walt Disney Company board of directors, also his last day as CEO of the company. The value of the company during Eisner's term (1984-2005) rose from US$3 billion to US$60 billion. New company CEO is Robert Iger.
Controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten.
The Parliament of Catalonia passes, with 120 plus votes and 15 against, the Project of New Catalan Statute of Autonomy, proclaiming in Article 1, "Catalonia is a nation".
The Parliament of Catalonia passes with 120 plus votes and 15 against, the Project of New Catalan Statute of Autonomy, proclaiming in its article 1, "Catalonia is a nation".
The controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten.
The world's largest bank, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, is formed by the merger of two Japanese banking conglomerates.
The 2005 Bali bombings kill 26 people and injure more than 100.
Almost exactly three years after a similar event, a bombing kills 23 people in Bali.
A shipwreck in Lake George, New York kills 20 people.
The Ethan Allen tour boat capsized on Lake George in Upstate New York, killing twenty people.
U.S. President George W. Bush nominates Harriet Miers for the Supreme Court of the United States.
St. Tammany Parish Schools reopen in Louisiana, just over a month after Hurricane Katrina closed them.
Hurricane Stan hits Mexico and Central America, killing over 1,620 people.
NHL started its season to end a year-and-a-half lockout.
United Nations nuclear agency director Mohamed ElBaradei is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

In Pakistan, a magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurs. At least 86,000 people killed, more than 69,000 injured and extensive damage in northern Pakistan. An estimated 4 million people in the area were left homeless.

Clemens August Graf von Galen (1878-1946) is beatified by Pope Benedict XVI. Von Galen was the Bishop of Mnnster during the dictatorship of Adolf Hitler. He openly opposed policies of the Germans as an affront to human dignity.
Polish presidential election: the first round results in a runoff between top candidates Donald Tusk and Lech Kaczynski.
China's State Bureau of Surveying and Mapping officially announced the new accurate height of Everest is 8848.43 m.
When Tropical Depression 23 strengthened into Hurricane Vince it made the 2005 Atlantic Hurricane Season the first season to use the V name.
Smoking is fully banned on the UK rail network.
Angela Merkel is announced to be the new chancellor of Germany.

In San Jose, California, Disney Chief Executive Officer Robert Iger announces the availability of Disney- and ABC-owned TV show episodes through Apple Computer's online iTunes store. Certain TV shows will be available for download for US$1.99 one day after initial airing on broadcast TV.
The second Chinese spacecraft, Shenzhou 6, is launched, carrying Fei Junlong and Nie Haisheng for five days in orbit.
The second Chinese human spaceflight Shenzhou 6 launched carrying Fèi Jùnl=ng and Niè H?ishèng for five days in orbit.
Veselin Topalov wins the FIDE World Chess Championship 2005.
A riot occurs in Toledo, Ohio during a Neo-Nazi rally on racial issues; 114 are arrested.
The referendum on the new Proposed Iraqi constitution is held.
Brett Hull retires from the NHL as third highest all-time goal scorer
Riot in Toledo, Ohio breaks out during a National Socialist/Neo-Nazi protest; over 100 are arrested
U.S. helicopters and warplanes bomb two villages near Ramadi in western Iraq, killing about 70 people.
Jens Stoltenberg becomes Prime Minister of Norway for the second time.
The United Nations tightens the rules for its staff, following several claims of financial impropriety and sexual abuse.
The second Airbus A380 takes to the skies.
The Houston Astros baseball team win their first National League Championship to advance to their first-ever World Series in franchise history.
The trial of Saddam Hussein begin.
Hurricane Wilma swells into a Category 5 storm.
The legendary Busch Memorial Stadium is closed and destroyed.
Hurricane Wilma becomes the most intense Atlantic hurricane on record with a minimum pressure of 882 mb.
Saddam Hussein goes on trial in Baghdad for crimes against humanity.
Hurricane Wilma enters the Mexican Caribbean, passing through Cozumel and then the Yucatn Peninsula, staying over Canc?n for over 60 hours.
Lyn Knight auction of Series 1890 $1000 US Treasury "Grand Watermelon" note sells for record US$1,092,500.
Tropical Storm Alpha forms, making the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season the most active on record.
Bellview Airlines Flight 210, a Boeing 737 airliner, crashes in Nigeria.
A referendum is held on the merger of Kamchatka Oblast and Koryak Autonomous Okrug.
Brazil holds a referendum about a ban on the sale of firearms and ammunition.
Polish presidential election, second round: Lech Kaczynski is elected.
Hurricane Wilma makes landfall in southwestern Florida as a category 3 hurricane.
Hurricane Wilma makes landfall in South Florida.
A violent attack by communist forces at a crowded train station in Yoskar, Kosamanu kills 15.

In the finale of the Japanese baseball series, the Chiba Lotte Marines win their first league championship in 31 years, defeating the Hanshin Tigers. Coach Bobby Valentine becomes the first foreign manager to win the Japan Series in the 70-year history of Japanese baseball.

The Chicago White Sox of the American League defeat the Houston Astros of the National League in four games to win the World Series Fall Classic. This gives the team its first World Championship since 1917.
The American death toll in the Iraq war reaches 2,000.
At the "World Without Zionism" conference in Tehran, Iran, Iranian president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad calls for Israel to be "wiped off the map", and condemns the peace process.
Two teenagers accidentally electrocute themselves in Seine-Saint-Denis, Paris, France, leading to widespread rioting.
Harriet Miers withdraws her name from consideration for the Supreme Court of the United States.
Iran launches its first satellite, sina 1, into space.
Riots begin in Paris after the deaths of two Muslim teenagers
Vice presidential adviser Lewis "Scooter" Libby resigns after being charged with obstruction of justice, perjury and making a false statement in the US Central Intelligence Agency leak investigation.
Plame affair: Lewis Libby, vice president Dick Cheney's chief of staff, is indicted in the Valerie Plame case. Libby resigns later that day.
At least 61 people are dead and many others wounded in three powerful blasts in the Indian capital, Delhi.
A train in Andhra Pradesh, India derails, killing at least 77 people.
Ghana International Airlines launched with inaugural flight from Accra to London.
29 October 2005 Delhi bombings kill more than 60.
Hurricane Beta hits the coast of Nicaragua. It is the 13th hurricane of 2005, breaking the 1969 record of 12 hurricanes.
The rebuilt Dresden Frauenkirche (destroyed in the firebombing of Dresden during World War II) was reconsecrated, after 13 years of rebuilding.
U.S. President George W. Bush nominates Federal Appeals Court Judge Samuel Alito to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
President George W. Bush nominates Appeals court judge Samuel Alito to join the Supreme Court of the United States.
United States Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid and his fellow Democrats force a closed session of the Senate over the Lewis Libby indictment.
The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall arrive in the United States for a state visit, their first overseas tour since their marriage.
Makybe Diva wins her third consecutive Melbourne Cup race.
The U.S. Senate enters a rare closed session to discuss the Plame affair and intelligence in the Iraq disarmament crisis.
First part of the Gomery Report, which discusses allegations of political money manipulation, is released in Canada.

The Spanish Congress of Deputies approves the admission to formality of the new Catalan Statute of Autonomy with the support of all the groups except the People's Party (PP), which the same day files an objection of unconstitutionality.
(to November 4) A severe aftershock measuring 6.3 on the Richter scale hits affected areas of Northern Pakistan.
The U.S. and Uruguay governments sign a Bilateral Investment Treaty.
Gorillaz play their first major concert in Manchester
Azerbaijan parliamentary election: Results are disputed between the New Azerbaijan Party and the Azadliq Party opposition.
A tornado hits western Kentucky and southwestern Indiana, killing at least 22.
Manchester United beats Chelsea F.C. at a football game at Old Trafford, Manchester to end the defending champion's 40-match unbeaten run in the FA Premier League.
The Evansville Tornado of November 2005 kills 22 in Indiana and Kentucky.
The military junta of Myanmar begins moving its government ministries from Yangon to Pyinmana.
French President Jacques Chirac declares a state of emergency on the 12th day of the French civil unrest.
Democratic U.S. Senator Jon Corzine is elected governor of New Jersey.
At least 50 people are killed and more than 120 injured in a series of coordinated suicide bombings in Amman, Jordan.
The Venus Express mission of the European Space Agency is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.
Muriel Degauque becomes the first Belgian female suicide bomber, wounding one in Iraq.
Suicide bombers attacked three hotels in Amman, Jordan, killing at least 56 people.
The Venus Express mission of the European Space Agency is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan makes his first visit to Iraq since the Iraq War began, and urges Iraqis to embrace a process aiming to reconcile all the country's ethnic and religious groups.
Andrew Stimpson, a 25-year old British man, is reported as the first person proven to have been 'cured' of HIV.
Chicago Bears cornerback Nathan Vasher returned a missed field goal 108 yards against the San Francisco 49ers. This was the longest play in NFL history.
In Australia, workers stage a massive protest against the Coalition government's planned Industrial Reform legislation.

The American baseball players' association and franchise owners agree to toughen the current penalties for the use of steroids, using a 50-game suspension for a first offense, 100 games for a second, and then lifetime ban for a third.
An earthquake hits near Sanriku in Japan, prompting a tsunami warning to be issued.
Italy's choice of national anthem, Il Canto degli Italiani, becomes officialised in law for the first time, almost 60 years after it was provisionally chosen following the birth of the republic.
Robert Blake was found liable for the wrongful death of his wife in a civil trial. The jury has ordered him to pay $30 million.
Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa takes office as President of Sri Lanka after the presidential election.
The Washington Post rebukes journalist Bob Woodward over his conduct in the US Central Intelligence Agency leak probe.
SBC Communications Inc. changes its company name to AT&T Incorporated.

The Prime Minister of Israel, Ariel Sharon, announces his resignation from Likud and his intention to form a new party devoted to peace in the region, Kadima, and asks the President of Israel to call a general election.

Microsoft launches the Xbox 360 video game system in North America. The system features IBM PowerPC with three cores, 3.2 GHz each with simultaneous multi-threading, 500 MHz ATI graphics with 10 MB cache, and 512 MB RAM. The Xbox 360 Core System costs US$299.99. The full Xbox 360 costs US$399.99, and includes 20 GB hard drive.
The Xbox 360 is released in North America.
Angela Merkel became the first female Chancellor of Germany
Ted Koppel retires after hosting Nightline for over 26 years.
The Licensing Act 2003 comes into force in England and Wales, introducing flexibility in the hours during which alcoholic beverages may be sold.

Conservative leader Stephen Harper, the leader of the Official Opposition in the Canadian Parliament, introduced a motion of no confidence, which NDP leader Jack Layton seconded. The motion was passed on November 28 which led to the dissolution to the 38th Canadian Parliament.
The Licensing Act 2003 comes into force in England and Wales, introducing flexibility in the hours during which alcoholic beverages may be sold.
Japanese J-rock/J-pop band, Do As Infinity, holds final live concert in Budokan.
B.J. Ryan agrees to a $47 million, five-year deal with the Toronto Blue Jays.
The Safeway (United Kingdom) brand in the United Kingdom retail disappears after 43 years of operation due to its takeover by Wm Morrison Supermarkets.
In Canada, for the second time in three years, the Edmonton Eskimos defeat the Montreal Alouettes 38-35 in an overtime thriller to win the 93rd Grey Cup at B.C. Place Stadium in Vancouver.
Manuel Zelaya is elected the new President of Honduras.
The first partial human face transplant is completed in Amiens, France.

The Liberal Party minority government in Canada is toppled by a non-confidence vote in the House of Commons, tabled by the Conservatives and backed by the Bloc QuTbTcois and the New Democratic Party, paving the way for a federal election on January 23, 2006.
Pitcher Billy Wagner agrees to a US$43 million, four-year contract with the New York Mets.
(to December 9) The United Nations Climate Change Conference is held in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.

The Official Opposition (Conservative Party of Canada , New Democratic Party, and Bloc QuTbTcois) bring down the 38th Minority Liberal Government of Canada in a vote of non-confidence forcing immediate campaigning for the 39th Federal Election.
E. Cardon Walker dies at age 89; president of Walt Disney Productions (1971-80), CEO (1976-83), and chairman (1980-83).
New Croatian Communist Party (KPH) is founded in Vukovar.
Surgeons in France carry out the first partial human face transplant.
Rt Rev John Sentamu becomes the first black archbishop in the Church of England as Archbishop of York.
South Africa becomes the fifth country in the world where same-sex marriages are recognized.
South Africa's Constitutional Court extends marriage equality to homosexual couples.
In Wentworth, North Carolina, Kenneth Boyd becomes the 1,000th person to be executed in the United States since the re-introduction of capital punishment in 1976.
The ?140 million (US$240 million) extension of the Docklands Light Railway in London opens, linking Canning Town to North Woolwich and London City Airport.
Kenneth Boyd becomes the 1,000th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976.
Microsoft's Xbox 360 is launched in Europe.
Van Tuong Nguyen is executed in Singapore for drug trafficking.
XCOR Aerospace makes first manned rocket aircraft delivery of US Mail in Mojave, California.
International Day of Action On Climate Change, to mark the first meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol. Includes images of demonstrations around the world.
A protest for democracy in Hong Kong draws 250,000 people.
Tens of thousands of people in Hong Kong protested for democracy and called on the Government to allow universal and equal suffrage.
