The Los Angeles Dodgers and Rafael Furcal agree to a US$39 million, three-year contract to play shortstop.
The Lake Tanganyika earthquake causes significant damage, mostly in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
The Civil Partnership Act comes into effect in the United Kingdom, and the first civil partnership is registered there.
The 2005 Southeast Asian Games end in Manila.
An Iranian C-130 Hercules airplane crashes into a ten-story building in a civilian area of Tehran, the capital of Iran, killing all 94 people aboard and 34 residents of the building.
The Toronto Blue Jays agree to a five-year, US$55 million deal with A.J. Burnett.
Several villagers shot dead during protests in Dongzhou, China.

The Internet's European Union top-level domain .eu is launched, and replaces .eu.int. Initially this will be only for business purposes. From 7 April 2006 onwards, EU citizens can also register .eu domains.
A U.S. Federal Air Marshal fatally shoots Rigoberto Alpizar on a jetway at Miami International Airport in Florida.
Rigoberto Alpizar, a passenger on American Airlines Flight 924 who allegedly claimed to have a bomb, is shot and killed by a team of U.S. federal air marshals at Miami International Airport.

At Japanese trading company Mizuho Securities, a new employee mistakenly sells 610,000 shares for 1 yan each, instead of 1 share for 610,000 yen. It costs the company about 40 billion yen (US$340 million).
Hurricane Epsilon dies in the eastern Atlantic Ocean. It becomes the longest-lived December hurricane on record and ties for second-place strongest December hurricane.
Southwest Airlines Flight 1248 overshoots the runway at Chicago Midway Airport, killing a 6-year-old boy and injuring 11 other people.
Ante Gotovina, Croatian army general accused of war crimes, was captured in the Playa de las Americas, Santa Cruz de Tenerife by the Spanish police
Southwest Airlines Flight 1248 slides off the runway at Chicago Midway Airport, killing a 6-year-old boy and injuring 11 other people.
Sosoliso Airlines Flight 1145 crashes in Nigeria.
The 2005 Hertfordshire Oil Storage Terminal fire north of London causes widespread damage, and is the largest explosion ever to occur in peacetime Europe.
The Cronulla riots occur in Sydney, Australia, involving up to 5,000 youths.

Sydney race riots: Thousands of Australians demonstate against ethnic violence resulting in a riot against anyone thought to be Lebanese (and many who were not) in Cronulla Sydney. These are followed up by ethnic attacks on Cronulla.
The Buncefield Oil Depot in Hemel Hempstead is rocked by explosions, causing a huge oil fire.
Gebran Ghassan Tueni is assassinated by a car bomb.
Scientists announce that they have created mice with small amounts of human brain cells in an effort to make realistic models of neurological disorders.
A 6.7 magnitude earthquake rocks South Asia.
Shakidor Dam fails in Pakistan due to heavy rain.
The Roads and Traffic Authority of New South Wales, Australia starts to issue NSW Photo Card.
The first parliamentary elections take place under Iraq's new federal constitution.
The 43rd Mersenne prime is found, 230,402,457 - 1. It was discovered with the GIMPS project by Dr. Curtis Cooper and Dr. Steven Boone, professors at Central Missouri State University.
Appalachian State University wins NCAA Division I-AA National Football Championship over University of Northern Iowa.
The last scheduled edition of US radio program The Howard Stern Show is broadcast on terrestrial radio.
The World Trade Organization's 6th ministerial conference concludes in Hong Kong with a limited trade deal being ratified.
Evo Morales wins the Bolivian Presidential Elections.

The bat Pete Rose used to hit his 159th career home run in 1985 is acquired by GoldenPalace.com for $103,631.91 during Lelands Winter 2005 Auction. The on-line casino plans to saw the bat in half to determine if the bat is corked as is widely believed.
Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is hospitalized after suffering a minor stroke.
New York City's Transport Workers Union Local 100 goes on strike for three days, shutting down all New York City Subway and Bus services.
2005 New York City transit strike: New York City's Transport Workers Union Local 100 goes on strike, shutting down all New York City Subway and Bus services.
An industrial action by bus drivers in Tehran, Iran, leads to the arrest of Mansour Osanlou and several other union activists.
Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 217 from Baku, Azerbaijan to Aktau, Kazakhstan crashes shortly after takeoff, killing 23 people.
Lech Kaczynski is sworn in as the President of Poland in Warsaw.
Chad declares a state of war against Sudan following a December 18 attack on Adre, which left about 100 people dead.
Johnny Damon signs a US$52 million, four-year deal to play for the New York Yankees.
U.S. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld announces the first in an expected series of troop drawdowns following the Iraqi elections.
Chad declares a state of war against Sudan following a December 18th attack on Adre, which left about 100 people dead.
Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 217 from Baku, Azerbaijan to Aktau, Kazakhstan crashed shortly after takeoff killing 23 people.
Pope Benedict XVI leads his first Christmas Midnight Mass as Pope, praying for peace in the Middle East.
The Chicago White Sox and Jon Garland sign a three-year, US$29 million contract.
A U.S. immigration judge orders John Demjanjuk deported to the Ukraine for crimes against humanity committed during World War II.
Agreeing to a US$60 million, five-year contract, Kevin Millwood joins the Texas Rangers American baseball team.
Tropical Storm Zeta forms in the open Atlantic, tying the record for the latest tropical cyclone ever to form in the North Atlantic basin.
Another second is added, 23:59:60, called a leap second, to end the year 2005. The last time this occurred was on June 30, 1998.
AT&T and SBC Communications merge, SBC name is dropped. A new AT&T is formed.
Russia cuts natural gas to Ukraine over a price dispute.
Sydney, Australia, has its hottest day on record, when the city swelters in 45 degree C heat.
Fifteen die in the Bad Reichenhall ice rink roof collapse in Bavaria, Germany.
An explosion in a coal mine leads to the death of 12 of 13 miners in the 2006 Sago Mine disaster in West Virginia.
The Bad Reichenhall ice rink roof in Germany collapses after heavy snowfall in the Bavarian Alps, killing 15.
Intel announces it is dropping the 25-year old "Intel Inside" campaign and the 37-year old Intel logo with dropped "e". The new logo is lowercase "intel" in an oval, with tag line "Leap ahead".
David Hill retires as chief engineer of the Corvette automobile, replaced by Tom Wallace.
Twelve dead coal miners and one survivor are discovered in the Sago Mine Disaster near Buckhannon, West Virginia, USA.

Serious media mixup when media organisations mistakenly reported that 12 miners were found alive in the Sago Mine Disaster. Several USA newspapers had frontpage headlines such as "ALIVE!", when in fact 12 miners had perished.
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel suffers a second, apparently more serious stroke. His authority is transferred to Acting Prime Minister Ehud Olmert.
Powers are transferred from Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to his deputy, Vice Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, after Sharon suffers a massive hemorrhagic stroke.
A hotel in Mecca, Saudi Arabia collapses, killing 76 pilgrims visiting to perform hajj.
The Toronto Blue Jays trade Corey Koskie to the Milwaukee Brewers for minor league pitching prospect Brian Wolfe.

18-year-old shortstop Justin Upton signs a five-year contract with the Arizona Diamondbacks for US$6.1 million, the largest signing bonus in a minor-league contract for a drafted player who was not a free agent.
The record-breaking 2005 Atlantic hurricane season officially draws to a close as Tropical Storm Zeta dissipates.
Tropical Storm Zeta (2005) finally dissipates after breaking many records.
At the sixth Negro Leagues Baseball Museum Legacy ceremonies in Kansas City, Bob Watson, the first black general manager in baseball history, receives the Jackie Robinson Lifetime Achievement Award.
United Kingdom Liberal Democratic leader Charles Kennedy resigns after revelations that he has a drinking problem.
Embroiled in multiple scandals, former U.S. House Majority Leader Tom DeLay announces he will not seek to reassume his former post.
Singaporean composer Bernard Tan's Violin Concerto received its world premiere performance by the Singapore Symphony Orchestra and violinist Lynnette Seah, conducted by Lan Shui.
A powerful, magnitude 6.9 earthquake centered off the coast of the Greek island of Kythera shakes much of Greece and is felt throughout the eastern Mediterranean basin.
A magnitude 6.9 earthquake epicentered just off the Greek island of Kythira hits much of the country and is felt throughout the entire eastern Mediterranean Sea.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 11,000 for the first time since June 7, 2001, closing at 11,011.90.
The Phantom of the Opera surpassed the record set by Cats for the title of longest running show on Broadway.
The first broadcast of The Howard Stern Show via Sirius Satellite Radio.
Apple Computer releases its first Macintosh (iMac) computer with an Intel processor.
Bruce Sutter becomes just the fourth relief pitcher to get into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
The Tampa Bay Devil Rays make their first agreement with a Japanese player as relief pitcher Shinji Mori signs a US$1.4 million, two-year contract.
The Augustine Volcano in Alaska erupts twice, marking its first major eruption since 1986.
A stampede during the Stoning of the devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills 362 pilgrims.
A stampede during the Stoning the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 Muslim pilgrims. (BBC)
The French warship Clemenceau reaches Egypt and is barred access to the Suez Canal. Greenpeace activists board the ship. (BBC)
Turkey releases Mehmet Ali A?ca from jail after serving 25 years for shooting Pope John Paul II. (BBC)

The foreign ministers of the United Kingdom, France, and Germany declare that negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program have reached a dead end and recommend that Iran be referred to the United Nations Security Council. (ABC)
Johnny Estrada agrees to a US$2 million, one-year contract to catch for the Arizona Diamondbacks.
A natural gas explosion in a coal mine kills eight in Romania.
NASA's Stardust mission successfully ends, the first to return dust from a comet.
Liu Xinjuan is committed by the Chinese government to a psychiatric hospital, allegedly for political activism.
Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf is sworn in as Liberia's new president. She becomes Africa's first female elected head of state.
Alex Rodriguez announces he will be a member of the United States team in the World Baseball Classic.

In Scottsdale, Arizona, the 30th Annual Barrett-Jackson Collector Car Auction is held, over six days. The #003 1953 Corvette sells for US$1 million; this is the first existing production Corvette. A 1967 convertible, with 427 ci 435 hp engine sells for US$350,000.
Clarence Ray Allen becomes the oldest condemned inmate executed in California and the 2nd oldest in the United States.

After an 80-day departure, Theo Epstein returns to the Red Sox in a yet-to-be named capacity. The youngest general manager in baseball history, who assembled a World Champion team in 2004, left Boston on Halloween Day citing the position was not 'the right fit'.
Jet Airways announces its purchase of Air Sahara, creating the largest domestic airliner in India.
Opening of the Canadian Undergraduate Software Engineering Conference 2006 in Montreal, Quebec.
The New Horizons probe was launched by NASA on the first mission to Pluto.
Baseball's second application to the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control to allow Cuba to play in the World Baseball Classic is approved.

In Quang Tri province, Viet Nam, just south of the demilitarized zone, the country's first baseball field is dedicated. The former soccer field was transformed into a diamond for the Le Loi High School using money donated from Major League Baseball and the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund.
Kobe Bryant scores 81 points in regulation NBA basketball play and is second only to the legendary 1960s center Wilt Chamberlain, who had 100 points.
Anfbal Cavaco Silva is elected president of Portugal.
NBA superstar Kobe Bryant scored 81 points against Toronto Raptors, the second highest total in NBA history.
Evo Morales is inaugurated as President of Bolivia, becoming the country's first indigenous American president.
Stephen Harper wins the federal election in Canada, forming a minority government.
Stephen Harper's Conservative Party wins the most seats in the Canadian federal election. Harper becomes the 22nd Prime Minister of Canada with a minority government.
Outfielder Jay Gibbons and the Baltimore Orioles agree to a US$21.1 million, four-year deal.
Mario Lemieux announces his retirement from the National Hockey League.
UPN and The WB announced that they will cease operations in September to form The CW Television Network.
Disney agrees to purchase Pixar in an all-cash deal, making Steve Jobs the largest shareholder in Disney.
Three independent observing campaigns announce the discovery of the first cool rocky/icy extrasolar planet around a main-sequence star (OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb, near the center of the Milky Way galaxy).
Deus Caritas Est, the first encyclical of Pope Benedict XVI, is promulgated.
Hamas wins the majority of seats in the Palestinian Legislative Council elections.
Three independent observing campaigns announce the discovery of OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb through gravitational microlensing, the first cool rocky/icy extrasolar planet around a main-sequence star.
The Council of Europe passes a draft resolution that emphatically condemns the atrocities and human rights violations of totalitarian communist regimes.
Western Union discontinues use of its telegram service.
A large fire breaks out on Table Mountain in Cape Town, South Africa.
The Kansas City Royals unveil new uniforms with a more traditional look, with script lettering on the front and its crown logo on the sleeves.
The Chicago Cubs and Mark Prior agree on a one-year $3.65 million contract.
Nobuhiko Matsunaka agrees to seven-year contract with Japan's Softbank Hawks for an estimated 500 million yen a year plus performance incentives.
A trade hall roof collapses in Katowice, Poland, killing 65 people.
ABC News co-anchor Bob Woodruff and his cameraman Doug Vogt were severly injured in Iraq following a car blast.
Sheikh Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah is sworn in as the Emir of Kuwait.
The Chicago Cubs and Jerry Hairston Jr. agree to a one-year, $2.3 million deal.
Samuel Alito is sworn in as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
Incapacitated Prime Minister of Israel Ariel Sharon officially exited politics after three decades when his Kadima party submitted its list of candidates for the upcoming election.
UAL Corporation, United Airlines' parent company, emerges from bankruptcy after being in that position since December 9, 2002, the longest such filing in history.
At a luncheon at Safeco Field, baseball player Craig Biggio becomes the 41st recipient of the Hutch Award.

In Calgary, Alberta, Canada, an exceptionally bright meteor is seen streaking across the sky, lasting for several seconds before breaking up into fragments. It is estimated that remnants of the meteorite land about 400 km south of Calgary, in Montana, USA.
A meteor falls in a field in Singpara village, Bangladesh; a hot, lead-like black material three feet below the earth is dug up, weighing 2.5kg.
An aging Egyptian passenger ferry carrying more than 1,400 people sinks in the Red Sea off the Saudi coast.
A stampede occurs in the ULTRA Stadium near Manila killing at least 74.
Anders Fogh Rasmussen cartoons published in response to the affair of the Muhammad drawings.
The Pittsburgh Steelers win Super Bowl XL, defeating the Seattle Seahawks 21-10.
The Conservative Party of Canada becomes a minority government in Canada's Parliament, replacing the Liberals after 13 years in power.
An aging Egyptian passenger ferry carrying more than 1,400 people sinks in the Red Sea off the Saudi coast.
Venezuela's Caracas Lions wins its first Caribbean Series championship since 1989, defeating the Dominican Republic's Licey Tigers.
Wayne Krivsky is selected as the Cincinnati Reds' general manager, replacing Dan O'Brien.
Palestinians attack Temporary International Presence in Hebron offices in Hebron; International observers end decade-long presence
Bengie Molina signs a US$5 million, one-year contract with the Toronto Blue Jays, with a $7.5 million option for 2007.
(to February 26) The XX Olympic Winter Games take place in Turin, Italy.
Alfonso Soriano sets a record for the highest salary ever awarded in baseball arbitration: he will receive US$10 million to play outfield for the Washington Nationals.
The 20th Olympic Winter Games begin in Turin, Italy with the Opening Ceremony.
U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney accidentally shoots his friend and lawyer, Harry Whittington, in the face with a shotgun on a south Texas ranch.
Pitcher Carlos Zambrano and the Chicago Cubs agree to a one-year deal worth US$6.5 million.
Michelle Bachelet inaugurated as first woman president of Chile.

Vice President Dick Cheney accidentally shoots friend Harry Whittington in the face during a hunting trip in Kenedy County, Texas, becoming the first Vice President to shoot a man since Aaron Burr assassinated Alexander Hamilton

A powerful Nor'easter Winter Storm blankets the Northeast United States dumping 1 to 2 feet of snow from Washington DC up to Boston, Massachusetts. The storm dumped a record 26.9 inches of snow in New York City.
Adam Dunn and the Cincinnati Reds agreed to a US$18.5 million two-year deal.
Jeff Weaver agrees to a one-year contract with the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim worth $8,325,000.
Kobe Airport, a controversial offshore airport in Kobe, Japan, opens for airline service.
A ball of fire is reported falling in the area of Stirling Castle in Scotland.
As many as 1,800 people die when a mudslide occurs on Leyte Island in the Philippines.
Sixty-five miners become trapped underground after an explosion in Nueva Rosita, Mexico; all 65 die.
The Rolling Stones made the largest show open to the public of the world in Copacabana beach, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. 1.3 million people went to the show.
A second ball of fire is reported falling in the area of Stirling Castle in Scotland.
New York City mayor Michael Bloomberg unveils a brand new sign on the corner of West 66th Street called Peter Jennings Way in honor of the late ABC News anchor Peter Jennings.
Over 53.1 million British pounds is stolen during the Securitas depot robbery, the largest ever cash robbery in the United Kingdom.
A bomb heavily damages the Al Askari Mosque, a Shiite holy site in Samarra, Iraq.
The one billionth song is purchased from the Apple iTunes Store.
The 1 Billionth song was downloaded on ITunes.
At least six men stage Britain's biggest ever robbery, stealing £53m (about $92.5 million or ?78 million) from a Securitas depot in Tonbridge, Kent.
A roof collapses on a Moscow market, killing 56 people.
A state of emergency is declared in the Philippines, after an alleged coup d'Ttat against President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo is foiled.
Philippine President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo declares Proclamation 1017 placing the country in a state of emergency in attempt to subdue a possible military coup.
Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni wins his second re-election, sparking riots in Kampala by opposition supporters.
Police officers and protesters are injured when a protest prior to the Love Ulster parade turns into a major riot.

Imette St. Guillen's body is found on Brooklyn's Belt Parkway, New York. She was raped, tortured, and murdered. Darryl Littlejohn, a nightclub bouncer at "The Falls", where St. Guillen was last seen alive, is indicted.
The world's estimated population reaches 6.5 billion.
The world's estimated population reaches 6.5 billion.
Sweden beats Finland in the hockey final of the Turin Olympic games.
The first confirmed case of H5N1 bird flu virus in Switzerland, a dead swan on Lake Geneva, near the city of Geneva.
Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the new debating chamber for the National Assembly for Wales in Cardiff, a milestone in devolution.
Tarja Halonen is inaugurated as president of Finland for the second and last time.
English-language Wikipedia reaches its one millionth article.
The newest version of the United States ten-dollar bill enters circulation.
Sir Menzies Campbell is elected the new leader of the UK Liberal Democrat Party.
In the opening game of the inaugural World Baseball Classic at the Tokyo Dome, South Korea blanks Taiwan, 2-0.
The final contact attempt with Pioneer 10 receives no response.
Prince Sverre Magnus of Norway is christened by Bishop Ole Christian Kvarme at the chapel inside The Royal Palace in Oslo.
A new species of shark was discovered in Mexico's Sea of Cortez, bringing the types of Mustelus shark found in the eastern North Pacific to five. [6]
The Deep Space Network tries one final contact attempt to Pioneer 10. [7]
Anti-war campaigners criticized British Prime Minister Tony Blair after he suggested his decision to go to war in Iraq would ultimately be judged by God. [5]
The 28th Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras is held in Sydney, Australia.
The central Papeete power station is damaged by a fire, resulting in limited power for some areas of Tahiti for a couple of weeks. [4]
South Dakota Governor Mike Rounds signs a bill into legislation that would ban most abortions in the state.
Apple Inc. is granted the patent to the iPod.
In their World Baseball Classic debut, Team USA blank Mexico, 2-0.
Fifteen people die and many others are injured in three blasts throughout Varanasi, India.
BBC News premieres its podcast NewsPod, the first internet-only BBC podcast.
In the first round of the World Baseball Classic, a Canadian team beats the highly-favored Team USA, 8-6.
NASA's Cassini-Huygens spacecraft discovers geysers of a liquid substance shooting from Saturn's moon Enceladus, signaling a possible presence of water.
Liquid Water discovered on Enceladus, the sixth largest moon of Saturn.
In the World Baseball Classic, Netherlands rout Panama, 10-0. The game is called after seven innings because of the mercy rule: a 10-run lead after seven innings.
NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter enters Mars orbit.
Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter arrives at Mars.
Mass unrest by the PCC started in São Paulo, the biggest city in Brazil. Which would eventualy kill more than 152 people

Slobodan Milo_evic is found dead at age 64 from an apparent heart attack in his prison cell in the United Nations war crimes tribunal's detention centre, located in the Scheveningen section of The Hague.
Michelle Bachelet is sworn in as the first female President of Chile.
Historic cricket match between Australia in South Africa, 5th ODI of the series.
Australia scores a world record 434 runs in a One-day International cricket match against South Africa. South Africa replies by beating the record again to score 438/9 to win.
Washington D.C. officials unveil the designs for a new 41,000-seat ballpark.
(to March 26) The 2006 Commonwealth Games take place in Melbourne, Australia.
Roy Halladay agrees to a $40 million, three-year contract extension with the Toronto Blue Jays.
In the second round of the World Baseball Classic, Mexico defeats Team USA 2-1, eliminating the US from the tournament.
The United Nations General Assembly votes overwhelmingly to establish the UN Human Rights Council.
The United States strikes its two remaining Iowa-class battleships from the Naval Vessel Register, ending the age of the battleship.
Second World Congress of Imams and Rabbis for Peace convened in Seville, Spain
In San Diego, California, Japan captures the first World Baseball Classic crown beating Cuba, 10-6.
Tropical Cyclone Larry makes landfall in Queensland, Australia.
Cyclone Larry makes landfall in eastern Australia.
Over 150 Chadian soldiers are killed in eastern Chad by members of the rebel UFDC. The growing rebel movement seeks to overthrow Chadian president Idriss Deby.
Swedish Minister for Foreign Affairs Laila Freivalds resigns after over a year of criticism.
ETA declares a permanent ceasefire in their campaign for Basque independence from Spain.
Three Christian Peacemaker Teams Hostages are freed by British forces in Baghdad after 118 days captivity and the death of their colleague, American Tom Fox.
Queen of the North runs aground on Gil Island and sinks; 101 on board, 2 presumed deaths.
ETA, armed Basque separatist group, declares permanent ceasefire.
Federal Reserve discontinues publishing M3 money supply see Petroeuro.
Long-term protests in Belarus are broken by police. More than 400 detained.
Pope Benedict XVI adds 15 men to the College of Cardinals, in the first consistory of his Pontificate.
Seven people die in the Capitol Hill Massacre in Seattle, Washington.
A revolutionary scramjet jet engine, Hyshot III, designed to fly at seven times the speed of sound, is successfully tested at Woomera, South Australia.
An estimated 500,000 people take to the streets in downtown Los Angeles to protest a proposed federal crackdown on illegal immigration.
Reading F.C. were promoted to the English Premiership for the first time in their 135 year history.
Over 500,000 people in Los Angeles were protesting against illegal immigration.

Protesters demanding a re-election in Belarus following the rigged Belarusian presidential election, 2006 clash with riot police. Opposition leader Aleksander Kozulin was among several protesters arrested.
The Capitol Hill massacre, where gunman kills six people before taking his own life at a party in Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood, one of the largest crime scenes the city has ever had.
The ban on smoking in public places such as bars and restaurants comes into effect in Scotland.
In Scotland the prohibition of smoking in all public places came into force.
The UN Commission on Human Rights holds its final meeting.
At least 1 million union members, students and unemployed take to the streets in France in protest at the government's proposed First Employment Contract law.
total solar eclipse observed from 08:36 GMT (09:36 BST) to 11:48 GMT (12:48 BST) in Eastern Brazil, West and North Africa, Turkey, Central Asia and Mongolia
Major League Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig appoints George Mitchell to head an investigation into the use of steroids in baseball.
The first Brazilian astronaut, Marcos Pontes, goes to space in a Russian Soyuz spacecraft, Soyuz TMA-8, at 2:29:00 CET.
Marcos Pontes is the first Brazilian astronaut in space.
The Chicago White Sox signs Jose Contreras to a $29 million, three-year contract extension.
The Serious Organised Crime Agency, dubbed the 'British FBI', is created in the United Kingdom.
Over 50 tornadoes breakout, hardest hit is Tennessee with 28 people killed.
A swan with Avian Flu is discovered in Cellardyke in Fife, Scotland (the first case in the United Kingdom).
The first case of H5N1 avian flu was confirmed in the UK after tests on a dead swan found in Cellardyke, Fife.
Numbersixvalverde, ridden by Niall Madden, wins the Grand National at Aintree.
The bodies of eight murdered men are found in Shedden, Elgin County, Ontario, Canada.
Bristol, United Kingdom celebrates the 200th birthday of Isambard Kingdom Brunel (actually April 9) by relighting the Clifton Suspension Bridge.
Bloc 8406 publishes their Manifesto on Freedom and Democracy for Viet Nam in Viet Nam; their name comes from this date.
Shedden massacre: A farmer near Shedden, Ontario, Canada finds the bodies of eight men, all shot to death, in a field. The murders are soon linked to the Bandidos motorcycle gang.
Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is removed from office after four months in a coma.
Disney says it will begin allowing the download of television shows from Web site abc.com, for a two month trial period.
Romano Prodi narrowly defeats Silvio Berlusconi in the Italian parliamentary elections.
Hundreds of thousands protest H.R. 4437 in cities across the United States.
US Vice President Dick Cheney throws out the ceremonial first pitch at the home opener at RFK Stadium.
President of Iran Mahmoud Ahmadinejad confirms that Iran has successfully produced a few grams of low-grade enriched uranium.
Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad announces that Iran has successfully enriched uranium.
Tiara Air , a new airline has begin flights to Curacao and Bonaire.
New York City officially opens the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal. Cost of construction was US$56 million.
Prince Albert II of Monaco reaches the North Pole, becoming the first reigning monarch ever to do so.
A suicide bombing by Islamic Jihad in Tel Aviv, Israel, kills nine people and injures dozens.
Han Myeong Sook becomes the first female Prime Minister of South Korea.

Iran announces a uranium enrichment deal with Russia, involving a joint uranium enrichment firm on Russian soil; nine days later Iran announces that it will not move all activity to Russia, thus leading to a de-facto termination of the deal.
Jalal Talabani re-elected for a second term as President of Iraq.
Four Canadian soldiers are killed 75 kilometres north of Kandahar, Afghanistan by a roadside bomb - the worst one-day combat loss for the Canadian army since the Korean War.
243 people were injured in pro-democracy protest in Nepal after Nepali security forces opened fire on protesters against King Gyanendra.
Three explosions in a tourist section of Dahab, Egypt kill 30 and injure over 115.
In Panama, a referendum on the Third Set of Locks Project is approved by 76.8 percent.
King of Nepal, King Gyanendra gives into the demands of the protesters and restores the parliament that he dissolved in 2002.
The Beaconsfield mine diaster occurs in Tasmania, Australia.
Construction on the Freedom Tower for the new World Trade Center in New York City officially begins.
Trevor Hoffman appears as a pitcher in his 803rd game for the San Diego Padres establiishing a new record for games pitched for any one team.
The Global Night Commute takes place in over 130 cities around the world to promote the visibility of the Invisible Children in Uganda.
Massive anti-war demonstrations and a march down Broadway in New York City mark the third year of war in Iraq.

In the Australian Football League, a match between Saint Kilda and Fremantle ends in controversial circumstances after Saint Kilda's Steven Baker is alleged to have kicked a behind after the final siren had went. Following an investigation, the Saints are stripped of two competition points and the full win is handed to Fremantle.

The mining incident in Beaconsfield, Tasmania, comes to a close. 14 days after being trapped 1km below the surface by a rock fall caused by an earthquake, miners Todd Russell and Brant Webb are brought to safety.
The Great American Boycott takes place across the United States as marchers protest for immigration rights.
Bolivian president Evo Morales orders military to occupy oil and gas fields in country, placing them under state control.
The Puerto Rican government ran out of money and had to force the closure of schools and all other government agencies.

Immigrants and their supporters across the United States carry out the Great American Boycott, a one day national protest against the enforcement of pending immigration laws criminalizing illegal immigrants and those who aid them, and calling for amnesty to be given to those in the U.S..
Zacarias Moussaoui is sentenced to life in prison in Alexandria, Virginia.
Armavia Flight 967 crashes into the Black Sea, killing 113 people on board, with no survivors.
A new coalition government takes office in Israel; its four political parties hold 67 of the 120 seats in the Knesset.
A large meteor shower crosses over El Paso, Texas, USA.
Local elections take place in England.
Zacarias Moussaoui is sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole for involvement in the September 11, 2001 attacks. He is spared the death penalty.
A Jewish synagogue in Petah Tikva is desecrated, The desecraters sprayed swastikas, devil related signs and the name "Rammstein" of the tanz metal German band.
One of the worst thunderstorms in decades hits Glasgow, Scotland and the surrounding area.
NASA astronomers announce the discovery of a storm system in the Jovian atmosphere, dubbed the Red Spot Junior.
Fiat chairman Sergio Marchionne announces that the Alfa Romeo automobile brand will return to the United States in 2008, after a 13-year hiatus.
The government of Sudan signed an accord with the Sudan Liberation Army (SLA).
Porter Goss announces his resignation as CIA director.
With a 8-5 victory over the Texas Rangers, Joe Torre wins his 1000th game, the fourth New York Yankees manager to do so.
Rolling Stone Magazine publishes its 1000th cover issue.
Sony, Humiliated in press conference at E3 2006
Delmon Young of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays is suspended for 50 games by the International League for throwing a bat which hit a replacement umpire in the chest.
After 14 days trapped underground, miners Todd Russell and Brant Webb are rescued in Beaconsfield, Tasmania, Australia.
2 miners, Todd Russell and Brant Webb were freed after 14 days trapped underground in a goldmine at Beaconsfield, Tasmania, Australia.

Hideki Matsui's streak of playing in every game since starting his Major League Baseball career with the New York Yankees ends at 518 games. Previous record holder was Ernie Banks, who played in 424 consecutive games with the Chicago Cubs.
A science team at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign successfully convert pig waste into crude oil (see: porcine petroleum).
Justin Gatlin ties the fastest 100m sprint ever in a time of 9.77 seconds in Doha, Qatar.
Liverpool F.C. defeat West Ham United F.C. on penalties in the 2006 FA Cup Final following a 3-3 draw after extra time.
Massachusetts and New Hampshire (U.S.) declared a state of emergency on May 14, 2006 as a result of massive flooding from the strongest rains to hit the region in a decade
The last episode of Malcolm In The Middle is aired on Fox.

Houston Astros pitcher Russ Springer strikes the San Francisco Giants player Barry Bonds on the shoulder with his fifth pitch. He is suspended for four games for his action. Bonds needs just one home run to equal Babe Ruth's career home run mark.
For the fourth time New York Yankees history, the team overcomes a nine-run deficit defeating the Texas Rangers at the Stadium, 14-13.
A large magnitude 7.4 earthquake occurs near New Zealand.
FC Barcelona beats Arsenal in the final of the UEFA Champions League played in Paris.
FC Barcelona defeats Arsenal F.C at the Stade de France and wins the Champions League for the second time since the foundation of the club.
The aircraft carrier USS Oriskany sunk in the Gulf of Mexico to be an artificial reef
The post Loktantra Andolan government passes a landmark bill curtailing the power of the monarchy and making Nepal a secular country.
Finland's Lordi wins the 2006 Eurovision Song Contest held in Athens, Greece.
Barry Bonds catches Babe Ruth with his 714th home run.
In Athens,Greece, Lordi wins the 51st Eurovision Song Contest representing Finland with the song "Hard Rock Hallelujah".
Barbaro breaks leg in 2nd leg of Triple Crown.
Munster Rugby Munster beat Biarritz Olympique in the Heineken Cup final 23-19.
The Dallas Mavericks beat the San Antonio Spurs in overtime to win the Western Conference semi-finals in the NBA Playoffs.
The Swedish ice hockey team Tre Kronor takes gold in the World Championship and becomes the first nation to take gold in both the World Championship and Olympic games in ice hockey.
The Republic of Montenegro holds a referendum proposing independence from the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro.
Results from the Montenegrin independence referendum, 2006 are announced. 55.4% of voters voted to become independent from the Serbia and Montenegro Union.
World Wrestling Entertainment's Wreckless Intent CD is released.
East Timor's Foreign Minister Horta officially requests military assistance from the governments of Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia and Portugal.
Kenneth Lay, CEO of Enron, is indicted on ten counts of securities fraud and related charges.
Kenneth Lay and Jeff Skilling are convicted for their roles in the collapse of Enron.

In Java, Indonesia, a magnitude 6.3 earthquake occurs. At least 5,749 people killed, 38,568 injured and as many as 600,000 people were displaced in the Bantul-Yogyakarta area. Total loss estimated at approximately US$3.1 billion
The Java Earthquake strikes at 10:54pm GMT devastating Bantul and the city of Yogyakarta killing over 6,600 people.
The first demonstration for gay rights in Moscow is broken up by the police.
Derek Jeter becomes the eighth player in New York Yankees history to collect 2,000 career hits.
An earthquake hits Java, killing upwards of 5,000.
President Alvaro Uribe Velez is re-elected in Colombia for a second term. He becomes the first president in over a century to serve consecutive terms.
At AT&T Park, Barry Bonds passes Babe Ruth for number of home runs as he hits the 715th homer of his Major League career. Bonds is now in second place, behind Hank Aaron.
German-born Pope Benedict XVI visits Auschwitz to conclude his pilgrimage to Poland.
Charles Gibson takes over as anchor of ABC World News Tonight.
Katie Couric last day as anchor of the Today Show on NBC after 15 years.
A fireball is reported crossing Minnesota, Wisconsin, North Dakota and Canada, estimated to be 20 miles above the Earth's surface. A sonic boom is heard over Minnesota.
In Ontario, Canada, seventeen men are arrested in the Greater Toronto Area for alleged ties to a terrorist plot to blow up targets in the region.
Montenegro declares independence after a May 21 referendum. The state union of Serbia and Montenegro is dissolved on June 5 leaving Serbia as the successor state.
The union of Serbia and Montenegro came to an end with Montenegro's formal declaration of independence.
Cincinnati Reds' player Ken Griffey Jr. hits a home run in his 43rd ballpark to tie the major league record also held by Fred McGriff.
Serbia declares independence from the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro
On the sixth day of the sixth month of the sixth year of the century, the Los Angeles Dodgers score six runs in the sixth inning during the sixth game of the homestand.
The Union of Islamic Courts gains control of Somalia's capital Mogadishu, ending warlord rule of the city.
Serbia declares independence from State Union of Serbia and Montenegro.
Al-Qaeda in Iraq leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi and seven of his aides are killed in a U.S. air raid just north of the town of Baqouba, Iraq.
British Houses of Parliament temporarily shut down due to anthrax alert.
Sjoerd van der Schaaf, Frisian journalist / writer, dies in Oenkerk, Netherlands.
Workers working on the regeneration of Broadmead, Bristol discover an unexploded German bomb from World War II. Broadmead has to be evacuated and stores temporarily closed.
Thailand begins celebrations of the 60th anniversary of the accession of Bhumibol Adulyadej to the throne.
An explosion kills eight Palestinian civilians on a Gaza beach. Israel denies responsibility for the blast.
The 2006 FIFA World Cup begins in Germany.
BYU officials announce the reopening of the Brigham Young University Jerusalem Center.
President Mahmoud Abbas sets July 26 as the date for a national referendum in the Palestinian National Authority.
Nintendo releases the Nintendo DS Lite handheld video game system in the USA. Case color is Polar White. Price is US$129.99.
Nintendo DS Lite released in North America.
Sonic Youth release their new album Rather Ripped
Phillips Fox announced that it had entered an exclusive alliance with the international firm DLA Piper Rudnick Gray Cary.
Bill Gates announces he will ease away from Microsoft duties over the next two years. Ray Ozzie is immediately shifted from chief technology officer to chief software architect.
The first Kazakh space satellite "KazSat" is launched.
The first Kazakh space sattelite, KazSat is launched.
A meteor show is observed in various places in Pennsylvania, USA.
In the National Hockey League, the Carolina Hurricanes defeat the Edmonton Oilers 4 games to 3 games to win the Stanley Cup.
IBM announces it has built a transistor that runs at 500 GHz when cooled to near absolute zero, about 100 times faster than current chips. The transistor is built from silicon laced with germanium.
The NHL's Carolina Hurricanes win their first-ever Stanley Cup.
The Miami Heat win the NBA Finals over the Dallas Mavericks, 4-2.
The Magen David Adom and Palestine Red Crescent Society are officially recognized by the International Committee of the Red Cross.
In Miami, Florida, the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrests seven men, accusing them of planning to bomb the Sears Tower and other attacks in Miami.
Warren Buffett donates over US$30 billion to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
The Republic of Montenegro becomes the 192nd member of the United Nations.

Ronaldo broke the all-time World Cup finals goal-scoring record of 14 goals set by Gerd Müller of Germany, scoring his 15th World Cup goal, and Brazil's first goal of the match (Round of 16), against Ghana in his 18th World Cup match.
Israel launches Operation Summer Rains, an offensive against militants in Gaza.
The Republic of Montenegro was admitted as the 192nd Member of the United Nations by General Assembly resolution 60/264.
The Dutch cabinet Balkenende II resigns after the political party of D'66 drops its support.
Women vote for the first time in elections for the National Assembly of Kuwait.
The Dutch cabinet Balkenende II resigned.
Boston Red Sox set a new Major League record of 17 consecutive errorless games.
The Qinghai-Tibet Railway launches a trial operation, connecting China proper and Tibet for the first time.
Austria hands over Presidency of the European Union to Finland.
The first operation of Qinghai-Tibet Railway in China.
A presidential election is held in Mexico. Felipe Calder=n is confirmed as the winner on September 5.
The asteroid labeled as 2004 XP14 flies within 432,308 km (268,624 miles) of Earth.
Asteroid labeled as 2004 XP14 flies by Earth's atmosphere.
North Korea tests four short-range missiles one medium-range missile, and a long-range Taepodong-2. The latter reportedly fails in mid-air over the Sea of Japan.
Space Shuttle Discovery launches at 18:37:55 UTC to commence mission STS-121 for the first time in NASA history. It is the first Independence Day shuttle launch.
Emergency United Nations Security Council meeting held at the U.N in New York City because of the North Korean missile tests a day before.
North Korea launched at least two short-range Nodong-2 missiles, one SCUD missile and one long-range Taepodong-2 missile.
The Nathula Pass between India and China, sealed during the Sino-Indian War, re-opens for trade after 44 years.
The Nathula Pass between India and China, sealed during the Sino-Indian War, re-opens for trade after 44 years.
Felipe Calderon is elected President of Mexico after a very close election.
S7 Airlines Flight 778 crashes into a concrete barrier shortly after landing, killing at least 122 people and leaving many injured.
Italy wins the 2006 FIFA World Cup by beating France 5-3 on penalties. The score after extra time is 1-1.
Italy Wins the FIFA World Cup for the 4th time, defeating France 5-3 on Penalties in the 2006 FIFA World Cup final.
At least 122 people are dead after a Sibir Airlines passenger jet Airbus A-310 with 200 people on board veered off the runway while landing at Irkutsk Airport in Siberia in wet conditions.
Pakistan International Airlines Flight 688 crashes in Multan, Pakistan shortly after takeoff.
An ice ball the size of a microwave oven lands in Douglasdale, South Africa, creating a small crater on the pavement where it lands.
A series of coordinated bomb attacks strikes several commuter trains in Mumbai, India during the evening rush hour.
Microsoft's official support of Windows 98 and Windows Me ends.
Israeli troops invade Lebanon in response to Hezbollah kidnapping two Israeli soldiers and killing three. Hezbollah declares open war against Israel two days later.
A meteor explodes over the Oslo Fjord, Norway, depositing numerous meteorites over the area.
Mariano Rivera of the New York Yankees records his 400th career save. becoming the fourth major leaguer to reach the milestone.

At Coney Island, New York, a New York-Penn League game between the Oneonta Tigers and the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Tigers win by 6-1 after 26 innings, lasting 6 hours 40 minutes. This is the third longest game by innings in professional baseball history.
Saint Louis, Missouri, is hit by two major derechos (violent windstorms) in a span of three days.

New York Yankees player Alex Rodriguez records his 2000th career hit, and at the same time becomes the youngest player to bat 450 home runs. Later in the day, San Diego Padres catcher Mike Piazza also makes his 2000th hit.

Canada defeats USA 15-11 in the 2006 World Lacrosse Championship. This marks only the second time the USA had not won the gold medal, and only the second time Canada had won the gold. Geoff Snider is announced as Most Valuable Player.
Phonak team rider, American cyclist Floyd Landis wins the Tour de France; however, tour officials soon announce that he has failed a doping test.
Intel releases Core 2 Duo - CPU based on new Core architecture.
Advanced Micro Devices agrees to pay US$5.4 billion in cash and stock to acquire ATI Technologies of Canada.
Alejandro Toledo concludes his term as President of Peru, and Alan Garc?a becomes president.
World's longest running music show Top of the Pops broadcast for the last time on BBC Two. The show has aired for 42 years.
Fidel Castro, President of Cuba, temporarily relinquishes power to his brother Ra?l before surgery.
BP oil company in Alaska announces it would have to replace 16 miles of feeder lines in its North Slope oil facility, shutting down about 50 percent of Prudhoe Bay's production.
Nintendo holds a 10th birthday PokTmon Party at the Bryant Park in New York City. Over 25,000 attend. Included is a giant Flying Pikachu from Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

London Metropolitan Police make 21 arrests in connection to an apparent terrorist plot that involved aircraft traveling from the United Kingdom to the United States. Liquids and gels are banned from checked and carry-on baggage.
A resolution to end the 2006 Lebanon War is unanimously accepted by the United Nations Security Council.
The last software patent will expire on the GIF format.
A United Nations cease fire takes effect in the 2006 Lebanon War.

Home plate umpire Bruce Froemming is honored during an on-field ceremony at Fenway Park for working his 5000th major league game of his 36-year career, second only to Bill Klem who arbitrated 5,374 games from 1905-40.
At Fenway Park, the New York Yankees beat the Boston Red Sox 14-11 in the longest nine-inning game in Major Leage history, at 4 hours and 45 minutes.
Pulkovo Airlines Flight 612 crashes near the Russian border in Ukraine, killing 171 people, including 45 children.
The ICM awards Grigori Perelman the Fields Medal for proving the Poincare conjecture, one of seven Millennium Prize Problems. Perelman refuses the medal.

In Austria, Natascha Kampusch manages to escape after being kidnapped eight years ago by Wolfgang Priklopil who locked her up in his cellar. Priklopil commits suicide by throwing himself in front of a train.
The International Astronomical Union defines 'planet' at its 26th General Assembly, demoting Pluto to the status of 'dwarf planet' more than 70 years after its discovery.
Comair Flight 5191, carrying 50 people, crashes shortly after take-off from Blue Grass Airport in Lexington, Kentucky.

A Greyhound Lines bus from New York City to Montreal, carrying 52 people, crashes at mile 115 on Interstate 87 near Elizabethtown killing five people including the driver, and several are seriously injured.
A fire kills 29 of 148 people aboard an Iran Air Tours Tu-154M aircraft after the plane lands in Mashhad, Iran.
US military hands over the Abu Ghraib prison to the Iraqi government.
A Nimrod MR2 plane based at RAF Kinloss, Scotland, crashes in the Southern Province of Kandahar, Afghanistan, due to a fuel leak. All 14 crew on board are killed.
Andre Agassi retires after his final tennis match against Benjamin Becker in the U.S. Open.
Spain wins the 2006 FIBA World Championship.
Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taipei is renamed to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
Seven-time World Champion Michael Schumacher announces he will retire from Formula One racing at the end of the year.
Apple Computer announces the iTunes movie store, initially with 75 Disney company movies for download. Prices range from US$10 to 16 per film.
A meteor streaks across the sky in New Zealand, creating a sonic boom at about 40,000kph, turning into a fireball and depositing rocks on the ground.
Pope Benedict XVI gives a lecture in Germany; he quotes a criticism of the Islamic faith, sparking mass protest.
A stampede at a rally in Yemen leaves 41 dead.
The Dawson College Shooting occurs in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, leaving one student dead and 19 others injured.
The solar system's largest dwarf planet, designated until now as 2003 UB313, is officially named "Eris"; its satellite is now known as "Dysnomia".
Spinach contaminated with E. coli kills one person and poisons over 100 others in 20 states of the United States.
Five churches are attacked in Palestinian areas following the Pope's comments on Islam.
The Alliance for Sweden claims victory in the Swedish general election.

A memorial service for recently deceased Australian personality Steve Irwin takes place at Australia Zoo, Queensland, Australia. The service is broadcast across Australia and other parts of the world.

Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand declares a state of emergency in Bangkok as members of the Royal Thai Army stage a coup d'Ttat. The army announces the removal of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra from power.
In Toronto, Ontario, Canada, the spot at Hanlan Point where Babe Ruth hit his first professional home run is commemorated with a plaque. The historic home run came on September 5, 1914.
In the USA, the CW Television Network (a merger of The WB and UPN) officially begins operations.
American League East baseball title won by New York Yankees.
A Transrapid Maglev train crashes into a maintenance vehicle on a test track in Germany, killing 23 and injuring 10; it is the first recorded fatal accident involving a Maglev.
Toomas Hendrik Ilves is elected President of Estonia.
At Camden Yards, Baltimore Orioles player Jay Gibbons hits a foul ball that hits wife Laura in the rib cage.
In Milwaukee's Miller Park, Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants hits his 734th career homer surpassing Hank Aaron and establishing a new all-time National League home run record.
Europe wins the Ryder Cup in Ireland.
The Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans re-opens 13 months after Hurricane Katrina with extensive repairs, including the largest re-roofing project in the United States.
Diet of Japan elects Shinzo Abe as new Prime Minister of Japan succeeding Junichiro Koizumi.
An armed suspect holds six female students as hostages in Platte Canyon High School located in Bailey, Colorado. One hostage is fatally wounded as the gunman kills himself.
After 40 years of development, Suvarnabhumi Airport opens in Bangkok, Thailand replacing Don Mueang International Airport as Bangkok's primary airport for commercial flights.
Sony issues a global recall of bad lithium-ion batteries.
Gol Flight 1907, a Boeing 737-800, collides with a business jet over the Amazon Rainforest killing all 154 onboard.
Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koisumi resigns office.
West Coast Eagles win the Australian Football League Grand Final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
Brisbane Broncos beat Melbourne Storm in the controversial 2006 National Rugby League Grand Final at Telstra Stadium in Sydney, Australia.
In general elections in Brazil, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva receives 48.6 percent of the presidential popular vote, with Geraldo Alckmin receiving 41.6 percent, forcing a run-off election on October 29.
Charles Carl Roberts IV, a 32-year-old milk-truck driver, kills five female students at an Amish schoolhouse in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania before shooting himself.
Per Westerberg takes office as Speaker of the Riksdag in Sweden.
North Korea announces plans to conduct a nuclear test.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 11,800 for the first time rising 123.27 points, or 1.05%, finishing at 11,850.61.
Hazardous waste plant near Apex, North Carolina explodes releasing chlorine gas, resulting in the evacuation of thousands and the hospitalization of over 100 residents.
North Korea claims to have conducted its first ever nuclear test.
An arc of blazing light is witnessed crossing the sky in Germany, resulting in a fire destroying a cottage in Siegburg, near Bonn, Germany and injuring a 77-year-old man.
Google buys YouTube for US$1.65 billion.
New York Yankees pitcher Cory Lidle is killed (born 1972), along with his flight instructor, when his plane crashes into a building in New York City's Upper East Side.
38 Muslim scholars create a statement appealing for a strategic dialog with Christian leaders, mainly the Pope.
Ban Ki-moon (of South Korea) is elected as the new Secretary-General of the United Nations.
With a 6-3 victory in Game 4 of the ALCS, the Detroit Tigers sweep the Athletics to win the American pennant for the first time since 1984.
Declaration of the etablishment of the Islamic State of Iraq.
Chief Justice of Japan Akira Machida retires upon reaching the age of 70.
In Hawaii, a magnitude 6.7 earthquake occurs. Power outages occur throughout the Hawaiian Islands. Damage estimated at US$73 million.
The United Nations agrees to sanction North Korea over nuclear testing issue.
The last MASH (Mobile Army Surgical Hospital) is decommissioned.
The United States population reaches 300 million based on a United States Census Bureau projection.
On the 19th anniversary of the 1987 stock market crash, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 12,000 for the first time, at 12,011.73.
Jeffrey Skilling is sentenced to 24 years and four months in US federal prison on charges of fraud and insider trading relating to the financial collapse of Enron.
Major League Baseball officials and the Players' Association announce a five-year collective bargaining agreement has been reached.
The New Jersey Supreme Court unanimously rules in favor of marriage equality.
Last Ford Taurus rolls off Atlanta assembly line.

At the Busch Stadium, the Saint Louis Cardinals beat the heavily favored Detroit Tigers, 4-2, in Game 5 of the Fall Classic to win the 2006 World Series of baseball. The Cardinals, who lost ten of their last 14 regular season games, won less games than any World Series champion in baseball history.
Luis Incio Lula da Silva is re-elected President of Brazil with 61 percent of the vote in the run-off election.

Aviation Development Company Flight 53 (Boeing 737) crashes shortly after take-off from Abuja, Lagos, Nigeria, killing 96 including Muhammadu Maccidio, spiritual head of Nigeria's Muslims. The crash is blamed on a storm.
Former President of Chile Augusto Pinochet is placed under house arrest for crimes committed at the Villa Grimaldi detention centre.
An airstrike on a madrasah in Bajaur kills dozens of suspected al-Qaeda and Taliban militants.
The Esperanza Fire burns over 61 square miles of Cabazon, California mountain territory.
The Stardust Resort & Casino closes after 48 years of business in Las Vegas.
Major League Baseball officials announce an office will be opened in China to help promote the game.
Iran successfully test-fires three new models of sea missiles in a show of force to assert its military capacities in the Gulf.
Former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and two of his senior allies are sentenced to death by hanging after an Iraqi court finds them guilty of crimes against humanity.
U.S. Midterm elections: Democrats win control of both houses of Congress for the first time since 1994.
In the U.S. congressional elections, Minnesota Democrat Keith Ellison becomes the first Muslim elected to the House of Representatives.
The Japanese town of Saroma, Hokkaido is struck by a tornado, killing nine. It is the deadliest tornado in Japan since 1941.
Margaret Chan is elected as the Director-General of the World Health Organization.
U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld resigns; President Bush nominates Robert Gates, a former Central Intelligence Agency director, as his replacement.
Sony releases the PlayStation 3 video game system in Japan. Total sales in the first nine days: 133,000.
Edinburgh Place Ferry Pier, Hong Kong, completes the last journey of its 49-year operation.
Gerald Ford surpasses Ronald Reagan as the longest lived President of the United States.
The former Soviet republic of South Ossetia holds a referendum on independence from Georgia.
Delmon Young is suspended for 50 games by the International League for throwing a bat which hit a replacement umpire in the chest.
The New York Mets stage a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the start of construction of the US$800 million 45,000-seat CitiField ballpark.
The BBWAA votes Jason Verlander of the Detroit Tigers as American League Rookie of the Year Award.

Microsoft launches the Zune portable music player. It features 30 GB hard drive, 3-inch display, FM radio, playback of unprotected audio and video files and protected files from the Zune Marketplace. Case colors are black, brown, or white. Price is US$249.
The BBWAA votes Brandon Webb of the Arizona Diamondbacks as winner of the National League Cy Young Award.
In the Kuril Islands, a magnitude 8.3 earthquake occurs. A tsunami with a recorded wave height of 176 cm damages a dock at Crescent City, California.
The State of Hawaii bans smoking in all enclosed public places.
Start of the Sales and Use Tax in Puerto Rico; a response to the Puerto Rico budget crisis of May 2006.
Al Jazeera launches its new English language news channel, Al Jazeera English.
Rioting in Nuku'alofa, the capital of Tonga, destroys about 80 percent of the CBD; eight bodies found and foreign forces requested.
NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office observes two Leonid asteroids hit the Moon, making 11 confirmed impacts in one year.
Sony releases the PlayStation 3 video game system in the USA.
Frank Thomas agrees to a $18.12 million, two-year deal to join the Toronto Blue Jays.
Lee High School bus crash kills four students in Huntsville, Alabama.
Iran and Syria recognize the government of Iraq, restore diplomatic relations, and call for a peace conference.
A gas explosion in the coal mine Halemba in Ruda Slaska, Poland, kills 23 miners approximately 1,000 metres below ground.
Israel's Supreme Court finds that Israel must recognize and register same-gender marriages celebrated in other countries.
Pierre Amine Gemayel, Lebanon's Minister of Industry, is assassinated in Beirut.
A General Election is held for the House of Keys in the Isle of Man.
The Christian Democratic Appeal wins a plurality of seats in The Netherlands.
Ten people are trapped and killed in the Kolkata leather factory fire in India.
A series of car bombs and mortar attacks in Sadr City, Baghdad, kill at least 215 people and injure 257 others.
Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian KGB agent, is killed by Polonium-210 in a London sushi bar.
Steve Bracks wins the Victorian state election.
US Judge James Robertson orders the US Treasury to change the dollar bill.
(to November 29) The NATO Summit 2006 takes place in Latvia.
Typhoon Durian triggers a massive mudslide and kills hundreds of people in the Philippines.
South Africa becomes the fifth nation to legalize gay marriage.
The 15th Asian Games start in Doha, Qatar; the closing ceremony takes place on December 15.
Felipe Calder=n is sworn in as the President of Mexico by the Congress in Mexico.
In Rome, about two million people, led by opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi, demonstrate against Romano Prodi's government.
Stephane Dion is elected the new Leader of the Liberal Party of Canada, on the fourth ballot.

Ed Stelmach is elected the new Leader of the Progressive Conservatives, Canada, after the second ballot results, and second choice votes for Ted Morton have been added up. Ed becomes the Premier-designate of Alberta.
Explosive demolition of Germany's tallest chimney at former Westerholt Power Station.
Hugo Chvez is re-elected President of Venezuela.
An adult giant squid is caught on video near the Ogasawara Islands south of Tokyo.
The military seizes power in Fiji by means of a coup d'Ttat led by Commodore Josaia Voreqe "Frank" Bainimarama.
A fire at a hospital in Moscow kills 45 people.
Christer Fuglesang becomes the first Swede in space.
Chivas defeats Toluca in the final of the Mexican Soccer League.
The Holocaust conference is opened in Tehran, Iran by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
Peugeot produce their last car at the Ryton Plant in Coventry signalling the end of mass car production in a city that was once a major centre of the British motor industry.
The Chinese River Dolphin or Baiji becomes extinct.
The Japanese government passes a bill to upgrade the Japan Defense Agency to a Ministry.
Jigme Singye Wangchuck, the King of Bhutan, abdicates in favour of his son Jigme Khesar Namgyal Wangchuck a year earlier than expected.
Lockheed Martin's F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter successfully flies for the first time.
An alleged assassination attempt on the Palestinian prime minister Ismail Haniyeh sparks inter-Palestinian clashes.
A Libyan court sentences five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor to death for knowingly infecting hundreds of Libyan children with HIV.
In Somalia, Islamic Courts Union fighters begin attacking the government-held town of Baidoa.
Saparmurat Niyazov, the dictator of Turkmenistan dies unexpectedly, sparking world concern over a possible power vacuum and instability in this energy-rich country.
Australian cricket player Shane Warne announces his retirement from the sport.
Ethiopia admits its troops have intervened in Somalia.
An oil pipeline is blown up in Nigeria's commercial capital, Lagos, killing at least 200 people.
The Hengchun earthquake in Taiwan kills two people, damages about 15 historical buildings and several undersea cable, disrupting Internet and IDD telecommunication services in Asia.
The San Francisco Giants reach a preliminary agreement with pitcher Barry Zito on the largest deal ever given to a pitcher in the history of the game: US$126 million for seven years.
In Somalia, Ethiopian and Transitional government troops capture Mogadishu without resistance.
Saddam Hussein, former Iraq president, is executed in Baghdad.
At least eleven bombs go off in Bangkok, Thailand, hours before the new year.
The U.S. soldier death toll in Iraq reaches 3,000.
South Korea's Ban Ki-moon becomes the new United Nations Secretary-General, replacing Kofi Annan.
War in Somalia: Fighters of the Islamic Courts Union abandon their last stronghold in Kismayo and flee for the Kenyan border.
A state of emergency is declared in Bangladesh.
Hong Kong's new smoking law starts. From this day onwards, smoking is prohibited in clubs, karaoke bars, restaurants, and all public places.
Slovenia adopts the euro as its official currency, replacing the tolar.
Bulgaria and Romania join the European Union.
Germany begins six-month term of presidency of the European Union.
Adam Air Flight 574, a routine domestic flight in Indonesia, disappears.
The new constitution of Gibraltar comes into force.
China conducts an anti-terror raid in Xinjiang.
A dense metallic meteorite about 1-inch in diameter crashes through the roof of a house in eastern New Jersey, USA.
Nancy Pelosi becomes the first female speaker of the United States House of Representatives.
Taiwan High Speed Rail opens between Taipei and Kaohsiung.
In Somalia, the first shots are fired in the battle for control of the border town of Ras Kamboni.
Randy Johnson agrees to a US$26 million, two-year Arizona Diamondbacks deal.
Russian oil supplies to Poland, Germany, and Ukraine are cut as the Russia-Belarus energy dispute escalates; restored three days later.
A Greek 467-465 BCE silver decadrachm of Athens sells for US$575,000, a record for a Greek coin.
An AerianTur-M Antonov An-26 crashes in Balad, Iraq. The Islamic Army in Iraq claims to have shot it down.
U.S. planes conduct air strikes in Somalia against suspected terrorists.
A meteorite falls in the Altai Territory in southern Siberia, Russia.
U.S. President George W. Bush announces a plan to station 21,500 additional troops in Iraq.
Vietnam joins the World Trade Organization as its 150th member.
In Bangladesh, a state of emergency is declared by caretaker President Iajuddin Ahmed, following weeks of violent protests preceding upcoming parliamentary elections.
China successfully destroys one of its old weather satellite orbiting 850 km above the Earth by a mobile ground-based ballistic missile.
The US Embassy in Athens is attacked with a rocket propelled grenade, causing minimal damage and no injuries.
An Argentine judge issues a warrant for the arrest of former President Isabel Mart?nez de Per=n in connection with the disappearance of a human rights worker in 1976.
Comet McNaught, the brightest comet in over 40 years, makes perihelion.
The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement officially adopt the Red Crystal as a non-religious emblem for use in its overseas operations.
The Toronto Blue Jays and first baseman Lyle Overbay agree to a four-year contract worth $24 million to stay in Toronto.
Comet McNaught makes perigee after coming close to the sun.
In Scottsdale, Arizona, the Barrett-Jackson Collector Car Auction is held, over six days. A 1967 silver Corvette coupe, the last Sting Ray built, sells for US$600,000.
Comet McNaught, the brightest comet to appear in over 40 years, becomes visible over the Southern Hemisphere.
US investment bank Merrill Lynch announces 2006 profit of US$10.4 billion, the most successful year in its history.
Israel releases US$100 million in frozen assets to President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian National Authority in order to bolster the president's position.
Yokozuna Asashoryu wins the Emperor's Cup at the New Year's Grand Sumo Tournament (Hatsu Basho) in Tokyo, Japan.
A bombing in a market in Baghdad, Iraq, kills 88 people.
In Giles County, Virginian, USA a meteor sighting if followed by a thundering tremor.
Willie Randolph agrees to a $5.65 million, three-year deal to manage the New York Mets through 2008.
The President of Israel, Moshe Katsav, takes a temporary leave of absence due to a sex scandal.
A battle between insurgents and U.S.-backed Iraqi troops kills 300 suspected terrorists in Najaf, Iraq.
(to February 4) The 2007 Asian Winter Games are held in Changchun, China.
A suicide bomber kills three people in a bakery in Eilat, Israel.
The New York Yankees agree to help establish baseball academies in China.
In Turkey, a meteorite flashes across the sky and lands in Yesilkent.
The Venezuelan National Assembly gives President Hugo Chvez the power to rule by decree for 18 months.
Delta Air Lines creditors officially reject US Airways' hostile takeover bid.
British Prime Minister Tony Blair is questioned for a second time in the 'cash for peerages' (Cash for Honours) probe as a witness.
Palestinian factional violence: Hamas and its rival Fatah renew their truce after violence broke out following the initial ceasefire.
Chinese President Hu Jintao signs a series of economic deals with Sudan.
Martti Ahtisaari unveils a United Nations plan for the final status of Kosovo; Serbian leaders denounce the proposal.
Eight people are killed in a mortar attack in Somalia's capital Mogadishu.
Three tornadoes cross a 70-mile path across Florida, USA, killing 21, injuring 100, destroying 1500 homes and mobile homes.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change publishes its fourth assessment report, concluding that "most" of the observed warming since the mid-20th century is "very likely" to have had a human cause.
The deadly H5N1 strain of bird flu is found at a Bernard Matthews turkey farm in Suffolk, United Kingdom.
State of Emergency is declared in Indonesia after 'El Nino'-like flooding.
A truck bombing in a crowded Baghdad, Iraq, market kills at least 135 people and injures a further 339 others.
The Indianapolis Colts defeat the Chicago Bears 29-17 in NFL's Super Bowl XLI, played at Dolphin Stadium, Miami, Florida.
Meteors and fireballs are reported in several states in the Midwestern USA.
HSBC announces it is setting aside US$10 billion to cover bad loans in its US mortgage division.
American model and television personality Anna Nicole Smith dies of combined drug intoxication in Hollywood, Florida at age 39 (born 1967).
U.S. Senator Barack Obama of Illinois announces a presidential bid in Springfield, Illinois, USA.
In a national referendum, Portuguese voters agree to legalise abortion.
All-star backstop Joe Mauer the Minnesota Twins come to terms on a $33 million, four-year contract.
An armed gunman shoots and kills five people at the Trolley Square Mall in Salt Lake City, Utah, before being killed by the police, bringing the evening's rampage death toll to six.

Taiwan opposition leader Ma Ying-jeou resigns as the chairman of the Kuomintang party after being indicted on charges of embezzlement; Ma also announces his candidacy for the 2008 presidential election.

North Korea agrees to shut down its nuclear facilities in Yongbyon by April 14 as a first step towards complete denuclearization, receiving in return energy aid equivalent to 50,000 tons of heavy fuel oil.
In Ohio, USA, a meteor streaks across the sky, creating a sonic boom.
The US Mint releases the George Washington Presidential dollar to circulation.
Baseball commissioner office approves a one-year contract worth $15.8 million for Barry Bonds with the New York Ginats.
In Banchola village, Rajasthan, India, three people are killed and four injured when a meteorite falls from the sky and hits them.
A large fire causes 26 fatalities in the Regi care center in Alsunga, Latvia.
A 4.2kg 20cm diameter meteorite falls on a beach in Rio Hato, Panama.
The European Space Agency confirms Rosetta's successful Mars trajectory fly-by.
The International Court of Justice finds Serbia guilty of failing to prevent genocide in the Srebrenica massacre, but clears it of direct responsibility and complicity in the case.
World stock markets plummet after China and Europe release less-than-expected growth reports.
At the Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan, a Taliban suicide attack kills 23. Visiting US Vice President Dick Cheney is not injured.
The New Horizons space probe makes a gravitational slingshot against Jupiter which changes its trajectory towards Pluto.
International Polar Year, a US$1.5 billion research program to study both the North Pole and South Pole, is launched in Paris, France (runs until March 1, 2009).
Airbus announces that it will cease work indefinitely on the A380F freight aircraft.
Mike Young signs an $80 million, five-year contract extension offered by American baseball's Texas Rangers.

Five Bluffton University baseball players and the driver and his wife are killed in a chartered bus accident in Atlanta. The players, Zach Arend, David Betts, Scott Harmon, Cody Holp, and Tyler Williams, were en route to to Sarasota, Florida.
Mixed martial artist Randy Couture wins the UFC heavyweight championship at the age of 43 in the main event of UFC 68.
Parliamentary elections take place in Estonia and in Abkhazia.
(to March 15) The 2007 National People's Congress is held in Beijing, China. The Property Law of the People's Republic of China is officially adopted.
In the USA, Mega Millions sets a new world record for the highest lottery jackpot of US$370 million.
Garuda Indonesia Flight 200, a Boeing 737-400, crashes at Yogyakarta on the Indonesian island of Java, killing many on board.
Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2007 is held.
Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert admits that Israel had planned an attack on Lebanon in the event of kidnapped soldiers on the border, months before Hezbollah carried out its kidnapping.
Music group Van Halen is inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
BBC journalist Alan Johnston disappears in Gaza City, Palestine.
A fireball lands in a farmer's field in Holland Landing, Ontario, Canada.
Chlorine bombs injure hundreds in Baghdad, Iraq.
The 2007 Formula 1 World Championship Begins with the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne.
NATO troops launch two assaults in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, killing 38 Taliban terrorists. NATO suffers no casualties.
Naval forces of Iran's Revolutionary Guard seize British Royal Navy personnel in disputed Iran-Iraq waters.
Eight human skeletons are discovered in Fort Myers, Florida, later linked to suspected serial killer Daniel Conahan.
In Berlin, Germany, 27 European ministers celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome.
Ozeki Hakuho clinches the Emperor's Cup at the Spring Grand Sumo Tournament (Haru Basho) in Osaka, Japan.
In the Canadian province of QuTbec, the Liberal Party wins a National Assembly election with 48 seats out of 125 and forms a minority government.
Prime Minister of Latvia Aigars Kalvitis and Prime Minister of Russia Mikhail Fradkov finally signs a border treaty between Latvia and Russia.
Former Major League Baseball pitcher Ugueth Urbina is sentenced to 14 years in prison.
Pilots of a Chilean passenger jet approaching the airport at Auckland, New Zealand report seeing flaming debris fall past their aircraft several kilometres away, falling at the speed of sound.
Sydney, Australia, turns off its lights for one hour between 7:30PM and 8:30PM as a political statement for Global Climate Change.
Smoke ban in enclosed places in Wales.
The Solomon Islands is shaken by a magnitude 8.1 earthquake, and hit by a subsequent tsunami.
New Century, a large American mortgage lender, files for bankruptcy protection.
A French TGV train on the LGV Est high speed line sets an official new world speed record.
Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko dissolves the Ukrainian Parliament following defections that increased the majority of his opponents. It has been nicknamed the "Second Orange Revolution".
Iran announces it will release the British sailors and marines that they captured on March 23. The captives arrive back in the UK the next day.
NATO and Afghan forces retake a key town from the Taliban in Sangin in southern Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
Severe clashes between two rival factions erupt in Parachinar, a tribal area of Pakistan bordering the famous Tora Bora Heights.
Zach Johnson wins the 2007 Masters Tournament.
Al Qaeda claims responsibility for two bomb blasts in the Algerian capital of Algiers. At least 33 people are killed and 222 others injured.
In the USA, Don Imus is fired by CBS for making controversial comments about the Rutgers women's basketball team.
Retired chess champion Garry Kasparov is detained in Moscow for participating in a banned march.
Fifteen British sailors are abducted by Iran, claiming they are in Iranian waters.
The British Pound Sterling hits a 15-year high against the US dollar, breaking through the US$2 level for the first time since 1992.
Student Cho Seung-hui kills 32 people plus himself at the premises of Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in Blacksburg, Virginia, USA.
The 2014 Asian Games is awarded to be held in Incheon, South Korea, winning over India's New Delhi.
32 Chinese steel workers are burnt to death in the Qinghe Special Steel Corporation disaster.
US and allied air forces conduct massive exercises over South Korea with over 500 planes.
Presidential elections are held in Nigeria.
The first round of the French presidential election of 2007 takes place.
Bogot, Colombia, begins its term as World Book Capital.
Gliese 581 c, a potentially habitable Earth-like extrasolar planet, is discovered in the constellation Libra.
Abortion is legalized in Mexico City, Mexico.
US Representative Dennis Kucinich (Democrat-Ohio), introduces articles to impeach Vice President Dick Cheney.
The Eliasberg specimen of the US 1913 Liberty Head nickel is sold for $5 million.
In the USA, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 135.95 points to close at 13089.89; its first close above 13000 in its history.
Russians riot in Tallinn, Estonia, about moving the Bronze Soldier. Two nights of rioting leave one dead.

The Royal Canadian Mint produces the first 100-kilogram gold coin with $1,000,000 face value, 53 cm in diameter, to celebrate the new $200 Maple Leaf gold coin with the world's highest purity, 0.99999 fine. Value of the gold in the coin is about US$2.6 million.
Local government elections in Scotland and most of England. The Scottish National Party becomes the largest party in Scotland for the first time in their history.
Tornado strikes Greensburg, Kansas, killing at least 12 and destroying about 90 percent of the town.
Executive Directive 51, which specifies the procedures for continuity of the federal government of the United States in the event of a "catastrophic emergency" is signed by President George W. Bush.
Kenya Airways Flight KQ 507 crashes in Cameroon.
Panathinaikos BC wins basketball's Euroleague after beating CSKA Moscow 93-91 in Athens Olympic stadium.
Manchester United wins the English Premier League.
Nicolas Sarkozy is elected President of the French Republic, defeating STgolFne Royal with 53 percent of the vote in the French Presidential Election.
A.C. Paranava? wins its first ever Paran State Championship.
Devolved government is restored to Northern Ireland, with Ian Paisley as First Minister and Martin McGuinness as Deputy First Minister.
Subtropical storm Andrea forms off the coast of Florida, the earliest subtropical storm since Ana in 2003.
Tony Blair announces he will resign as British Prime Minister on June 27, triggering a Labour Party leadership election.
A fireball falls across the centre of Spain, with sightings in Cuenca, Toledo, Ciudad Real and Valladolid.
The final of the Eurovision Song Contest 2007 is held in Helsinki, resulting in Serbia's first victory.
A meteor likely causes a 2.1-magnitude earthquake in Hubbardton, Vermont, USA.
Senatorial Elections in the Philippines are held.
Rotterdam, The Netherlands, commemorates the attack of 1940 by German bomber planes with a display of spotlights outlining the destroyed portion of the city center.
Coalition government of Fatah and Hamas in Palestinian National Authority appears to break down, as massive fighting breaks out in Gaza Strip.
Sony reports its games division lost US$1.9 billion during the fiscal year.
Nicolas Sarkozy officially becomes President of the French Republic after taking over from Jacques Chirac.
The Russian Orthodox Church Abroad and the Moscow Patriarchate re-unite after eighty years of schism.
Alex Salmond officially becomes First Minister of Scotland after taking over from Jack McConnell.
