The 126th FA Cup Final is held, the first at the new Wembley Stadium. Chelsea defeat Manchester United 1-0.
Clashes in Tripoli, Lebanon, spark the 2007 Lebanon conflict.

The ruler of Dubai, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum makes the largest single charitable donation in modern history, committing 7.41 billion euros to an educational foundation in the Middle East.
A.C. Milan beats Liverpool F.C. 2-1 in the UEFA Champions League 2006-07 final at the Olympic Stadium in Athens, Greece.
General election in the Republic of Ireland. Taoiseach Bertie Ahern and his Fianna Fil party win a majority of seats for the third election in a row.
Ozeki Hakuho clinches the Emperor's Cup at the Summer Grand Sumo Tournament (Natsu Basho) in Tokyo, Japan.
Danish former professional bicyclist Bjarne Riis admits to having used doping when winning the 1996 Tour de France.
In Woburn, Massachusetts, USA a meteorite punches a hole through a warehouse roof.
Russia is once again recognized as a full-fledged superpower by the United States.

Radio Caracas Televisi=n (RCTV) is taken off the air after the government of Venezuela refuses to renew its license. This action results in protests. On July 16, RCTV resumes broadcasting via cable and satellite.
Riyo Mori is crowned the new Miss Universe 2007 in Mexico City, Mexico.
Inauguration of newly elected President Umaru Yar'Adua of the Federal Republic of Nigeria at the Abuja Eagle Square in Lagos; first civilian-to-civilian transfer of power in Nigeria.
Valdis Zatlers is elected President of Latvia, defeating Aivars Endzin_ in the Latvian presidential election.
A calendar blue moon occurs in the Western Hemisphere and parts of the Eastern Hemisphere.
A 2100-year-old melon is discovered by archaeologists in western Japan.
U.S. warships bombard a Somali village where Islamic militants had set up a base.
Four people are charged with a terror plot to blow up JFK International Airport in New York.
The Valley of Geysers in Russia is destroyed by a mudflow.
Ten people, including a California National Guard officer and former Hmong general, are charged over plans to overthrow the Laotian Government.
Eleven people are killed and 23 others injured in a train crash near Kerang in Victoria, Australia.
NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft makes its second fly-by of Venus en route to Mercury.
A mass grave in southern Ukraine, found accidentally by workers in May, is confirmed to be filled with thousands of victims of the Holocaust.
(to June 8) The 33rd G8 summit takes place amid strong protests in Heiligendamm, Germany.
Twelve people are killed by cyclone Gonu in Oman.
Povel Ramel, Swedish writer/singer/musician/songwriter/comedian, dies at age 85.
The Anaheim Mighty Ducks defeat the Ottawa Senators 4 games to 1 to win the NHL's Stanley Cup.
At Petco Park, San Diego Padres' pitcher Trevor Hoffman becomes the first reliever to save 500 games.
A large meteorite strikes a mountainside in Reisadalem in northern Norway, landing with an impact comparable to the atomic bomb used at Hiroshima.
The Space Shuttle Atlantis is successfully launched on mission STS-117.
At Jamsil Stadium in Seoul Yang, Jun-hyuk of the Samsung Lions becomes the first player in the 26-year history of the Korean baseball league to collect 2,000 hits.
Two large meteoroids enter the atmosphere over Sri Lanka, breaking into smaller pieces and landing in several areas.
A general election is held in Belgium.
Lewis Hamilton wins the Canadian Grand Prix becoming the first driver of mixed racial origin to win a Formula One race.
The 61st Tony Awards, honoring Broadway theatres' best shows, takes place at Radio City Music Hall.
The first round of a legislative election is held in France.
The San Antonio Spurs sweep the Cleveland Cavaliers to win the 2007 NBA Finals.
The Green Party enters government for the first time in Ireland, with Fianna Fil and the Progressive Democrats.
Nine Charleston, South Carolina firefighters are killed by a roof collapse while battling a furniture store fire.
Three people are injured and one dead in a shooting near Flinders Street in Melbourne, Australia.
The Argentinian team Boca Juniors beat the Brazilian team Gr?mio to win the Copa Libertadores 2007.
A Force 5 tornado tears through Elie, Manitoba, Canada; no injuries are reported.
A wildfire starts in South Lake Tahoe eventually destroying 254 homes in the area.
The refurbished Millennium Dome, now called The O2, reopens in London, England.
WWE wrestler Chris Benoit, his wife Nancy Benoit, and son Daniel, are found dead as the result of a murder-suicide that took place over the previous weekend.
Intense heatwaves begin to hit Southeast Europe as temperatures reach 46 celcius in Bulgaria and Greece.
In England, following the wettest June on record, Sheffield and South Yorkshire are affected by flooding. Much of Sheffield, Doncaster and Rotherham is flooded when the River Don breaches its banks.
(to July 15) The Copa AmTrica 2007 soccer tournament takes place in Venezuela.
The military police of the state of Rio de Janeiro invades the favela of Complexo do Alem?o ending in a massacre.
Tony Blair resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom; New Labour Party leader Gordon Brown is appointed Prime Minister by Queen Elizabeth II.

In the aftermath of Greece's worst heatwave in a century, at least eleven people are reported dead from heatstroke, approximately 200 wildfires break out nationwide, and the country's electricity grid nearly collapses due to record breaking demand.
The US Fish and Wildlife Service announces it would remove the bald eagle fom the endangered species list.
In Asunci=n, Paraguay, the presidential summit of the Mercosur trade group is held.
Apple's new iPhone is released in the USA.
Assassination attempt on prime minister Guillaume Soro of C?te d'Ivoire; three rockets hit his landed plane at BouakT airport, killing four, wounding 14.
British police defuse a bomb in Haymarket, Central London.
The Hawaii Superferry arrives in Honolulu after a 7,600-mile journey from Mobile, Alabama.
A parliamentary election is held in Papua New Guinea.
The FIFA U-20 World Cup 2007 soccer tournament takes place in Canada.
A calendar blue moon occurs in most of the Eastern Hemisphere.
A Jeep Cherokee drives into the entrance of the main terminal of Glasgow International Airport in an apparent terrorist incident, resulting in a petrol-driven fire.
Hong Kong celebrates ten years of Chinese rule.
The Concert For Diana is held at Wembley Stadium to commemorate Diana, Princess of Wales.
Smoking in public and work places is banned in England.
Russia is composed of 85 federal subjects instead of 86 as Koryak Autonomous Okrug and Kamchatka Oblast are merged into the Kamchatka Krai, following a 2005 referendum.
Smoking is banned in pubs and clubs in New South Wales and Victoria, Australia.
A law goes into effect lowering the voting age in Austria from 18 to 16 in federal elections.
Portugal takes over the six-month Presidency of the Council of the European Union from Germany.
US President George Bush annuls the 30-month prison sentence given to Lewis Libby for perjury and obstruction of justice.
Venus and Saturn are in conjunction, separation 46 arcsecs.
10th anniversary of the collapse of the Thai baht, which triggered the Asian Financial Crisis.
South Korea passes legislation of deregulation to remove bureaucratic barriers in its securities industry.
Torrential rains cause the onset of the 2007 Sudan floods, the worst in the Sudan's history.
Ghana redenominates its currency, dropping four zeros of the cedi.

In Islamabad, Pakistan, the army begins a seige on the Lal Masjid (Red Mosque), where thousands of Islamist extremists reside. In the day's clashes, at least 16 are killed, thousands surrender, hundreds continue resistance. Cleric Abdul Aziz is captured.
In Turin, Italy, Fiat launches the Cinquecento (Fiat 500) automobile. Price is 10,500-14,500 euros (US$14,400-19,900).
The 50-star U.S. flag becomes the longest-flying American flag, replacing the 48-star flag that flew from 1912 to 1959.
Sochi is elected as the host city of the 2014 Winter Olympics, during the 119th International Olympic Committee Session in Guatemala City.
A meteor breaks apart in the lower atmosphere with a trio of fericious explosions, and rains stones on Cali, Colombia.
Live Earth Concerts are held throughout nine major cities around the world.
Venus Williams wins the Women's Singles, at Wimbledon for a fourth time.
(to July 29) The 2007 Tour de France begins, with the grand dTpart being from London.
(to July 29) The Asian Cup 2007 Football (Soccer) tournament begins, taking place in Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam.
Roger Federer wins the Men's Singles of tennis, at Wimbledon for the fifth time in a row.
While celebrating Argentinean Independence Day, snow falls in Buenos Aires for the first time in almost 100 years.
A Cessna 310R twin-engine airplane crashes into two homes in Sanford, Florida, killing three adults and two children.
2007 Major League Baseball All-Star Game in San Francisco, California (American League 5, National League 4).
European Union finance ministers approve entry of Malta and Cyprus into the euro currency bloc.
Zheng Xiaoyu, head of State Food and Drug Administration of the People's Republic of China, is executed.
In Islamabad, Pakistan, 200 army troops storm Lal Masjid, killing almost 100, including Abdul Rashid, head of the group.
The ninth All Africa Games kick off in Algiers, Algeria.
Queen Elizabeth II visits the world's largest Commonwealth war grave in Ypres, Belgium to pay respects to fallen soldiers of the Battle of Passchendaele.
Rio Tinto mining firm offers US$38.1 billion for Canada's Alcan company.
The 15th Pan Am Games opens in Rio de Janeiro.
Following a presidential decree, Russia withdraws from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe.
Brazil defeats Argentina 3-0 in the Copa AmTrica 2007 Final.
In Tacoma, Washington, USA, the second span of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge opens to traffic, making it the longest twin suspension bridge in the world.
Earthquake occurs in Japan, killing seven and causing a pipe at a nuclear power plant to break and release about 300 gallons of radioactive water.
Britain expels four Russian diplomats in response to a refusal by the Russians to extradite Andrei Lugovoi, suspected to be behind the murder of former KGB spy Alexander Litvinenko in London.
TAM Linhas ATreas Flight 3054 (Airbus 320 jet) overruns the runway of Congonhas-S?o Paulo International Airport and crashes into a warehouse, killing all 186 on board and others on the ground.

Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick and three other men are arrested on charges related to their alleged operation of a dogfighting ring based at one of Vick's properties in southeastern Virginia.
Franco-Spanish cigarette-maker Altadis agrees to 16.2 billion euro (US$22.4 billion) takeover offer by Britain's Imperial Tobacco.
Nelson Mandela convenes a group of world leaders to contribute their wisdom, independent leadership and integrity to tackle some of the world's toughest problems as he turns 89.

At the height of rush hour in New York City a major steam pipe bursts, releasing millions of gallons of boiling water and super heated steam. Only one fatality occurs, a pedestrian who goes into cardiac arrest.
Prathiba Patil is elected as the first female President of India.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 14,000 for the first time in history.
Ol Doinyo Lengai mountain erupts, bringing a stop to the daily week long tremors experienced in Nairobi and Northern Tanzania.

Russia expels four British embassy staff in a tit-for-tat response over Britain's expulsion of four of Russia's diplomats, and announces its officials would no longer travel to Britain, and it will stop issuing visas to British officials.
U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney serves as Acting President for two and a half hours, while President George W. Bush undergoes a colonoscopy procedure.
Yokozuna Asashoryu conquers the Emperor's Cup at the Nagoya Grand Sumo Tournament (Nagoya Basho) in Nagoya, Japan.

Floods cause chaos through wide areas of Britain, especially the counties of Gloucestershire, Warwickshire, Worcestershire and Oxfordshire, leaving hundreds homeless and thousands of vehicles stranded on major roads.
Parliamentary elections take place in Turkey. Recep Tayyip Erdogan of the Justice and Development Party is elected Prime Minister with almost 47 percent of votes.
The US dollar drops to US$2.06 against the British pound sterling, the lowest since 1981.
Pratibha Patil is sworn in as India's first female president.
A 50-pound chunk of white ice crashes through the roof of a house, in Dubuque, Iowa, USA. Other large chunks of ice fall from the clear sky, tearing through nearby trees.
Two television news helicopters collide in midair while covering a police chase in Phoenix, Arizona, killing both pilots and two photojournalists.
Nikola Radosavljevic shoots dead nine people and wounds two in village Jabukovac in eastern Serbia.
Iraq wins its first Asian Cup football championship, beating Saudi Arabia 1-0.
The ruling coalition of Japan loses its majority in the upper house after the election.
Swedish film director Ingmar Bergman dies, at age 89, at home on Fsr island, off the Baltic coast of Sweden.
New British Prime Minister Gordon Brown visits U.S. President George W. Bush for the first time as Prime Minister.
Operation Banner, the presence of the British Army in Northern Ireland, the longest-running British Army operation, comes to an end.
An 8-cm diameter meteorite falls in a field in Hotipur village, India.

The I-35W Mississippi River Bridge on I-35W over the Mississippi River in Minneapolis, Minnesota between University Avenue and Washington Avenue collapses at 6:05 pm CST during the later part of rush hour, killing 13 people.
A strain of foot and mouth disease is found on a farm at Wanborough, near to Guildford, Surrey.
Smoking in public places is banned in Slovenia.
(to August 11) The 92nd World Congress of Esperanto is held in Yokohama, Japan.
A UK-wide ban on movement of all livestock is in place after foot and mouth disease is found on the Surrey farm.
At Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida, NASA launches a Delta II rocket carrying the Mars Phoenix lander to explore the north of Mars.
(to August 11) The National Eisteddfod of Wales is held at Mold, Flintshire, Wales.
American Home Mortgage files for bankruptcy.

Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert arrives in historic Palestianian town of Jericho, becoming the first Prime Minister of Israel to visit the West Bank or Gaza Strip in over seven years. Olmert meets with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas.
The Crandall Canyon Mine in Emery County, Utah collapses, trapping six miners.

At AT&T Park in San Francisco, California, San Francisco Giants' player Barry Bonds surpasses Hank Aaron as the all-time home run leader with his 756th home run. During the 10-minute celebration following the historic homer, a video message is played on the scoreboard in which Aaron congratulates the left fielder for breaking the 33-year old record.
The 21st World Scout Jamboree at Hylands Park, Essex closes.
The Space Shuttle Endeavour is successfully launched on mission STS-118.
Large French bank B.N.P. Paribas suspends withdrawals from three of its mutual funds, due to investments in American subprime securities.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average loses 387.18 points, its largest single-day drop since February 27.
The European Central Bank injects about US$130 billion into money markets.
The US Federal Reserve announces it would lend banks as much cash as necessary to keep money markets operating smoothly.
A likely meteor shower is reported over Sonora, California.
Presidential and parliamentary elections are held in Sierra Leone.
Tiger Woods wins PGA Championship, his 13th career major.
In Canada, investment bank Coventree declares it is seeking CDN$700 million in liquidity funding. Seventeen other funds seek secure bank credit lines.
At least 22 people are killed, and at least 39 missing, as a bridge collapses in the southeastern province of Hunan, China.
Pakistan marks the 60th anniversary of their independence from the British Empire.
In western Uganda, a 29-year-old miner dies of Marburg disease, likely contracted from bats in the Kitaka gold mine.
Multiple suicide bombings kill 572 people in Yazidi community in Qahtaniya, northwest Iraq.
In China, Zhang Shuhong, owner of a toy manufacturing company, commits suicide. His company made the flswed toys for Mattel.
American toy-maker Mattel announces a recall of 436,000 toy cars painted lead-based paint and 18 million toys containing small magnets that could be swallowed by children. All were made in China.
Shares in large American mortgage lender Countrywide Financial fall 13 percent, following a stock analyst's rating switch from buy to sell.
NBA referee Tim Donaghy surrenders to police and pleads guilty to charges brought up by the FBI investigation that he placed bets on games that he refereed.
India marks the 60th anniversary of their independence from the British Empire.

An 8.0 Richter scale earthquake strikes off the southwest coast of Peru, near Pisco, killing 512 people, injuring more than 1,500, leaving 100,000 homeless, and causing tsunami warnings in the Pacific Ocean.

JosT Padilla is convicted in the USA of conspiracy to murder individuals overseas, conspiracy to materially aid terrorists, and materially aiding terrorists in fact. Padilla had first been arrested in May 2002.
The Crandall Canyon Mine in Emery County, Utah, collapses a second time, killing three rescue workers and injuring six more.
The US Federal Reserve reduces the discount rate from 6.25 to 5.75 percent.

Vladimir Putin issues a statement, revealing that Russia is to resume the flight exercises of its strategic bombers in remote areas. The flights were suspended in 1991 after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Typhoon Sepat makes landfall in eastern Taiwan.
In Myanmar, the government imposes fuel price increases: gasoline up 67 percent, diesel up 100 percent, canisters of gas up 500 percent.

Parliamentary electrions take place in Kazakhstan. Nursultan Nazarbayev is re-elected President. His Nur Otan Party wins all contested seats (98) of the lower house of parliament, with 88 percent of the vote.
Thailand holds its first-ever referendum, on a new constitution. Voter turnout is 58 percent, with 57 percent voting in favor.
NASDAQ announces its intention to sell its 31 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange.

Chief veterinary officer in China reports Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome in pigs had been brought under "preliminary control". The disease had infected 257,000 pigs in 26 provinces; 68,000 died, 175,000 were destroyed. 100 million re now protected through vaccination program.
Hurricane Dean, a powerful Category 5 storm, slams into a sparsely populated area of the Yucatn Peninsula of Mexico. Hundreds of Mayan village houses are destroyed.
The Texas Rangers score thirty runs in one game, setting the modern (post-1900) Major League Baseball record for most runs by one team in a single game, in a 30-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
Myanmar government arrests thirteen dissidents who led protests against huge rises in fuel prices.
(to September 2) The 2007 World Championships in Athletics was held at Nagai Stadium in Osaka, Japan.
Forty-four people are dead after two bombs explode in Hyderabad, India.
Greek Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis declares a national state of emergency after a series of devastating wildfires ravage western Peloponese and southern Euboea, killing 68 people.
United States Attorney General Alberto Gonzales announces his resignation, to be effective September 17.
Acer of Taiwan announces it will buy Gateway of the USA for US$710 million.
The Venetian Macau casino opens in Macau. With a capacity of 15,000 patrons, it is the world's biggest casino, with 870 tables, and 3400 slot machines. Cost to build was US$2.4 billion.
Abdullah Gnl is elected as the eleventh President of Turkey by the Turkish Parliament, after secularist concerns delayed his initial candidacy.
United States Air Force nuclear weapons incident in which a B-52 flies from Minot Air Force Base, North Dakota to Barksdale Air Force Base, Lousiana carrying six nuclear warheads.
Canada begins arming customs officers along the border with the USA.
Finland switches off all of its analogue terrestrial television signals as part of the digital switchover.
Price of an ounce of gold hits a 27-year high of US$739.50.
(to September 9) The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation hosts its 19th annual city meeting in Sydney, Australia.
Danish police arrest eight young Muslims in Copenhagen, Denmark, averting a major terrorist attack.

In Jamaica, Bruce Golding of the Jamaica Labour Party is elected prime minister, breaking eighteen years of rule by the People's National Party. Golding won 50.1 percent of the popular vote, and 32 of 60 seats.
In Bangladesh, police arrest Khaleda Zia, leader of Bangladesh Nationalist Party, former Prime Minister, on charges of corruption.
Steve Fossett takes off from a private airstip in western Nevada, then he and the plane vanish.
British troops withdraw from the Basra region of Iraq.
Official groundbreaking for the Panama Canal expansion project.
Northeast Nicaragua takes a direct hit from Hurricane Felix. The hurricane is a strong Category 5 storm when it reaches the coast.
Three are arrested in a village in central Germany, charged with plotting a bomb attack on Frankfurt airport.
A bomb explodes in Batna, Algeria as a crowd gathered to see Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika. Nineteen people die, while 107 are wounded by the attack.
The Rugby World Cup 2007 starts in France.
Spot price of gold on New York Mercantile Exchange hits $700 per ounce.
Over 50 people die when a car bomb explodes in the Algerian port city of Dellys.
The general election in Guatemala elects the president, vice president, congressmen, municipal mayors, and representatives to Parlacen.
Former leader of Panama Manuel Noriega finishes 15 years in Miami, Florida Prison for drug trafficking.
In Mexico, a truck hauling 25 tons of ammunium nitrate from an explosives plant to a mine crashes, exploding in a huge fireball, killing over 30 people.
In Veracruz state of Mexico, six explosions on gas pipelines disrupt oil and natural-gas supplies to factories and thousands of homes.

In Pakistan, former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrives in Wawalpindi from seven-year exile. Four hours later, he is charged with corruption, arrested, and General Pervez Musharraf expels him to Saudi Arabia.
(to September 30) The 2007 FIFA Women's World Cup is held in China.
(to September 24) Inaugural Twenty20 World Championship is held.
Russia tests the "Father of all bombs," the largest conventional weapon ever.
Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Fradkov and his entire cabinet resign. President Vladimir Putin announces his replacement will be Viktor Zubkov.

In Manila, Philippines, the Sandiganbayan court finds former President Joseph Estrada guilty beyond reasonable doubt on the charges of plunder but acquitted on the charges of perjury. He is sentenced to life imprisonment.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announces his resignation, to be effective September 19.
US dollar falls to new low versus euro: $1.39.
Royal Caribbean Cruises launches new cruise line, CDF CroisiFres de France for the French market.
The Burj Dubai became the world's tallest free standing structure after surpassing the CN Tower in Toronto.
Viktor Zubkov is approved as the new Prime Minister of Russia after a vote in the Duma.
The British government makes a public statement that the Bank of England will provide emergency funding to Scotland's Northern Rock. This begins a bank run by depositors.

Over 3000 Taiwanese Americans and their supporters rally in front of United Nations in New York City to demonstrate the dedication that UN should accept Taiwan. At the same time, over 300,000 Taiwanese people rally in Taiwan to make the same plea.
A stony meteorite estimated with 1m diameter travelling at 24,000 km/h plows into a dry riverbed near Lake Titicaca in Carancas in the Puno region of Peru.
One-Two-GO Airlines Flight 269 crashes in Phuket, Thailand, killing 89 of the passengers and crew.
The bank run on Scotland's Northern Rock ends when chancellor of the exchequer announces all Northern Rock deposits will be 100 percent guaranteed by the British government.
Former prime minister Benazir Bhutto returns to Pakistan after an eight-year self-imposed exile.
The Federal Reserve cuts interest rates in the U.S. by half a point (0.5 percent) for the first time since 2006 to ease the ongoing panic in the financial markets due to the subprime mortgage crisis.
Typhoon Wipha hits Fuding, China. Authorities had evacuated over two million people prior to the storm's landfall.
Opening of the 2007 Universal Forum of Cultures, in the city of Monterrey, Mexico.
The Canadian dollar reaches parity with the American dollar for the first time since 1976.
The Supreme Court of Chile rules that former Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori must be extradited to Peru so Fujimori can face charges of corruption and human rights abuse.
The Dalai Lama visits Chancellor Angela Merkel in Germany.
Yokozuna Hakuho wins the Emperor's Cup at the Autumn Grand Sumo Tournament (Aki Basho) in Tokyo, Japan.
Gordon Brown addresses delegates for the first time as Prime Minister of the UK at Labour Party Conferences in Bournemouth.
India wins the ICC Twenty20 WorldCup beating Pakistan by five runs.

The One Laptop Per Child organization launches the Give 1 Get 1 marketing plan. For US$399, a buyer will purchase two XO computers, receiving one in early 2008, with the other being sent to a child in Cambodia, Rwanda, Afghanistan, or Haiti.
In southern Vietnam the Can Tho Bridge, which is under construction, collapses, killing scores of workers.
Emperor Akihito formally swears in Yasuo Fukuda as the 91st Prime Minister of Japan.
First confirmed deaths resulting from the Myanmar military's crackdown on weeks long anti-government protests. Buddhist monks are arrested and Internet access is cut from the public.
General elections in Ecuador: Acuerdo Pa?s party wins a majority, with leader Rafael Correa.

Parliamentary re-elections occur in Ukraine after Ukrainian President Victor Yuschenko dismisses Parliament. Viktor Yanukovich's party wins most votes, with Yulia Tymoshenko's party then winning 31 percent.
Russian President Vladimir Putin announces he will head the United Russia party's list in the December general election, and he is likely to become Prime Minister in March.
The minimum age for purchasing tobacco products is raised from 16 to 18 across England and Wales.
Citigroup and UBS announce writedowns of US$9.3 billion of debt due to the credit crisis.
(to October 4) For only the second time, South Korean president Roh Moo-hyun meets with North Korea's president King Jong Il, in Pyongyang. Several agreements are made.
Los R?os Region of Chile officially begins its functions as a new region.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng stock market index hits a new high above 28,000.
Hundreds of witnesses report seeing a flaming ball cross the skies of Minnesota, accompanied by a sonic boom, and a rain of debris.
Spanish authorities arrest 22 people associated with the banned Batasuna party which campaigns for Basque independence, but also has ties to the terrorist group ETA.
Merrill Lynch announces it would write off about US$5 billion in investments for the quarter, its largest trading loss ever.
Presidential election occurs in Pakistan. General Pervez Musharraf is re-elected president.
Track and field star Marion Jones surrenders her five Olympic medals she won in the 2000 Sydney Games after admitting to doping.

A consortium of banks (Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander of Spain, and the Dutch-Belgian Fortis bank) announce that shareholders of Dutch bank ABN AMRO have accepted its 72 billion euro (US$101 billion) takeover offer, the world's biggest banking transaction.
SAB Miller and Molson Coors announce a joint venture, MillerCoors, to better compete with Anheuser-Busch in the US market.
An election is held in the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at a high of 14,164.53.
Shares in Criteria Caixa Corp savings bank of Catalan, Spain, are first traded, raising 3.5 billion euros (US$4.9 billion), Spain's largest ever initial public offering.
The Foreign Affairs Committee of the US House of Representatives passes a resolution calling the Ottoman empire's slaughter of Armenians in 1915-23 genocide.
The SuccessTech Academy school shooting occurs in Cleveland, Ohio.
A small private plane crashes into a house in the Fontibon neighborhood near the El Dorado International Airport in Bogot, Colombia, killing five on board and two in the house.
Oracle announces a hostile bid of US$6.7 billion for BEA company.
138 Muslim scholars create a statement appealing for a strategic dialog with Christian leaders.
Local Government Elections are held in New Zealand.
Sir Menzies Campbell resigns as leader of the British Liberal Democrats.
The 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China takes place.
Fox Television Stations Group launches a new business television cable channel in the USA.
Whitehaven, England becomes the first place in the United Kingdom to have one of its analog terrestrial television signals switched off as part of digital switchover.
Turkish parliament votes to allow the government to attack guerillas of the Kurdistan Workers' Party in northern Iraq.
Twin suicide blasts kill 140 people at a rally in Karachi, Pakistan, to welcome back Benazir Bhutto. Bhutto escapes uninjured.
In France, transport, electricity, and gas unions hold a one-day strike in protest of a planned reform of allowing those members to retire at age 50 on full pension, rather than at age 60.
A gas explosion rocks Glorietta, a shopping mall in Makati, Philippines which killed eleven and injured more than 100 people.
Jungle (open) primary election are held for governor and the legislature of the U.S. state of Louisiana.
(to November 9) Wildfires in Southern California result in the evacuation of more than one million people and destruction of over 1,600 homes and businesses. Total damage estimate is US$1 billion.
South Africa defeats England at the Rugby World Cup 2007 final in Stade de France, Paris.
Georgia's governor Sonny Perdue declares a state of emergency due to drought conditions.

Parliamentary elections are held in Poland. Civic Platform party wins 41 percent, 209 seats of 460 member lower house, with leader Donald Tusk. Law and Justice party wins 166 seats, Democratic Left Alliance wins 53, and the People's Party wins 31.

Parliamentary elections are held in Switzerland. Of the 200 seats in the lower house, Swiss People's Party wins 62, Socialists wins 43, Free Democrats wins 31, Christian Democrats wins 31, Liveral Greens wins 23, and the Green Party wins 20.
Kimi RSikknen is crowned world champion as the 2007 Formula One season ends at the Brazilian Grand Prix.
First round of the presidential elections in Slovenia.
Mexico and the USA agree on a plan for the US to pay US$1.4 billion in aid over three years for Mexico to fight drug traffickers.

In the space of a few hours, Comet Holmes develops a coma and flares up to half a million times its former brightness, becoming visible to the naked eye. Its coma later becomes larger in volume than the Sun, making it the second comet to do so in 2007 after Comet McNaught.
Merrill Lynch publishes its third quarter financial results, including a US$8.4 billion write-down resulting from bad mortgage loans. This is the company's first quarterly loss in six years.
The inaugural Caesars Palace Classic poker tournament is won by David Singer, winning US$1 million.
The first Airbus A380 passenger flight, operating for Singapore Airlines, with flight number SQ380, flies scheduled service between Singapore and Sydney, Australia.
Elections in Argentina for the President and members of the National Congress. Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner wins presidential elections and becomes the first female elected president in Argentina.
The Vatican beatifies 498 Spanish victims of religious persecution from before and during the Spanish Civil War.
The Boston Red Sox win the 2007 World Series in a four-game sweep against the Colorado Rockies.
Brazil is announced as the host of the FIFA World Cup 2014.
A bus bomb in the central Russian city of Tolyatti kills eight and injures over 50 people.
World Economic Forum releases The Global Competitiveness Report 2007-2008, at 11:00 CET.

London's Metropolitan Police Service is found guilty of endangering the public following the fatal shooting of Jean Charles de Menezes, an innocent Brazilian who officers mistook for a suicide bomber.
The Election commission of Bangladesh is separated from the Judiciary department.
Martina Hingis of Switzerland announced her second retirement from professional tennis due to doping allegations and injuries.

In California, the Urban Challenge is held, a competition sponsored by the Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency to design a robot car capable of negotiating urban streets and normal traffic. The US$2 million first prize is won by engineers from Carnegie Mellon University for a pilotless Chevrolet Tahoe.
President Pervez Musharraf declares state of emergency in Pakistan, suspends the constitution, the Supreme Court, and provincial high courts.
?lvaro Colom wins the second round of the presidential elections in Guatemala.

Reformation Sunday is observed by Lutherans and other Protestants around the world, to commemorate the 490th anniversary (October 31) of the Ninety-Five Theses, which began the Protestant Reformation.
The Writers Guild of America goes on strike.
A team of nuclear experts begin disabling three of North Korea's nuclear facilities at Yongbyon.
Italian police seize Salvatore Lo Piccolo, his son Alessandro, and two others. Piccolo is the most senior Sicilian Mafia boss, on the run for 24 years.
PetroChina energy producer debuts on the Shanghai stock market. It instantly becomes the world's most valuable company.
A suicide bomber kills at least 50 people in Mazari Sharif, Afghanistan. Among the dead are six members of the National Assembly.
Legislative elections are held in the U.S. states of Kentucky, Mississippi, New Jersey, and Virginia; Kentucky and Mississippi also hold gubernatorial elections.
A 48-hour long state of emergency for Tbilisi is declared by Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili due to the intense anti-government protests that have gripped the capital city.
The Canadian dollar reaches its highest level since the 19th century against the American dollar, at US$1.10.
The German government approves a one-year extension of its participation in Operation Enduring Freedom, in patroling shipping off the Horn of Africa, and within Afghanistan.
The Jokela school shooting occurs. Finnish youth Pekka-Eric Auvinen shoots dead eight people and wounds one at the Jokela School Centre.
BHP Billiton announces plans to acquire Rio Tinto, giving the combined company a market capitalization of about US$360 billion, the biggest merger in history.
The 8th annual Latin Grammy Awards are held at the Mandalay Bay Events Center at Mandalay Bay on the Las Vegas Strip in Paradise, Nevada, USA, near Las Vegas.
China Merchants Bank becomes the third Chinese bank to open a branch in New York.

At the Ibero-American summit in Santiago, Chile, Spain's prime minister JosT Luis Rodriguez Zapatero responds to heckling by Venezuela's president Hugo Chvez by telling him "Why don't you just shut up?".
Slovenians vote in the final round of the nation's presidential elections. Danilo Tnrk won the race with 68.26 percent of the vote.
Parliamentary elections in Denmark. Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen's Center-right coalition wins a third term.

An explosion hits the south wing of the House of Representatives of the Philippines in Quezon City, north of Manila, killing four people, including Basilan Congressman Wahab Akbar, and wounding six others.
High Speed 1 from London to the Channel Tunnel is opened to passengers.
A 7.7 magnitude earthquake occurs in northern Chile.
In France, union strikes begin with railway, bus, and metro workers. The rolling strikes are to protest against President Nicolas Sarkozy's plan to end special regimes for public-sector pensions.
Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries sells a US 24-cent Jenny invert airmail error stamp for US$977,500, a new record for a single stamp.
4,000 people are killed by flooding by Cyclone Sidr in Bangladesh. Cost of damage totals US$2.3 billion.
The Zasyadko mine disaster in eastern Ukraine claims the lives of 101 miners.

The UK's HM Revenue and Customs admits that it has misplaced two computer discs which contain the records of child benefit claimants data, including bank details and National Insurance numbers, in the United Kingdom, leaving up to 7.25 million households susceptible to identity theft.
Senegalese street vendors riot in Dakar after government attempts to ban them from operating in the center of the capital city.
Vladimer Gurgenidze becomes the 17th Prime Minister of Georgia.
The National Australian Football League draft takes place.
Police break up anti-Putin demonstrations in Saint Petersburg and Moscow.
Australian Labor Party wins the federal election in Australia; Labor leader Kevin Rudd is elected to succeed John Howard as Prime Minister of Australia.
Riots continue for a second night in Val-d'Oise, France following the death of two youths in a motorcycle collision with a police vehicle.
A European Parliament election takes place in Romania.
Nawaz Sharif makes a second attempt to return to Pakistan along with his brother Shahbaz Sharif and other family members.
Parliamentary elections are held in Croatia.
The Annapolis Conference, a peace conference trying to end the Arab-Israeli conflict, is held in Annapolis, Maryland in the United States.
United Nations Development Programme releases the 2007/2008 Human Development Report.
President of Pakistan Pervez Musharraf stands down as the head of the Pakistan Army and is succeeded by Lt. General Ashfaq Parvez Kayani.
The Armed Forces of the Philippines lays siege to The Peninsula Manila after soldiers led by Senator Antonio Trillanes stage a mutiny.
The German government mandates a minimum wage for postal workers, the first minimum wage in the country.
Atlasjet Flight 4203 crashes near Ke?iborlu, Turkey, killing all 56 people on board.
The 2007 Atlantic Hurricane Season officially ends.
United Russia party of Vladimir Putin wins parliamentary elections in Russia, increasing their majority with 64 percent of the votes.
Activision and Vivendi Games announce a merger, to be called Activision Blizzard. The US$18.9 billion deal is the biggest ever in the videogame industry.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chvez's proposed changes to the Venezuelan constitution are narrowly defeated in a nationwide referendum. The proposal would make changes to 69 of 350 articles of 1999 constitution to concentrate almost all power in the executive, and instituting socialism.
(to December 14) United Nations Climate Change Conference at Nusa Dua in Bali, Indonesia.
Kevin Rudd is sworn in as the 26th Prime Minister of Australia, by Governor General Major-General Michael Jeffery.
The OECD Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) releases the results of the PISA 2006 survey.
19-year old Robert A. Hawkins shoots eight people dead and injures five at the Westroads Mall in Omaha, Nebraska, then commits suicide.
A pipe bomb explodes in a law office in Paris, France, killing one person.
Uranus' orbit is positioned such that the sun shines directly above its equator (i.e. an equinox).

2007 Africa - European Union Summit takes place as 27 European Union and 53 African Union leaders gather in Lisbon, Portugal, for their first joint summit in seven years, to discuss trade and economic ties. The British and Czech prime ministers boycott the event due to the presence of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe.
In Oruro, Bolivia, part of the constituent assembly accepts 411 new clauses of the constitution.
Seven South American governments agree on the creation of the Banco del Sur, a common development bank for the region.
Canadian Conrad Black is sentenced in Chicago, Illinois, to 6.5 years in jail for embezzling US$6.1 million from his Hollinger media empire.
The United Nations deadline for a negotiated settlement on the future of Kosovo passes without an international agreement.
Music group Led Zeppelin reunites in London, England, for the Ahmet Ertegnn tribute.
In Argentina, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner succeeds husband NTstor Kirchner as president.

In Algiers, Algeria, two bombs explode within ten minutes of each other, the first near a UN office and the other detonated close to the Algerian Supreme Court. The official death count for both blasts stands at 31.
The Society of the Cincinatti badge of George Washington (later owned by the Marquis de Lafayette) is sold at auction by Sotheby's for US$5.3 million.

Election by the Swiss Parliament of Switzerland's highest executive authority, the Swiss Federal Council (seven members). All the sitting members are confirmed, except Christoph Blocher, who in an upset is replaced by Eveline Widmer-Schlumpf. This is only the sixth time in Swiss history a sitting member is not reconfirmed.
The US Federal Reserve, the Bank of England, the European Central Bank, the Bank of Canada, and the Swiss National Bank announce a joint plan to ease liquidity crisis in global money markets.
Former US Senator George J. Mitchell publicly releases a report accusing 88 retired and active Major League Baseball players of anabolic steroid use.
European leaders sign the Treaty of Lisbon in Lisbon, Portugal.
Entry into force of the revised version of the European Patent Convention (EPC), known as the EPC 2000.
European Union leaders attend a formal summit in Brussels, Belgium.
(to December 24) FAI World Grand Prix Gliding Championship at Omarama, New Zealand.
The World Bank convinces 45 countries to give it US$25 billion to hand out to the world's poorest states over the next three years.
President of Pakistan Pervez Musharraf lifts the State of Emergency in Pakistan.
Turkish aircraft bomb Kurdish rebel positions deep inside northern Iraq, and 300 troops cross the border in pursuit of fighters of the Kurdistan Workers' Party.
British military hands over control of Basra province to Iraqi security forces.
The Caribbean Forum of fifteen member states signs a trade agreement with the European Union.
The International Finance Corporation of the World Bank unveils a US$1 billion health-care strategy for Africa.
Jacob Zuma is elected president of the African National Congress political party in South Africa during the party's national conference.
The European Central Bank lends 350 billion euros to banks.
The Verkhovna Rada (parliament) approves Yulia Tymoshenko to become Prime Minister of Ukraine by a one-vote margin.
An explosion and fire at the T2 Laboratories facility in Jacksonville, Florida kills four and injures 14.
Vladimir Putin, President of Russia, is announced as Time magazine's 2007 Person of the Year.
A presidential election takes place in South Korea. Former mayor of Seoul Lee Myung-bak, of the Grand National Party, wins with 50 percent of the vote against two other major opponents.
An earthquake of magnitude 6.6 ML hits the east coast of the North Island of New Zealand, causing one death and significant damage in the town of Gisborne.
A group of activist Lakota Indians send a letter to the United States State Department declaring their secession from the Union.
The Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia join the Schengen border-free zone.
Queen Elizabeth II becomes the oldest-ever monarch of the United Kingdom, surpassing Queen Victoria, who lived for 81 years, 7 months and 29 days.
In Nepal, parliament votres almost unanimously to abolish the 240-year-old monarchy.
A general election is held in Thailand. The People's Power Party, which is associated with former Prime Minster Thaksin Shinawatra, wins a majority of seats (233 of 480) in the parliament.
The Nepalese government announces that the country's 240-year-old monarchy will be abolished in 2008 and a new republic will be declared.
Queen Elizabeth II broadcasts her 50th televised Royal Christmas Message to the Commonwealth.
An escaped tiger at the San Francisco Zoo kills one person and injures two others.
An overcrowded suspension bridge collapses near Nepalgunj, Nepal. At least 15 people are dead, with 100 to 200 missing.
Presidential and parliamentary elections take place in Kenya. Mwai Kibaki re-elected President. Accusations of wide-spread rigging on both sides leads to hundreds of deaths.

At an election rally in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, former President Benazir Bhutto, leader of opposition Pakistan People's Party, is assassinated. At least 20 others are killed by a bomb blast. Ensuing violence leaves about 60 dead.
After defeating the New York Giants 38-35, the New England Patriots become the second team in NFL history to finish the regular season undefeated.
Kenya's electoral commission head declares Mwai Kibaki president, then he is sworn in as president at the State House.

In Baltimore, Maryland, USA, the Baltimore Ravens fire long-time head coach Brian Billick, after finishing a disappointing 5-win, 11-loss season. Billick spent nine seasons in Baltimore and was the Ravens' most successful coach with an 85-67 record.
Over 200 people are killed in Kenya due to riots over the results of the presidential election which occurred on December 27.
The massive Big Dig construction project in Boston, Massachusetts ends.

At the Ralph Wilson Stadium in Buffalo, New York, the first regular-season outdoor NHL hockey game in the US is held. 71217 fans watch the 2008 Winter Classic, in which the Buffalo Sabres play the Pittsburgh Penguins, running into overtime, and ending with a shoot-out with the Penguins winning.
The United Nations' African Mission in Darfur takes over peacekeeping duty from the African Union.
A suicide bombing occurs in Zayouna, Baghdad, killing over 25 people during a funeral over the deaths from the preceding attack.
Venezuela redenominates its currency at one bolivar fuerte to 1000 bolivars. Seven new coins are issued, from 1 centimo through 1 bolivar fuerte.
Cyprus and Malta adopt the euro currency.
Jeff Bewkes is new chief executive officer of Time Warner.
The Gulf Cooperation Council common market officially begins.
Slovenia begins six-month term of presidency of the European Union.
Price of crude oil in the USA reaches US$100 per barrel for the first time.
In London, England, price of gold reaches a record US$861.10 per troy ounce, passing the previous high of $850 in January 1980. Platinum also rises to a record high $1,544 per ounce.
A car bomb detonates, killing at least 4 and injuring 68, in Diyarbakir, Turkey. Police blame Kurdish rebels.
In Venezuela, President Hugo Chavez announces a major cabinet reshuffle, naming Ramon Carrizales vice-president, and making 12 other cabinet changes.

In Iowa, USA, the Democratic caucuses choose Barack Obama as candidate for the presidential election on November. National front-runner Hillary Clinton places third, behind John Edwards. The Republican caucuses choose Mike Huckabee over Mitt Romney.
Rare snow flurries in southeast Florida, USA.

In the USA, Warner Bros studio announces it will drop support for the HD DVD video disc format on June 1, and will exclusively release high-definition DVDs in Sony's Blu-ray format. Warner Bros is Hollywood's biggest seller of DVDs, representing about 19 percent of sales in the United States.
Georgia presidential election: 52 percent vote for Mikhail Saakashvili.
General elections in the Marshall Islands. With 18 seats of the 33-member administration, Litokwa Tomeing defeats Kessai Note to become new president.
In New Hampshire, USA, the Democratic caucuses choose Hillary Clinton as candidate for the presidential election on November. The Republican caucuses choose John McCain.

An attempted assassination of Maldivian president Maumoon Abdul Gayoom is thwarted after a Boy Scout grabs the attacker's knife. The Boy Scout is injured, but after a scuffle police arrest the attacker.
The government of China announces tighter price controls on a range of products.
70-car pileup along Interstate 4 in Florida, USA, due to fog and smoke. Five deaths.
In Colombia, FARC releases two former Colombian politician women hostages held captive in the country for six years: Clara Rojas and Consuela Gonzlez de Perdomo.

In Auckland, New Zealand, Sir Edmund Hillary dies of a heart attack in hospital at age 88. He was the first man to climb to the peak of Mount Everest, in 1953, knighted by Queen Elizabeth II, and made an honorary Nepali citizen.
Parliamentary elections are held in Taiwan, resulting in a landslide victory for Ma Ying-jeau's Kuomintang party.
A Macedonian Army Mil Mi-17 helicopter crashes in thick fog southeast of Skopje, killing all 11 military personnel on board.
In Venezuela, the Unified Socialist party for Venezuela is launched, under leadership of Hugo Chvez.
Toshiba America Consumer Products cuts prices of its HD DVD players by between 40 and 50 percent, putting its range of prices at US$149 to US$399.
U.S. researchers in Chicago, Illinois, report that new genetic evidence supports the theory that Christopher Columbus brought syphilis to Europe from the New World, in 1495.
In London, England, price of gold reaches a record US$910 per troy ounce, Platinum also rises to a record high $1,590.50 per ounce. Silver reaches US$16.80 per ounce, highest in 27 years.
A group of Taliban suicide bombers attack Serena Hotel in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing eight staff and guests.

In Scotland, the University of Edinburgh unveils the fastest computer in the United Kingdom, the HECToR (High-End Computing Terascale Resource). It can make 63 million calculations per second. The computer was made by American manufacturer Cray, at a cost of 113 million pounds.
The Board of Control for Cricket in India sells broadcasting rights to the Indian Premier league for US$1 billion.
A Polish 1621 gold 100-ducat coin of King Sigismund III sells for US$1,380,000 by Stack's auctioneers in New York City, a world record price for a non-US coin.

The U.S. space agency's MESSENGER (Mercury Surface, Space Environment, Geochemistry and Ranging) probe passes about 126 miles over Mercury. This is the first spacecraft since 1975 to fly past the planet.
Israel and the Palestinians open peace negotiations, the first final-status talks since 2001.
A general election is held in Barbados. David Thompson and the Democratic Labour Pary win with 20 of the 30 parliamentary seats.
The Federal Court of Australia orders a Japanese whaling company to stop research whaling within their Exclusive Economic Zone.
The governments of Singapore, Kuwait, and South Korea invest US$21 billion in American finance companies Citigroup and Merrill Lynch through sovereign-wealth funds.
In Michigan, USA, the Rupublican caucuses choose Mitt Romney as candidate for the presidential election on November.
In India, Reliance Power raises a record 115 billion rupees (US$2.9 billion) in the first minute of stock trading.
In Boston, Massachusetts, USA, Oracle Corp announces it will acquire BEA Systems for US$8.5 billion in cash.
Israel closes the border with Gaza due to a rise in Qassam rockets hitting towns.
Reverend Ian Paisley resigns from the Free Presbyterian Church which he founded 56 years ago.
In New York City, New York, a federal judge sentences Canadian Mohammed Mansour Jabarah to life in prison for plotting to bomb U.S. embassies in Singapore and the Philippines.

French bank SociTtT GTnTrale discovers that stock trader JTr?me Kerviel had managed to defraud the bank of 4.9 million euros (US$7.1 billion) through bad bets on stock futures. This is the biggest trading scandal in banking history.
Stock market share prices worldwide drop in the worst day of trading since September 11, 2001.
The U.S. Federal Reserve reduces the federal funds rate by 0.75 points, to 3.5 percent, the largest single drop in 23 years.

Russia stages the largest naval exercise since the fall of the Soviet Union in the Bay of Biscay. The Russian aircraft carrier Admiral Kuznetsov, along with 11 support vessels and 47 long-range bomber aircraft, practises strike tactics off the coast of France and Spain, and test-launches nuclear-capable missiles in foreign waters.
Polish Air Force EADS CASA C-295 crashes on approach to the 12th Air Base near Miroslawiec. All 20 personnel on board die.
Palestinians blast holes in the metal wall along Gaza-Egypt border. Tens or hundreds of thousands of Palestinians pour through to buy supplies in Egypt.
Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi resigns after losing a no-confidence vote in the Senate.
A peace deal ends the Kivu war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
The Board of Control for Cricket in India announces it has sold eight ten-year franchises in the Indian Premier League for a total of US$723 million.
In Las Vegas, Nevada, USA, the Monte Carlo Resort & Casino is evacuated due to a fire which engulfed parts of the upper floors, facade and roof before being brought under control.
In South Africa, several large producers of gold, platinum, coal, and diamonds shut down their underground mines due to uncertainties in the electricity supply.
China's worst snowstorm since 1954 kills 133, delays traffic, and causes massive power outages in central and southern parts of the country.
In South Carolina, USA, the Democratic caucuses choose Barack Obama as candidate for the presidential election on November. The Republican caucuses choose John McCain.
In Florida, USA, the Rupublican caucuses choose John McCain as candidate for the presidential election on November. The Democratic caucuses choose Hillary Clinton.
Iran's judiciary sentences to prison 54 Bah'? Faith followers for 'anti-regime propaganda'.
Microsoft offers to buy Yahoo for US$44.6 billion: US$31 per share in cash and stock.
In Baghdad, Iraq, two suicide bombers kill 72 people, wounding another 149.
In Dambulla, Sri Lanka, a bomb explodes on a civilian bus, killing 18 people and wounding 50.
French President Nicolas Sarkozy marries model Carla Bruni.
Rebels attack the capital of Chad, N'Djamena.

In Glendale, Arizona, the NFL's Super Bowl XLII is played. The New York Giants beat the previously undefeated New England Patriots with a 17-14 victory. Most Valuable Player is Giants' Quarterback Eli Manning.
Boris Tadic is re-elected president of Serbia.

U.S. President George W. Bush unveils a record US$3.1 trillion spending plan for fiscal 2009, including US$515 billion for military spending, and US$70 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan for just part of 2009. Domestic programs would be deeply cut. The budget is the first to be presented electronically.
In Colombia, over one million people protest in the streets against FARC, the largest demonstration in the country's history.
A Palestinian suicide bomber kills one and wounds 13 in a Dimona, Israel shopping center.
Texas Tech University basketball coach Bob Knight resigns. He had coached for 42 years, presiding over 902 winning games, a record among US men's college basketball coaches.
Iran opens its first space center and launches a rocket into space.
(to February 6) A tornado outbreak, the deadliest in 23 years, kills 58 in the Southern United States.
U.S. stock market indices plunge more than 3 percent after a report shows signs of economic recession in the service sector. The S&P 500 fall 3.2 percent, The Dow Jones Industrial Average 370 points.

In the USA, 24 states hold Republican and/or Democratic caucus elections for presidential nominee. This day is referred to as "Super Tuesday". For the Democrats, Barack Obama wins in 12, Hillary Clinton wins in 7 For the Republicans, John McCain wins in 8 states, Mitt Romney wins in 6, and Mike Huckabee wins in 5.
In Kenya, the death toll reaches 1000 in the crisis over a disputed election in December.
Over 60 tornadoes across the US South in two days kill 48 and injure over 150.
New lunar year 4705, Year of the Rat to the Chinese system of Earthly Branches.
In the USA, the Supreme Court of Nebraska rules the electric chair is unconstitutional (cruel and unusual). This is the last state in the country to have allowed death by the electric chair.
At a Philip Weiss auction, a 24-cent US postage stamp of 1869, Declaration of Independence with inverted-center error sells for US$1.27 million, a new record for a single US stamp.
Fire severely damages Namdaemun, the first National Treasure of South Korea.
In Honolulu, Hawaii, the NFL Pro Bowl game is held. NFC beats AFC 42 to 30. Most Valuable Player award goes to Adrian Peterson.
In Timor-Leste, rebels battle presidential guards at the president's home. President JosT Ramos-Horta is shot and wounded. Rebel leader Alfredo Reinado and another rebel are killed.

In Los Angeles and New York, film and television writers vote to lift their 100-day-old strike against major studios and return to work. Writers Guild of America members voted 92.5 percent in favor of ending the strike, with a new three-year contract approved in principle.
At the International Space Station, the Columbus laboratory module built by the Europe Space Agency is installed and opened for the first time.

Bridgestone, under investigation for an alleged price-fixing cartel, uncovers improper payments of at least 150 million Japanese yen to foreign governments and withdraws from the marine hose business.
In the USA, General Motors reports a fiscal 2007 year loss of US$39 billion.
PDVSA, a state oil company in Venezuela, suspends sales of crude oil to ExxonMobil, in response to a legal challenge by them.

In Damascus, Syria, Hezbollah leader Imad Moughniyah is killed by a car bomb attack. Moughniyah was an elusive international terrorist of 25 years, accused or convicted of many high-profile bombings in the 1980s.
Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia delivers a formal apology to the Stolen Generations.
US President George Bush signs a law for individual tax rebates and temporary investment incentives worth US$168 billion.
Swiss bank UBS announces a fourth quarter 2007 loss of 12.5 billion Swiss Frances (US$11.3 billion).
At Northern Illinois University, former student Stephen Kazmierczak fires over 50 shots, killing five students and himself, injuring 16 others.
Cook County Circuit Court in Chicago, Illinois, declares missing millionaire adventurer Steve Fossett legally dead, five months after the airplane he was flying disappeared over Nevada.
In New York, Wal-Mart Stores announces it will exclusively sell high-definition DVDs in the Blu-Ray format. Sales of HD DVD systems and drives will be phased out until June.
The spot price of platinum closes at over $2000 for the first time, at $2060.
In Daytona, Florida, the 50th NASCAR Daytona 500 race is held. Winner is Ryan Newman of Penske Racing.
Hallmark/Westland Meat Packing Company recalls 143 million pounds of beef, the USA's largest meat recall in California, due to the slaughter of cattle unfit for human consumption.
British central bank chancellor announces the Northern Rock bank would be nationalized.
Kosovo Albanians declare independence of Serbia.
A suicide bombing by a Taliban member kills up to 80 in Kandahar, Afghanistan.
The British government introduces emergency legislation to temporarily nationalize Northern Rock, the fifth largest mortgage bank in the UK, due to the bank's financial crisis.
General elections are held in Pakistan. The Pakistan People's Party is first by votes (88 of 268 seats), with leader Asif Zardari.
Europe's major powers and the United States recognize the independence of Kosovo.
In Cuba, President and commander-in-chief Fidel Castro steps down, turning over power to brother Raul.
A fireball and sonic boom are reported in parts of Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana, and British Columbia.
Armenia presidential elections: Serzh Sarkisian wins 53 percent of votes.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average removes Altria Group Incorporated and Honeywell International Incorporated from its index, replacing them with Bank of America Corporation and Chevron Corporation.
Toshiba of Japan announces it is giving up on its HD DVD format.
In Wisconsin and Hawaii, Democratic caucuses Barack Obama over Hillary Clinton for Presidential candidate. John McCain wins Wisconsin on the Republican side.
A total lunar eclipse crosses North and South America, Europe, Africa, and Southwest Asia.

A U.S. Navy warship neat Hawaii fires a missile at a defunct spy satellite 153 miles up in the atmosphere, to destroy the fuel tank of hydrazine fuel, to prevent it from being released as a toxic gas if it had fallen to Earth.
In Belgrade, Serbia, rioters storm the US embassy and set it on fire. British, German, Croatian, and Turkish embassies are also attacked.
Thousands of Turkish troops cross into northern Iraq to hunt Kurdish rebels. This is the largest such incursion in ten years.
In a court in Yunan, China, four men plead guilty to producing fake receipts valued at 1.05 trillion yuan (US$147 billion), the largest scan in China since 1949.

No survivors are found after a rescue helicopter discovers the wreckage of Santa Brbara Airlines Flight 518 just northeast of MTrida, Venezuela. The commercial plane had 46 people on board, including crew.
Former building society Northern Rock is the first bank in Europe to be taken into state control, due to the U.S. subprime mortgage financial crisis.
Microsoft announces it will cease making HD DVD players for the Xbox 360.
In Saarland, Germany, shifting coal mine workings trigger an earthquake measuring 4.0. Work is suspended pending an investigation of safety of re-opening.
Electronic Arts video game company makes a hostile bid of US$2 billion for Take-Two.
In Cuba, Ra?l Castro is formally designated to succeed brother Fidel Castro as head of the Council of State.
In Cyprus, Demetris Christofias of the Communist Akel party wins the presidential election with 53.4 percent of votes.
A man in Yorkshire, England, wins 1 million pounds on a 50 pence bet on horse racing, by selecting all eight winners of races throughout the country.
Lee Myung-bak is sworn in as South Korea's new president.
Sotheby's reports 2007 sales of US$6.2 billion, a 51 percent increase above 2006. A record 748 works sold for over US$1 million each.

The European Commission fines Microsoft 899 million euros (US$1.35 billion) for using high prices to discourage software competition, in defiance of a 2004 order from Brussels to provide the information on reasonable terms.

In the jungle of Colombia, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) free four Colombian hostages taken six years ago to Red Cross helicopters from Venezeula, in a deal brokered by Venezuela's President Hugo Chavez.
In the USA, the Fannie Mae government-backed mortgage company reports a loss of US$3.55 billion for the fourth quarter of 2007, due to increased foreclosures.
The US dollar drops to an all-time low against the euro, at 66 cents.
The European Court of Human Rights rules unanimously that a government may not deport an individual to a state where he may be at risk of torture.

In Kenyan, President Mwai Kibaki and opposition leader Raila Odinga sign a deal setting up a coalition government. Odinga will become prime minister with wide-ranging executive powers, cabinet posts will be shared, and the constitution will be amended to formalize power-sharing.

A report by the Pew Center on the United States says the American penal system held more than 2.3 million adults at the start of the year, meaning more than one in every 100 American adults is confined in a prison or jail, the highest ratio in the nation's history. The report also notes that the United States incarcerates more people than any other country in the world.
Thaksin Shinawatra returns to Thailand from exile since 2006 military coup deposed him.
In Gaza Strip, at least 52 Palestinians and two Israeli soldiers are killed in the most intense Israeli air strikes since 2005.
The 59-acre Aquatica water park opens at Sea World in Orlando, Florida, USA.
Venezuela and Ecuador move troops to the Colombian border, following a Colombian raid against FARC guerrillas inside Ecuador's national territory.
Intel announces the name for its new low-power microprocessor family: "Atom".
The Isle of Man releases a triangular coin containing sand from the tomb of Egyptian pharoah Tutankhamun.
Dmitry Medvedev is elected President of Russia with 72 percent of total votes, to succeed Vladimir Putin in May.
Russian energy company Gazprom cuts gas supplies to Naftogaz in the Ukraine by 25 percent, in a dispute over debts owed to the company.
The board of Porsche Automobil Holdings approves Porsche acquiring a further 20 percent of Volkswagen giving it a controlling majority of 51 percent.
Volkswagen announces it is taking over Swedish truck-maker Scania for 2.9 billion euro (US$4.4 billion) increasing its stake from 31 percent to 68.6 percent.
Venezuela and Ecuador cut diplomatic ties with Colombia, following Colombian bombing raids inside Ecuador to kill a leftist rebel.
The United Nations' Security Council votes in favor of increasing economic sanctions against Iran for refusing to suspend nuclear enrichment and other sensitive activities.
Reverend Ian Paisley announces he will stand down in May as Northern Ireland's first minister and leader of Democratic Unionists.
Platinum hits a record high of US$2273 per ounce on the London spot market.
Russian energy company Gazprom cuts gas supplies to the Ukraine by a further 25 percent.
A large meteor fireball over southern Ontario, Canada is captured on video by The Physics and Astronomy Department at Western.
In Germany, members of the Verdi union stage a work strike, grounding flights at airports.
Russian energy company Gazprom restores gas supplies to Naftogaz in the Ukraine.
In Baghdad, Iraq, two bomb attacks in a shopping area leave over 50 dead and 130 injured.
Eight Israeli civilians are killed and 9 wounded when a Palestinian attacker opens fire at a Jewish seminary in Jerusalem.
A dozen tornadoes cause much damage in northern Florida and southern Georgia. Cars are flipped, trees and power poles knocked down, homes and businesses damaged, and two people are killed.
A summit is held in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador and Nicaragua re-establish diplomatic relations.
The US Federal Reserve promises to provide up to US$200 billion in temporary loans to banks and bond-market dealers.
A meteorite (black, 3kg, 40cm diameter) falls in a thunderous crash in Yaka, Turkey.
Elections in Malaysia: the National Front coalition wins election in the federal parliament and 8 of 13 state assemblies, but loses its 2/3 majority in Parliament.
General elections in Spain, for 350 members of the Cortes, the lower house of parliament: Socialist Party wins 169 seats, with leader JosT Luis Rodr?guez. Popular Party wins 153 seats.
The Pakistan People's Party and Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz agree to work together to form a government.

At the Kourou spaceport in French Guiana, the Automated Transfer Vehicle is launched aboard an Ariane 5 rocket into space. The unmanned European Space Agency cargo freighter is on a mission to resupply the International Space Station.
Michael Todd, Chief Constable of Greater Manchester Police, United Kingdom, is found dead on Bwlch Glas mountain in north Wales.
In Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi is sworn in as Prime Minister by the King.
Great balls of fire are seen falling from the sky over Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
Two suicide blasts in Lahore, Pakistan, kill 24, injuring over 100.
The US Federal Reserve promises to lend up to US$200 billion of Treasury bonds on a monthly basis with mortgage-backed securities as collateral.
Oil hits a record US$110 per barrel.
The US dollar drops below 100 Japanese yen for the first time in 12 years, and gold rises to US$1000 per ounce.
A meteorite is videotaped hitting the Moon.
Violent riots occur in Lhasa, Tibet, against Chinese presence.

A huge gun factory explosion in G?rdec, Albania kills more than 30 people. Over the following week, Albania, Kosovo, and some surrounding countries supply and support G?rdec's population with food, blood, etc.
In China, Hu Jintao is elected for another five-year term as president. Hu Jintao is also re-elected chairman of the Central Military Commission. Xi Jinping won election as vice-president.
In the Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill, Tiger Woods sinks a 24-foot putt on the 18th hole to win with 10 under par.

American investment bank Bear Stearns, 5th largest on Wall Street, is bought by JP Morgan Chase for $2 per share, a total of $236 million. In mid-2006, Bear Stearns was worth $200 per share. The Federal Reserve also provides a US$30 billion loan, and announces it will directly loan to other investment banks and brokers.
Price of an ounce of silver peaks at US$20.92.
Price of gold hits a record US$1011.25 per ounce on the London market.
The US dollar hits an all-time low of US$1.59 to the euro.
Share prices of American investment bank Lehman Brothers lose 20 percent of value on the stock market.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes 420 points higher than the previous day.
The London PM fix for spot price of gold closes at US$1006.75 per ounce.
The US Federal Reserve cuts the interest rate by a further 0.75, down to 2.25 percent.
An exploding star halfway across the visible universe becomes the farthest known object ever visible to the naked eye.
French President Nicolas Sarkozy announces France will reduce its number of airborne nuclear weapons by one third, to fewer than 300.
A magnitude 7.3 earthquake occurs in the northwest region of Xinjiang province in China, with aftershocks of 5.1 and 5.2 within half an hour.

In Taiwan (Republic of China), the presidential election is held. Opposition candidate Ma Ying-jeou, of the Kuomintang party, wins with nearly 17 percentage points ahead of Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Two referendums on joining the United Nations fail due to less than 50 percent voter turnout.
In a bingo hall in Coatbridge, north Lanarkshire, Scotland, a woman wins a record 1,167,795 pounds (US$2.3 million) in the National Bingo Game.
US soldier death toll in the Iraq war reaches 4000, after five years of fighting.
In Greece, the Olympic torch begins its journey to Beijing, China.
In northern Chile, a 6.1 magnitude earthquake strikes.
First election in Bhutan, with turnout of 80 percent of 320,000 registered voters. Druk Phuensum Tshogpa party wins 44 of 47 seats, with leader Jigme Thinley.

In Iowa City, Iowa, USA, former bank executive Steven Sueppel, facing trial for embezzlement, beats to death his wife Sheryl Sueppel and the couple's four adopted children, then kills himself by ramming his car into a highway sign post.
The American Major League Baseball Season opens, with the Boston Red Sox beating Oakland Athletics 6-5 in Japan.
African Union and Comoros forces invade the rebel-held island of Anjouan.
In western Austria, over 60 vehicles are involved in a highway accident, caused by poor visibility in a major snowstorm. One person is dead, 30 are injured.
A 414 square kilometre (160 square mile) chunk of Antarctica's Wilkins Ice Shelf disintegrates, leaving the entire shelf at risk.
Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf swears in new prime minister Yousaf Raza Gilani.
Top commander Pedro Antonio Mar?n (Manuel Marulanda) of Colombian leftist rebel group FARC dies of a heart attack at age 78.
Advanced Micro Devices unveils the "Phenom" microprocessor for desktop personal computers.
Tata Motors of India announces it will buy Jaguar and Land Rover from Ford Motor of the USA for US$2.3 billion.
Terminal 5 opens at Heathrow airport in London, England.

In Zimbabwe, general elections are held. After recounts, the Zanu-PF party of President Robert Mugabe fails to regain its parliamentary majority. Opposition party MDC and a smaller faction win a combined 109 seats, compared to 97 for the Zanu-PF. Morgan Tsvangirai of the Movement for Democratic Change receives 47.9 percent of votes for president, Robert Mugabe receives 43.2 percent.
In Vietnam, the Ho Chi Minh City's stock market's value is 44 percent lower than the value of January 1.
Pernod Ricard, French drink company, wins an auction to buy Sweden's Vin & Sprit company for 5.6 billion euros (US$8.9 billion).

UBS, Switzerland's largest bank and world's biggest wealth manager, announces write-downs on American mortgage-backed securities of US$37 billion, resulting in a first quarter loss of 12 billion Swiss francs. Chairman Marcel Ospel announces his resignation.

Namibia's Namdeb diamond company discovers a shipwreck off the coast of Namibia. Three bronze cannons are dated to 16th century Spain; other objects recovered are thousands of Spanish and Portuguese gold coins, and several tonnes of elephant tusks.
Liam Tancock of Exeter, England, sets new world record 50m backstroke of 24.47 seconds, at Pond's Forge, Sheffield, England.
At the Intel Developer Forum in Shanghai, China, Intel introduces the low-power Atom microprocessor, in speeds up to 1.86 GHz.
Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahein announces his resignation, effective May 6.
ATA Airlines of the USA files for bankruptcy for the second time in 5 years and ceases all operations.

In Geneva, Switzerland, a used block of 39 of Norway's first stamp, the 1855 4-skilling blue Coat of Arms, sells at auction for 1.4 million euros (US$2.2 million). An unused 1851 Baden unused 9-kreuzer stamp on blue-green paper sells for 1.3 million euros.
In Miami, Florida, American Serena Williams defeats Serbia's Jelena Jankovic 6-1, 5-7, 6-3 to win the Sony Ericsson Open for the fifth time.
In Argentina, a meteor is witnessed falling in flames of changing colors, crashing in Entre Rios Province.
In San Antonio, Texas, the Kansas Jayhawks defeat the Memphis Tigers 75-68 in overtime to win their first NCAA basketball national championship in 20 years.

Child Protective Services of Texas remove 401 children from a ranch in west Texas belonging to jailed polygamist leader Warren Jeffs, and dozens of women leave or are removed in an investigation of sexual and child abuse.
The International Monetary Fund announces plans to cut costs (380 jobs) and sell 403 tonnes of its gold reserves, to raise about US$17 billion.

A British inquiry in to the deaths of Princess Diana and Dodi al-Fayed concludes the pair were unlawfully killed by the grossly negligent driving of their chauffeur and paparazzi photographers pursuing them into a Paris road tunnel ten years ago. The inquiry cost 10 million pounds (US$20 million).
Privy Council of Sark dismantles its feudal system to comply with the European Convention on Human Rights. The first elections under the new law will be held in December 2008.
The Venezuelan government announces it will re-nationalize the Sidor steel complex.
Kosovo's parliament adopts a new constitution, which is to come into force on June 15.
US intelligences sources report the death of Abu Obaidah al-Masri, the militant chief of al-Qaeda in Afghanistan, within the last two months.
General elections in South Korea: Lee Myung-bak's Grand National Party wins 153 of 299 seats in the National Assembly.

In London, England, a 12th century key to Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine in Mecca, sells at Sotheby's auction for ?9.2 million (US$18.1 million), a record for the sale of an Islamic work of art. Sotheby's Islamic art sale realises more than ?21.5 million in total.
Nepal general elections: Communist Party of Nepal wins, with leader Pushpa Kamal Dahal.

In Augusta, Georgia, the final round of the U.S. Masters golf tournament is held. Trevor Immelman wins by three shots over Tiger Woods, with a score of 75, the first South African to win the U.S. Masters in 30 years.
In Montevideo, Uruguay, 1250 people grill 26,400 pounds (12 metric tonnes) of beef, setting a new Guinness world record.

Passenger train service between Calcutta, India, and Dhaka, capital of Banglasdesh, resumes for the first time since service was cut in 1965 due to the war between India and Pakistan. Bangladesh was East Pakistan at the time.
Delta Air Lines announces it will acquire Northwest Airlines for US$3 billion in stock, creating the world's biggest airline.
Italian general election: Silvio Berlusconi wins election as prime minister for the third time. His People of Freedom Party wins 413 of 630 seats in the lower chamber.
Vladimir Putin accepts an invitation to become leader of the ruling United Russia party.
In Goma, Congo, a Hewa Bora Airways McDonnell Douglas DC-9 plane crashes into a market district, killing at least 33 people and injuring 80.
Suicide bombings in three cities in Iraq (Baquba, Ramadi, and Mosul) kill over 70.
A fireball with fluctuating colors is observed over Entre R?os, Argentina. Vast brush fires reported the following day in Buenos Aires and Entre R?os may have been caused by the meteor exploding.
Heritage Auction Galleries auctions the Queller Collection. The Mickley specimen of the Class I US 1804 dollar sells for $3,737,500.
US President George Bush announces an initiative to have American greenhouse gas emissions peak by 2025.
Pope Benedict XVI makes his first official visit to the US, welcomed by President George Bush at Andrews Air Force Base.
Raila Odinga becomes the new Prime Minister of Kenya after the formation of a coalition government, ending the political crisis in Kenya.

In Tokyo, Japan, a high school regional baseball game is halted in the second inning, after one team had scored 66 runs. The coach of the losing team asked for the game to end to spare his pitcher's arm, with over 250 pitches already thrown.
European Poker Tour Grand Final at the Monte Carlo Bay Hotel Casino Resort in Monte Carlo, Monaco. Winner is Glen Chorny, collecting US$3,193,822.
Heritage Auction Galleries sells at auction a USA 1804 Draped Bust dollar coin for US$3,737,500.
Iran displays its military power at a ceremony to mark the country's annual army day. President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad says Iran is the most powerful nation in the world.
A suicide bomber strikes a funeral in northern Iraq, killing 50 and wounding 55.
A 5.2-5.4-magnitude earthquake rocks Illinois, USA, centered near West Salem, the largest in the region in 40 years, and felt 350 miles away.
In Quito, Ecuador, a nightclub fire started by fireworks kills 14.

Robert Cheruiyot of Kenya wins his fourth Boston Marathon, with a time of 2:07:46. In the Woman's Marathon, Dire Tune of Ethiopia finishes in 2:25:25, beating Alevtina Bittimirova by two seconds, in the closest finish in the history of the race. Each winner earned a prize of US$150,000, the biggest in major marathon history.
The Walt Disney Company announces the launch of a new film label, Disneynature, dedicated to producing wildlife and environmental documentaries.
