In Montreal, Quebec, Canada, a riot following the Montreal Canadiens' Game 7 win over the Boston Bruins breaks out on Ste-Catherine Street West, resulting in sixteen police cruisers torched a dozen stores vandalized, and sixteen arrests.
In Paris, France, city hall makes visiting Dalai Lama an honorary citizen.

Bank of America, the largest American retail bank, reports a 77 percent decline in the quarter ending March 31, the third straight quarterly loss. The loss included over US$5 billion in write-downs and credit-related costs.
Surgeons at London's Moorfields Eye Hospital perform the first operations using bionic eyes, implanting them into two blind patients.
John Smoltz of the Atlanta Braves becomes the 16th Major League Baseball pitcher to record 3000 career strikeouts.
In general and provincial elections in South Africa, winner is Jacob Zuma of the African National Congress party with 66 percent of votes.
In Abbortsford, British Columbia, Canada, a church hall packed with 1200 guests collapses during a Christian rock concert, injuring over 40 people.
A fire at a mattress factory in Casablanca, Morocco, kills 55 people.
The Taliban attempts to assassinate Afghan President Hamid Karzai in a military parade in Kabul.
India sets a world record by sending ten satellites into orbit in a single launch.

Mars Incorporated and Berkshire Hathaway team up to buy chewing gum manufacturer Wm Wrigley Jr Company for US$23 billion, creating the world's largest confectionery company. Warren Buffet will loan US$4.4 billion for 20 percent stake in Wrigley.
A Ukrainian Mi-8 helicopter crashes onto an offshore drilling platform in the Black Sea, killing all 20 people on board.

Two passenger trains collide in eastern China, killing at least 70 people and injuring hundreds. The crash, the worst in China since 1997, was caused by human error, with one train travelling much faster than the speed limit.
The skeletal remains of Alexei Nikolaevich and one of his sisters (possibly Anastasia) are found in Ekaterinburg, Russia.

A US navy ship off the coast of Somalia makes a missile attack on the home of Aden Hashi Ayro in Dusamareb, killing him and at least ten other people. Ayro was military leader of al-Shabab, in control of most of Somalia.
Near the tip of the Aleutian island chain off Alaska, a 6.5 magnitude earthquake occurs.
In Havana, Cuba, hundreds of thousands of Cubans attend a May Day parade.
Great Britain's Labor Party suffers worst election defeat on record, losing 331 councilors in local elections to the opposition Conservatives, who gained 256.
In Diyala province of Iraq, two suicide bombers detonate themselves in a market in Balad Ruz, killing at least 35 people and injuring 65.
In the Patagonia region of Chile, volcano Chaiten begins erupting for the first time in over 9000 years. Two nearby towns are completely evacuated.

A plane crashes in southern Sudan, killing at least 22, including Sudan's defence minister Dominic Dim Deng and senior presidential adviser Justin Yak. The plane's pilot reported engine trouble, but the plane blew up before he could make an emergency landing.
In Saada, north Yemen, a bombing at the Ben Salman mosque kills at least 15 and injures 55.

At Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky, USA, the 134th running of the Kentucky Derby is held. Race favorite Big Brown wins by nearly five lengths. Second place finisher Eight Belles broke both front ankles, and was immediately euthanized. Race attendance was 157,770, the second-largest in history of the race.

Tropical cyclone Nargis passes through western Myanmar killing over 140,000 people and destroying thousands of homes. Winds reached 120 mph and tidal waves reached 12 feet high. 2-3 million residents are left homeless. This is the country's deadliest natural disaster ever in recorded history.

The Philadelphia Flyers beat the Montreal Canadiens 6-4 in Game 5 of the NHL Stanley Cup playoffs, eliminating Montreal and Canada's last hope for the Cup this season. A Canadian team has not won the Cup in 15 years.
Real Madrid wins a record 21st Spanish soccer league title, defeating Osasuna 2-1.
The Dallas Stars advance to the next round by defeating the San Jose Sharks 2-1 in Game six of Stanley Cup playoffs, in the 8th longest game in NHL history, with four overtime periods.
The Pittsburgh Penguins defeat the New York Rangers 3-2 to win the Eastern Conference in Game 5 of their Stanley Cup series.
Crude oil prices for June delivery in the US hit a record US$120.36 per barrel.
In Jackson, Georgia, USA, convicted murderer William Earl Lynd is executed by lethal injection, at age 53. Lynd was convicted of killing Ginger Moore in December 1988.
In Moscow, Russia, Vladimir Putin formally steps down as president. Dmitry Medvedev is sworn in as Russian president, and nominates his predecessor Putin as prime minister.
Start of armed clashes and fighting in Lebanon.
Silvio Berlusconi is sworn into office as Italy's Prime Minister.
Tornadoes and strong storms across central United States kill 22 and severely damage towns of Picher, Oklahoma, and Seneca, Missouri.
General election in Serbia. Coalition of President Boris Tadic wins 39 percent, the Radicals win 29 percent.
A 7.8-magnitude earthquake hits China's southwestern Sichuan province, killing about 90,000, injuring 300,000, leaving 5 milion homeless.
In Jaipur, India, seven bombs explode in the crowded streets of the walled quarter, killing 61 people and wounding 216. An 8th bomb explodes outside a nearby Hindu temple.
NASA announces the discovery of Supernova remnant G1.9+0.3.
The U.S. government lists polar bears as a threatened species under its Endangered Species Act because of the effects of global warming.
In Manchester, England, the final game of the UEFA Cup of soccer is held. Russia's Zenit St. Petersburg defeats Scotland's Glasgow Rangers 2-0.
Microsoft reports total sales of the Xbox 360 video game system have reached 10 million, beating the Nintendo Wii and PlayStation 3 to that sales level.
A Francis Bacon triptyck sells for US$86.3 million at Sotheby's auction in New York.
Price of a gallon of regular gasoline hits a US record $4 (on average) in Alaska.
An explosion along Nigeria's oil pipeline in Lagos, ruptured accidentally by a bulldozer, kills over 100.
In Egypt, Abdullah Kamel Mohammed is sentenced to 1,000 years in prison for defrauding hundreds of people out of about US$52 million since the 1980s.
California Supreme Court legalizes same-sex marriage.
The Simpsons Ride officially opens at Universal Studios Orlando, in Florida, USA.

Vietnamese police seize a shipment of cannabis resin hidden with blue jeans in two trucks heading for the Chinese border. Value of the illegal drugs is estimated at US$90 million, the largest ever seizure in Vietnam.
A letter written by Albert Einstein in which he dismissed belief in God as a "product of human weaknesses" sells at auction for more than US$330,000 in London, England, to a private collector.
CBS announces it will buy web media company CNET Networks for about US$1.8 billion.
In Quebec City, Quebec, Canada, the semifinals of the men's world hockey tournament is held. Canada beats Sweden 5-4 to advance to the final against Russia.
In Quebec City, Quebec, Canada, the semifinals of the men's world hockey tournament is held. Russia defeats Finland 4-0, advancing to the final on May 18.
In Kuwait, elections for parliament are held. Sunni and Shia Islamists win nearly half of the 50 seatsm a gain from 2006's election.
President Leonel Fernandez wins re-election (53 percent) in the Dominican Republic.
Portsmouth defeats Cardiff City 1-0 to win the FA Cup at Wembley, England. This is the first cup win for Portsmouth since 1939.
In two southern Indian states, poisonous illegally-brewed alcohol results in the deaths of about 150, with a further 135 people in hospital.
In Baltimore, Maryland, USA, the 133rd running of the Preakness Stakes is held. The undefeated 3-year-old Big Brown wins by 5 1/4 lengths, ridden by Kent Desormeaux.
In Quebec City, Quebec, Canada, the runoff of the men's world hockey tournament (IIHF) is held. Finland defeats Sweden 4-0 for the bronze medal.
In Quebec City, Quebec, Canada, the final game of the men's world hockey tournament (IIHF) is held. Russia beats Canada 5-4 in overtime for the gold medal.
The Pittsburgh Penguins beat state NHL rivals Philadelphia Flyers 6-0 in Game 5 to advance to the Stanley Cup final.
The Detroit Red Wings defeat the Dallas Stars 4-1 in Game six to advance to the NHL Stanley Cup final game.
Nintendo launches the Wii Fit exercise game for the Nintendo Wii video game system in the US, initially only in New York City. Price is US$90 including game and balance board input device.
Canada's S&P/TSX composite index closes at a record high above 15,000 (15,047).
In the US Presidential Democratic race, caucus voting results in Oregon and Kentucky give Illinois Senator Barak Obama a majority of pledged delegates.
US Senator Edward Kennedy (age 76) is diagnosed with a malignant brain tumour at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
Mike Piazza of the Oakland Athletics retires at age 39 from Major League Baseball. Piazza was a 12-time all-star catcher, with 427 career home runs.
General election in Georgia. President Mikheil Saakashvili wins 60 percent of vote. David Gamkrelidze of opposition part wins 15 percent.
In Kenya, eleven elderly people accused of being witches are burned to death by a mob.
U.S. crude oil price passes US$130 per barrel, rising $5 above the previous day to a record high of US$134.
At the Belgrade Arena in Serbia, the Eurovision Song Contest is held. Russian singer Dima Bilan wins with ballad "Believe". This is Russia's first win in the contest.

At a summit in Brazil, the leaders of 12 South American nations sign a treaty creating the Union of South American Nations (Unasur), a regional body aimed at boosting economic and political integration in the region. The Unasur members are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay and Venezuela.
The International Court of Justice awards Middle Rocks to Malaysia and Pedra Branca to Singapore, ending a 29-year territorial dispute between the two countries.
In central Colombia (55km from Bogota), a 5.7 earthquake occurs, killing at least six people, causing landslides and shaking buildings.
Lebanon's parliament elects army commander General Michel Suleiman as president.
In Indianapolis, Indiana, the 89th running of the Indianapolis 500 race is held. Winner is Scott Dixon of Target Chip Ganassi Racing.
Nepal's constituent assembly in Kathmandu votes 597 to 4 to abolish 240 years of royal rule, becoming a democratic republic nation.

A Standard & Poor's/Case Shiller composite index of 20 metropolitan areas in the USA reports prices of single-family homes dropped a record 14.4 percent in March from a year earlier. The US Commerce Department reports sales of new homes in April were down 42 percent from a year ago, the largest year-over-year drop in nearly 27 years.
The Los Angeles Lakers advance to the NBA finals by beating the San Antonio Spurs 100-92 in Game Five.
An earthquake measuring 6.1 hits southern Iceland, 50km from Reykjavik.

In the USA, Bear Stearns shareholders vote 84 percent in favor of selling the 85-year-old investment banking company to JPMorgan Chase & Company for US$9.32 a share, a total of US$1.5 billion. Shares in the company had traded at a record high of US$173 in January 2007.
In Panama City, Panama, a helicopter crashes into a warehouse, killing eleven people, including Chile's national police chief, General Jose Alejandro Bernales.

In Dublin, Ireland, diplomats from 111 countries, have formally adopt the Convention on Cluster Munitions treaty banning cluster bombs. The United States, Russia, China, Israel, India, and Pakistan didn't participate.
The Boston Celtics advance to the NBA finals with their 89-81 Game 6 win over the Detroit Pistons.
Usain Bolt of Jamaica sets a world record of 9.72 seconds in the 100-metre sprint at the Reebok Grand Prix at Icahn Stadium in New York.
Elections in Macedonia: ruling Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski's coalition wins a majority.
China Merchants Bank of China announces it will buy Hong Kong's Wing Lung Bank for US$4.76 billion.
A car bomb explodes outside the Danish embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan, killing at least five.
US Democratic Party presidential candidate Barack Obama wins the support of a group of uncommitted delegates, giving him more than the required 2118 to win the party's nomination.
The Detroit Red Wings win the NHL's Stanley Cup in a 3-2 Game Six win over the Pittsburgh Penguins.
J.M. Smucker Company announces it will acquire Folgers, the largest U.S. coffee business, from Procter & Gamble Company for stock in a deal valued at US$2.95 billion.
Verizon Wireless announces it would buy mobile phone service provider Alltel for US$28.1 billion.

Serbia's Ana Ivanovic wins the French Open tennis championship, defeating Dinara Safina of Russia, 6-4, 6-3. Pablo Cuevas of Uruguay and Luis Home of Peru defeat Canada's Daniel Nestor and Serbia's Nenad Zimonjic 6-2, 6-3, winning the men's doubles championship.
US Senator Hillary Clinton suspends her campaign to become the Democratic nominee for US president, and asks her supporters to help elect Barack Obama.
In the Akihabara area of Tokyo, Japan, a 25-year-old man stabs seven to death and wounds ten, before being arrested.
Spain's Rafael Nadal wins his fourth consecutive French Open tennis championship in Paris by beating rival Roger Federer in straight sets 6-1, 6-3, 6-0.
Southern Greece is struck by a 6.5-magnitude earthquake, killing two, injuring 20, and collapsing some buildings.
In Maryland, USA, 19-year-old Yani Tseng of Taiwan wins the LPGA Championship.
Afghan and British forces uncover a stash of 237 tonnes of hashish in Kandahar province of Afghanistan, believed to be the world's biggest seizure of drugs by weight.

An IBM supercomputer under development sets a computing milestone, operating at one thousand trillion calculations per second (1 petaflop). The computer, codenamed Roadrunner, incorporates 20,000 4-GHz Cell processors, the same processor used in the Sony PlayStation 3.
Ken Griffey Jr becomes the sixth major league player to hit 600 career home runs.
In San Francisco, California, Apple unveils a new iPhone with faster Internet access that will run on advanced wireless networks and sell for US$199.

A Sudan Airways Airbus A-310 passenger jet carrying more than 200 passengers bursts into flames after veering off a runway at an airport in the Sudanese capital of Khartoum, killing at least 28 people.

700,000 protesters assemble in Seoul, South Korea, to protest the resumption of beef imports from the USA, calling for the resignation of President Lee Myung-bak. Prime Minister Han Seung-soo, all 15 cabinet ministers, and nine of Lee's senior aides offer ro resign.
The Gamma-ray Large Area Space Telescope is launched.

Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper delivers in the House of Commons an unqualified apology to the assembled leaders of First Nations, Inuit, and MTtis people, for the poor treatment of them from 1870 to 1996. 100,000 aboriginal children were forced to attend state-funded Christian boarding schools aimed at assimilating them.
A public vote in Ireland on the European Union's Lisbon treaty results in a "no" decision, by 53.4 percent to 46.6. All members of the European Union must ratify the treaty for it to take effect.
Oil company OGX, started in 2007 by Eike Batista in Brazil, raises US$3.6 billion in its initial public stock offering. The company has no proven reserves, and has not even started drilling.
In Kandahar, Afghanistan, a group of Taliban armed fighters and suicide-bombers blast open the Sarposa prison, releasing over 1000 inmates.
At RM's Joe's Garage sale in Tustin, California, a 1960 Meskowski Bowes Seal Fast Special race car sells for US$462,000. Also, a 1923 Miller 122 Supercharged race car sells for US$2,035,000.
In Iwate, northern Japan, a 7.2 magnitude earthquake occurs, killing nine, injuring over 200, and causing landslides.
Expo 2008 is held in Zaragoza, Spain, with the topic of "Water and sustainable development".

In France, the 24 Hours of Le Mans race concludes. Audi scores its fifth straight victory, with drivers Allan McNish of Scotland, Rinaldo Capello of Italy, and Tom Kristensen of Denmark. This is a record eighth victory for Kristensen.
Tiger Woods wins the U.S. Open at Torrey Pines in San Diego, California. This is Woods' 14th major and third U.S. Open.
California performs its first legally recognized same-sex weddings.
A car bomb explodes in a market area of Baghdad, Iraq, killing 51 people and wounding 75. The blast set fire to 20 shops and leveled a multi-storey building.
The Boston Celtics win a record 17th NBA championship by defeating the Los Angeles Lakers 131-92 in Game Six.
Queen Elizabeth II gives royal assent to the European Union's Lisbon Treaty for the United Kingdom.
The Janus-2 satellite is launched from the Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, atop a Delta-2 rocket. The satellite will be used for measuring the shape of the world's oceans.
American comedian George Carlin dies of heart failure in Los Angeles, California, at age 71.
Research firm Gartner estimates that the number of personal computers in use around the world has surpassed 1 billion.
Seattle Mariners' pitcher Felix Hernandez become the first American League pitcher to hit a grand slam home run in 37 years.

Queen Elizabeth II strips Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe of his honorary knighthood. British Prime Minister Gordon Brown announces that Britain no longer recognizes Mugabe as Zimbabwe's legitimate leader.
The US Supreme Court overturns District of Columbia's handgun ban, asserting that individuals have the right to own guns.
Shares of General Motors Corporation drop to their lowest level since 1955, after Goldman Sachs gives the stock a "sell" rating.
The U.S. Senate approves US$161.8 billion in new funds to continue fighting the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan for the next year.
Company founder Bill Gates leaves his full-time executive role at Microsoft, to focus on his philanthropic organization, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
Robert Mugabe wins re-election in Zimbabwe's presidential run-off election, unopposed.
Robert Mugabe is sworn in for a sixth term as Zimbabwe's president, after electoral officials declare him the country's run-off election.
Spain wins the Euro 2008 soccer championship defeating Germany 1-0.
US President George Bush signs a US$162 billion war spending bill for Iraq and Afghanistan.

At the U.S. Olympic swimming trials in Omaha, Nebraska, American swimmer Michael Phelps sets a world record in the 400-metre individual medley at 4:05.25. Katie Hoff also wins the women's 400-metre individual medley, in 4:31.12.
France takes over the six-month rotating presidency of the European Union.
In British Columbia, Canada, a new carbon tax is applied to all carbon-based fuels, at a rate of CDN$5 per tonne of greenhouse gases generated (i.e. 2.4 cents per litre on gasoline).
The Starbucks coffee company announces it will close an additional 500 stores in the USA, on top of 100 already announced.

Colombia soldiers disguised as members of a non-government organization trick FARC rebels into releasing fifteen long-held hostages. They are French-Colombian politician Ingrid Betancourt, held for six years, three American defence department contractors, and eleven members of the Colombian security forces.

In England, the country's largest house builder fails to raise 500 million pounds (US$1 billion), and is forced to write down the value of about 660 million pounds worth of land. The company's share value is now about 1/15th of a year ago.
The NBA's Seattle SuperSonics basketball team announces they will move to Oklahoma City next season.
At the U.S. Olympic swimming trials in Omaha, Nebraska, American swimmer Michael Phelps sets a world record in the 200-metre individual medley at 1:54.8.
Opening of regular direct charter flights between China and Taiwan.
Venus Williams beats her sister Serena 7-5 6-4, capturing her fifth Wimbledon tennis title.
Daniel Nestor of Canada and teammate Nenad Zimonjic of Serbia win the Wimbeldon doubles tennis match, defeating Jonas Bjorkman of Sweden and Kevin Ullyett of Zimbabwe 7-6, 6-7, 6-3, 6-3.
The United Arab Emirates cancels the entire debt owed to it by Iraq, almost US$7 billion.
Rafael Nadal beats Roger Federer 6-4 6-4 6-7 (5-7) 6-7 (8-10) 9-7 in men's singles tennis to win his first Wimbledon title.
(to June 9) The 34th G8 summit is held in Toyako, Hokkaido, Japan.
In Kabul, Afghanistan, a car bomb explodes outside the Indian embassy compound, killing 41, injuring 139. This is the worst such attack since the US invasion in 2001.
In Ecuador, the government seizes almost 200 companies owned by the Isa?s family, to sell as compensation for the loss of US$661 million when the owners of Filanbanco fled to the USA.
Former Macedonian Interior Minister Ljube Bo_koski is acquitted of all charges, by a UN Tribunal accusing him of war crimes.
Crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange hits a record high of US$147.27 per barrel.
Russia's Yelena Isinbayeva breaks her own world record in the women's pole vault at Rome's Golden Gala meet, jumping 5.03 metres.

In California, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp takes over mortgage lender IndyMac Bancorp, second largest banking failure (US$32 billion in assets) in U.S. history, and the fifth U.S. bank to fail this year. The insurance firm estimates the cost of the failure at between $4 billion and $8 billion.
At Bonhams' Goodwood Sale, a 1934 ERA RIA race car sells for US$720,237. A 1955 Jaguar D-Type XKD 509, first customer car, sells for US$4,416,676.
In Monterey, California, Mid America Auctions sells a 1915 Cyclone Board Track Racer motorcycle for a world record US$520,000 at the Inaugural Monterey Motorcycle Auction.
In Paris, France, French President Nicolas Sarkozy launches a new international body, the Union for the Mediterranean, with 43 member nations aimed at ending conflict in the Middle East.
US Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson unveils an emergency plan to save Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, mortgage holders of US$5.2 trillion.
Standard & Poor's 500 stock market index has its worst single day fall since its creation in 1989.

American Anheuser-Busch accepts a US$52 billion takeover bid from Belgium-based InBev, creating the world's largest beer maker and placing the U.S. company into foreign hands. The cash offer, once approved by regulators, would be the largest cash transaction in history, and the second-biggest ever foreign takeover of a U.S. company.
(to July 20) World Youth Day takes place in Sydney, Australia. Pope Benedict XVI appears at the event.

The American League takes a 4-3 victory over the National League in the 79th All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium in New York. The 15th inning game was the longest-ever All-Star game, lasting four hours and 50 minutes.
American investment bank Merrill Lynch & Company posts a US$4.89 billion quarterly loss after writing down bad debts, and unveils plans to sell billions of dollars of assets.
A 6.6-magnitude earthquake strikes off the eastern coast of Japan.
Radovan Karad?ic, the first president of the Republika Srpska, is arrested in Belgrade, Serbia on allegations of war crimes, following a 12-year long manhunt.
China and Russia sign an accord settling the border in the north east of China, ending long-standing dispute and tensions in the area.

The United Progressive Alliance-led government in India survives a crucial no-confidence vote, based on disagreements between the Indian National Congress and Left Front, over the Indo-US nuclear deal.
In Nepal an election is held for the Constituent Assembly. 220 of 601 seats are won by the Communist Party of Nepal. The President is Ram Baran Yadav of the Nepali Congress party.
An earthquake of magnitude 6.8 hits Japan's northern island of Honshu, causing damage to buildings and leaving thousands without power.
Cape Verde joins the World Trade Organization as its 153rd member.
Ford Motor Company of the USA posts a record US$8.7 billion quarterly loss, due to slumping truck and SUV operations.
A series of seven bomb blasts rock Bangalore, India, killing two and injuring 20.
In India, 19 separate explosions in the western city of Ahmedabad, all within an hour, kill 51 people and wound 200.
In the general election in Cambodia, 90 seats of the 123-seat national assembly are won by the Cambodian People's Party with leader Hun Sen.

Rafael Nadal wins his second Rogers Cup tennis championship in Toronto, Ontario, Canada with a 6-3, 6-2 win over German Nicolas Kiefer in the final. In the men's doubles final, Toronto's Daniel Nestor and partner Nenad Zimonjic of Serbia defeat the American pairing of Bob and Mike Bryan 6-2, 4-6, 10-6.
Carlos Sastre wins the Tour de France bicycle race in France.
At least 17 are killed and over 154 wounded in two blasts in Istanbul.
Relief pitcher Rich "Goose" Gossage and former manager Dick Williams are inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, New York.
Typhoon Fung-Wong dumps up to 28 inches of rain on Taiwan, killing one person and causing widespread flooding.
The NBA's Golden State Warriors re-sign centre Andris Biedrins to a six-year, US$62-million US contract.

Three suicide bombers kill at least 28 people and wound about 90 in attacks on crowds in the Iraqi capital Baghdad. In the northern city of Kirkuk, a suicide bomb detonates in a crowd of Kurdish protesters, killing at least 25 and injuring at least 150.
Wall Street investment bank and brokerage company Merrill Lynch reports it will take a US$5.7 billion third-quarter writedown due to risky debt.
Russia's Yelena Isinbayeva breaks her own pole vault world record, clearing 5.04m at the Super Grand Prix meeting in Monaco.
Southern California is hit by a 5.4 magnitude earthquake, felt from Los Angeles to San Diego and slightly in Las Vegas.
Heritage Numismatic Auctions sells a 1944-S steel Lincoln cent graded MS-66 by NGC for US$373,450, a record for any small cent.
Brazil's President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva launches the Amazon Fund, in which foreign individuals and governments invest in preservation of the Amazon rainforest.
Venezuela's President Hugo Chvez announces the government will buy the country's third-largest bank, Banco de Venezuela, from Spain's Grupo Santander.
George Tupou V is crowned as the new King of Tonga, an event that had been delayed for over two years following the 2006 Nuku'alofa riots.
General Motors of the USA announces second quarter loss of US$15.5 billion, worst in the company's history.
A stampede at a Hindu temple at Naina Devi in Bilaspur, Himachal Pradesh, India kills 162 and injures 400.
Two members of the East Turkestan Islamic Movement kill 16 and injure another 16 officers at a police station in Kashgar, Xinjiang, China.
In local elections in Bangladesh, the Awami League candidates win 12 of 13 mayoral races.
Military coup in Mauritania, lead by Colonel Muhammed Ould Abdelaziz, as President Sidi Mohamed Ould Cheikh Abdallahi is arrested and relieved of duties.
Georgia sends its army to regain control of South Ossetia which has had de facto independence since 1992.
Russian forces clash with Georgia inside the breakaway South Ossetia region.
(8:08 PM) In Beijing, China, the Games of the XXIX Olympiad open. An estimated one billion people worldwide watch the opening ceremonies on TV.
US home mortgage funder Fannie Mae posts a second-quarter loss of US$2.3 billion, its fourth straight quarter loss, totaling US$9.44 billion over the past year.
Russian troops enter South Ossetia to counter Georgian offensive against the breakaway province.
Royal Bank of Scotland, Britain's second-biggest bank, records a 5.9 billion pound (US$11.4 billion) writedown on risky assets for the first half of the year.
The Games of the XXIX Olympiad will begin with the Opening Ceremony in Beijing, China.
Ireland's Padraig Harrington wins the PGA Championship at Michigan's Oakland Hills, shooting a 277 total.

At the Beijing Olympics, American swimmer Michael Phelps wins the 400-metre individual medley in a world-record 4:03.84. Stephanie Rice of Australia wins the women's 400-metre individual medley in a world record time of 4:29.45.
Russian troops invade western Georgia and Russian planes launch air raids across the country.
Kirsty Coventry of Zimbabwe breaks the world record in the semifinals of the women's 100-metre backstroke at 58.77 seconds at the Summer Olympics in Beijing, China.
Michael Phelps wins Olympic gold in 200-metre freestyle swimming, becoming only the fifth person to win nine career Olympic gold medals. His win also set a new world record time of 1.42.96.
Togo wins its first ever Olympic medal, bronze in the men's single kayak slalom won by Benjamin Boukpeti.
Russian President Dmitry Medvedev orders a cease fire in Georgia.

At the Beijing Olympics, American swimmer Michael Phelps wins his 10th and 11th career gold medals, in men's 200-metre butterfly and 4x200 freestyle relay in world record 6:58.56). Phelps is now the record holder of most career Olympic gold medals.
At the Beijing Olympics, Federica Pellegrini of Italy wins gold in the women's 200-metre freestyle in world record 1:54.82.
At the Beijing Olympics, Stephanie Rice of Australia wins gold in the women's 200-metre individual medley in world record 2:08.45.
Fernando Lugo takes office as president of Paraguay.
In Beijing, China, an Olympic Torch used in the relay to China sells for over US$42,000. A torch from the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games (first torch relay) sells for almost US$25,000.
Poland signs a deal with the US to host part of its new missile defence shield. The US will install ten interceptor missiles at a base on the Baltic coast, and help strengthen Polish air defences.
Nepal's parliament elects Maoist leader Prachanda as the country's new prime minister, with 80 percent of votes.

At the Beijing Olympics, American Michael Phelps won his sixth gold and his sixth world record in the 200 metres individual medley. American Ryan Lochte wins gold in the Olympic men's 200-metre backstroke in a world-record 1:53.94.

At the Beijing Olympics, Jamaica's Usain Bolt wins the men's 100 metres in world record time of 9.69 seconds. American Michael Phelps equals Mark Spitz's 36-year record of winning seven golds in one Olympic games, winning the 100m butterfly. Zimbabwe's Kirsty Coventry, wins the women's 200 backstroke, in a world record time. Britain's Rebecca Adlington also breaks a world record to take gold in the women's 800 freestyle.
Russia signs a French-brokered peace plan with Georgia, ending their nine-day-old conflict.
Michael Phelps wins his record eighth gold medal of the Beijing Games, in the 4x100 medley relay, in record time of 3:29.34. Phelps now holds the record for most gold medals at an Olympics event.
In Nepal, Prachanda is sworn in as prime minister by President Ram Baran Yadav.

Russian Proton Breeze M rocket launches one of the biggest commercial satellites ever built - the Inmarsat-4 (I4-F3). The telecommunications satellite is 7m long, with a 9m wide antenna reflector. Inmarsat's network delivers high-speed mobile internet and phone services to users on land, at sea and in the air.
Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf announces his resignation. Speaker of the Pakistani Senate, Muhammad Mian Sumroo, takes over as caretaker president.
Taliban insurgents kill 10 and injure 21 French soldiers in an ambush in Afghanistan.
A suicide bomber rams a car into an Algerian military academy, killing 43 and injuring 45.
Zambian leader Levy Mwanawasa dies at age 59 in a Paris hospital after suffering a stroke in June.
Jamaica's Usain Bolt wins the 200m sprint at the Beijing Olympic Games in new world record time of 19.30 seconds.
Spanair flight JK 5022 passenger plane taking off for the Canary Islands from Madrid's Barajas airport swerves off the runway and crashes, killing 153.
In Los Angeles, Saxophonist LeRoi Moore, a founding member of the Dave Matthews Band, dies of complications from a vehicle accident in June, at age 46.
Twin suicide bombings outside Pakistan's main munitions factory in the town of Wah kills at least 63 people.
Pirates hijack German, Iranian, and Japanese cargo ships off the coast of Somalia, in seven such attacks since June 20.
President of Argentina declares a state of emergency due to drought in five northern provinces.
Usain Bolt captures a third gold medal and a third world record at the Beijing Olympic Games, as Jamaica wins the men's 4x100m relay gold in world record of 37.10 seconds.
An aircraft crashes in Guatemala, killing 10, including four Americans on a humanitarian mission.

In Beijing, China, the Games of the XXIX Olympiad close, with the Olympic flag being handed to London mayor Boris Johnson, for the 2012 Games in England. Official cost of the games: US$2.2 billion, plus US$40 billion on preparation of infrastructure and cleaning the environment. China won 51 gold, more than any other country for the first time.
Am Itek Air Boeing 737 passenger plane crashes shortly after take-off from Kyrgyzstan's capital, Bishkek, killing 68 out of the 90 passengers and crew.
Russia unilaterally recognizes the independence of Georgian breakaway republics Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
Alberto Gonzales announces his resignation as US attorney general as of September 17.
At the Democratic National Convention in Denver, Colorado, Illinois senator Barack Obama is nominated as Democratic presidential nominee.
India agrees to a free-trade agreement with the countries in the Association of South-East Asian Nations.
The US Mint officially launches the 2008 Alaska State quarter dollar coin at the Alaska State Fair.
In Dayton, Ohio, Senator John McCain announces Alaska Governor Sarah Palin as his vice presidential running mate for election as US President.
Thomas J. Bata, Canadian shoe company industrialist, dies in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, at age 93.
Hurricane Gustav hits Louisiana as Category 2 hurricane, causing US$372 million damage to crops, and forcing 1.9 million to evacuate, largest in state history.
Prime Minister Samak Sundaravej of Thailand declares a state of emergency in Bangkok.
Prime Minister of Japan Yasuo Fukuda resigns, less than a year after taking office following Shinzo Abe's resignation.
Argentine President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner announces the promise to repay US$6.7 billion of loans to 19 creditors.
Tropical Storm Gustav disperses, after causing US$20 billion damage in the US, and 283 deaths in the US and Caribbean.
President's Dimitris Christofias and Mehmet Ali Talat hold peace talks in Nicosia, aimed at reunifying Cyprus.
Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani of Pakistan survives an assassination attempt near Islamabad, while on his way to meet British Leader of the Opposition David Cameron.
Arizona Senator John McCain is nominated as US Presidential candidate for the Republican party, with Alaskan Governor Sarah Palin as vice presidential candidate.
The Russian stock market total value drops to 30 percent since the invasion of Georgia on August 8. Up to US$20 billion in foreign capital has been pulled out of Russia during August.
General election in Angola: ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola wins re-election landslide, with over 80 percent of vote.
At least eight boulders dislodge from a cliff near Cairo, Egypt, killing at least 90 and burying an estimated 500 people.
Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, is elected Pakistan's new president, with 481 of 702 votes.
Serena Williams captures her third U.S. Open womens tennis title, beating Jelena Jankovic 6-4, 7-5.

American mortgage companies Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae are taken over by the US government, due to their risk to the economy. The two companies account for nearly half of home mortgages in the US. The two firms will be administered by the Federal Housing Finance Agency until their long-term future is decided. Together, Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae own or guarantee about US$5.3 trillion of mortgages and have made a combined loss of about US$14 billion in the past year.
General election in Hong Kong: pro-China parties win 30 seats, pro-democracy parties win 23 seats, others win 7 seats.
Roger Federer wins a fifth straight US Open mens tennis title, defeating Andy Murray 6-2, 7-5, 6-2, in one hour 51 minutes at Flushing Meadows.
Canada's TSX closes up 848.42 points, or 7.03 percent, a record one-day gain.
Asif Zardari is sworn in as president of Pakistan.
The Constitutional Court of Thailand orders Prime Minister Samak Sundaravej to resign, after he is paid for appearing on a television cooking show.
An undersea earthquake measuring 7.6 on the Richter scale hits the eastern Moluccas islands.
China's tainted-milk scandal begins, with melamine-laced milk from Sanlu dairy farm resulting in tens of thousands of children sick.
The Large Hadron Collider in Geneva first begins accelerating protons. The Collider can measure events within a millionth of a billionth of a billionth of a second.
Lehman Brothers investment bank of New York posts a record quarterly loss of US$3.9 billion.
Asian broadcaster ESPN Star Sports pays nearly US$1 billion for the commercial and marketing rights to the inaugural Twenty20 Champions League of cricket for the next ten years.
A Metrolink train collides head-on into a freight train in Los Angeles, California, killing 25 and injuring 130.
Hurricane Ike hits Galveston, Texas, as Category 2, causing estimated damage of US$27 billion, 3rd costliest in US history.
Aeroflot Flight 821 crashes near the city of Perm, Russia, killing all 88 on board.
Following negotiations, President Robert Mugabe and opposition leaders Morgan Tsvangirai and Arthur Mutambara sign a power-sharing deal, making Tsvangirai the new Prime Minister of Zimbabwe.
American investment bank Merrill Lynch & Company agrees to sell itself to Bank of America Corp, for US$50 billion. Stock in Bank of America drops 21.3 percent, reducing market value by US$33 billion.

158-year-old American investment bank Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc files for bankruptcy protection, becoming the largest U.S. bankruptcy. Lehman's assets total about US$639 billion, leveraged by only US$30 billion of equity.

The U.S. Federal Reserve Board announces the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will lend up to US$85 billion to the American International Group, and the U.S. government will receive a 79.9 percent equity interest in AIG.
The U.S. House of Representatives passes legislation lifting a ban on offshore oil drilling, opening most of the U.S. coastline to exploration.
Pink Floyd keyboard player and founder member Richard Wright dies at age 65, from cancer.

Russia's Moscow stock markets are closed after stocks fell to the lowest level in almost three years. The country's Finance Minister plans to support the three largest banks with 60 billion rubles (US$2.3 billion) in loans.
The International Astronomical Union classifies Haumea as the fifth dwarf planet in the Solar System.
Somchai Wongsawat, brother-in-law of ousted Thai leader Thaksin Shinawatra, wins a majority parliamentary vote to become the country's new prime minister.

Major League Baseball's instant replay system produces its first reversal when Tampa Bay Rays' Carlos Pena had a two-run double changed to a three-run homer during the fourth inning against the Minnesota Twins. The initial umpire call was based on fan interference, which the video replay showed was not the case.
South African president Thabo Mbeki resigns at the request of the African National Congress.
In Islamabad, Pakistan, a suicide truck bomb kills at least 54 people at the Marriott Hotel. At least 270 people were injured in the blast.

Nearly 13,000 children in China are hospitalised after drinking the milk of the Sanlu Group containing the industrial chemical melamine; four have died. Melamine was first found in baby milk powder made by the Sanlu Group.
The US Treasury proposes to Congress a fund worth up to US$700 billion of taxpayer money to buy back much of the bad debt held by banks and other financial institutions.

Jose Molina hits the last home run in the 85-year history of Yankee Stadium in New York, to give the New York Yankees a 7-3 win over the Baltimore Orioles. The stadium will be demolished, replaced by a new US$1.3 billion Yankee Stadium across the way from the exisiting facility.
The United States claims the 2008 Ryder Cup golf trophy with a 16.5-11.5 victory over Europe.
Argentine's president Christina Fernndez de Kirchner announces the government would possibly settle with all debtors from the 2001 default.
Microsoft unveils plans to spend US$40 billion buying back its shares from investors, the biggest single buy-back plan in history.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average removes American International Group from its index, replacing it with Kraft Foods.
In Kauhajoki, Finland, 22-year-old student Matti Juhani Saari kills ten people at a college before shooting himself and later dying in hospital.
France's EDF announces it will buy British Energy for 12.5 billion pounds (US$23.2 billion).
Japan's parliament confirms Taro Aso as the country's new prime minister, following the sudden resignation of the last prime minister, Yasuo Fukuda, in early September.

U.S. regulators seize bank Washington Mutual, the biggest bank failure in the nation's history, and sell its assets to JPMorgan Chase & Company for US$1.9 billion. Washington Mutual was the largest savings and loan bank, with $307 billion of assets and $188 billion of deposits.
Kgalema Motlanthe is sworn in as interim president (until an election) of South Africa, replacing Thabo Mbeki.
Russian President Dmitry Medvedev announces it plans to build a space defense system and a new fleet of nuclear submarines by 2020.
Election in Belarus, all 110 seats won by candidates loyal to President Alyaksandr Lukashenko.
Ecuadorians vote 64 percent to approve new constitution.
Election in Austria: Social Democratic Party 30 percent, People's Party 26 percent, Freedom Party 18 percent, Alliance for Austria's Future 11 percent.
Canada's TSX stock market index drops a record 840.93 points, to 11,285.07.
The U.S. House of Representatives votes 228-to-205 to reject a US$700 billion bailout plan for the financial industry.
The Belgian, Dutch and Luxembourg governments take a 49 percent stake in Fortis bank giving it a 11.2 billion euro (US$16.4 billion) injection of cash.
The American Federal Reserve announces it will lend a further US$620 billion to other national central banks.
Wachovia Corp, fourth largest US bank, agrees to sell most of its assets to Citigroup Inc for US$2.16 billion in a deal brokered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.
Dora de PTdery-Hunt, Hungarian-born designer of effigy of Queen Elizabeth II for Canadian coinage (1990-2003), dies at age 94 in Toronto, Ontario.
Morgan Stanley sells 21 percent of itself to Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, for US$3 billion, plus a further $6 billion of convertible preferred stock.

The Dow Jones industrial average posts its largest point decline ever, 778 points, 6.98 percent of total value. The benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 Index has its worst day since the 1987 crisis with an 8.8 percent drop, or 106.59 points. The Nasdaq Composite Index loses 199.61 points, or 9.14 percent. Latin American stocks tumble 13 percent, their biggest decline in more than a decade. Gold price jumps up, and US crude oil drops $10 to close at US$96.37 per barrel. World stocks, as measured by the MSCI's world index, lose about $1.7 trillion for the day.
A Jodhpur temple stampede in western India kills over 224 people, and injures 400.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rebounds by 485.21 points (4.68 percent), the third largest one-day point gain.

The U.S. Senate votes 74-to-25 to endorse a revised US$700 billion bank bailout plan. It involves the Treasury buying bad loans from institutions. The plan, rejected by the House earlier, was revised to include a tax cut and extended federal protection for bank deposits.
US President George Bush tells congress the US will sell US$6.5 billion worth of weaponry to Taiwan.
In Dallas, Texas, Spink Shreves Galleries auctions the William H. Gross collection of stamps. A Mauritius 2-penny deep blue Queen Victoria stamp (Scott #4) sells for US$97,750.
The U.S. House of Representatives approves the modified US$700 billion bank bailout plan, voting 263 in favor, 171 against. President George Bush quickly signs the bill into law.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average drops below 10,000.
Germany's government finance ministry agrees to a 50 billion euro (US$70 billion) plan to save private Hypo Real Estate, one of the country's biggest banks.
The UK's FTSE 100 stock market index records its biggest ever one-day points fall (since 1984), 391.1 points, or 7.85 percent, representing a drop of 93.4 billion pounds.
NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft makes its second of three flybys of Mercury, decreasing the velocity for orbital insertion on March 18, 2011.
An earthquake measuring 6.6 magnitude kills at least 65 in Kyrgyzstan.
Russia agrees to provide Iceland with a 4 billion euro loan.
New York stocks drop for a fifth straight day, resulting in the Dow Jones Industrial Average's biggest five-day point loss ever, more than 1400 points, or nearly 13 percent.
The meteoroid 2008 TC3 impacts Earth, becoming the first such object to be discovered prior to impact.

Central banks around the world cut interest rates in unison for the first time ever. The coordinated rate cuts were made by financial policymakers in response to the global credit crisis. Central banks of the USA, China, Europe, Great Britain, Canada, Sweden, and Switzerland all cut their main lending rate by half a percentage point.

The British Treasury announces a bail-out plan for British banks, investing up to 50 billion pounds (US$87 billion) of public money to increase bank capital in exchange for preference shares, will make available at least 200 billion pounds in Treasury bills in exchange for less liquid assets of banks, and will guarantee up to 250 billion pounds of new bank-obtained funding.
The Tokyo stock market drops 9.4 percent; the Hong Kong stock market drops 8.2 percent.
Canada's TSX composite index closes down 456 points at 9,600, a 4.5 percent decline. In New York, the Dow Jones loses 679 points or 7.3 percent, while the Nasdaq sheds 95 points or 5.5 percent.
Mexican retailer Comercial Mexicana files for creditor protection after losing US$4 billion on derivatives contracts.
General Motors Corp share price drops to US$4.65, its lowest level since 1950. Market capitalization drops to US$2.6 billion, lower than its value of about $4 billion in March 1929.

Following a major banking and financial crisis in Iceland, the Icelandic Financial Supervisory Authority takes control of the three largest banks in the country: Kaupthing Bank, Landsbanki, and Glitnir.
The Canadian government announces it will buy CDN$25 billion in mortgage-backed securities to support the country's financial institutions.
Canada's currency briefly drops to 82.97 cents US, its lowest level since November 2004.
Russia test-fires an intercontinental ballistic missile a distance of 11,500km, a new record for a missile fired from a submarine.
Iceland shut downs its stock market and abandons attempts to defend its currency, and requests financing from the International Monetary Fund.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rebounds 936.42 points, nearly doubling the largest daily point gain in history, bringing the index back above 9,000 points. Stocks worldwide add more than US$1.7 trillion in value, based on a record 9.3 percent gain in the MSCI world equity index.
Britain, Germany, France and other European countries pledge more than 1 trillion euros (US$1.36 trillion) for bank guarantees and equity stakes.
U.S. Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson announces plans to take equity stakes totaling up to $250 billion in financial institutions.

Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd announces the government would guarantee all deposits in Australian banks and other savings institutions for three years. Rudd also announces a spending plan of A$10.4 billion (US$7 billion).

Federal elections in Canada: Prime Minister Stephen Harper's Conservatives secure a stronger minority government, with 143 seats, up from 127. The Liberal party takes 76 seats, down from 95. Bloc QuTbTcois wins 50 seats, the NDP wins 37 seats, and two independents hold on to their seats.
Canada's TSX stock market index closes up 890.50 points, or 9.82 percent, ending the day at 9955.66, a record one-day gain. At one point during the day, the TSX was up 1600 points.
The US Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank, and the Swiss National Bank announce they will allow unlimited loans in US dollars.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average index falls 733 points (7.87 percent) to 8,577 points, its biggest percentage fall since October 1987. The United Kingdon's FTSE 100 falls 7.16 percent, Germany's Dax drops 6.49 percent, and France's Cac 40 loses 6.82 percent.
In the Barbados, 13 Caribbean countries sign approval of a new Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union.
Thai and Cambodian troops fight an hour-long battle with small arms and rockets on a disputed stretch of border.
The Philadelphia Phillies advance to their first World Series in 15 years after winning the National League Championship Series with a 5-1 Game Five win over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Crude oil drops as low as US$69.15 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, less than half its July record high.
American second largest bank Citigroup posts its fourth straight quarterly loss of $13 billion due to write-downs and credit losses. The bank has recorded US$71 billion in losses over five quarters.
The Perth Mint in Australia stops accepting orders for bullion coins, to catch up on production to fulfill existing orders due to extremely high demand.
The United Nations General Assembly elects Turkey, Austria, Japan, Uganda, and Mexico to two-year terms on the Security Council.
The South Korean Government announces US$130 billion rescue of economy for guarantees of foreign-currency debts, and for banks in need of dollars.

At the Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Florida, the Tampa Bay Rays beat the Boston Red Sox 3-1 to win the American League championship 4-3 and reach the World Series for the first time in their 11-year existence.
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is officially inaugurated. It is a collaboration of over 10,000 scientists and engineers from over 100 countries as well as hundreds of universities and laboratories.
Hungary's central bank raises its interest rate from 8.5 percent to 11.5.
Wachovia Corp reports a third-quarter loss of US$23.9 billion, a record quarterly deficit for a banking company in the global credit crisis.
French president Nicolas Sarkozy announces a strategic investment fund of borrowed money to acquire stakes in French industries to prevent foreign take-overs.
The International Monetary Fund reaches an agreement with Iceland for a US$2.1-billion loan package to help the country.
The International Monetary Fund reaches an agreement with Ukraine for a US$16.5-billion loan package to help the country.
American commandos make a raid on a farm in Syria, across from Iraq. The Syrian government claims eight civilians killed.

The Toronto stock market's S&P/TSX composite index suffers its fourth-largest one-day loss ever, falling 756.75 points or 8.14 per cent to close at 8,537.34, the lowest close in more than four years. Japan's Nikkei index falls 6.4 percent to a 26-year low, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index drops 12.7 percent.
The Royal Canadian Mint releases its third (and world's third) colored circulating coin, with a red poppy honboring the 90th anniversary of the end of World War I.
Maldives President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom concedes electoral victory to opposition leader Mohamed "Anni" Nasheed (54 percent of vote). Gayoom was president for 30 years.

Volkswagen briefly becomes the world's biggest company by market value, with short sellers paying up to 1,005 euros a share. At that price Volkswagen's voting stock was worth 296 billion euros (US$370 billion).

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 889.35 points, or 10.88 percent, to 9,065.12, its second-biggest point gain. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index gains 91.59 points, or 10.79 percent, to 940.51, also its second-biggest point gain. The Nasdaq Composite Index rises 143.57 points, or 9.53 percent, to 1,649.47.
The International Monetary Fund reaches an agreement with Hungary for a US$25.1-billion loan package to help the country.
British foreign secretary changes Britain's position on Tibet, saying "Tibet is part of China. Full Stop." The previous position was that China held "suzerainty" over Tibet.
An earthquake of 6.4 magnitude hits Baluchistan province in south-western Pakistan, killing at least 160 people. Four aftershocks register at up to 6.2.
Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries sells a US 1868 3-cent rose George Washington postage stamp with "B" grill embossing for US$900,000 (US$1,035,000 with buyer's fee). The stamp is one of four known.
Delta Air Lines merges with Northwest Airlines, forming the world's largest commercial carrier.
Hungary's currency and stock markets rise on the news that it will receive an international economic bailout package worth US$25 billion from the IMF, European Union, and World Bank.
The US Federal Reserve cuts interest rate to 1 percent.
The American Federal Reserve announces it will loan up to US$30 billion to Brazil, Singapore, South Korea, and Mexico.
Eleven bomb blasts rip through the main city of India's Assam state and three other towns, killing 77 people and wounding 320.

The Philadelphia Phillies win the World Series of baseball, their first since 1980, defeating the Tampa Bay Rays four games to one. Game Five was suspended in the sixth inning on October 28 due to rain, with the score tied 2-2.
Japan, the world's second biggest economy, unveils a 5 trillion yen (US$51 billion) package of spending measures to support its economy.
The U.S. economy shrank by 0.3 percent in the third quarter (July-September), the most in seven years, with consumer spending during the quarter at the lowest in 28 years.
Papua New Guinea is the second country to release a colored circulating coin, a 50-toea coin with red on white logo of the Central Bank of Papua New Guinea, marking the 35th anniversary of the bank.
Bolivian President Evo Morales suspends indefinitely the operations of the US Drug Enforcement Administration in Bolivia.
In Brazil, Ita? and Unibanco banks announce a merger, making it the largest bank in Latin America, with assets worth 575 billion reais (US$263 billion).
U.S. electronics retailer Circuit City Stores begins liquidation sales at 155 of its stores, to leave it with 566 U.S. stores.
California votes to approve a constitutional ban on gay marriage.

In general elections in the USA, Democratic Party nominee Senator Barack Obama is elected first half-black president, with running mate Joe Biden as Vice President. The electoral college presidential vote is 364 to 174, with popular vote 52 to 46 percent. The Democratic party increases their number in Congress by about 20 seats, and in the Senate control 60 of 100 seats. This was the longest election in US history, and most expensive.
Arkansas votes 63 percent in favor of a state lottery.
Plane crash in Mexico kills fifteen, including Interior Minister Juan Camilo Mourio.
A ferry capsizes during a freak storm in the central Philippines, killing 39 people.
The International Monetary Fund approves a US$16.5 billion loan program for Ukraine.
Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher Greg Maddux wins his record 18th Gold Glove Award for fielding excellence in the National League.
St. James Auctions sells a unique Russian 1755 Elizabeth I gold 20-ruble pattern coin graded AU-58 by NGC for 1,782,500 pounds (US$2.82 million), world record price for a non-US coin.
King Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck of Bhutan is crowned, having ascended to the throne in 2006.
The Bank of England drops the interest rate from 4.5 percent to 3, lowest since 1955.
The three-storey La Promesse College in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, collapses, killing 92, with another 150 injured.
An accident aboard Russian submarine K-152 Nerpa kills 20.

New Zealand's opposition National Party ends Prime Minister Helen Clark's nine-year Labour government, winning 45 percent to 34. The United Future and ACT parties will join the National Party to form the next government.
A fire extinguishing system is activated by mistake during sea trials of a Russian submarine, killing at least 20 people by freon gas suffocation.

Indonesia executes three Muslim militants for the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings that killed 202 people. Imam Samudra, Amrozi Nurhasyim, and Ali Ghufron are executed by firing squad on Nusakambangan island in central Java.
China announces a 4 trillion yuan (US$586 billion) stimulus package of investments in infrastructure and social welfare by the end of 2010.
Circuit City Stores, second-largest U.S. consumer electronics retailer, files for bankruptcy protection.
The US government restructures its bailout of insurance company American International Group, raising the package to a record US$150 billion.
The US Mint officially launches the 2008 Hawaii quarter dollar in Honolulu, and releases it to circulation. This is the last coin of the 50 State Quarters Program.
South African singer Miriam Makeba dies of a heart attack after a concert in Italy at age 76.
DHL, overnight-delivery company, announces it will shut down its express-delivery service in the USA.
The US Treasury decides not to use money of the Troubled Asset Relief Program to buy mortgage-backed securities, but instead to directly inject cash into selected banks.
In Washington, D.C., leaders of the "G20" nations, representing 90 percent of global GDP, meet for an economic summit, for the first time ever.
Pakistan agrees to borrow US$7.6 billion from the International Monetary Fund, to prevent a run on the rupee and defaults on international loans.
Sri Lanka President Mahinda Rajapaksa announces the capture of Pooneryn from the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, for the first time in 15 years.
Iraqi cabinet approves a withdrawal agreement for American troops to leave Iraqi cities and towns by the end of June 2009, and the country by the end of 2011.
Pitcher Ryan Dempster agrees to a four-year contract worth US$52 million to remain with the Chicago Cubs.
Heads of automakers General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler appear before a Senate banking committee to ask for financial assistance.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls below 8000.
Claudia Castillo of Spain becomes the first person to have a successful trachea transplant using a tissue-engineered organ.
Canada's S&P/TSX composite index drops below 8,000 points for the first time in more than five years, closing at 7,724.80. The day's drop of more than nine percent is the second-largest on record.
Oil prices drop to below US$50 a barrel, settling at US$49.62 a barrel, the lowest since May 23, 2005.
Argentine Congress approves nationalizing the private pension system.
Launch party for the Altantis hotel in Dubai, 2500 people on the guest list.

An estimated 10-tonne object explodes in the atmosphere over Canadian provinces Alberta and Saskatchewan, landing south of Lone Rock, Saskatchewan. Within weeks, 130 stony meteorites (type H4), totalling 40 kg are recovered.
The Museum of Islamic Art opens in Qatar.

Ginza Coin Auction of Tokyo sells a British 1847 Victoria Gothic, Plain Edge gold crown pattern graded AU (one of two known) for 48.4 million yen (US$511,055), a record for a British milled coin. A British Proof 1937 Edward VIII sovereign sells for about US$313,602.
An earthquake measuring 6.7-6.8 strikes off the Indonesian island of Sumatra.
(to November 23) The APEC Peru 2008 Summit is held in Lima.
The Calgary Stampeders defeat the Montreal Alouettes 22-14 to win the 96th Canadian Football League's Grey Cup game.
The U.S government rescues Citigroup Inc, agreeing to assume losses on about $250 billion of the bank's risky assets, and inject new capital of $20 billion.
Fernando Verdasco of Spain wins the Davis Cup tennis title, defeating Jose Acasuso of Argentina, 6-3, 6-7 (3), 4-6, 6-3, 6-1 at Islas Malvinas Stadium in Mal del Plate, Argentina.
Floods in Santa Catarina, Brazil kill 126 and force the evacuation of over 78,000 people.
The US Federal Reserve announces it will buy up to US$100 billion of debt issued by mortgage enterprises, and it will also buy up to US$500 billion of mortgage securities.
Greenland holds a referendum for increased autonomy from Denmark. The vote is over 75 percent in favour.
In Thailand, protesters from the People's Alliance for Democracy party storm into Suvarnabhumi Airport and block flights from taking off.

Ten heavily-armed gunmen launch co-ordinated attacks at five locations across India's financial capital of Mumbai, killing 174 people, wounding 295, and holding several people hostage through the night at two luxury hotels, the Taj Mahal Palace & Tower and the Oberoi. An organization calling itself the Deccan Mujahedeen claims responsibility for the attacks.
Cell phone maker Nokia announces it will pull out of the Japanese market due to a lack of demand.
Jorn Utzon, Danish architect of the iconic Sydney Opera House, dies at age 90, after suffering a heart attack.
Robert Karlsson and Henrik Stenson score 63 to win golf's World Cup for Sweden at Mission Hills in China.
About 150 pilot whales die after being stranded in a remote coastal area of the Australian island of Tasmania.
End of three days of destruction in Jos, Nigeria, following protests over local government elections. 300 killed, 7000 homeless, many businesses, churches, mosques destroyed.
A triangular conjunction formed by a new Moon, Venus and Jupiter is a prominent object in the evening sky.
The price of a barrel of light crude oil falls US$5.15 to US$49.28.
Canada's TSX stock market index drops a record 864.41 points, to 8,406.21.
The largest U.S. chicken company, Pilgrim's Pride Corp, files for voluntary bankruptcy protection.
Canadian media magnate Ted Rogers, founder and CEO of Rogers Communications, dies at age 75 in Toronto, Ontario.
A sestertius coin of Emperor Hadrian (117-138 C.E.) sells for a record 2.3 million Swiss francs (US$1.9 million) at auction in Geneva, Switzerland.
Australia's central bank cuts the interest rate from 5.25 percent to 4.25.
The Bank of Japan announces it will accept, until April, corporate debt as collateral from commercial banks for new loans, up to 3 trillion yen (US$32 billion) total.
US President-elect Barack Obama names New York Senator Hillary Clinton as his nominee for secretary of state, and asks U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates to remain in office.

After weeks of opposition-led protests, the Constitutional Court of Thailand dissolves the governing People's Power Party and two coalition member parties, and bans leaders of the parties, including Prime Minister Somchai Wongsawat, from politics for five years. As such, Wongsawat promptly resigns and is replaced by Deputy Prime Minister Chaovarat Chanweerakul as caretaker Prime Minister.
At the Bonhams' Olympia sale, a 1925 Bentley 3.0-litre SuperSports "Brooklands" Two-seater sells for US$401,406.
The Bank of England cuts interest rates by one percentage point, down to 2 percent - the lowest level since 1951.
In Oslo, Norway, 94 countries sign the Convention on Cluster Munitions treaty banning the use of cluster bombs.
New Zealand's central bank cuts the interest rate from 6.5 percent to 5.
Iraq's Presidency Council approves a security pact with the United States, which requires U.S. troops to withdraw from Iraqi towns by mid-2009 and leave the country by the end of 2011.

Canada's Governor General Micha?lle Jean grants a request from Prime Minister Stephen Harper to suspend Parliament until January 26, to avoid a confidence vote set for Monday that could have toppled his minority government.

The European Court of Human Rights rules unanimously that holding DNA samples and fingerprints of innocent suspects violates their right to privacy. The ruling is binding on all 46 members of the Council of Europe, and affects databases of about 850,000 innocents.
The US White House and congressional democrats agree on a plan to provide a US$15 billion emergency loan to the country's automakers.
Patriarch Alexiy II, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, dies at age 79, outside Moscow.
Human remains found in 1991 are finally identified as Tsar Nicholas II of Russia, using DNA analysis.
Armed robbers steal at least US$102 million worth of jewels from Harry Winston's jewellery shops in Paris, France.
Police in Greece shoot and kill 15-year-old Alexandros Grigoropoulos, leading to days of rioting throughout the country.
US heiress Martha "Sunny" von Bulow dies at age 76 in New York, following 28 years in a coma.
The University of Hawaii activates a new telescope designed specifically to look for dangerous asteroids under 1km diameter.
In the USA, the Tribune Company files for bankruptcy.

Greg Maddux announces his retirement from Major League Baseball after 23 seasons and 355 wins. Maddux pitched for the Chicago Cubs, Atlanta Braves, San Diego Padres, and the Los Angeles Dodgers, and claimed four successive Cy Young Awards from 1992 as best pitcher in the National League.
The Bank of Canada drops the overnight interest rate to 1.5 percent, lowest in 50 years.
The New York Yankees sign starting pitcher CC Sabathia to a seven-year, US$161-million contract - the largest ever for a free-agent pitcher.
The Channel Island of Sark, a British crown dependency, holds its first fully democratic elections under a new constitutional arrangement, becoming the last European territory to abolish feudalism.
Ali Alatas, foreign minister of Indonesia, dies at age 76 in Singapore.
A suicide bomber kills at least 50 people at a restaurant near the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk. Around 100 people are injured in the blast.
The British pound reaches a record low of 1.1236 euros, the lowest level since the euro was launched in 1999.
The Canadian federal government and Ontario reach a deal to offer CDN$3.3 to the auto industry if a proposed US aid package is approved in Washington.
Switzerland becomes the 25th European country to join the Schengen Agreement, whereby cross-border passport checks will be abolished.

The Moon moves into its nearest point to Earth, called perigee, at the same time as its fullest phase of the Lunar Cycle. The Moon appears to be 14 percent bigger and 30 percent brighter than the year's other full moons.
Former chairman of the Nasdaq Stock Market Bernard Madoff is arrested and charged with allegedly running a $50 billion "Ponzi scheme", among the biggest fraud cases ever.
Ecuador president Rafael Correa announces the country is not obligated to pay its national debt, as they had been signed by unelected military dictators who were coerced by World Bank, IMF, and CIA.
Italy launches a high-speed train link between the northern cities of Milan and Bologna, part of a planned expansion to reach Rome next year.
A bus plunges into an irrigation canal along a narrow road in southern Egypt, killing 57 people.

Siemens (European engineering firm) pleads guilty to charges of bribery and corruption, and agrees to pay fines of US$800 million in the USA and 395 million euros (US$540 million) in Germany, in addition to an earlier 201 million euros.
Thai parliament asks Abhisit Vejjajiva to form a new coalition government.
Transport links between China and Taiwan begin regular crossings.
Ruins of an ancient Wari city are discovered in northern Peru.
The U.S. Federal Reserve cuts the country's federal funds interest rate to a target range of zero to 0.25 percent, the lowest level on record in the United States for the rate.
Sammy Baugh, football player who set numerous passing records with the Washington Redskins (1937-1952), dies at age 94 in Rotan, Texas, USA.
OPEC oil ministers agree to cut 2.2 million barrels per day, their deepest output cut ever, effective January 1.
A United Nations court sentences former army colonel Theoneste Bagosora to life in prison. Bagosora was accused of masterminding the slaughter of 800,000 people in Rwanda in 1994.

The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda convicts ThToneste Bagosora and two other senior Rwandan army officers of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes and sentences them to life imprisonment.

Mark Felt, the mysterious "Deep Throat" source who helped reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein crack the Watergate scandal that brought down President Richard Nixon, dies at age 95 in Santa Rosa, California.
US President George W. Bush announces US$17.4 billion in emergency loans to U.S. carmakers to prevent a collapse of the industry and save hundreds of thousands of jobs.
U.S. crude oil prices drop to US$33.87 a barrel, lowest since February 2004.
Olga Lepeshinskaya, Russian ballerina who danced with the Bolshoi for over 30 years dies at age 92 in Moscow.
At the Bonhams' Gstaad sale, a 1955 Ferrari 4.4-litre 121 LM sells for US$3,646,488.
Gwadar port, Pakistan becomes fully operational.

The American Environmental Protection Agency publishes a Clean Water Act General Permit that will allow cruise ships to dump unlimited quantities of untreated "graywater" into the ocean just a mile from U.S. shores.
A military coup d'Ttat is announced in Guinea shortly after the death of long-time President Lansana ContT.
Harold Pinter, influential British playwright (32 plays, 22 screenplays, Nobel Prize for literature 2005), voice of political protest, dies of cancer at age 78.

Israel launches air strikes on dozens of Hamas security compounds in the Gaza Strip, killing 230, wounding over 400. The strikes were in response to over 300 rocket attacks in a week. Militants in Gaza respond by sending at least 180 rockets and mortar shells into Israeli border communities.
Opposition leader John Atta Mills wins Ghana's presidency, 50.23 percent to Nana Akufo-Addo's 49.77 percent.
The Detroit Lions end the football season with no wins, sixteen losses, the worst losing record in NFL history.
Bangladesh holds its general elections after two years of political unrest over the interim government.
Japan's stock market records its worst year on record, with the Nikkei share index losing 42 percent of its value.
An extra leap second (23:59:60) is added to end the year.
Moscow Dynamo defeats Canada in hockey to win the Spengler Cup in Davos, Switzerland.

A massive fire sweeps through the Santika Club nightclub in Bangkok, Thailand, killing at least 59 people and injuring more than 200 others. Cause of the fire may have been an indoor foreworks display, or handheld firecrackers brought in by guests.
U.S. crude oil price rises 14 percent on the final trading day of 2008, with February futures settling up US$5.57 to $44.60 per barrel.
Austria, Japan, Mexico, Turkey, and Uganda assume their seats on the United Nations Security Council.
Iraqi security forces take control Baghdad's fortified Green Zone after a UN mandate for troops expires. The Basra International Airport is also turned over to Iraqi forces.
In Brazil, new spelling rules come into effect, standardising spellings, removing silent consonants, removing various accents, and officially adding letters k, w and y to the Portuguese alphabet.
Asunci=n, the capital of Paraguay, becomes the American Capital of Culture and Vilnius and Linz become the European Capitals of Culture.
Helen Suzman, South African Member of Parliament and anti-apartheid campaigner, dies at age 91.
The U.S. military in Iraq falls under Iraqi authority for the first time since the U.S.-led invasion ousted Saddam Hussein in 2003.
Claiborne Pell, Rhode Island Democratic Senator (1961-97), dies at age 90 of Parkinson's disease.
Slovakia becomes the 16th member of the Euro Zone, changing its currency from the koruna to the euro.
The Czech Republic takes over the presidency of the Council of the European Union from France.
Turkmenistan redenominates its currency, making 1 new manat equal to 5000 old manat, and releases a new series of coins and currency.
The first commercial flight between Western Europe and Baghdad in at least 17 years lands in Iraq from Denmark.
Sri Lanka's military seizes control of Kilinochchi, the Tamil Tiger rebels' de facto capital.
Maria de Jesus, believed to be the world's oldest living person, dies at age in Tomar, Portugal.
Jett Travolta, 16-year-old son of American actor John Travolta, dies suddenly of a seizure while on a family holiday in the Bahamas.
At the Hollywood Wheels Fort Lauderdale auction, a 1965 Shelby 427 SC Cobra CSX 3021 sells for US$3,780,000.
Israel launches a ground invasion of the Gaza Strip as the Gaza War enters its second week.
A series of powerful earthquakes hits eastern Indonesia, the strongest with a magnitude of 7.6, north of the city of Manokwari in West Papua province.
At least 33 people die in a landslide in northern Guatemala; many more are missing.
Free-agent outfielder Milton Bradley reaches terms on a three-year, US$30 million contract with the Chicago Cubs.
German billionaire Adolf Merckle commits suicide at age 74, stepping in front of a train in Germany.
Canada beats Sweden 5-1 to win gold in the world junior hockey championships. This is Canada's fifth straight championship, and its 15th gold, matching Russia/Soviet Union for the all-time lead.
The new US embassy in Baghdad, Iraq, opens. The compound is one of the biggest and most expensive embassies the US has ever built, where about 1,200 staff will live and work.
Awami League leader Sheikh Hasina is sworn in for a second term as prime minister of Bangladesh.
Russia shuts off all gas supplies to Europe through Ukraine. Prime Minister Vladimir Putin publicly endorses the move and urges greater international involvement in the energy dispute.

In India, software and services company Satyam, founder and chairman Ramalinga Raju admits to years of fraud in the company's accounts, inflating revenues and fabricating non-existent cash balances of about US$1 billion.
The Bank of England cuts interest rates to 1.5 percent, the lowest level since the Bank of England was founded in 1694.

Citigroup and Morgan Stanley agree to combine their brokerages, with Morgan Stanley paying Citigroup US$2.7 billion for a 51 percent stake in the joint venture. The new Morgan Stanley Smith Barney will have US$1.7 trillion in client assets.
Ethiopian military forces begin pulling out of Somalia, where they have tried to maintain order for nearly two years.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel unveils an economic stimulus package worth about 50 billion euros (US$67 billion).
Canada's Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's biggest telephone equipment maker, files for bankruptcy protection.
Palestinian deaths in the Gaza Strip reach 1000, with injuries at nearly 5000, since Israeli launched a campaign to end rocket fire on December 27. Israeli deaths stand at 13.
American apparel chain Goody's files for bankruptcy to liquidate its remaining 282 stores.
American department store chain Gottschalks files to reorganize under bankruptcy protection.
Bank of America, the largest U.S. bank, posts its first quarterly loss in 17 years, of US$1.79 billion.

A US Airways Airbus 320 Flight 1549 makes an emergency landing into the Hudson River off New York City shortly after takeoff from LaGuardia Airport, after birds disable both engines. All 155 passengers and crew members are safely rescued.
The British Government gives the go-ahead for a third runway at Heathrow airport.
Longtime CBC Vancouver announcer Dan McAfee ("Dr. Bundolo") dies at age 73.
Bank of America is rescued by the U.S. government with a US$20 billion bailout and a guarantee for almost $100 billion of potential losses on toxic assets.
The Slovak koruna currency ceases to be legal tender.
At Gooding's Scottsdale Auction, a 1970 Ford Mustang Boss 302 Trans Am sells for US$407,000.
Israel announces a unilateral ceasefire in the Gaza War. It comes into effect the following day, on which Hamas declares a ceasefire of its own.
Joannie Rochette defends her Canadian figure skating championship, as she wins her fifth-straight national title.
The Danish government unveils a 100 billion crown (US$17.8 billion) bank credit package.
The Pittsburgh Steelers beat the Baltimore Ravens 23-14 in the AFC Championship game. The Arizona Cardinals defeat the Philadelphia Eagles 32-25 to claim the NFC crown.

Israel begins a unilateral ceasefire in Gaza, three weeks after launching a full-scale assault against Hamas. The Palestinian militant group announces an immediate ceasefire for a week to give Israel time to withdraw its forces from the Gaza Strip. Estimate of homeless in Gaza from the fighting: 50,000.
Baltimore Orioles' outfielder Nick Markakis agrees to a six-year, US$66 million contract.
Irish bank shares plunge over 50 percent.

The United Kingdom Government launches a second bank rescue plan, allowing banks to insure themselves against losses on their riskiest assets, offering guarantees on their debt, and setting up a 50 billion-pound (US$75 billion) fund to buy up high-quality securities.

Royal Bank of Scotland records the biggest loss in UK corporate history, up to 28 billion pounds (US$52 billion), and RBS shares close down 67 percent. The government increases its stake in RBS from 58 percent to 70.
Barack Hussein Obama is inaugurated as the 44th President of the United States.
The Bank of Canada cuts borrowing costs to a record low to one percent. The previous record low was 1.12 percent in 1958.
Israeli troops complete their pullout from Gaza, ending their 22-day offensive in the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip.

Italian carmaker Fiat and American carmaker Chrysler agree to a global strategic alliance. Fiat will get a 35 percent stake in Chrysler, which will get access to Fiat's fuel-efficient vehicle technologies.
George W. Bush's Presidential term expires.
Israel completes its withdrawal from the Gaza Strip. Intermittent air strikes by both sides of the preceding war continue in the weeks to follow.
The U.S. Senate endorses former New York Senator and former first lady Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State.
Congolese rebel leader Laurent Nkunda is captured by Rwandan forces after crossing over the border into Rwanda.

The Intermediate People's Court in Shijiazhuang, China, sentences two men (Zhang Yujun and Geng Jinping) to execution and gives former top executive Tian Wenhua of the Sanlu Group a life sentence for their roles in the country's deadly tainted milk scandal. Others of 12 defendants were given prison terms of five to 15 years. At least six children died, and close to 300,000 people became ill from drinking milk intentionally contaminated with melamine, used to give milk an apparently higher nutrition content in protein tests.
South Korea's Samsung Electronics posts its first-ever quarterly loss, at 937 billion won (US$682 million).
Japan launches an H-2A rocket carrying eight satellites into space; one satellite is to monitor greenhouse gases over the Earth's surface.
US President Barack Obama orders the prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to be closed within a year.
